HEADLINE: THE 1993 PRIMARY: The Voters;
Casting Their Ballots, Looking for a Better City

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Talking of the need of the city and reflecting on Mayor David N. Dinkins's term at City Hall, voters went to the polls yesterday to cast their ballots and their hopes like pennies in a wishing well. They could not predict the outcome, they said, nor could they be sure that they would influence it much. But the act itself felt good.
As they cast their ballots in the Democratic primary for citywide offices, and in local races, many voters reflected on their years in the city and on how it has both changed and stayed the same. Some spoke with praise of Mayor Dinkins; others expressed contempt for his record. 
 Most spoke of the importance of voting and of their pride in a city like no other: harder, more expensive, more diverse, more competitive. Their city, good and bad.
In Borough Park, Morris Strassburger, 79, a native of Israel, said his mind was mostly on the November Mayoral race, when he plans to vote for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate.
"It's terrible what's going on," he said. "A robbery here. A killing there. Riots sometimes in Crown Heights. It's terrible under Dinkins. Listen to me. Four years ago I voted for Dinkins. Now I change my mind."
 
Concern About Holtzman
 Across the city, among that small fraction that bothers to vote, the most consistent topics yesterday were the city's safety, or lack of it, troubles in the schools, public housing and the economy.
Alec Wallings, a long-time West Sider, said he was concerned about "guns, guns, guns, guns, guns" and the basic dignity of city politicians. He said he voted against Elizabeth Holtzman for Comptroller. He shrugged off the recent investigation that has marred her run for re-election. His real gripe, he said, was her tone: "It's an arrogance that needs to be slapped down by voters."
Betty Spector, a poll worker at Public School 9, at 100 West 84th Street in Manhattan, said, "I don't like either one of the two that are running for Mayor" in the November election. She said she considered Mr. Dinkins somewhat ineffectual and Mr. Giuliani too "law and order."
In addition, she said, "I don't like this fusion thing," a reference to Mr. Giuliani's decision to run with two Democrats, Herman Badillo for Comptroller and Susan D. Alter for Public Advocate.
"What if Badillo wins and Dinkins wins? I'm not sure that would work out," she said.
 
For Many, a Somber Mood
 In the Bronx, Bertram Bowers, 22, said, "We have to think about housing. About the homeless. About schools and education." He said he wanted to give Mayor Dinkins another term to finish what he had started.
In a voting station on Lenox Avenue in Harlem at midday, Eula Dalton, 67, a cleaning lady, said she had made a special effort to get to the polls because of what she saw as a plot by Mr. Giuliani to have Roy E. Innis, a Democratic challenger, siphon votes from the incumbent.
"Everybody's talking about Roy Innis and what is he even doing in this," she said. "He's just doing it so he can get a job with Giuliani. Even if I had never voted before I would have voted this time just to knock Roy Innis out."
 
Crime Affects Choices
 In Park Slope, Brooklyn, Rosie Jackson, 50, an assistant deputy director of the New York City Department of Human Resources, said her vote was cast in part because of her fear of crime.
"I'm a Southern black," she said. "We had to fight for the right to vote." This year, she said, her vote was a vote of protest against the Mayor. "I think he's been weak on crime and I don't think he's allowing the police to do their jobs," she said.
But there were voters who celebrated the exercise and the city it affects.
Dona D. Vaughn, 47, a stage director who has lived on the Upper West Side for 20 years, said she hoped those running would work to improve city services, schools and housing. But she also took a moment just to say how happy she is to call New York City home.
"There's no place like it," she said. "Here you are living in this big city. Yet you feel very much a part of it. And, really, everybody basically gets along."
Then, too, she said, there are the city's more sublime advantages. Ms. Vaughn brushed her hand over her freshly laundered blue jeans and said with a smile: "You can dress any way you like!"
And no politician has ever dared to mess with that.

HEADLINE: Investor Edginess Sends Dow Down 18.45

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The edginess of stock market investors was on full display yesterday, as bad news about inflation pummeled the bond market and stocks quickly followed, though they found some equilibrium later in the day.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany, said the day began with nervousness among investors that "we'd get some bad news for the bond market, and we'd see the bond market decline sharply, and that would touch off a decline in stock prices." He added, "Those worries became a reality at 8:30 this morning."
 
A Jolt to the Market
 The jolt to the market was administered when the Labor Department said consumer prices had risen three-tenths of 1 percent in August, while expectations had been that the number would be no higher than two-tenths. The announcement revived fears of inflation, which had considerably abated. 
 "Even though that wasn't an alarming number, it was enough above expectations to touch off profit-taking," Mr. Johnson said. "the principal reason for the decline in stock prices today was the sharp decline that occured in bond prices, and the rise in long-term interest rates, which got lots of those edgy fence-sitters off the fence and got them into selling both bonds and stocks."
The Dow Jones industrials were down more than 25 points early in the day before recovering to close down 18.45, at 3,615.76. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 258.7 million, up from 245 million on Monday. Transportation stocks were hit hard, with the Dow Jones transportations down a sharp 22.23 points, to 1,612.53.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2.16, to 459.90, and the American Stock Exchange composite index was down 1.54, to 452.76. The Nasdaq composite fell a whopping 7.68, to finish at 732.64, on particularly bad performances by a number of technology stocks.
The weakest sectors of the market were airlines, technology, automobiles and interest-rate-sensitive stocks like money center banks, regional banks and insurance companies, Mr. Johnson noted.
Technology stocks were brought to their knees across the board. Intel was down 1 1/2, to 63 1/4; Microsoft was down 1 1/8, to 75 1/4; Apple was down 1, to 24 1/4; Texas Instruments was down 1 3/8, to 75 3/4, and the Digital Equipment Corporation, down 1 5/8, to 40.
 
The Airlines Worst Hit
 Among airlines, worst hit was United Airlines, down 4 1/4, to 142 1/4. Delta was down 1 5/8, to 52 5/8, and Southwest Airlines was down 7/8, to 31 7/8.
Of the auto makers, the General Motors Corporationwas down 1 3/4, to 45 3/4; Ford Motor was down 1 1/4, to 53 3/4, and Chrysler was down 7/8, to 44 5/8.
An analyst for Paine Webber downgraded Bankers Trust and J .P. Morgan. Bankers Trust was down 2 1/2, to 80, and J. P. Morgan closed at 75 7/8, down 1 1/2. Another bank stock, Wells Fargo, fell 1 3/4 to 118 3/8.
Home Depot, long a darling of Wall Street, sank to 36 1/4, down 4, when Goldman, Sachs took the stock off its recommended list.
Another big decliner was the Cyrix Corporation, a semiconductor maker, which closed at 28 1/4, down 5 5/8, after Lehman Brothers reduced its earnings estimates.

HEADLINE: Frederick Ungeheuer, Journalist, 61

 BODY:
Frederick Ungeheuer, a senior correspondent covering the financial industry for Time magazine, died yesterday after a fall from his 12th-floor apartment on East 70th Street in Manhattan. He was 61.
Police Officer Scott Bloch said an investigation into the death had not been completed. 
 Mr. Ungeheuer was a correspondent in Europe and Africa, first for Reuters and then for Time from 1958 to 1969, when he became a contributing editor in Europe for Harpers magazine. He rejoined Time as its United Nations bureau chief from 1971 to 1973 and again in 1977 as a European economic correspondent, then as Paris bureau chief. He returned to New York this year.
Mr. Ungeheuer was born in Frankfurt, Germany, and graduated from Harvard in 1957, magna cum laude.
He is survived by his wife, Barbara.

HEADLINE: Narrow House Victory For S.& L. Cleanup Bill

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Ending months of debate and delay, the House of Representatives narrowly passed legislation today to complete the cleanup of the savings and loan industry.
Earlier this year, the Senate passed its own version of the legislation with $34 billion in total financing, compared with the $26.3 billion of the House version. A House-Senate conference committee will try to resolve the differences. 
 To satisfy Republican members whose support was needed to build a majority for the perennially unpalatable S.& L. bailout, leaders of the House Banking Committee presented a compromise that cut in half, to $8 billion, the amount of money taxpayers would contribute to a new insurance fund that would guarantee repayment of deposits in future S.& L. failures.
 
Restoring R.T.C. Authority
 At the same time, the legislation extends for another year and a half the operations of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which seizes the assets of bankrupt savings and loans and sells them to pay depositors. The R.T.C. had been scheduled to stop taking over S.& L.'s on Oct. 1.
The bill restores the authority of the R.T.C. to use $18.3 billion in previously appropriated funds for this purpose before the new insurance fund takes over the task.
The unwillingness of the House to commit tax dollars to future S.& L. failures has been the single biggest political obstacle to enacting a bill. Once the R.T.C. completes its work in 1995, deposits at S.& L.'s will be insured by the new fund, called the Savings Association Insurance Fund.
By whittling down the amount of Federal money available to the S.A.I.F., which is to be built up from deposit insurance premiums paid by savings and loans, the House bill would leave the industry facing a long period of relatively high deposit insurance premiums.
Some industry and Government experts warned that high premiums could cause problems.
"If adequate funds are not appropriated for the S.A.I.F., it is likely that S.A.I.F. member institutions would operate at an ongoing disadvantage to other financial concerns, and consequently would be less able to attract capital to maintain their financial health," said Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in a recent statement to the Senate Banking Committee.
 
A Healthier Industry
 For the time being, most savings and loans, like most other financial institutions, are enjoying healthy profits as a result of low interest rates. Unless the economy turns sour, the bill's passage could mean the closing of one of the costliest financial traumas ever to face the nation.
Already, the R.T.C. has spent more than $86 billion cleaning up the S.& L. crisis, not counting interest payments.
The vote in the House was 214 to 208, with 24 Republicans voting for the bill. The differences between the House and Senate bills are not expected to be irreconcilable.
"I truly believe that this is the last time we will have to vote on the R.T.C.," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is a senior member of the House Banking Committee.
 
The Cost of Delay
 Without the legislation, the R.T.C. has been left holding nearly 80 S.& L.'s and operating them at a loss, which has cost taxpayers an estimated $3 million a day, or more than $1 billion a year.
Many members of the House, especially Republicans, have adamantly opposed increasing the cost to taxpayers of the S.& L. debacle. Without a handful of Republican votes, the Democratic leadership had been unable for months to muster enough support to bring the bill to the floor for a vote.
The bill also calls for changes in management practices at the R.T.C., which has been criticized for inefficiency over the years. And it extends from three years to five years the statute of limitations for prosecuting some officials of S.& L.'s that went bankrupt.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Given a Lift From Latest Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Modest gains in retail sales and consumer prices gave precious metals a lift yesterday after two days of steep losses.
On other commodity markets, lumber futures fell sharply while oil futures rose. 
 Gold for October delivery rose $2.10, to $345.20 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, also gained $2.10, to $346.90. September silver rose 6.7 cents, to $3.972 an ounce.
Gold had skidded $11.70 in the two previous sessions following Friday's Government report of an unexpected six-tenths of 1 percent drop during August in the Producer Price Index.
Traders were braced for a drop in retail prices, too, but the Labor Department said yesterday that the Consumer Price Index rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in August after three months of virtually unchanged prices.
 
 
Retail Sales
 In addition, the Commerce Department said retail sales grew a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month.
The numbers were hardly the sort to rekindle investor demand for gold as an inflation hedge. On the other hand, "it did show the economy was maybe not as bad as some people had thought," said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter in Chicago.
The modest rise in consumer prices provided an excuse for traders who recently sold precious metal futures to buy them back at lower prices, said James Steel, metals analyst with the futures brokerage firm of Refco Inc.
The marginally positive economic data did not stem the slide in lumber futures prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Spruce two-by-fours for November delivery plunged $7.40, to $309.40 for 1,000 board feet, after a $10 drop on Monday.
Meanwhile, light sweet crude oil for October delivery finished 1 cent higher at $16.96 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a day of seesawing prices. October heating oil climbed 0.35 cent, to 51.74 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline fell 0.41 cent, to 48.16 cents a gallon, and October natural gas fell 3.9 cents, to $2.157 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Bond Deal Is Reviewed By G.O.P.

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Searching for evidence that the Florio administration was incompetently, and perhaps even corruptly, being taken to the cleaners by a crafty Wall Street banking house, Assembly Republicans today opened their formal investigation of the state's bond-issuing practices.
The hearings, invested with the Republican majority's newly acquired power to subpoena witnesses, are focusing on a complicated, $1.8 billion deal entered into by the state with Lazard Freres & Company last December to refinance old debt at high interest rates, turning it into new debt at lower rates. 
 The Republicans, with an eye out for a corruption scandal that could be used against Gov. Jim Florio in his re-election campaign, maintain that Lazard Freres walked away from the deal with unreasonably high fees.
The State Treasurer, Samuel Crane, maintained in his appearance before the committee that the banking house had devised an innovative plan that saved the state millions of dollars in interest payments. The Treasury notes bought by the state from Lazard Freres as part of the deal came at a fair market price, Mr. Crane said, so the banking house's profit was not to the detriment of the state's taxpayers and voters.
 
Theater, or Substance?
 The hearings were conducted by the Assembly Appropriations Committee with the kind of legalistic pomp that day-time television viewers have come to expect from Congressional investigation and hearings by special prosecutors. Although the committee's subpoena power was not used in today's session, witnesses were elaborately sworn to tell the truth, read a Miranda-like caution of their rights as witnesses, and offered the chance to buy a tape recording of their testimony.
Mr. Crane, a veteran of many appearances before the Appropriations Committee, objected to having to raise his right hand this time. "Putting people under oath has more to do with theater than substance," he said.
Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, the chairman, again spurned the Democrats' charge of political grandstanding, as he had Monday when he appealed to the Assembly's two-to-one Republican majority for the power to subpoena witnesses.
"The process by which the state and its authorities issue bonds may be imperfect in many respects," he said before taking Mr. Crane's testimony. "But never in so many quarters where bonding is a common practice, whether it be the Treasurer's office, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, the Sports and Exposition Authority or the Health Care Facility Financing Agency, have there been so many rumors of self-dealing, personal gain and centralized management of both the fiscal and political details of bond issuances."
 
Aide to Florio
 A Justice Department investigation is under way into allegations of kickbacks in the underwriting of New Jersey Turnpike Authority bonds involving a company half owned by Joseph P. Salema, who was Gov. Florio's chief of staff until May.
Mr. Salema, maintaining that his interest in the firm, Armacon Securities Inc., was in a blind trust and that he had done nothing wrong, resigned soon after the existence of the investigation became public in May.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has also asked for bond records from the Sports and Exposition Authority in connection in the Armacon inquiry.
The December refinancing with Lazard Freres worked like this: The banking house underwrote the issuance of $1.8 billion in new bonds for the state, half of which was earmarked to retire old debt that was out at higher interest rates, and the other half to go into a series of funds for capital and debt payment outlays.
Because the old bonds had staggered call dates, the dates when the state can pay them off, the cash raised in the new bond sales was used to buy short-term Federal Treasury notes from Lazard Freres. The innovation that won Lazard the refinancing contract from the state, despite misgivings by some of Mr. Crane's own subordinates, was the way that the banking house arranged the sale of treasury notes whose maturity dates coincided with the call dates of the old bonds.
 
Test of the Deal
 Lazard Freres has not disclosed the size of its profit in selling Treasury notes to New Jersey. The Wall Street Journal has put the figure at $10 million, and that number was widely taken as fact at today's session.
Mr. Crane, however, argued today that the test of the deal was the low interest rate obtained by Lazard Freres for the $1.8 billion in new debt, not whatever profit the house made on notes that the state would in any case have had to buy elsewhere if not from Lazard.
The Republican critics of the deal argued that such a large refinancing should have been broken up among several underwriters, and put out to competitive bidding in an effort to drive down costs.
Because Lazard Freres was able to complete the deal before the end of last year, after first discussing it only in September, Mr. Crane said, the state saved $50 million.
The hearings will be resumed in about two weeks, Assemblyman Freylinguysen said. Witnesses have not been announced.

HEADLINE: Disney Considers Move Into Times Sq.

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company is talking to city and state officials about occupying a landmark theater on 42d Street at Times Square, city and state officials say.
The talks center on the New Amsterdam Theater, a graceful 10-story Art Nouveau building that was the home of the Ziegfeld Follies from 1913 to 1927 but has fallen into disrepair. Disney's representatives have discussed using the theater for live shows, said Carl Weisbrod, President of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. 
 "We have been in discussions with them, and obviously it would be terrific for 42d Street if Disney came to the block," Mr. Weisbrod said.
A person close to the project, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "There's a great deal of interest among entertainment users in 42d Street right now. The one that's farthest along -- although that doesn't mean it's going to happen -- is Disney."
When asked about the report, Thomas Deegan, a spokesman for Disney, said, "It's speculation, and we don't comment on speculation."
The reports of Disney talks came on the eve of a press conference scheduled for today at which city and state officials are to announce that they are proceeding with condemnation of the buildings on the northwest half of the 42d Street block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, as well as the buildings on the east side of Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets, for use in the project. The condemnation is being announced by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins, who will be represented by Deputy Mayor Barry F. Sullivan. The addition is a big part of the remaining privately-held area in the redevelopment project.
 
Hiatus in Change
 Under the original 42d Street Redevelopment Project, a city and state development that was to use mostly private money, Times Square was to receive a $2.5 billion make-over. But plans by Park Tower Realty and the Prudential Insurance Company of America to build office towers there were shelved in August 1992 until economic conditions improved. By the time plans were suspended, many buildings had already been cleared of tenants.
The head of the state agency in charge of the development project confirmed the Disney talks but gave no details. "We are in discussions with Disney," said the official, Rebecca Robertson, the president of the 42d Street Development Project Inc., a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. "But I really can't characterize the discussions at all."
The cost of repairing the New Amsterdam would presumably be substantial, and it is not clear how much -- if any -- public money would be made available to the Disney organization to go forward with the theater. Mr. Weisbrod said, he "wouldn't want to get into a discussion of financial arrangements at this time."
In the spring of 1991, reports circulated widely that the New York City Opera was considering relocating from the State Theater at Lincoln Center to the 1,900-seat New Amsterdam Theater, which was the height of New York nightlife glamour in its heyday before the Depression, but has deteriorated badly. The talks never bore fruit, however, and the theater, which Ms. Robertson's organization acquired from the Nederlander Organization last fall, has stood empty and dark at 214 West 42d Street.
The New Amsterdam, which opened in 1903, has a luxurious interior of marble and classical friezes that was legendary even by the standards of the rich Broadway theaters of the time. The roof garden was turned into the swanky Midnight Frolic supper club by Florenz Ziegfeld in 1915. In 1937 the theater was converted for movies, and was used that way until 1982. The theater is on the National Register of Historic Places.
Mr. Deegan said Disney had a live show of "Beauty and the Beast" that was scheduled to open a New York run in the spring at the Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, where "The Will Rogers Follies" recently closed. "Disney's Symphonic Fantasy," a revue of song and dance from Disney movies, had a two-week run this summer at the Metropolitan Opera House.
 
Using Other Theaters
 Mrs. Robertson's organization also has jurisdiction over two other theaters, the Empire and the Harris.
Six other 42d Street theaters taken over by the city and the state during the 1990 condemnation for the original redevelopment project are under the jurisdiction of New 42d Street Inc., a nonprofit organization that is independent of Ms. Robertson's group and is responsible for the restoration and long-term management of those theaters. They are the Victory, the Lyric, the Times Square, the Apollo (also known as the Academy), the Selwyn and the Liberty.
Cora Cahan, the president of New 42d Street, said her group was "hoping and planning" to make an announcement in late September on its plans for "some of the theaters on 42d Street." She declined to discuss any specifics of the plans.

HEADLINE: Orchestras Sound Loud Notes Of Strife Over Money Matters

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The managers of America's symphony orchestras have complained increasingly in recent years that the rising incomes of musicians and the trend toward extended concert seasons, coupled with cuts in government subsidies, have had a devastating effect on the bottom line. Now the managements of several small and medium-sized orchestras are fighting back, demanding salary and roster cuts and shaving the number of guaranteed performing weeks.
These moves, combined with the contract talks in progress at some of the larger orchestras, are making for a decidedly unharmonious concert season. 
 In recent weeks, the management of the Buffalo Philharmonic suspended operations and dismissed its musicians; the Honolulu Symphony canceled its first few weeks of concerts, and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra in Minnesota said it planned to file for bankruptcy if its players did not agree to its proposals by Sunday. The Philadelphia Orchestra's contract expires the same day, and if a new agreement is not reached there, its players may call their first strike since 1966. That would leave Carnegie Hall without an orchestra to open its season on Sept. 23.
 
Strike in Washington

 
 The Kennedy Center Opera Orchestra has been on strike since Sept. 1, and the National Symphony Orchestra, which also performs at the Kennedy Center, has refused to cross the picket line. The National's own contract expired on Sept. 6, but the players have agreed to negotiate until Oct. 18; they are leaving for a Russian tour next week. The Cleveland Orchestra, the Atlanta Symphony and the Milwaukee Symphony are performing without contracts.
The only reason New York City's orchestras have been unaffected by this turmoil is that they have already faced something like it, though less severe. Last winter, a consortium of freelance orchestras struck for several weeks, and eventually won modest increases in benefits, as well as tenure guarantees. And the New York Philharmonic's contentious negotiations in 1991 led to a contract that gave the musicians some of the increases they sought and a voice in the running of the orchestra.
"The negotiations this year," said Liza Hirsch DuBrul, the lawyer representing the musicians in Milwaukee, St. Paul and Atlanta, "are marked by what I consider to be a very deliberate attack on the entire system of collective bargaining in the arts."
From the Kennedy Center musicians' point of view, that is exactly what is at issue in their strike. The talks broke down when the center said it wanted to eliminate contract provisions that guarantee the orchestra's 61 players 10 weeks of ballet performances each season. "If we need 40 musicians," asked the center's lawyer, Norman Samnick, "why should we hire 61? If we have six weeks of work, why should we pay for 10?"
 
50 Years in the Balance

 
 Leonard Leibowitz, the musicians' lawyer, describes the center's approach as union busting. "Orchestras have fought for job security for 50 years," he said, "and, having achieved it, to be told to go back to the bad old days is unacceptable."
But elsewhere, management is making sacrifices, too. In Milwaukee, management has taken pay cuts of from 4 percent to 7 percent, and has instituted a wage freeze. Zdenek Macal, the orchestra's music director, took a 7 percent pay cut and has agreed to forgo a 7 percent increase promised in his contract.
These and other belt-tightening measures are expected to save the orchestra $370,000. But last year, its deficit was $870,000, and its cumulative deficit is $2.2 million. Its $10 million endowment does not generate enough income to cover the shortfall. And although it is trying to attract donations to increase the endowment to $35 million, prospective donors have said that they will not give the orchestra money until its finances are stable. Orchestras elsewhere are hearing similar responses to their pleas for cash.
 
A Summer Problem

 
 Joan H. Squires, the Milwaukee orchestra's executive director, said one of the main problems was that several attempts to market a summer series had been unsuccessful. What she would like to do is drop seven summer weeks from the orchestra's contract, bringing its season to 41 weeks from 48. That would mean a 14 percent cut for the players, who made an individual minimum of $46,080 under the old contract.
"We've offered to have a summer task force," Miss Squires said, "with management, board and musician input into finding work for the summer. We're interested in exploring proposals. But we cannot commit to pay them for weeks if we don't know how we'll use them."
The situation in St. Paul is more complicated. In May, the Minnesota Opera attempted to redefine its relationship with its orchestra, saying its players were not employees. The Internal Revenue Service, the National Labor Relations Board and the state disagreed, and the musicians went on strike.
The opera company's management then formed an administrative alliance with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra and the Ordway Musical Theater and proposed making the St. Paul ensemble the resident orchestra for all the organizations. The players object to this proposal, although in some ways it would be good for them. With a contract that runs only 40 weeks, the players could use the extra work. And shared administrative costs would help management contend with an accumulated deficit of $1.55 million.
"We instantly acknowledged the fundamental intelligence of having three small arts organizations pool their administrative resources," Ms. DuBrul said. "But this proposal would mean that the St. Paul orchestra is being asked to become a strikebreaking orchestra for the opera. And the musicians won't do that."
The Milwaukee and St. Paul orchestras have agreed to play their concerts this weekend. But with the St. Paul management's bankruptcy ultimatum looming this weekend, that orchestra's future is uncertain. And neither union representatives nor management in Milwaukee were willing to say how long that orchestra would keep playing.
 
'We've Run Out of Cash'

 
 In Honolulu, the musicians have not picked up their instruments this season.
"Last year," said Tony Dechario, the orchestra's executive director, "we began the last year of a three-year contract with a deficit of $535,000. We asked the musicians to renegotiate, but they weren't interested in that. So in violation of the contract, I made unilateral cuts, which was the only way I could get through the year. The musicians filed a grievance, which they won, so now we owe them $450,000 back pay, which we have not yet paid them. Then the question of the new contract came up. Our problem is that we've run out of cash."
But Mr. Dechario can also see the battle from the musicians' point of view.
"The musicians' problem is that the salary minimum we're offering is only about $20,000 for a 38-week season," he said. "They're eligible for unemployment, which gives them another $7,000. But you can't live in Hawaii for that. They're frustrated because they don't see any progress. And I can understand that. But we're just a microcosm of what's happening nationally.
"What we need is for managements and unions to sit down and figure out new ways to generate revenue. Unfortunately, right now, everyone's so concerned about the wording of the contracts that we're driving each other further into the corner, and it's getting harder to find solutions to our mutual problems."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Striking musicians from the Kennedy Center Opera Orchestra picketing yesterday outside the theater in Washington. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. IS SAID TO BE CLOSE TO SALE OF NEW JERSEY PLANT

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation is close to selling its Inland Fisher Guide plant in Ewing Township, N.J., to William D. Hurley, a New Jersey investor, a state official said yesterday. G.M. signed a nonbinding memorandum of understanding on Friday with Mr. Hurley, indicating that the two were negotiating terms of the proposed deal, said Barbara W. McConnell, New Jersey's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development. She said the state might provide economic assistance to help Mr. Hurley and his company, Independent Component Systems of Farmingdale, N.J., make the acquisition. G.M. would say only that negotiations were continuing for the sale of the parts plant, situated just outside Trenton. The plant employs about 1,300 people who make door handles, seat adjusters and body moldings for automobiles.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off After Report On August Consumer Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against other currencies yesterday after a report of higher-than-expected inflation.
 The yen, meanwhile, surged in a broad rally spurred by huge sales of Australian dollars, Brazilian debt restructuring and a growing Japanese trade surplus.
 The dollar jumped briefly in reaction to news that the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of a percent in August, exceeding forecasts for a gain of a tenth of a percent. Higher inflation can push up the dollar if it nudges interest rates higher, since it increases yields on dollar-denominated investments.
 But a selloff quickly ensued when dealers recalled a long string of American economic data pointing to a slow recovery.
 "The data was a little stronger than the awful figures expected," said a dealer for an American bank in London. "When you get down to it, the recovery is moribund."
Rumors that European central banks were buying German marks to replenish intervention reserves also depressed the dollar. In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.6090 marks in New York, from 1.6110 on Monday. 
 Earlier, the dollar fell in Tokyo, as the yen surged on rumors of the sale of $1 billion (Australian) for yen. This led to a broad selloff that pushed the Australian dollar to a seven-year low despite aggressive intervention by the Reserve Bank of Australia.
 The Bank of Japan also stepped in to rescue the dollar as it slid further against the yen on $400 million to $600 million in sales by Japanese banks in Brazilian debt restructuring deals.
 Moreover, news that Japan's trade surplus had widened fanned fears that the United States would renew its call for a stronger yen to bolster Japanese imports.
 The dollar steadied at 105.98 yen in late New York trading, down from 106.27 yen on Monday, as dealers awaited Japan's economic stimulus package to announced tomorrow.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1054 words

HEADLINE: Rivals Sound Themes in New York Mayoral Battle

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Bracing for the political fight of his career, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday used the moment after his easy renomination to wrap himself in the support of top Democratic politicians at a pep rally, even as his Republican-Liberal rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, pulled hard for the crossover Democratic voters he will need to win in November.
Surrounded by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, Labor Secretary Robert Reich and David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, the Mayor marched to a lectern on the steps of City Hall, took off his suit coat and tie, and undid the top two buttons of his white shirt. Then he lit into the Republican policies that he said Mr. Giuliani represents and that he contends have hurt New York. 
 "We know where we stand," Mr. Dinkins told the midday crowd, reading from his text in the undramatic style he favors. "And we know where our Republican opponent stands: anywhere and everywhere he can. To him, pro-choice means choosing a different position every day. This election is a choice between dividing our city and uniting it."
 
Runoff on Sept. 28
 Hours later, Mr. Giuliani went to the same spot to receive the endorsement of City Councilman Michael DeMarco of the Bronx, a blunt-spoken regular Democrat and former Finance Committee chairman who has made it plain that Mr. Dinkins does not speak for the Councilman's overwhelmingly white middle- and working-class district.
"Next year this city is not going to be a partisan city, a Democratic or Republican city," Mr. Giuliani said.
The Mayor's defeat of his gadfly Democratic challengers, Roy E. Innis and Eric Ruano-Melendez, by better than 2 to 1 means that the rematch between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani, which has sputtered and flared all year, can at last grow white hot. There will be one last sideshow, though: a runoff for the Democratic nomination for comptroller between the incumbent, Elizabeth Holtzman, and Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens, the first such runoff for a secondary citywide office in the city's history.
As low as turnout was in Tuesday's primary -- about one-quarter of the city's more than two million registered Democrats -- it is expected to be even lower in the Sept. 28 runoff. That could favor Mr. Hevesi, who has a field organization and support among organized labor, and further hurt Ms. Holtzman, who drew her strongest support in black districts where voters, without Mr. Dinkins at the top of the ticket, may just stay home.
Ms. Holtzman was invited to the rally but, a sudden pariah in her own party councils, she did not attend, preparing instead for a news conference on an official city report that found her "grossly negligent" in taking a bank loan for her failed Senate campaign from a company whose sister concern was later awarded lucrative city bond underwriting business. By contrast, Mr. Hevesi stood just behind the Mayor in the same frame as Mark Green, the party's nominee for the No. 2 spot, public advocate.
 
Politics of Blocks and Tackles
 That sideshow may distract from the Mayor's efforts to make his case against Mr. Giuliani, though yesterday, with just seven weeks until Election Day, both candidates' seconds made it clear that not only the campaign season but football season had begun, as they burst out in sports metaphors. The Mayor's aides warned that they were prepared to draw sharp comparisons and questions about Mr. Giuliani's record sooner rather than later, in paid television commercials, if necessary. Mr. Giuliani's team, happy with some recent polls that have shown their candidate in the lead, vowed to move straight ahead.
"You just keep driving between center and tackle," said Mr. Giuliani's strategist, David Garth. "Our way is fairly clear. A lot can be told by the way the Mayor handled himself last night, starting with the attacks. He didn't have to put out a road map to tell us where he's worried when he opens up speaking Spanish worse than I do."
The Mayor's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, asked about his boss's sharper tone, replied: "We're in campaign mode now. This is about running and tackling." Asked, in the patois of politics, if the Mayor would "go negative" on Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Lynch replied: "I don't rule out anything within the realm of campaigning. We're going to look at a number of options. My major concern is whether or not we can pull our coalition of 1989 together and expand on it and that we get the Mayor's record and vision out there."
The Mayor's supporters have been urging him for weeks to go on the offensive. Before the Mayor spoke yesterday, the Governor urged him in an unsually public exhortation to shake off his celebrated reserve.
"I don't believe David Dinkins got his due in 1989," Mr. Cuomo said. "I don't believe he got the vote he was entitled to in 1989. I don't believe he gets what he's entitled to now, in terms of credit. And I don't know exactly why.
"I have a suspicion. It may have something to do with his civility. It may have something to do with his unflappability. It may have something to do with the way he closes that double-breasted jacket. I don't know what it is. He's got this easy manner about him, and that civility maybe is mistaken for weakness.
 
'Marine Toughness'
 "He has kept this city together. And done what he did all through this terrible recession, with that high civility and Marine toughness. Maybe what he has to show a little bit more of, just a little bit more, David, is a little bit more of the Marine toughness.
"I don't want you to lose your civility, but just show us a little bit more of the rest, and then finally he will get his due, which is not a victory on Nov. 2, it will be an enormous triumph, a huge triumph for David Dinkins."
Mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins had made the uncharacteristic decision to shuck his suit coat before the Governor's advice.
One participant in the rally had a special role: Mr. Green, who handily won the Democratic nomination to be the city's chief ombudsman, pledged to campaign hard for the Mayor he would be sworn to monitor if he won.
"It is an anomolous situation," Mr. Green acknowledged. "I look forward to doing everything I can to see that David Dinkins is the next Mayor so next year I can be the watchdog looking over his shoulder."

HEADLINE: Guarded Optimism for Peace Ushers In Jewish New Year

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
Letty Cottin Pogrebin, a writer, came back to Manhattan from the historic handshake in Washington with a feeling of euphoria, ushering in the Jewish New Year last night with chicken soup (her mother's recipe), brisket and a palpable -- though guarded -- sense of hope.
"I who love language have been reduced to the most ordinary cliches," said Ms. Pogrebin, chairwoman of Americans for Peace Now, a Zionist advocacy group. "So here goes: I never thought I'd live to see the day. I couldn't believe my eyes. It's a dream come true." 
 Avi Weiss, an Orthodox rabbi, on the other hand, returned to the Bronx depressed, his spirit damped for the High Holy Days. "I'm so worried that what lies on the horizon is a mortal threat to Israel," he said before the holiday began at sunset yesterday. "I'm going to have to tell my congregation that I'm emotionally and spiritually drained on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah."
 
A New Year Like No Other
 Across New York and the country, American Jews began their 10-day observance of the High Holy Days charged with mixed emotions after a historic week in which Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization signed an agreement that raised the possibility of peace in the Middle East. As they shared round challah and dipped apples in honey, as they walked to synagogue at sunset and prayed to be inscribed in the book of life, their emotions ran the gamut.
But whether jubilant, skeptical or furious about the accord, most agreed that this was a New Year like no other, a New Year that could transform the political and emotional landscape of American Jewry -- for better or worse.
And so rabbis feverishly rewrote their sermons to accommodate this defining moment.
On the Upper West Side, some progressive Jews, like Ms. Pogrebin's family, sang Hebrew peace songs over dinner. And in Borough Park, Brooklyn, many Orthodox Jews said they would pray as if this year were no different from any other -- but acknowledged that the week's events would color their emotions.
At 3 P.M. yesterday, Aaron Braun, a 36-year-old Orthodox Jew, pushed a cart of holiday dinner fixings out of Landau's Supermarket, which calls itself "the kosher inflation fighter."
"We are going to pray for peace, for the well-being of the world, as we always do," he said. "But we cannot rely on guns, we cannot rely on agreements. We can only rely on God."
 
Coincidence of Events
 In contrast, Margie Ostrove, a 27-year-old money-market trader doing last-minute shopping at Zabar's on the Upper West Side, said that a peace agreement was a very good start.
"I think we're just looking at the holiday as more of a beginning this year," she said. "We're more excited than usual -- not that we're cooking Palestinian foods yet, mind you."
Despite the last-minute preparations, many religious leaders said they relished the coincidence of events, that such a momentous time in Jewish history fell on the eve of the Jewish New Year.
"The timing means the Jews will be getting their direction on this not so much from Dan Rather and the secular Jewish leadership, but from their rabbis," said Rabbi Susan Grossman, who leads Genesis Agudas Achim, a Conservative congregation in Tuckahoe in Westchester County. "I cannot get over the fact that this happened this week, when the whole focus of Jewish life is on changing, having hope and looking toward the future. I mean, we always looked to the Middle East and said it's never going to change and here it did."
On Tuesday and Wednesday, Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Temple Beth-El, a Reform synagogue in Great Neck, L.I., who said he writes his best sermons under extreme deadline pressure, struggled to find a way to impart his own uplifted feelings at the possibility for change. He joked about borrowing President Clinton's speechwriter, and grew somber at the prospects for shaking his congregants loose from "the deep-seated stereotypes into which they have been frozen."
"They've been raised to see all of these Arab leaders' faces as the enemies'," he said. "Now somehow they have to be persuaded to let that image of the handshake -- halting as it may have been -- sit alongside or even eclipse some of the mental pictures of the intifada or Munich."
Rabbi Arthur Schneier, the senior rabbi at the Orthodox Park East Synagogue in Manhattan, said he would call for guarded optimism from a congregation that he described as "bewildered and anxious." His congregants want to believe that peace is imminent, but cannot quite let go of their distrust, he said.
"It has been said that Jews are paranoid but, I think, based on our history of persecution, we have a right," said Rabbi Schneier, a Holocaust survivor. "Nonetheless, by nature, we are a faith of optimism. We are blessed not only with the faculty to remember, but the capacity to forget. Personally, I would be paralyzed if I were to live through, on a daily basis, the loss of my family to the gas chambers, my experience of the beast and brutality in man. And as a people, we would be paralyzed if we clung to well-worn enmities of the conflict in the Middle East."
Still, many rabbis have a hard time preaching whole-hearted hopefulness. Rabbi Susan Schnur of Princeton, N.J., said that many Jews, conditioned to expect suffering, find good news hard to assimilate.
"The prayerbook is really a catalogue of Jewish tsuris, a catalogue of misery," said Rabbi Schnur of the progressive String of Pearl Congregation. "Good things don't happen to Jews overtly, and when they do, it feels dangerous."
Rabbi Balfour Brickner, the senior Reform rabbi emeritus at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan, however, had no hesitation about delighting in the peace agreement.
"This dove is crowing, you better believe it," said Rabbi Brickner, an advocate of peace for 25 years, noting that the main response in the occupied territories was jubilation. "You didn't seen the walls of Jericho go down in flames. You saw them festooned with flowers and flags."
Stopping to shop for some last-minute cheese on the way to her sister's home for dinner, Trudy Steinberg of Yonkers said the family's celebration would be "more upbeat, more glad, more hopeful." But her husband, Leon, interrupted her in disagreement. "No it won't -- I'm pessimistic," he said. "You're dealing with people who are murderers over there. As soon as it's over, they want Jerusalem."
People cannot help but be of two minds, said Morris A. Schmidman, an Orthodox rabbi who is director of the Council of Jewish Organizations in Brooklyn. "You have hope that it will be successful at the same time as a realization that the sordid past puts a dimmer on the prospects," he said.

HEADLINE: Environment Groups Are Split on Support For Free-Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A dispute over the trade pact with Mexico and Canada has split the American environmental movement, exposing a profound ideological rift over whether some large national environmental organizations have become too friendly with the Clinton White House.
The rift, which has been simmering since early this year, boiled over into a public feud today after a group of environmental leaders appeared with Vice President Al Gore to voice their support for the North American Free Trade Agreement now being considered by Congress. 
 The feud generally pits big national environmental groups based in New York and Washington -- which have shown a willingness to compromise to increase their influence at the highest levels of the Government -- against other organizations, some of which are just as large, that are focused on grass-roots efforts.
The grass-roots groups look askance at compromise, insisting that the trade agreement would weaken environmental and health standards in the United States. The groups supporting the trade agreement have gained prominence in Washington since the election, in part because some of their former staff members are now members of the Clinton Administration.
The fight that boiled over today concerns both the trade agreement and political tactics. But the differences also mirror other battles in the environmental community over public lands policy, wetlands, endangered species and managing toxic compounds. Many of those differences have been quietly brewing since the first months of the Clinton Presidency.
This morning the leaders of six prominent national environmental groups promised to help the White House fight for Congressional passage of the trade pact. Groups opposing it immediately responded in terms environmentalists normally use for polluters. Each side accused the other of distorting facts, failing to recognize economic or political reality and imperiling public safety.
The endorsements came during a news conference on Capitol Hill at which Mr. Gore was flanked by the heads of the National Audubon Society, the National Wildlife Federation, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Environmental Defense Fund, the World Wildlife Fund and Conservation International.
Jay D. Hair, the head of the National Wildlife Federation, the nation's largest conservation group, accused environmentalists that oppose the trade agreement of "putting their protectionist polemics ahead of concern for the environment." He added that the groups attacking the proposal "haven't seen the documents," "don't have the facts," and "are feeding off misinformation."
 
'Between a Rock and a Sponge'
 The environmental organizations opposing the trade agreement include the Sierra Club, the Humane Society of the United States, Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace and nearly 300 state, regional and community groups. Leaders of these groups, arguing that the agreement would weaken environmental laws in the United States, have begun a campaign to prevent its passage.
The groups opposing the agreement have formed a new coalition, the Citizens Trade Campaign, which is preparing a newspaper advertisement for publication next week asserting that the National Wildlife Federation and the five other groups have become too close to big business. A draft of the text of the advertisement, which circulated today in Washington, asks, "Why are some 'green' groups so quick to sell off the North American environment? Maybe they are too cozy with their corporate funders."
Tim Hermach, the executive director of the Native Forest Council, an environmental group in Eugene, Ore. that opposes the trade agreement, said: "Environmentalists who are in support of this agreement are a sponge. They don't know what they want. They are not sure how to get it, and they can be squeezed any time. Industry is absolutely clear about what it wants, and they are absolutely ruthless in doing anything to get it. So Bill Clinton is between a rock and a sponge and which one would you pick to have as an enemy?"
 
Critics See No Compromise
 The trade agreement would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada, much of it by the end of the decade. On Tuesday, President Clinton signed a supplemental agreement negotiated by Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, and Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, that is designed to prevent each country from lowering environmental standards to gain a competitive advantage.
The environmental provisions also call for the United States, Canada and Mexico to establish a commission to oversee each country's enforcement of its own laws. And the White House has agreed to establish a $4 billion fund for environmental cleanup along the border with Mexico.
The plan's critics in the environmental movement said the provisions were too vaguely worded to have real impact if a dispute over environmental issues arose between two countries. They also argued that the public is not allowed to participate fully in resolving disputes between nations and that the overall effect of the agreement would be to lower standards to accommodate the Mexican economy.
"It's perplexing to me how any environmental group could support this agreement," said Lori M. Wallach, director of the trade program for Public Citizen in Washington.
John H. Adams, the executive director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said he had anticipated such criticism from colleagues in his movement. "I recognize that this is a complex and difficult issue on which reasonable people with the same values and objectives can differ," he said.
 
Supporters Helped Devise Plan
 Mr. Adams said that members of his staff had spent thousands of hours participating with Administration officials in the development of the environmental provisions of the agreement and that they had provided a "solid institutional framework" that would protect Mexico without weakening American environmental and health statutes.
Kathryn Fuller, the president of the World Wildlife Fund, noted that Mexico has more biological resources than almost any other country and that by acquiring greater economic opportunities through the trade agreement, Mexico would also have more money available to protect valuable species of plants and animals.
Peter Berle, the president of the National Audubon Society, Fred Krupp, the executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, and Dr. Russell Mittermeier, the president of Conservation International, also said they had no doubt that approving the trade agreement was better for the environment.
Legal and scientific experts who have reviewed the text of the environmental agreements or followed the debate in the environmental community, said today they agreed with environmental leaders who support the pact.
"The trade agreement provides a context for dealing with the environment in Mexico and a way to cooperate to take better care of our environment," said Dr. Peter H. Raven, a botanist and director of the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis. "Mexico has to have the resources to deal with these problems. You can't deal with these issues if you're poor."

HEADLINE: Hailing Health Plan but Denouncing Trade Pact, Big Labor Is Heard Again

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
After years of falling membership and political influence, organized labor has emerged as a force behind both the drive to stop President Clinton's proposed trade agreement with Mexico and Canada and the campaign to enact his overhaul of the health care system.
One reason for the new clout of the unions, which have long been irrelevant to the debates over such national issues, is a serendipitous convergence of their agenda with the agendas of many other interest groups, in particular advocates for the poor and the environment. Another is a friend in the White House who, despite the differences over trade, has been granting labor easier access and more of its wishes than any President since Lyndon B. Johnson. 
 Despite likely quibbles, unions can be expected to support the health plan. "The President has pointed the nation in the right direction," Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said a few days ago. But labor vehemently opposes the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Mr. Kirkland called "a poison pill left over from the previous Administration."
For weeks, the conventional wisdom has had it that the agreement would lose if the House of Representatives were to vote on it now. The Senate appears to support the agreement, but at present most Democrats in the House of Representatives, with an eye on next year's congressional elections, appear opposed. One prominent union leader, William H. Bywater, president of the electrical workers union, is promising to fight the reelection of congressmen who support the agreement.
 
Hitting Labor's 'Hot Button'
 Freshman Democrats in the House said they voted in secret on Monday to oppose the agreement. Two House leaders who are from union strongholds in Michigan -- David E. Bonior, the majority whip and third-ranking leader, and William D. Ford, chairman of the education and labor committee -- are unequivocally opposed. And Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader and the recipient of strong union support, has been sharply critical of the agreement.
"Nafta hits the hot button," said Gerald W. McEntee, president of the 1.3-million-member American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees. "Health care is important. Reducing the deficit is important. But No. 1 is still jobs, and Nafta has a direct relationship to jobs. People understand that. They see a real possibility their companies will go south."
Thomas J. Downey, a political consultant here and former Democratic House member from Long Island, said: "With all due respect to my friends in labor, I'm for Nafta. But they are effective and persistent. They have much of the soul of the Democratic Party. They are going to play a very big role in the President's agenda."
It is too soon to gauge whether unions can win this one. It was not until Tuesday that President Clinton began to fight, mustering former Presidents Bush, Carter and Ford to a White House ceremony and dispatching cabinet officers to help promote the agreement. But on no other issue in recent years has organized labor committed such energy, and on no other has it found such wide support.
 
Union Membership Dropping
 As an institution, organized labor has not changed as much as the climate around it. Most unions, gathered under the umbrella of A.F.L.-C.I.O., are led by white males, most older than 60. While stalwart defenders of democracy, only a few unions, like the teamsters and the mine workers, elect their leaders directly. In most other unions, leaders are elected indirectly by delegates to conventions, often by acclamation. And unlike most of their members today, most leaders have secure jobs. Once in office, many die there.
Organized labor's membership, strongest in shrinking manufacturing industries and weakest in growing services industries, is still receding. Officials close to the federation say that at its biannual convention next month in San Francisco it is likely to report that membership of the affiliated unions has dropped by close to one million, to 13.9 million, in just two years. Union members today make up less than 16 percent of the work force.
And labor may still lack sufficient influence, even with Democrats in control of the White House and Congress, to achieve their more parochial goals, like rewriting labor laws they believe are stacked against them or stopping companies from firing striking workers.
But organized labor can marshal one of the nation's mightiest political networks, as well as fat campaign coffers, in pursuit of its causes. The Federal Election Commission reports that of the 10 largest contributions by political action committees to candidates for Federal office in 1991 and 1992, five were from unions. And labor can rally hundreds of thousands of men and women to lobby legislators, get out the vote and march in demonstrations.
 
'Things Are Bad Enough'
 The deployment of such resources has had little effect on the course of public policy in recent years. But the trade agreement has aroused many other interests that have joined labor in a new lobby called the Citizens Trade Campaign.
The campaign's participants include Friends of the Earth and Environmental Action, which fear a surge in air and water pollution from American companies moving south of the border, the National Consumers League, the National Council of Senior Citizens and the National Farmers Union.
In the past, said Mark Anderson, director of trade affairs at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Government's trade-opening treaties were worked out in the back rooms of Congress and the Administration. "This fight will take place in the cities and towns across the country," he said.
Union workers, and many nonunion workers, see the trade agreement aggravating an already volatile job market in which major companies like General Motors Corporation and I.B.M. lay off workers by the tens of thousands, companies relocate factories to low-wage countries and employers replace full-time jobs with part-time and temporary jobs.
"Things are bad enough,"said Ben Fischer, a professor of public service at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh and a former steelworkers union officer. "There's so much insecurity. Why add to it?"
 
Support for Health Overhaul
 Unions are fairly content with the other big proposal on the President's fall agenda, the health plan. Some wanted a single-payer system that would be entirely taxpayer financed and Government managed, like Canada's, not the mixed, public-private arrangement the President is proposing.
Some also expect to find grounds for dispute once they know more details. But they say it still meets their long-sought, once politically quixotic goal of guaranteed health care for all.
"It's a major step in the right direction," said Ronald Carey, president of the 1.4-million member teamsters union. "It's not single-payer, but it's okay if it is for all Americans and does not have working people paying all the freight."
By contrast, labor considers the trade agreement rotten to the core. The agreement would phase out many obstacles to investment and trade between the United States, Canada and Mexico. Canada, with an economy much like that of the United States, has not been an issue. But unions say the agreement's implications for commerce with Mexico are alarming.
Low wages are an obvious lure for those American companies whose labor costs represent a major part of the prices they charge. Average wages and fringe benefits in Mexico are about one-seventh those in the United States. Unions say the difference can give Mexican companies a big edge in competing with American producers, thus jeopardizing American jobs.
In defense of the agreement, President Clinton echoes most economists in arguing that history shows that everyone gains in wages, jobs and economic growth when trade obstacles like tariffs and quotas are removed.
Indeed, American exports to Mexico have grown since the relaxation of some trade barriers in the 1980's. Such growth benefits workers who produce export items, though it does not help workers who lose jobs to imports from Mexico. Mr. Clinton also argues that as the Mexican economy improves, illegal immigration, which many workers see as a threat to their jobs, will abate.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who supports most of labor's agenda, including raising the minimum wage and a law against dismissing striking workers, confronted the unions on trade in a speech last week. He accused labor of indulging in Luddite-like "politics of preservation grounded in fear."
But unions look not to the wide effects of a change in economic policy but to the businesses that have abandoned factories in the United States, impoverishing some communities and leaving workers either jobs that are much worse in terms of pay and benefits or no jobs at all.
 
Questioning Pact's Fairness
 The agreement, says Mr. Anderson of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., would lead to more letters like one the Smead Manufacturing Company in Hastings, Minn., makers of file folders and other office products, sent its 2,600 workers on Aug. 4.
"In my July 1, 1993 notice, I stated that we were in the process of making a decision regarding assembling selected products in Mexico, Smead's president, Ebba C. Hoffman, wrote." After a careful review, she said, "the decision has been made to start assembling selected five-piece pockets and expanding files in Mexico."
And the production of several other products would also be moved to Mexico in coming months, she said, adding: "We simply cannot continue losing sales of these key products."
Unions say they are all for more trade, but they insist on an agreement with Mexico that would raise minimum wages there, give Mexican workers the right to form unions and require tough workplace health and safety standards.
Donald Ross, an assistant secretary of labor, acknowledges the unions' fears but says there is little the Government can do to tame the economy's tides. "Because of the way the economy has changed," he said, "the reality of job security that our parents had is largely a thing of the past. It's not honest to say we can fix it."
 
Emphasis on Job Training
 He and Mr. Reich have promised to do more to help workers adjust. They are preparing a sweeping overhaul of the Government's job training programs and its assistance to unemployed workers. Mr. Reich also envisions training workers for a high-skill, high-wage workplace of the future. But unions are skeptical.
"Retrain people for what?" Mr. Carey asked. "Workers want to know, Will I be able to get married, or purchase a house?"
Professor Fischer said: "Unions are not philosophical societies. They are oriented toward the immediate needs of their members. They represent the people who pay their dues. They have no other constituency.
"They have no choice but to look at Nafta and say, 'Can this represent any gain for my members?' They would have to make a devious, remote case to show that it would."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD;
Iranian Leader Denounces Peace Pact

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, has denounced the accords between the P.L.O. and Israel as "the most degrading times for the Islamic holy war in Palestine" and predicted that they will fail to yield peace.
"The Palestinian problem cannot be solved by several people signing an agreement in the White House," Mr. Rafsanjani said on Tuesday of the formal ceremony in Washington on Monday. 
 Widely viewed as the Iranian leader most inclined toward pragmatic economic and foreign policy, the President has effectively added his voice to that of the ideological rank and file of the Iranian clergy and Government-owned news organizations opposed to the peace pact.
Lower-ranking Iranian figures have villified the accord over the last few days as "a stain of shame" for Arabs and Muslims across the world and condemned the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, as a "traitor" for reaching agreements with Israel on mutual recognition and on limited self-rule for Palestinians in Gaza and Jericho.
 
Dismissed as Mere Paper
 Ayatollah Mohammad Yazdi, the influential Chief Justice of Iran, had opened the Iranian clergy's offensive against the accords a few days ago by rejecting them as nothing more than pieces of paper signed by a few men.
Still, experts on Iranian affairs found it significant that Mr. Rafsanjani did not speak out until nearly two weeks after news of the draft peace agreement first leaked out and until after it was signed on Monday..
They interpreted the delay as a sign of Teheran's sensitivity to widespread support for the accord among among Palestinians and Arab governments, including gulf states that Iran has been courting since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Mr. Rafsanjani's delay also reflects Iran's severe economic problems, which limit its willigness or ability challenge an accord that has international support and the United States as a guardian.
Baqer Moin, an expert on Iranian affairs and a commentator on Persian Gulf affairs in London, said that Iran's policy reflected the competing priorities Teheran now faces in dealing with the Arab world. "On one hand Iran wants to lead the Islamic fundamentalist movements, which oppose virtually every Arab regime as well as the peace process, while, in the same time, trying to improve its relations with gulf Arabs and Egypt," he said
The Arab gulf countries whose good will Iran is courting, particularly Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, unambigiously support the agreement on limited Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho, a factor that may restrain the Iranian Government from openly encouraging pro-Iranian groups to sink the accord.
Although Iran has a proxy army in Lebanon -- the pro-Iranian Party of God militia -- there is little it can do there directly to sabotage the accord. Troops from Syria, Iran's only strategic Arab ally, still control much of Lebanon.
So far Syria has refrained from opposing the P.L.O.'s peace efforts until it is clear what effect they will have on a potential Syrian-Israeli settlement over the Golan Heights.
 
A Shrinking Tolerance
 In any case, there is shrinking tolerance among the Lebanese for foreign powers playing havoc with their country, an attitude that raises questions about the future sway of the Party of God there.
Iraq, which would have been widely expected to denounce the accord, has also been doling out its condemnations in measured doses, keeping some room for maneuver. Neither President Saddam Hussein nor any of his senior aides have loudly and clearly clearly denounced the pact, leaving statements of disapproval to the Government-owned news organizations.
The Iraqi-based opposition to the Iranian Government known as the Mujahedeen Khalq has proclaimed its support of the agreement, suggesting that it did so with a nod from its Iraqi hosts.
"The Iranians are equally anxious and angry about this agreement," said Qassem Jaafar, a Middle East strategic and military affairs expert who writes for Al Hayat, a London-based daily.
"It is a deal that raises anxiety in places like Damascus and Baghdad as well, the more so since it appears that Palestinians by and large are rallying behind Arafat so far," Mr. Jaafar said in a telephone interview.
 
Something Iran Can't Ignore
 For economic reasons alone, Iran cannot afford to ignore a budding Arab-Western alliance to make the Israeli-Palestinian agreements work. With oil prices having fallen steeply over the past six months and its foreign debt exceeding $20 billion, Iran is highly in a vulnerable spot. The United States has been tightening existing bans on the export of Western technology, weapons and chemicals to Iran and forbids its oil companies from importing Iranian oil.
The sharp decline in oil prices and the growth in debt have led most foreign oil and industrial companies to freeze credit to Iran. The Iranian central bank is trying to contain spending of precious hard currency and has stopped guaranteeing letters of credit for Iranian importers, strangling domestic industries that depend on imported spare parts and raw materials.
Oil prices have tumbled by roughly $4 a barrel over the last six months, and experts say that each dollar drop represents a loss of a billion dollars in annual income a year for Iran.
