HEADLINE: Fearful of Tourism Decline, Florida Offers Assurances on Safety

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 15

 BODY:
As law-enforcement authorities here stepped up their search for the killers of a British tourist, Florida tourism officials today issued new pledges intended to make the state's streets and highways safer and to limit damage to the state's vital tourism industry.
Galvanized by the blizzard of negative publicity around the world that followed the shooting death of 34-year-old Gary Colley early Tuesday at a highway rest stop east of here, the authorities in Jefferson County, where Mr. Colley was killed, began a dragnet aimed at young blacks with criminal records, a move that immediately generated controversy. 
 At the same time, the state's top law-enforcement officer and its tourism chief appeared at a news conference this morning to plead with residents and tourists alike to remain calm and wait for the new security measures to take effect.
"Florida does care, we are concerned, and we are addressing the problem," said Greg Farmer, Secretary of the Department of Commerce, which oversees the state's $31 billion-a-year tourist industry.
"Statistically, this is a very safe place to visit," he added.
 
'Now There Is a Problem'
 Mr. Colley's death, which the police said occurred when he tried to flee robbers, was the second of a foreign tourist in Florida in less than a week and the ninth since last October. James T. Moore, director of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, said that the car used in Tuesday's attack had been found and that "some useful information" had been recovered from it. He declined to give details.
Mr. Moore also defended the security measures in place on Florida highways before Mr. Colley was shot. "How many places can we guard?" he asked. "We had no reason to think we should deploy scarce resources at rest areas, because there was not a problem there. Now there is a problem."
He also suggested that the robberies and killings of foreign tourists were part of a broader social malaise not limited to Florida and one that law-enforcement officials could not be expected to control, much less solve. "We've got to do a better job helping people respect the value of a human life, and not wait until they are 17 years of age to realize that," he said.
In Jefferson County, sheriff's deputies began rounding up every black male ages 15 to 22 with a criminal record involving firearms or stolen cars. Sheriff Ken Fortune said that as many as 60 potential suspects would be photographed and fingerprinted as part of the investigation into Mr. Colley's death. According to the 1990 census, 43 percent of the county's 11,296 residents are black.
"We have not focused on any one person," Sheriff Fortune said. But, he added, "we've got some mothers very upset because we're picking up their children."
Since Mr. Colley was slain, the state government has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of his killers, has set up a toll-free number to provide safety and other tourism tips and has begun providing security at all 76 rest areas on its Interstate highways. Those efforts, supplementing an existing campaign to provide safety brochures to foreign visitors, won praise today from European tourism industry executives.
"I actually think the Florida tourism authorities have taken a good and positive approach to this problem," Keith Betton, a spokesman for the Association of British Travel Agents, said in a telephone interview. "I can think of many countries that would be tempted to play this down and pretend it is not happening. But Florida's whole attitude has been very professional."
Foreigners account for about 7 million of the 42 million people who visit Florida each year, and until the two recent killings, tourism over all had been on the way to a record year. Now, however, Mr. Farmer, the Commerce Secretary, said he expected the pace to drop by 12 percent to 15 percent. But travel industry executives around the state today offered varied assessments of the probable impact of the violence.
In Orlando, the state's most popular tourist destination, officials at attractions like Disney World and Universal Studios said their business was at normal levels. Illustrating the importance of tourism to the Florida economy, Gov. Lawton Chiles flew to Orlando today to join Universal executives in announcing plans to build a second theme park, several hotels, and new movie and television production sites there.
"Some of our international business has been decreasing," said Randy Garfield, vice president for marketing at Universal Studios Florida, "but it's still considerably up from last year." Mr. Garfield said the recent slippage could be traced not only to crime but also to higher airfares and sluggish economies in Europe.
 
Reaction Among Europeans
 Bryn Roden, president of American Connections, a Miami Beach tour agency whose clients are exclusively European, said the full impact of the killings will not be felt for weeks. Mr. Roden said he expected a decline of 25 percent to 30 percent in his bookings, since the killings occurred precisely when British and German tour operators were printing brochures for the 1994 season and tourists from those countries were planning next summer's holidays.
"Europeans can go on vacation and be robbed or mugged anywhere," said Mr. Roden, a Briton. "The big difference is that when they come here they can also end up looking down the barrel of a gun. That simply does not happen in European vacation resorts. Europeans are not used to guns, and they are frightened. It's as simple as that."
Those comments were echoed today by a group of British tourists eagerly waiting at Miami International Airport for the plane that would take them home. Ed and Karen Bolton of London said they had felt safe only in their hotel and that they were afraid even to rent a car in Florida after the first of the killings, in Miami, last week.
"I would never ever come here again, unless it was for business," said Mr. Bolton, who has been a frequent visitor in the past, "and then I would leave as soon as possible. The United States needs gun laws. I think your Government needs a swift kick in the butt. It's a shame, because this is such a lovely country."
While bookings from Europe are falling, tourism authorities said there had been no discernable decline in domestic bookings, which still account for more than 80 percent of Florida's tourist business. Mr. Farmer said that was in part because Americans tended to perceive their own country as "a violent, gun-ridden society" and to regard crime as just another feature of the landscape.
When a tourist is killed, he said, "it's not as much a shocker" to Americans as to foreigners. Domestic visitors understand, he added, that the recent attacks are "isolated incidents" that could have occurred almost anywhere.
Nevertheless, there were signs all over the state that the tourist killings are forcing Florida's 13 million residents to take a closer look at crime and how to control it. Some legislators have called for a ban of possession of handguns by minors; others, concerned that many "smash-and-grab" robberies are committed by criminals who had been released early from prisons because of overcrowding, said they would press for more money to build jails and prisons.
State officials emphasized today that less than a 10th of a percent of the tourists who visited Florida last year became victims of crime. But Florida's index of violent crime, 1,184 per 100,000 people in 1991, is the highest in the nation, according to statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and some here are demanding tougher treatment of the criminals who prey on the elderly and tourists.
"'We should shoot them down like the dogs they are," Secretary of State Jim Smith told The Tallahassee Democrat. Mr. Smith, who is seeking the Republican nomination for governor in 1994, also said the state had "find a way to declare war on people out there."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE PRIMARY: Westchester;
Democrats Vow United Front In Effort to Unseat O'Rourke

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
With occasional flashes of discomfort, the victor and the vanquished in the Westchester County Democratic primary came together today to declare a united front against County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, whom they hope to unseat in November.
Richard L. Brodsky, the 47-year-old Assemblyman from Greenburgh who squeezed out a 920-vote victory in a contest in which 32,000 votes were cast, and his defeated opponent, Andrew J. Spano, the County Clerk, embraced each other at what was billed as a Democratic unity rally. It was held on the steps of the County Office Building, where Mr. O'Rourke has had his offices for the last 11 years. 
 For the first time in generations, the Democrats believe they have a solid chance to capture the top two county offices, the executive's job and the post of District Attorney. Michael G. Cherkasky, 43, career prosecutor in Manhattan, won in a landslide over his opponent, Paul W. Pickelle, a Scarsdale criminal lawyer, in the district attorney's race; he will face Jeanine Pirro, a former county judge, in the Nov. 2 election.
In this century, only one Democrat, Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive from 1973 through 1982, has held either of the two top jobs, and it was a canny piece of political stagecraft that he was chosen to serve as the rally master of ceremonies today.
 
From Scorn to Praise
 At the rally Mr. Brodsky praised Mr. Spano, whom he had belittled as "Clerk Spano," as "an extraordinary spirit" who has shown "grace under pressure." And Mr. Spano called Mr. Brodsky, whom he had scorned as arrogant, "one of the brightest, most creative people I know."
The two had agreed to work together for a Democratic victory at one of the breakfast sessions at which party leaders like Dennis Mehiel served as peace makers. But Mr. Spano could not keep his resentment from the campaign entirely in check. "By coming together, we're going to benefit Richard, who can use a little adjustment once in a while," he said. Still, Mr. Brodsky was willing to kiss Mr. Spano on the cheek for the cameras.
 
Plans for Attack
 In his remarks to a small sidewalk crowd, Mr. Brodsky suggested that he would attack Mr. O'Rourke for the county's floundering economy and for what he described as Mr. O'Rourke's conflicts of interest in allowing three people close to him -- his daughter, his companion and her son -- to obtain jobs with county contractors. An investigation by District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, who is retiring after 25 years in the job, found Mr. O'Rourke had broken no laws.
"I promise you honest government, a government that will put people back to work," Mr. Brodksy declared.
Mr. O'Rourke, at a news conference nominally about a $4 million program to improve the county's training school for firefighters, shot back at Mr. Brodsky, asserting that Mr. Brodsky would not be able to withstand the scrutiny that Mr. O'Rourke has received as the county's highest official. He also termed Mr. Brodsky a "coward," accusing him of dodging controversial votes in the State Assembly.
"It will not be a campaign that Westchester has seen before and that's too bad, but that's the way these things go," he said.
He argued that his personal ethics should no longer be a campaign issue since an erroneous "perception" had been cleared up by Mr. Vergari.
Mr. Brodsky's narrow victory was helped by a compelling town supervisor's contest in Greenburgh that drew more Democrats, 6,500, than almost anywhere else in the county. By a 3-to-1 margin, they voted for their fellow resident, Mr. Brodsky, for county executive. Paul J. Feiner, the incumbent, won the nomination for Greenburgh town supervisor.
In the much larger city of Yonkers, where Mr. Spano enjoys strong support, the primary drew only 7,800 voters.
This will be Mr. Brodsky's second try for the county executive's job. Four years ago, he lost to Mr. O'Rourke by a margin of 52 percent of the vote to 45 percent. But this time Democrats have achieved a considerable edge in registration in this historically Republican county, 178,753 to 152,729, and Mr. O'Rourke is considered more vulnerable.
Mr. Brodsky, whose father was a structural-steel engineer and whose mother was active in politics, was born in Flatbush, Brooklyn. His family moved to Ardsley in Westchester when he was 11. He attended Brandeis University and graduated from Harvard Law School in 1971.
He worked for several years for a foundation set up by the widow of Robert F. Kennedy and then as legislative counsel to Mr. DelBello. In 1975, he made his first bid for political office, winning election to the county's Board of Legislators. He served as a county legislator for four terms and first ran for the Assembly in 1982.
He is married to the former Paige Massman, a onetime Broadway actress who with her family owns a beef-cattle ranch in Montana. The Brodskys spend vacations there and come hom with beef for a large barbecue at their 300-year-old Greenburgh house for friends and associates. They have two daughters, Emily, 7 and Julianne Willie, 2.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard L. Brodsky, the winner of the Democratic primary for Westchester County Executive, speaking at a rally yesterday in White Plains to call for unity among Democrats in the fight to unseat Andrew P. O'Rourke. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Eye on Olympics, China Pursues Air Safety

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Worried that its effort to become the host to the 2000 Olympic Games could be undermined by safety concerns among foreigners who fly on China's airlines, Chinese aviation authorities have announced a major crackdown on safety violations.
For anyone who has flown in China, the new safety drive is much overdue. China's economic takeoff has produced a boom in air travel -- and accidents -- with the increase in new domestic airlines last year allowed by the breakup of the state air monopoly in 1988. 
 At Beijing International Airport, British Airways has banned the boarding of passengers during refueling operations because the local ground crews refuse to put out their cigarettes.
"Can you imagine the fumes from 100 tons of fuel in the air and a guy is sitting there with a butt in his mouth?" a manager of an international airline said. "I tell off about four people a week, but it doesn't do any good."
On many flights, seat belts are optional, flight crews and cabin staff invisible and, in one noted accident in Hong Kong harbor in 1988, life jackets nonexistent. Chinese travelers seldom check bags because they will get lost, so the aisles of China's airliners are often so clogged with luggage, not to mention standing passengers, as to make a speedy exit impossible.
At a recent news conference, Yan Zhixiang, deputy director general of the Civil Aviation Administration of China, told reporters, "The aviation sector, which is undergoing rapid expansion, has failed to carry through rules on air safety and security."
Lax safety and security standards prompted one passenger association in the United States to quip in its newsletter that flying in China was more dangerous than strolling through the streets of Sarajevo.
An exaggeration, to be sure, but the barbs from abroad have been reinforced by so many scare stories from China's frequent fliers that the leadership was forced to crack down before the country's air safety record was thrown onto the list of reasons China's critics have been compiling to keep the 2000 Games away from here, airline industry officials say.
International aviation officials are loath to say China's air fatality record is worse than that of other developing countries, in part because China still does not report its safety data to industry organizations. But China's aviation authorities themselves said last week that the total of 331 deaths in commercial airliner crashes in the last 13 months was intolerable and constituted a warning that safety systems had gone awry.
Among the worst aspects of the system is air-traffic control, where old radars and inadequate communication systems at times keep controllers in the dark about what is going on.
Flight delays are also epidemic these days. The aviation authority's most recent figures show that delays in scheduled flights jumped from 8 percent in May and June last year to 18 percent this year and that most of those delays were due to air-traffic control problems.
Airline officials say air-traffic controllers often have little choice but to delay flights because the bulk of China's airspace is reserved for the military. When narrow civilian flight corridors fill up with traffic, controllers cannot assign flights to parallel military corridors without getting permission from the military, another time-consuming procedure.
Steps China has taken to improve its performance include signing contracts with international aviation companies to help Chinese airlines set up new maintenance and training programs.
Boeing is running a large pilot-training program as part of its contracts to sell billions of dollars in new aircraft here. British Airways has just signed a 12-month contract with China Southern Airline to help develop its maintenance program.
But in the largest aviation improvement program for the Olympics the Chinese authorities hope to entice foreign airlines and investors to build or modernize 100 airports nationwide by the year 2000 to meet an estimated demand of 180 million annual passengers, a tripling of the estimated 60 million yearly passengers now.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Promises Help on Medical Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans and the American Medical Association vowed today to cooperate with President Clinton in revamping the nation's health care system, but they said Mr. Clinton's proposals relied far too much on Government regulation to control costs.
Excitement and anxiety about Mr. Clinton's plan, to be unveiled on Sept. 22, produced a dozen news conferences around town today. Even critics of the Clinton plan said they assumed that Congress would, by the end of next year, pass a bill to guarantee medical care for all Americans. 
Lobbyists for the alcohol and tobacco industries skirmished today over one of the major unresolved elements of Mr. Clinton's plan: taxes.
Members of Congress from tobacco-producing states pleaded with White House officials to propose an increase in the Federal excise tax on alcoholic beverages, so cigarettes would not bear the full burden of new taxes.
President Clinton wants to raise $105 billion over seven years from what he calls new "sin taxes." He has said that he would propose higher cigarette taxes but that he has not decided on the amount of the increase. He is said to be seriously considering a higher tax on alcohol but expects widespread opposition in Congress and thus has not decided whether to propose it.
 
Defense of Alcohol
 Fred A. Meister, president of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, a trade association for liquor manufacturers, said: "The tobacco industry realizes that the Administration wants to increase its taxes very substantially. Tobacco lobbyists are using every political argument they can to pass the tax off onto beverage alcohol generally and liquor in particular."
"There is no reason alcohol should be asked to carry the tax burden for cigarettes," Mr. Meister said, asserting that "alcohol may have some cardiovascular health benefits."
Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, and other Republicans praised the President and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, for serious efforts to guarantee coverage for all Americans, including the 37 million who have no health insurance. But Mr. Dole said Republicans had their own plan.
"Our proposal is dramatically different from the Administration's," Mr. Dole said. "We do not mandate employers to pay for health care. We do not create mandatory health alliances that are monopolies. We do not create global budgets through the use of premium caps. Nor do we create a variety of new costly benefits and entitlement programs."
 
G.O.P. Cites Flexibility
 The Republicans, like Mr. Clinton, would establish health insurance purchasing groups in every state, to buy coverage for millions of consumers and thousands of small businesses. The Republicans said that participation in these groups would be voluntary under their plan but compulsory for most Americans under the Clinton plan. The Republican proposal would require all Americans to obtain health insurance but allow people to buy individual policies.
Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said the Republican proposal would allow several purchasing groups to operate in the same geographical area, whereas the Clinton plan would allow only one.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the A.M.A., said he was distressed at the "degree of proposed Government intrusion into the relationship between physician and patient" under the Clinton plan. "The health of our patients and their families may suffer as economics becomes more important than quality," he said.
Under the Clinton plan, Dr. Todd said, "our biggest concern is that we will have a health care system run by the insurance industry" and by a powerful new Federal agency, the National Health Board. The doctors support a Federal mandate requiring employers to buy insurance for their employees, but they oppose Mr. Clinton's proposal for Federal regulation of health insurance premiums.
For years, the nation's doctors and hospitals have been seeking relief from Federal antitrust laws. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission issued new guidelines today to ease fears of the health care industry that cost-cutting mergers and joint ventures might violate such laws.
The Government said, for example, that it would generally not challenge hospital mergers in which one hospital is more than five years old and has fewer than 100 beds and fewer than 40 patients a day.
 
'We Are Disappointed'
 Administration officials said the guidelines were simply clarifications of existing policy and did not provide the broad exemptions from antitrust law sought by doctors and the hospital industry.
Kirk B. Johnson, general counsel of the American Medical Association, said: "We are disappointed. The guidelines really don't give us any additional flexibility. They authorize conduct that we always believed was safe."
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, chairman of the Judiciary Subcommittee on Antitrust, said: "We're going to solve a problem in the antitrust field without changing one word, one comma or one semicolon of the antitrust laws, and there is no need to. Our antitrust laws are not to blame for the high cost of health care."
Mrs. Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform considered major changes in antitrust law that would have exempted doctors and hospitals. But the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission strenuously opposed such changes, saying they would weaken competition in the health care industry, harm consumers and undermine the Government's enforcement power.
In a report delivered today to Mrs. Clinton, a consumer group estimated that two million Americans lose health insurance coverage each month.
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of the consumer group, Families USA, said that most of those people regain insurance in five to nine months. But their experience "shows why there is so much insecurity about the nation's health care system," Mr. Pollack said.

HEADLINE: 2 Small Banks Cut Prime to 5 3/4%; Others Stay at 6%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Southwest Bank of St. Louis and the Central Fidelity Bank of Richmond cut their prime rates yesterday to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent, but the moves were not followed by larger banks.
Executives of some big New York banks indicated that they had no immediate plans to cut their prime rates. 
 Short-term interest rates have been steady since July of last year, when the prime rate was cut to 6 percent from 6 1/2 percent. Bankers and others have been wondering whether the next cut in the prime could come without waiting for the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term rates.
Because the prime rate is unusually high relative to other short-term rates, and the banking industry has been earning record profits over the last 18 months, some analysts say banks could afford to lower their prime rates.
 
A Benchmark Rate
 The prime rate is a widely used benchmark for setting interest rates on consumer loans, particularly credit cards and home equity loans. Most loans to businesses fluctuate according to short-term interest rates controlled by the Federal Reserve, not banks, but loans to small and medium-sized businesses are frequently based on the prime.
Gerard Cassidy, a banking analyst at Tucker Anthony, the securities firm, said the combination of 1994 elections and a weak economy was likely to lead to an outcry from Washington that "to help kick-start the economy the banks should cut the prime rate to 5 percent."
Other analysts said that the Clinton Administration had not yet done any favors for the banking industry that would encourage banks to cooperate. "Obviously, at some point the banks could catch some heat from the Clinton Administration, but it's too soon for that now," said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst at CS First Boston. He does not expect large banks to lower their prime rates until early next year.
Lewis N. Miller Jr., president of the Central Fidelity Bank, said he had cut the prime rate because of the unusually wide spread between the interest rates banks pay on deposits and other borrowed money and the rates they have been collecting on loans. The lower rate was a message to local businesses, he said, that the bank is eager to lend.
Bankers in New York, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, said they had discussed the possibility of a lower prime rate in recent days. But they have not lowered the rate because there has been no signal from the Fed that it wants to reduce short-term interest rates.
 
Rates Could Go Up
 In fact, one banker said short-term rates could move up, not down, and added that the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned two months ago about the possibility of higher interest rates.
Still, banks have cut some other interest rates over the last year. In the credit card business, where competition for customers has grown sharper, the average rate on cards issued by large banks has fallen to 17.22 percent from 18.07 percent a year ago, said Robert McKinley, president of RAM Research, a Frederick, Md., company that compiles lists of credit card interest rates.
Although weak demand is usually a reason to lower prices for most businesses, bankers do not expect that demand for business loans would be increased much by a slightly lower interest rate. Some pointed to the experience of the Chemical Bank, the nation's third-largest bank, which cut its prime rate in April 1992 to 6 1/4 percent while other banks stayed at 6 1/2 percent. After three months, Chemical returned to 6 1/2 percent and said the lower rate had not attracted much new business.
"The level of interest rates does not matter as much to businesses as the reason for the borrowing," said Irwin Kellner, senior vice president at Chemical Bank.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rally Erases Bonds' Early Losses

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Where do we go from here? That was the question of the day in the bond market yesterday morning.
Following a sharp selloff on Tuesday that was sparked by an higher-than-expected inflation report, prices slumped sharply for the second day and yields jumped as trading opened in New York. 
 But a furious afternoon surge, which wiped out most of the losses on the day, turned out to be a pretty strong reply: Don't declare the rally over yet.
The price of the 30-year bond, which was down as much as 112/32 points in early trading, finished down just 1/32 . And the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, ended the day unchanged at 5.97 percent, after jumping as high as 6.07 percent.
The recovery was even stronger among Treasury notes. The price of the 10-year note was up 8/32 on the day as the yield fell to 5.36 percent, from 5.39 percent. During the day, the price of the note had been down 23/32 , with the yield up to 5.48 percent.
 
Two-Year Note Up
 Short-term notes also performed well, as some investors bought them because they would be less volatile and risky if long-term interest rates did begin to climb. The price of the two-year note was up 3/32 as the yield dropped to 3.84 percent, from 3.89 percent.
What became clear yesterday was that several of the forces that helped drive the recent rally were still in place, including investor demand for higher-yielding securities and the postive -- for bond traders -- economic fundamentals. And this means that there is still a lot of support for prices and yields around the 6 percent level on the 30-year bond, the 5.45 percent level on the 10-year note and the 3.85 percent level for the two-year note.
Even if the market settles into a trading range for a while, the bias is still toward lower interest rates and the risk of an upward spike is, for now, very low. But this means the market could also be extremely volatile, making sharp swings as it did in one day yesterday or over several days, as as it did last Thursday, when it sold off, and Friday when prices rebounded.
 
A 'Two-Way' Market
 "We are now in a two-way trading type of market," said William Pike, who runs the primary dealer operation at Chemical Securities. "It is not a one-way market anymore. But there is no evidence for me to conclude that the bull market is over."
One of the forces supporting prices is the continued demand by many investors for higher yields, which is prompting many of them to buy longer-term maturities.
That demand was clearly evident yesterday as portfolio managers and other institutional investors snapped up a record $5.5 billion of Italian global issues, with $3.5 billion of that amount in 30-year bonds and the rest in 10-year notes.
"The flows are still favorable," said Glen E. Murphy, chief investment officer at Travelers Asset Management International in Hartford, of the cash coming into the market looking for higher yield. "People are still wanting to buy bonds."
The successful sale of the Italian bonds, which will be formally completed today, also lifted a worry among traders about its reception and the impact of such a huge supply of new securities, and contributed to the rally in the afternoon, Mr. Pike said.
 
Little Risk Seen
 Another support for prices is that slow economic growth and moderate inflation, which is the picture still being drawn by current economic data, means that securities do not have to move far below their recent peaks in price and lows in yields before they become attractive again.
Mr. Murphy said he did not think 10-year notes were a good value at 5.22 percent, the 25-year low reached last week, but they were quite attractive at a yield around 5.50 percent. Yesterday, with the yield driving to 5.47 percent, he was taking some of the cash he had accumulated in the last several months and buying 10-year notes.
"I see little risk in the market at 5.5 percent," he said.
Mr. Pike said he saw the same kind of buying support in the market yesterday. "There was retail buying on weakness," he said, referring to the buying by portfolio managers and other money managers. "And if we were in a market with a less favorable climate there would not be that kind of buying."
 
A Successful Debut For Italian Bonds
 Italy made its first foray ever into the long end of the global bond market, with its $5.5 billion issue of 30-year bonds and 10-year notes easily outdistancing the previous high of $3 billion. The bonds, which will be formally priced today, are also the first Italian Government bonds to be sold in the United States.
Alberto Giovannini, the head of the council of experts at the Italian Treasury, said the demand for the issue was very strong. He said the Italian Government chose to issue 30-year bonds now because there was a strong demand for long-dated issues and because long-term interest rates in the United States were so low.
He said it was expected that with the final sale, the yield on the 30-year bonds would be 80 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the 7.125 percent, 30-year bond due in February 2023. The yield was at 6.13 percent yesterday. The 10-year notes will yield 62 basis points over the current 10-year note.

HEADLINE: Concert Hall Aims for Hartford's Revival

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 15

 BODY:
In yet another effort to make over Hartford into a regional center for night life and entertainment, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. unveiled plans today for a 30,000-seat indoor-outdoor concert amphitheater to be built on the edge of the city's impoverished North End.
Mr. Weicker said that, barring snags, ground would be broken this fall for the $20 million project, a joint venture between the state and two private developers. It is to be finished, he said, in time for next summer's pop and rock concert tours, many of which have skipped Connecticut for lack of a place to perform. 
 "The turning of shovels is imminent," the Governor said. "This is not something that is a year out."
The developers -- the Nederlander Organization of Chicago and Metropolitan Entertainment Inc., a New York-area concert promoter -- said the design would be the first of its type in the world, with 7,500 seats that could be fully enclosed for winter use, and 22,500 more on a grassy bank for summer shows. The developers said they expected to book 80 concerts a year, drawing 400,000 to 500,000 people into the city, and that the theater would employ about 600 local teen-agers under an arrangement that ties a theater job to good grades in school.
The Connecticut Center for the Performing Arts, as the theater complex is to be known, is the latest in a series of aggressive steps by the state to advance the idea of Connecticut's economically troubled capital city as a destination for fun.
This summer, Connecticut rescued the financially floundering Hartford Whalers hockey team in a deal that, among other things, gave the state control of parking and the skyboxes at the Whalers' arena, the Hartford Civic Center. Next week, a special legislative session will consider the cost and benefits of wooing the New England Patriots football team south from Massachusetts to a 60,000-seat stadium that the Governor wants to build in Hartford.
Mr. Weicker said today that the goal is to achieve a critical mass of attractions that increases the allure of Hartford, large parts of which empty at 5 P.M. as office workers head home to the suburbs.
"With the Civic Center and the Whalers, and now the Center for the Performing Arts, we're achieving that critical mass," he said.
Hartford's Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry, said the prospect of summer jobs for teen-agers -- who, she declared, might otherwise be lured into gangs -- was one of the plan's most important elements. Under the arrangement, the theater will guarantee each of Hartford's three public high schools a specific number of part-time summer jobs. Competition for those jobs will be based in part on grade-point average -- with 3.0 or better as cutoff for applicants.
"The job component of this project is extraordinarily important," she said. "It is another choice for those who want access out of these gangs."
State economic development officials said that they expected few significant delays.
Under a program created last year by the Legislature, bonds can be sold for such projects, with the principal and interest payments based on taxes generated by the project -- including, in the case of the theater, a 10 percent admissions tax. No bond issue has yet been floated for this project, and a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Economic Development, Joseph Cohen, said that the final mixture of financing sources -- bonds, loans from the state and grants -- had not been worked out.
Jim Koplik, president of Metropolitan Entertainment, said he did not think the new arena would directly compete with the Civic Center because the older 15,000-seat auditorium was not drawing many shows anyway, especially in the summer when many performers and fans prefer outdoor performances. In the winter, he said, the new theater with its enclosed 7,500-seat space could provide a smaller house than the Civic Center for performers who cannot fill big halls.
Officials at Nederlander, which has built theater complexes around the country, said that a 20-foot wall behind the outdoor seats would shield nearby neighborhoods from concert noise, and that the wall would provide insulation, as well, from Interstate 91 nearby.
A huge landfill just off I-91 that in high summer sends a foul aroma drifting across much of the area will also not be a problem, according to the developers. "The smell, thank goodness, doesn't head in our direction," Mr. Koplik said.

HEADLINE: Fed Fears a Market Bubble If It Lowers Interest Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Seeking to forestall pressures to cut interest rates to lift the still-sluggish economy, several Federal Reserve officials have put forward a new -- and surprising -- reason why it would be unwise to lower rates: It could encourage a speculative bubble in stocks and bonds.
In interviews this week, two central bank officials voiced fears that lower rates could cause runaway investment that would push financial markets to unjustifiable levels, setting the stage for an inevitable plunge. 
 David W. Mullins Jr., the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, suggested that the central bank needed to help prevent a replay of Japan's speculative bubble and subsequent slump. In the late 1980's, low interest rates there fueled a huge rise in stock and real estate prices. When that bubble burst, Japan slid into its current deep slump.
Mr. Mullins said, "That's one reason to be wary of being more accommodative," that is to say, of cutting rates further.
Mr. Mullins, who is widely viewed as the Fed's most influential member after its chairman, Alan Greenspan, was quick to add that America's near-record stock and bond prices did not now appear to be inflated. In his view, stock and bond levels are consistent with the recent decline in inflation and the prospect of moderate economic growth.
Lower inflation pushes up the bond market by making a fixed-income investment more valuable, and it also helps drive up stock prices for several reasons: for instance, it increases the chances of higher corporate profits and it encourages bank depositors to shift their money into the stock market.
Nonetheless, Mr. Mullins said, "Some people are concerned about the possibility that excess liquidity will create imbalance, such as a bubble in asset prices."
The concern at the Fed seems to be that strong growth in some measures of the money supply, fueled in part by the lowest interest rates in two decades, could create speculative frenzy.
Early last year, many economists urged the Fed to cut rates to spur the economy. Long-term interest rates have, indeed, come down sharply since then, but the Federal Reserve has not adjusted short-term rates since Sept. 4, 1992, making it one of the longest periods that the Fed has left rates unchanged. The pressures to cut rates largely abated last winter when economic growth picked up.
But with growth at a meager 1.3 percent in the first half and inflation slowing in recent months, a growing number of economists, including Paul Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, are again urging the Federal Reserve to cut its short-term rates.
Although Administration officials would probably like the Fed to lower rates, they have not put pressure on the central bank.
 
Fed Seems Unfazed
 Although long-term rates shot up this week on Tuesday's report that consumer prices rose by three-tenths of 1 percent last month -- slightly more than expected -- Federal Reserve officials hardly seemed fazed.
"It's statistically in line with recent experience," Mr. Lindsey said. "It isn't bad, but it could be better."
The central bankers disputed the President's economic advisers, who warned this week against raising rates soon in light of the recent slowdown in growth and inflation.
Speaking about the current short-term interest rates of 3 percent, Mr. Lindsey said, "I'd call them accommodative." In his view, rates are low enough to support steady growth.
Echoing Mr. Greenspan's Congressional testimony in July, Mr. Mullins and Mr. Lindsey seemed to lay the groundwork for a rate increase, not tomorrow or the next week, but in coming months.
 
In the Bully Pulpit
 When price increases suddenly picked up last winter, Mr. Lindsey used his bully pulpit to warn that the Fed would not let inflationary expectations get out of hand. This week, however, Mr. Lindsey appeared in no rush to raise rates because inflation has simmered down since last winter and growth remains lackluster.
The tenor of Mr. Mullins's remarks was that an interest rate increase was inevitable, but probably not soon. He cautioned that real short-term interest rates -- the interest rate minus the inflation rate -- have been at zero or negative in recent months.
At such times in the past, "the results haven't been pleasant at all," he said. "That happened in the 1970's, and was followed by a period of rapid inflation."
In an interview this week, Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said there was no need to consider raising rates. Speaking about real interest rates, he said, "I think you can stay pretty near zero for a long period of time. Zero short-term rates are not historically aberrant."
 
Surprise at Fed Case
 Other economists expressed surprise at the case the Fed officials were making for higher rates. David M. Jones, chief economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said he was surprised that Fed officials were so concerned that low rates could produce a speculative boom. He said low rates were helping to achieve one of the Fed's main goals: strengthening bank and corporate balance sheets.
Last May, the Federal Reserve's main policy-making committee effectively voted to raise rates if inflation did not simmer down. But with inflation down appreciably over the last six months, some economists predict that at its meeting next Tuesday, the committee will adopt a neutral stance. Some economists argue that it will maintain a bias toward higher rates mainly to show it will remain tough on inflation.
Mr. Mullin said he had finally solved a mystery that has engrossed the Fed: Why did inflation suddenly shoot up at a rate of more than 4 percent last winter?
The final clue, he said, came last month when the Commerce Department revised its 1992 growth estimate to 2.6 percent, not 2.1 percent as previously estimated, and by a robust 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
"What happened last winter," Mr. Mullin said, "was that businesses that had been very reluctant to try to increase prices for several years felt the economy might be taking off in the second half of last year." This encouraged them to try to raise prices.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance on Triple-Witching's Spell

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The stock market sank under steep losses early in the session yesterday and then recovered on program buying associated with tomorrow's "triple witching" expiration of options and futures contracts.
Triple-witching days -- the simultaneous expiration of stock options, stock index futures and stock index options -- normally occur on the third Friday of each month. Yesterday, however, traders planning to be absent for the Jewish Rosh ha-Shanah holiday today apparently began limiting their exposure in advance, bringing volatility to the day's trading. 
 The market started the day by plunging 29 points, as long-term interest rates rose sharply on inflation concerns, with the 30-year bond yield as high as 6.07 percent. But around noon, the computerized buying of stocks began to erase the losses, driving the Dow Jones industrials sharply higher to close up 17.89 points, at 3,633.65. Yields on the 30-year bond eventually settled down as well, at 5.97 percent, unchanged.
 
Switch to Cash Position
 Phil H. Smyth, an analyst for Birinyi Associates, said: "Generally, as you approach the expiration day, one thing that you get is index funds, which may have previously purchased futures and options, switching over to a cash position. They do that either by waiting until the last day and letting the options expire, or they close out their futures position while at the same time running a buy program to establish the position in an underlying stock."
Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at the Kemper Securities Group in Chicago, said he thought the economic news that buffeted the bond market had little to do with the stock market's swift changes.
"Of late, stocks and bonds, even though they still are maintaining a close relationship, are not as closely related as they used to be," he said, adding that the market's moves were partly "a bond-market upturn, but that's not the whole reason."
Mr. Chalasani added: "If you look at the intensity of the buying that took place later in the day, after a persistent selloff in the morning, and if you realize that the propensity of buying accelerated in the afternoon, which is indicative of program-related buying, you see that it is related to triple-witching."
 
Heavy Trading Volume
 Volume was heavy yesterday at 298.3 million shares, up from 258.7 million on Tuesday.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 461.60, up 1.70. The American Stock Exchange composite index ended at 453.74, up 0.98, and the Nasdaq composite index rose to 739.55, up 6.91.
Among the strongest sectors of the market were the technology stocks. Intel was up 1 5/8, to 64 7/8; Motorola was up 2 5/8, to 93; Lotus was up 2 1/2, to 38 1/2; Microsoft was up 1 1/4, to 76 1/2; Applied Materials was up 3 1/4, to 71 5/8, and Micron Technology was up 1 5/8, to 58 3/8.
The auto makers also did relatively well, with Chrysler up 7/8, to 45 1/2; Ford Motor up 1, to 54 3/4, and General Motors up 1 1/2, to 47 1/4.
A big loser was the Walt Disney Company, which suffered when an analyst cut his earnings estimates. The stock fell 1 1/2, to 39 1/8.
Federal Express gained sharply to close at 58 3/4, up 3 3/8, after it said its first-quarter earnings had more than tripled, to a point beyond what analysts had expected.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark But Gains a Little on the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday to its lowest point in about three months, but it rose slightly against the Japanese yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar tumbled to 1.5945 marks, from 1.6090 marks on Tuesday. It edged up to 106 yen from 105.98 yen. 
 Meanwhile, prices for gold rose for the second consecutive day as it tried to recover from steep losses on Friday and Monday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery gained $2.70 to close at $347.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $347.40 an ounce, up $2.60.
 
 
Brazilian Debt
 Traders said the mark rose against most currencies partly because of a restructuring of Brazilian debt in Europe. The deal involved Brazil's purchase of long-term, mark-denominated bonds to serve as collateral for the repayment of the debt, traders said. The purchase stimulated demand for the mark.
In addition, European central banks were continuing to replenish mark reserves they had used up to defend their currencies during July's exchange-rate turmoil, traders said.
"All of the dollar-selling activity we saw today was the result of variables not associated with the dollar" in terms of its economic fundamentals, Belal Khan, senior foreign exchange dealer at the Bank of Tokyo Ltd., said in New York.
 
 
Trade Surplus
 The dollar rose against the yen a day before the Japanese Government is expected to announce a package of measures to stimulate its economy. The package is expected to address Japan's growing trade surplus with the United States, which has pushed the yen higher this year since importers need to buy more yen to pay for their purchases.
Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, predicted the dollar would get a boost from the announcement. However, she said, "on second thought, people will have a lot of questions" on whether the package will be carried out and how much effect it would have on the trade deficit.
Among other currencies, the British pound rose to $1.5495 in New York, from $1.5460 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Reynolds Cutbacks May Signal Wide Job Loss in Tobacco

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's announcement that it would cut 1,000 workers is just the beginning of job cuts for an industry where price wars have eroded profits and new legislation threatens to narrow earnings further, analysts said yesterday.
"This was expected, and I definitely think there will be more cuts," said Howard Penney, an analyst for Morgan Stanley. "As the price structure of domestic tobacco has changed, companies need to get their cost structure commensurate as soon as possible." 
 In a letter distributed Tuesday at the company's headquarters in Winston-Salem, N.C., James W. Johnston, chairman and chief executive of Reynolds, a unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, said that as many as 1,000 workers, about 9 percent of the work force, would be dismissed.
 
Message to Employees
 "I am well aware that the single most important question in many of your minds right now is whether you will lose your job," he wrote. "Regrettably, the answer is that some of you will."
The industry's drastic price reductions began in April, when the Philip Morris Companies slashed Marlboro prices by 40 percent and other companies followed. After that, R. J. Reynolds, the nation's second-largest tobacco company behind Morris, saw its second-quarter earnings fall 37 percent. Mr. Johnston said that expectations for the third and fourth quarters were worse and that he expected the company to earn $900 million less for the entire year than it did in 1992.
It is uncertain, however, exactly how many employees will be affected as the company tries to trim costs. "Things are still shaking out," Maura Payne Ellis, a company spokeswoman, said yesterday, adding that the final number would depend upon the extent to which the various political and economic changes influence sales.
Primary among those concerns is how much the Federal excise tax on cigarettes, now at 24 cents a pack, is increased under the financing provisions of the Clinton Administration's health care program. As Mr. Johnston told his employees, "If a tax increase reduces cigarette sales, jobs will be lost throughout the tobacco industry."
 
Other Cost-Cutting Plans
 He stressed, however, that the company was trying to cut costs in other ways. "Most of our cost reductions will come from reducing nonpersonnel costs associated with developing, manufacturing, marketing and selling our products," he wrote.
RJR Nabisco stock was unchanged yesterday, closing at $4.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Penney said he expected all American tobacco companies, including Philip Morris, would be forced to dismiss employees.
"This is a process that takes time; it doesn't happen overnight," he said. "Philip Morris hasn't announced any cuts yet, but they probably will. They just need some time to assess their position, to see where they're going. But I'm sure they will do it as soon as it's possible."

HEADLINE: Pickup in the Economy Is Seen in Two Reports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Fresh reports suggested today that the economy would pick up a bit during the second half of the year. One showed businesses with lean inventories, and another indicated that consumers were paying their debts more easily.
Inventories of goods fell five-tenths of a percent in July to a seasonally adjusted $860.3 billion, the Commerce Department said. The decline was the first since September and the steepest since March 1991. Inventories were unchanged in June. 
 Also, the American Bankers Association said the percentage of Americans behind on their consumer loan payments fell during the second quarter to the lowest level in nine years.
 
Better Second Half Seen
 "Both numbers bode for slightly stronger economic performance in the second half of the year than we had in the first half," said David Jones, economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a government-securities dealer in New York. The loan delinquency rate decline "should support slightly higher consumer spending," he said.
Difficulty by businesses in reducing an inventory buildup slowed economic growth in the April-June quarter, but stocks now are at a level that should not impede future growth, he said.
Much of the July inventory decline was the result of a 4.9 percent fall in auto dealers' stocks, the largest decline in nearly seven years.
However, business sales were weak in July. They fell 1.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $583.6 billion. It was the biggest drop since December 1991.
At the retail level, inventories fell 1.3 percent. They were flat at factories and down two-tenths of a percent at wholesalers.
July sales were weakest at factories, where they fell 2.6 percent. They edged down a tenth of a percent at wholesalers and rose three-tenths of a percent at retailers. In an advance report on Tuesday, the department said retail sales rose two-tenths of a percent in August.
 
Delinquencies Drop
 The bankers association said a seasonally adjusted 2.06 percent of consumer loans were 30 days or more past due at the end of June, down from 2.31 percent at the end of the first quarter and 2.6 percent a year earlier.
The latest rate, a composite of eight types of installment loans, was the lowest since 2.02 percent at the end of June 1984.
Economists said slow-but-steady improvement in the job market, low inflation and extensive mortgage refinancing had improved consumers' ability to repay their loans.
"Consumers are halfway home in terms of redressing their balance sheet," said an economist, Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "They are midway between what could be considered a healthy debt level and the dire situation they had gotten into by the late 1980's."
The report also showed that the delinquency rate for bank credit cards, which are not included in the composite rate, dropped to 2.63 percent at the end of June from 2.74 percent at the end of March.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Judging Lorenzo, air regulators are where they didn't want to be.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS Frank Lorenzo, devil to organized labor and hero to the budget traveler, fit to run an airline? The legal battle to certify ATX, Mr. Lorenzo's carrier modeled on the successful Southwest Airlines, was expected to be fought over the issue of whether previous bankruptcies and a blemished aircraft maintenance record should keep the Houston entrepreneur's planes on the ground.
But the drama abruptly veered toward farce last week, when a Federal administrative law judge decided he did not like the tactics or manners of Mr. Lorenzo and his lawyers and recommended that the former boss of Continental and Eastern airlines be sent packing. Now the onus rests firmly on the Department of Transportation, which must decide whether Congress really, truly meant to deregulate the market for air transportation. 
 In March, ATX applied for permission to start an airline based in Baltimore. The idea was (and is) to offer low-priced service on short, densely trafficked routes where the established carriers now charge premium fares.
New airline applications are routinely approved, provided the owner has a bit of cash in the bank and the wherewithal to keep the wings bolted on. Just last month, the Government certified Renown Aviation to start flights to the Bahamas in spite of the fact that its parent company owed the Internal Revenue Service $1.1 million and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation more than $1.7 million.
Oh yes, there were also questions of safety: The new owner once had an airline called TPI International that ran afoul of Federal aircraft maintenance rules on numerous occasions.
But Renown's chief executive had never offended the airline pilots', mechanics' and baggage handlers' unions, which persuaded some 120 members of Congress to declare their opposition to the Lorenzo certification.
The Transportation Department ordered ATX to supply reams of documents regarding the hundreds of lawsuits filed against Lorenzo-related airlines over the last decade. And it took the unusual step of appointing an administrative law judge to hold hearings, giving the unions an opportunity to attack Mr. Lorenzo's fitness.
The idea apparently was to insulate the department from criticism when it eventually followed precedent and gave the green light to ATX. But the judge, Robert L. Barton Jr., apparently had his own ideas.
He sparred for two months with ATX's lawyers over who was responsible for the failure to produce every document requested by the Government. Many were the property of Mr. Lorenzo's adversaries, who were understandably unenthusiastic about aiding his paper chase. Finally on July 30, the department ordered Judge Barton to get on with it, arguing that a substantial portion of the missing material "appears to be of peripheral relevance to the proceeding."
The department's order was buttressed by the Public Counsel, the Government's official representative at the hearings. "The burden of providing evidence now shifts to the other parties," wrote the department's assistant general counsel for aviation enforcement.
In an unexpected turn of events, however, Judge Barton pulled the plug. Without hearing the unions' case to the contrary, he ruled that ATX was indeed financially fit and managerially competent to run an airline. But the judge, who was not available for comment, decided that ATX had ailed to demonstrate a "proper compliance disposition."
For one thing, the judge wrote, ATX's lawyers had filed "unsupported, frivolous and vexatious pleadings" during the long summer of his discontent. For another, Mr. Lorenzo was not a credible witness, a finding based in part on the judge's "careful observation of the demeanor (including pauses, facial gestures and body language) of the witnesses."
All this leaves the department precisely where it did not want to be. The Government could follow the judge's recommendation, an unlikely course in light of its counsel's own pleading. It could certify ATX -- almost as unlikely a choice, since the unions never got their day in court. The betting now is that the department will order the judge to reopen the hearings and complete the record, then decide that ATX is at least as fit as Renown to put planes in the air.
There is the temptation to accent the positive, namely the entertainment value of watching the department hoisted with its own petard. But many economists wonder why, 15 years after the airline market was deregulated, this show is taking place at all. Safety, everyone's premier concern, is primarily the responsibility of the Federal Aviation Administration. And outright abuse of consumers -- stranding passengers at the gate -- has become an extremely rare event in spite of the wrenching dislocations in the airline business.
"The intent of deregulation was to encourage new entry," concludes John Robson, a fellow at the Heritage Foundation who was the airlines' chief regulator in the Ford Administration. "That's what keeps the game honest."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Islanders Sign Turgeon To a 4-Year Contract

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 15

 BODY:
By making Pierre Turgeon one of hockey's 10 highest-paid players today, Don Maloney and the Islanders hope they sent a signal across Long Island and through the National Hockey League, a message that carries beyond the payroll.
In agreeing to pay Turgeon an average of $2.75 million per season on a four-year contract, the Islanders hope they have begun to shed a negative reputation that surrounded the franchise during its Great Recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. 
 "Every time you turned around the Islanders were seen as a third-rate organization," Maloney said today at a luncheon in the Long Island Marriott hotel. "Nobody gave a darn. That was the image the franchise seemed to take on."
Without conceding the truth of the perception, Maloney did admit: "Maybe we did sit back, five, six or seven years ago, and put our feet up and close our eyes as the world passed us by."
By signing Turgeon to the largest contract in team history, Maloney said: "We made a point. We will stay up with the big boys. We can play the game."
 
It's All in the Marketing
 The deal includes the right to market Turgeon's image on commercial products such as shirts, Maloney said, although Turgeon will retain any product-marketing rights, such as those for trading cards, that are negotiated by the Players Association in the new collective bargaining agreement with the team owners.
Similar deals involving marketing rights have been made in recent months between the Pittsburgh Penguins and Mario Lemieux and by the Ottawa Senators with Alexandre Daigle. In addition, the Islanders are taking offers from three local public relations firms and will choose one to coach Turgeon on public speaking and image.
The winner of the Lady Byng Trophy for skillful and gentlemanly play, Turgeon is a polite but shy 24-year-old from French Canada who still struggles with English as a second language. That will change, Maloney said, as Turgeon buys a home on Long Island, maintains year-round residence and represents the team at local events.
 
A Bargain in the Making?
 "We don't expect him to become Dale Carnegie or Anthony Robbins in the next month," said Maloney, who compared Turgeon to Jean Beliveau because he has "a quiet dignity about him." As for Turgeon's pay scale, Maloney predicted, "We're hoping that three years from now it'll be a real bargain."
Turgeon joined the team in October 1991 in a multiplayer deal that sent Pat LaFontaine to Buffalo. LaFontaine had refused to play for the team because of a salary dispute that epitomized the image of the team in that era. Last season, his sixth in the N.H.L., Turgeon had a career-high 132 points on 58 goals and 74 assists. He is a center with advanced puck-handling skills, a deceptive shot and above-average skating ability. Moreover, Turgeon makes those around him better, creating scoring opportunities for linemates. His teammates call him Sneaky Pete.
Turgeon, as is his style, was cordial and smiling at today's luncheon, accompanied by his wife, Elizabeth, and their twin daughters, Alexandra and Elizabeth. "There's pressure there," Turgeon said. "The attention is there. I get paid well. The money's there. My main thing is to go on the ice and play hockey."
 
A Paycheck Passage
 Just where Turgeon's salary ranks among other stars is a little difficult to determine at this point. Lemieux leads all players at $5 million per year, with Eric Lindros second at $3.556 million and Wayne Gretzky third at $3 million. Turgeon's average salary of $2.75 million would rank him fourth in the N.H.L. this season, if he is indeed paid that figure this season. Sometimes, however, salaries on multiyear contracts are distributed in such a way that they will grow over the length of the contract.
In addition, several star players are negotiating contracts that should put them in a higher bracket. Among them are Ray Bourque of Boston, Chris Chelios of Chicago and Doug Gilmour of Toronto. Patrick Roy of Montreal this week signed a new contract for $16 million over four seasons. On average, that puts him ahead of Turgeon, $4 million to $2.75 million, but Roy will make only $2.70 million of it this season.
Players' salaries have increased dramatically over the past few years in part because union members voted in 1990 to share pay information. Once the going rate for top talent became widely known, other star players had a plateau from which to bargain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pierre Turgeon signed an $11 million dollar deal with the Islanders, the largest contract in the team's history. (Richard Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Investigators' Findings in Holtzman Loan Inquiry

 BODY:

 Following is the concluding passage of a New York City Department of Investigation report summarizing the findings of an inquiry into a campaign loan to the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman:
 
 
 
Subject to Ethics Rules
 Fleet Bank's $450,000 loan to the Holtzman Senate Campaign Committee is not excepted from the Charter's ethics proscriptions because it was not made to Holtzman and was, by the bank's definition, an "undesirable" loan, which could be made only by certain designated bank officers for a "justifiable business reason." 
 The Charter permits public officials to receive loans from banks doing business with the city only if the loan was obtained on terms and conditions available to the public. Although Holtzman guaranteed the $450,000 loan to her campaign committee, she was not the recipient of the loan. For this reason alone, the loan is not one excluded from the reach of the Charter's ethics proscriptions.
In addition, Fleet Bank's Commercial Credit Policy Manual characterizes campaign loans as "undesirable." Such loans are generally not available to candidates for public office and, by definition, are not available to members of the general public.
The evidence, in particular the memorandum Fleet Bank Loan Officer Nancy O'Connor prepared when reviewing the loan application, indicates that the loan was made to generate goodwill for Fleet Financial Group ("FFG") in continuation of FFG executive James Murphy's campaign to obtain business from the Comptroller's Office through contacts with senior-level officials in the Comptroller's Office and financial assistance to Holtzman's political campaigns. According to O'Connor's memorandum, the loan was not made because it was by itself a sound business transaction but, rather, because it would "support the bank's relationship with [Holtzman]."
 
Entering a Relationship
 In guaranteeing the $450,000 loan from Fleet Bank to her Senate campaign committee, Holtzman entered into a financial relationship with a subsidiary of FFG, which was doing and actively seeking business with the Comptroller's Office.
In June 1990, the Comptroller's Office entered into an agreement with the Norstar Mortgage Company, a division of Fleet Real Estate Funding Corporation, in connection with "Project Home," a $100 million program to help low- and moderate-income families obtain home mortgages. Holtzman attended a press conference at City Hall in August 1990 announcing the initiation of the program.
In September 1990, the Comptroller's Office issued a press release announced that Norstar Bank, a subsidiary of FFG, was participating in a $50 million program to provide low-interest loans to small business.
From 1990 through 1992, executives from FFG and Fleet Securities met and corresponded with senior officials of the Comptroller's Office in an effort to obtain a role in managing city pension funds and city municipal bond offerings. These officials included, in addition to Holtzman: Edward O'Malley, deputy comptroller and chief of staff; Michael Nairne, the Comptroller's delegate to the city's four pension boards on which the Comptroller sits; Darcy Bradbury, deputy comptroller for Finance; William Paolino, bureau chief for Asset Management; John Gilliam, deputy comptroller for Asset Management, and Thomas Bettridge, director of Targeted Investments.
For these reasons, FFG clearly had business dealings with the Comptroller's Office, and the Comptroller's Office necessarily, therefore, has taken actions affecting FFG, either in the administration of business FFG was already performing or in assessing whether to consider the company for new business.
 
Participated in Process
 Holtzman participated in the process leading to her office's recommendation and selection of Fleet Securities to be a co-manager.
Holtzman delegated the work of screening and evaluating candidates for senior and co-managers to Darcy Bradbury and her staff. However, she did not recuse herself from the selection process. The selections were made pursuant to her personal authority as Comptroller, and she, with Mayor Dinkins, personally announced the selections in a joint press release on March 17, 1993, which listed Fleet Securities as one of 23 co-managers. In addition, she participated in two aspects of the selection process: the evaluation of candidates for senior manager and the appointment of minority- and women-owned firms to co-manager positions. Finally, on April 1, 1993, she personally approved a "tombstone," which also listed Fleet Securities as a co-manager, that provided public notice of the initial bond offering.
 
Suggestion of Knowledge
 The evidence strongly suggests that Holtzman knew that FFG, Fleet Securities, or other FFG subsidiaries were doing and seeking business with the Comptroller's Office.
The following facts strongly suggest that Holtzman knew that FFG, Fleet Securities, and other FFG subsidiaries were doing or seeking business with her Office. First and most strikingly, Holtzman attended a meeting in June 1992 at the Vista Hotel with executives of Fleet Securities, who pitched the firm's qualifications for 45 minutes to an hour and specifically asked that the firm be considered for co-manager status.
Second, senior aides on her staff and campaign committee, including Deputy Comptroller Edward O'Malley, her closest political aide and the director of two of her campaigns for Comptroller and the Senate, and Campaign Finance Director Sheila Levin, and a senior adviser, Joseph McDonald, were aware as of January 1993 that Fleet Securities had applied for co-manager status. Ostensibly, to avoid an appearance of impropriety, they therefore refused to discuss repayment of the Fleet Bank loan. Each knew that Holtzman was distressed that the bank was pressing for repayment. Yet Holtzman contended that they did not inform her that they had put the bank off or that she faced a conflict of interest based on Fleet Securities' application to be a co-manager. Given the importance of both issues to Holtzman, and the close professional relationship of O'Malley, Levin and McDonald to her, it is unlikely, in DOI's opinion, that she was not informed that Fleet Securities was seeking to be selected as a co-manager.
Third, Fleet Securities was identified as one of the firms selected for co-manager in documents it would be expected she would review, including the press release announcing the selection of senior managers and co-managers, and the "tombstone" announcing the initial bond offering.
Fourth, two FFG subsidiaries participated in loan programs administered by the Comptroller's Office and executives of FFG and its subsidiaries had numerous contacts with senior officials of the Comptroller's Office in an effort to get business.
Holtzman was grossly negligent in failing to ascertain whether FFG, or any company related to FFG, was doing or seeking business with her office before her campaign committee sought the $450,000 loan from Fleet Bank and before she participated in the process in which Fleet Securities was selected as a co-manager.
Under the Charter, Holtzman had an affirmative obligation to learn whether FFG, Fleet Securities or other FFG subsidiaries had business dealings with her office before and after she guaranteed the $450,000 loan from Fleet Bank to her campaign committee.
Holtzman testified that she was unaware that Fleet Bank or any company related to it had business dealings with her office. While her assertions of ignorance are contradicted by substantial evidence, the record is devoid of evidence indicating that she took affirmative steps to ascertain whether Fleet Bank or any company related to it had business dealings with her office before authorizing her campaign committee to seek the loan and before she personally guaranteed the loan. Given that Fleet Bank was a major financial institution doing business in New York (which Holtzman knew since it was her bank), reasonable care should have led her to inquire whether the bank had done or was seeking business with her office in order to avoid a conflict of interest.
After the loan was obtained, the potential for a conflict of interest to arise continued. Having guaranteed the loan and assumed a contractual financial obligation to the bank of approximately $200,000, Holtzman could not involve herself in any matters in which the bank had a direct or indirect interest. Nevertheless, while there is evidence that Holtzman knew that Fleet Securities was a candidate for co-manager, the record is devoid of evidence that she took any affirmative action to learn whether the bank, or any company-related to the bank had business dealings with her office.
Holtzman's failure to inquire whether Fleet Bank or companies related to it were doing or seeking business with her office constitutes, in this department's opinion, gross negligence.
