HEADLINE: Perot Leads Attack on Trade Agreement

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton mobilized three former Presidents to answer criticisms of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the pact's opponents resumed their attacks, with Ross Perot leading the charge.
On two television talk shows, Mr. Perot warned that the agreement would throw up to five million Americans out of work, destroy the American middle class and wreck the Federal Government's tax base. 
 If approved by Congress, the agreement would gradually eliminate trade and investment barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States. Advocates contend this will create American jobs through rising exports to Mexico, but opponents like Mr. Perot maintain that jobs will be lost as American companies move to Mexico.
The treaty has badly divided the Democrats and created considerable intraparty tension. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Democrat from Michigan, where auto workers are worried that their employers might move factories to Mexico, suggested today at a Senate Finance Committee hearing that Secretary of State Warren Christopher might be biased because Mr. Christopher's former law firm worked for the Mexican Government during the trade negotiations last year.
 
Conflict Is Denied
 Mr. Christopher denied that there was a conflict of interest. He said that as far as he knew the Washington office of the firm O'Melveny & Myers might have done work for the Mexican Government but that he had been in the firm's Los Angeles headquarters and had knownnothing about it.
Despite the Democratic split, a majority of the 20 Senators on the Finance Committee, the main Senate committee with jurisdiction over trade, appears to support the trade agreement. All 9 Republicans are likely to vote for it, and 2 of the 11 Democrats, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Max Baucus of Montana, expressed support today. But the agreement has a cloudy future in the House, where the Democratic leadership is divided on the pact.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the Finance Committee's chairman, said today that he had invited Mr. Perot to testify before the panel this fall on the agreement, but that no details had been worked out. United We Stand America, Mr. Perot's political organization, could not confirm tonight whether the invitation had been received.
Responding to alarms sent to the White House by free trade supporters in Congress, President Clinton flew today to a hastily arranged rally in New Orleans to support the agreement.
 
Clinton Sees Opportunity
 He appeared at the same Mississippi River wharf where President Bush attacked Mr. Clinton as waffling on his free trade positions last fall just before the general election. President Clinton said that supporting the trade agreement would provide "the opportunity for us to get off the defensive in our economic policies and go on offense."
Neither the President nor the members of Congress who appeared with him today were eager to address the questions raised by Mr. Perot. Mr. Clinton said it was up to reporters to hold Mr. Perot accountable for the statements he makes.
"Why do you guys keep asking that question?" the President snapped at one point when reporters asked whether he was losing the public relations battle to Mr. Perot. "It's not about me and him. It's about the American people and their future. I think the American people will win on this one."
 
Carter Challenged
 But former President Jimmy Carter made a clear allusion to Mr. Perot at a White House ceremony on Tuesday with President Clinton and former Presidents Gerald Ford and George Bush: "Unfortunately, in our country now we have a demagogue who has unlimited financial resources and who is extremely careless with the truth, who is preying on the fears and the uncertainties of the American public."
Mr. Perot responded on NBC's "Today" and in a taping of PBS's "Charlie Rose" for broadcast tonight by suggesting that Mr. Carter was ignorant of how Mexican employees of United States concerns lived. "I think if he ever goes to Mexico and sees how Mexican workers live in one-room shacks with dirt floors, no electricity and no plumbing that work in these big U.S. companies, he will be shocked," Mr. Perot told Mr. Rose.
Today, Robert A. Pastor, a fellow at the Carter Center in Atlanta, said Mr. Carter had helped build 100 homes in Tijuana three years ago. "Carter has traveled through Mexico and he has seen that Mexico has cardboard shacks but also has Monterrey, which is an industrializing city," Mr. Pastor said.
The acrimony and highly political accusations going back and forth have obscured the substance of the agreement, which has repeatedly been inaccurately characterized or distorted by all sides. Mr. Perot, for example, has clung to his predictions of catastrophic effects upon the American economy from the agreement.
On "Today" he said approval of the free trade pact would so undermine the United States economy that the country would be unable to handle the national debt. "You're going to destroy the middle class in this country, and that destroys the tax base, and that eliminates our chance to pay back the debt," he said.
 
No Reply From Perot
 When asked about estimates by business executives and economists that labor represents only 10 or 20 percent of production costs, Mr. Perot gave no direct reply. Instead, he contended that a more accurate impression of the role of wages in industrial location decisions could be inferred from the Mexican state of Yucatan's advertisements and other efforts to lure American businesses with low wages.
Yet dozens of economists have repeatedly pointed out that because Mexico's economy is only 4 percent of the size of the American economy, the overall effects of the free trade agreement on the United States will be very small.
While avoiding Mr. Perot's hyperbole, the White House has also made a few errors. The Administration released two weeks ago a lengthy rebuttal of Mr. Perot's new book, "Save Your Job, Save Our Country: Why NAFTA Must Be Stopped -- Now!" (Hyperion, $6.95), that quotes the book heavily but often inaccurately.
The rebuttal by the Office of the United States Trade Representative uses numerous quotes that appear differently in the book or not at all.
 
Errors Called Clerical
 "It's a clerical mistake, certainly not a deliberate effort," said Anne Luzzatto, the press secretary for the office. She said that the agency had incorrectly used quotation marks when paraphrasing the book's points.
But Patrick Choate, a writer in Washington who helped Mr. Perot with his book, said, "The White House has done exactly what they've accused us of doing and which we didn't do: playing fast and loose."
Twice the trade office's rebuttal alters quotes that might otherwise offend President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, the Administration's close ally in the fight for Congressional approval. Mr. Perot's book, for example, contends that, "Nafta gives Mexican investors, such as the 29 elite businessmen at the Salinas dinner, a distinct competitive advantage in the U.S.-Mexican trucking industry."
The White House repeats the quote but omits, without using ellipses, the reference to the dinner and never explains that the dinner was an occasion for Mr. Salinas to seek political donations of $25 million apiece from businessmen who stood to benefit from the free-trade pact.
In another instance, Mr. Perot's book says, "Multinational corporations have had their eye on Mexico for years -- not as a market of any real consequence, but as a locale for an unlimited supply of cheap, high-quality labor with weak unions and a sympathetic central government."
The White House rebuttal stops with a period after "high-quality labor," omitting "with weak unions and a sympathetic central government."
Ms. Luzzatto responded, "There was no conscious effort to omit comments critical of Salinas."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
The U.A.W. and Ford agreed on a new three-year labor contract covering 96,000 U.S. workers. The union fought off demands that workers pay more for health care. [Page D1.] Organized labor has emerged as a force behind both the drive to stop Nafta and the campaign to overhaul health care. [A21.]
Wang Laboratories is about to emerge from bankruptcy protection as a smaller computer maker that could surprise a few in the industry who had written it off for dead. [D1.] 
 American Cyanamid will spin off its Cytec chemical unit into a public company and take a $420 million after-tax third-quarter charge. Other companies have made similar moves. [D1.]
The DeBartolo shopping center empire will become a real estate investment trust with a $600 million public offering, joining other real estate owners in turning to Wall Street for money. [D1.]
Fleet Bank approved a loan to New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman to gain her favor in its effort to win more investment business from the city, according to investigators. [A1.]
General Motors will sell its Allison Gas Turbine division to managers and Clayton, Dubilier for about $300 million. [D4.]
R. J. Reynolds's plan to cut 1,000 workers is seen as the beginning of wider cuts in an industry hurt by price wars. [D4.]
Canandaigua Wine will buy Vintners International to create the nation's second-largest wine company. [D4.]
A new prototype Citibank branch office breaks the mold of traditional branches and emphasizes "personal banking." [D4.]
Universal Studios Florida will undergo a $3 billion expansion to allow it to compete head-on with Walt Disney World. [D5.]
Bristol-Myers Squibb's president, Charles A. Heimbold Jr., will succeed Richard L. Gelb as chief executive on Jan. 1. [D5.]
 
International
Environmentalists are split on the Nafta, exposing a rift over whether some groups have become too friendly with the White House. [A1.] Led by Ross Perot, opponents of the trade pact with Canada and Mexico pressed their attacks. [A20.]
French farmers demonstrated in opposition to a U.S.-E.C. agreement to reduce European agriculture subsidies. [A3.]
 
The Economy
Several Federal Reserve officials have put forward a new and surprising reason why it would be unwise to lower rates: It could encourage a speculative bubble in stocks and bonds. [D1.]
Businesses inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent in July and consumer loan delinquencies declined in the second quarter. [D2.]
Two small banks cut their prime rates to 5 3/4 percent from 6 percent, but the moves were not followed by larger banks. [D3.]
Florida's tourism industry is expected to decline 12 to 15 percent this year because of attacks on foreign visitors. [A14.]

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MACHINE FALTERS IN DETROIT

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A former State Supreme Court Justice handily outpolled two other candidates on Tuesday in a fight to become the city's first mayor in two decades, delivering a blow to the once-powerful political machine of the retiring Mayor, Coleman A. Young.
The former justice, Dennis Archer, won 53 percent, or 95,962 votes, according to complete but unofficial returns. Sharon McPhail, an assistant Wayne County prosecutor who will face him in a nonpartisan runoff on Nov. 2, gathered 36 percent, or 47,733 votes. No woman has ever been mayor of Detroit. 
 Arthur B. Blackwell 2d, chairman of the Wayne County Board of Commissioners, won only 12 percent of the vote. Mr. Blackwell had run as the candidate of Mayor Young, 75, who did not seek re-election because of ill health.
In an interview today, Mr. Archer, 51, said, "I am very pleased with the result, but I expect it will get closer."
That view was echoed by Ms. McPhail, 44, a native of Cambridge, Mass., who said: "He's not the winner. I am one of the two winners."
 
Promises and Papers
 The candidates have each issued a series of detailed position papers calling for fundamental change in many facets of city government. Both have emphasized aiding Detroit's crumbling neighborhoods and have vowed to preserve city workers' jobs and not to contract out services, as some civic groups advocate.
Mr. Archer, who gave up his seat on the State Supreme Court to explore a mayoral candidacy in 1990, has promised to make Detroit "a safe city with an open form of government," to improve delivery of city services and "to boost the employment prospects" of the city's 115,000 unemployed."
Now a partner at one of Detroit's most exclusive law firms, Mr. Archer, endured severe poverty while growing up in the rural Michigan town of Cassopolis. He put himself through college and law school in Detroit.
Ms. McPhail also comes from a disadvantaged background; as a teen-ager, she helped rear six younger brothers and sisters after her father died and her mother was hospitalized. She moved to Detroit in 1975 to be a lawyer at the Ford Motor Company.
 
From Ridicule to Runoff
 Ms. McPhail was a virtual unknown, but she steadily gained support, in part because of her effectiveness as a speaker. "This election will be between the million-dollar man and the million-dollar plan," she said on Tuesday, noting that Mr. Archer had raised $1.6 million to her $172,000.
Ms. McPhail has billed herself as "the only candidate with a law-enforcement background," and she has pledged to make crime-ridden Detroit safer, partly by putting 2,000 more police officers on the streets. She has also promoted a theme of luring business back to Detroit by abolishing the city's corporate income tax, lowering other taxes and offering entrepreneurs the chance to take over some of the city's many abandoned buildings.
Both candidates are black, as are 76 percent of Detroit's one million residents. Mr. Young, the first black Mayor in Detroit's history, frequently assailed Detroit's suburbs, which are overwhelmingly white and have more than three million people. Mr. Archer campaigned on a pledge to "foster a spirit of cooperation between city and suburb," and some suburbanites have been heavy donors to his campaign.
Ms. McPhail has also said there is a need for better relations between city and suburbs.
Mr. Young announced on filing day that he would not seek a fifth four-year term. Polls showed he had lost much of his political support. He said on Tuesday night that Ms. McPhail had asked for his support and that he was considering her request.

Crowded Fields in Minnesota
By The Associated Press
The retirements of two mayors paved the way for crowded fields in primaries in Minnesota on Tuesday, while voters in South Dakota rejected a measure backed by the actor Kevin Costner to increase betting limits in state casinos.
In Minneapolis, 17 candidates sought to replace Mayor Don Fraser, who is retiring after four terms. The top two finishers in the nonpartisan race were Sharon Sayles Belton, the City Council president, and John Derus, a former Hennepin County Commissioner. Ms. Belton, who won 28 percent of the vote, and Mr. Derus, who had 20 percent, will face each other in a November runoff.
A similar situation prevailed across the Mississippi in St. Paul, where Assistant Attorney General Norm Coleman finished first with 28 percent of the vote and State Representative Andy Dawkins came in second with 22 percent among 16 nonpartisan candidates. They will compete in November to replace Mayor Jim Scheibel, who is stepping down after one term.
In a nonpartisan primary in Seattle, Mayor Norm Rice finished far ahead of David Stern, who created the "happy face." They will meet in the November election.
Voters in South Dakota rejected a measure to raise betting limits at gaming halls in Deadwood and at Indian casinos. Fifty-five percent of the voters opposed raising betting limits to $100 from $5. The plan had the support of Mr. Costner and his brother, who wanted to build a $65 million casino resort at Deadwood.

HEADLINE: Census Figures Show a Racial Salary Gap

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Black Americans with college degrees still receive lower pay than white graduates for many jobs, the Census Bureau reported today.
In executive, administrative and managerial jobs, black male college graduates were paid about 77 percent of the amount earned by white male college graduates, the report said. 
 Census figures also showed that the number of black men 25 and over with at least a bachelor's degree rose from 7.7 percent in 1980 to 11.9 percent in 1992. Among black women, the rate rose from 8.1 percent to 12 percent.
Education translated into earnings power for both blacks and whites, but whites were paid more. The annual median salary for black college graduates was $30,910, compared with $18,620 for black high school graduates 25 and older. The median salary for white college graduates was $37,490, compared with $22,370 for white high school graduates 25 and older.
The census report was released in conjunction with the Congressional Black Caucus' annual legislative meeting opening today. The census figures were underscored by a Wall Street Journal analysis of Federal labor records, which found that black workers were the only group to experience a net loss of jobs during the recession of 1990-1991.
Black workers lost 59,479 jobs from July 1990 through March 1991, after three years of gains, the newspaper said. Black employment fell in six of nine major industry groups.
Asians gained 55,104 jobs in the same period, and Hispanics gained 60,040 jobs. Whites gained 71,144 jobs, though they outnumbered blacks nearly eight to one at the companies surveyed.

HEADLINE: Clinton Asserts He Might Bend On Health Plan

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton formally opened his campaign to revise the nation's health care system today by inviting ordinary Americans to the Rose Garden to voice their complaints and by asserting his willingness to compromise on key elements of his plan.
Mr. Clinton told a group of small-business owners who met him later at a hardware store in an industrial area of northeast Washington that he was willing to reconsider elements of his proposal that they say would hurt business owners with 50 to 100 employees.
 
Clinton Considers Plea
 Owners of businesses of this size have been among the most vocally opposed to the President's plan because larger employers are better able to afford insurance for employees, and employers with fewer than 50 workers would be given Government assistance to ease the hardship. 
 "There is no way we can, I don't think, solve every problem, but if there is something we can do for people who have between 50 and 100 employees, if there's something else we need to look at, we ought to do it," Mr. Clinton said.
The White House hopes to set the stage for Mr. Clinton's health care speech to a joint session of Congress next Wednesday by presenting the health plan as a package of proposals that can be adjusted to accommodate complaints from opponents and by stressing the long-term benefits of reshaping the medical system.
"This is the most complicated issue that the United States has had to face in a long time," Mr. Clinton said. "It has a very human face when you deal with the human dimensions of it, but it's extremely complex.
"But the first hurdle is to try to get everybody singing out of the same hymnal, as we say at home."
Mr. Clinton is using this week to lay out the scope of the health care problem.
In the earlier event in the Rose Garden, Mr. Clinton was joined by Vice President Al Gore, Tipper Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has headed the Adminstration's health care task force.
Participants flown in from around the country read letters they had sent to the White House about their problems in getting insurance coverage for everything from multiple sclerosis to nursing home care to AIDS. Their fares were paid by Families U.S.A., a consumer group that supports the health plan.
 
President Sees Sacrifice
 The letters were read under a tent erected in the Rose Garden to protect against rain showers. The readers detailed their fears over losing insurance coverage when they changed jobs or lost employment or made unpalatable choices in order to care for ailing relatives.
Karl Kregor, 55, a self-employed consultant from San Antonio, said he and his wife, who is also self-employed, feared they would be unable to afford insurance when they reached retirement age.
"Maybe language like hostage and blackmail doesn't seem fair," Mr. Kregor said. "But the economic as well as psychological consequences are just as real."
Conceding that some taxpayers would see their premiums rise if coverage is to be extended to address these common concerns, Mr. Clinton said that such steps would nevertheless be necessary to bring what he described as a "wildly inefficient" health care system under control.
"I think most young, healthy, single Americans would be willing to do that to avoid the kind of horror stories we've heard today," he said.
Mrs. Clinton pledged that the Administration would not back down from its commitment to end insurance coverage that excluded people who suffer from preexisting illnesses.
"I never could figure out why insurance companies only wanted to insure people who had never been sick or never would get sick," she said. "I think that eliminates everybody."
Mr. Clinton has acknowledged that some of his fiercest opposition would come from small business owners. He said they needed to be convinced that the extra cost was necessary and worthwhile. Even among the handful of specially invited guests that the Small Business Administration brought to meet the President today, there were complaints about the plan.
"We cannot finance your proposed 7.9 percent payroll tax on the backs of small business without job loss," said Daryl Routzahn, a business owner from Frederick, Md. who said his business had shrunk by two-thirds in the last 18 months while his health care costs tripled. "A mandate will hurt our struggling economy."
Mr. Clinton responded: "We're trying to work this out in a fair way that's bearable. But I believe it will aid the American economy and will help small business growth if we do it properly."
 
Owners Not Mollified
 But Mr. Clinton did not mollify the business owners. Pedro Alonso, the owner of a computer and management consulting concern in Washington, said afterward that he was not satisfied with the plan.
"Right now, it's a matter of mandating health care reform on small business," he said. "But small businesses won't be around to reap those benefits. A lot of us won't be able to be competitive. Who do we pass the cost on to?"
Erskine Bowles, Director of the Small Business Administration, said he did not know what form the relief for small businesses would take, but he defended the overall plan. "Every single company won't win," he said. "That's impossible, O.K.? But the vast majority will."
But as the White House prepares to defend its plan, it is counting on the stories of the families like those who appeared in the Rose Garden to counter a television advertising campaign that denounces the health care proposal as the handiwork of bureaucrats plotting to limit individual choice.
"This is not fair," said Brigitte Burdine of Los Angeles, whose 22-year-old sister, Heather, had her insurance suspended after she contracted AIDS. "No one should be refused top-notch medical care in this country because of financial reasons, and when someone becomes chronically ill, it should not be allowed to wipe out their entire family financially."

HEADLINE: A Primer: Why Economists Favor Free-Trade Agreement

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
When economists of every stripe agree on anything, it is noteworthy. So it is a sign of unusual accord that 300 economists, ranging from conservatives like James M. Buchanan and Milton Friedman to liberals including Paul A. Samuelson and James Tobin, recently signed a letter to President Clinton supporting the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Politicians have spoken so loudly and so often on the free-trade agreement that the economists seem to have been pushed into the background. Depending on who is talking, political leaders have argued that the pact would either send millions of jobs swooshing south to Mexico (Ross Perot) or add hundreds of thousands of high-paying jobs to the American economy (Mickey Kantor).
 
'Economically Trivial'
 Most economists say that neither is the case. The letter to President Clinton cited a review of dozens of studies of the trade agreement's impact on American jobs and pay. It concluded that while the signers had minor differences, they concurred that "the effects on the U.S. economy -- both good and bad -- would be small for many years." 
 Some radical economists -- like Samuel Bowles at the University of Massachusetts -- predict large and negative effects from the agreement. But much of the national debate has been grounded more in politics and hyperbole than in economics.
Paul Krugman, a trade economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that for the United States, the agreement is "economically trivial." Professor Krugman supports the treaty, saying he thinks it will help to keep free-market reformers in power in Mexico. He sums up the war of words this way: "The anti-Nafta people are telling malicious whoppers. The pro-Nafta side is telling little white lies."
 
 
Well-Established Theories
 An arsenal of theories and models supports the conclusion that the trade agreement would have a minor economic impact on the United States. Fundamental insights about international trade have not changed much in 250 years; Paul Samuelson, in his legendary textbook, quotes the English philosopher John Stuart Mill as saying the benefit of international trade is "a more efficient employment of the productive forces of the world."
Trade theory describes how international trade affects countries' material well-being as well as the benefits and costs of restrictions like tariffs. The lesson of most trade theory is that while razing barriers may hurt some businesses and workers, it generally raises all countries' incomes.
Perhaps the easiest way to think of trade between two countries is to imagine two people, say one who is very good at growing corn and another who is great at stitching clothes. Each can do both tasks for himself, splitting his time between farming and sewing. But if one farms for both, and the other sews for both, together they could produce more -- and therefore consume more -- by specializing. Economists refer to this as comparative advantage.
Even if one man is better at both activities than the other, it makes sense for each to focus on what he is relatively best at. Janet Reno may well be a faster typist than her secretary, but it is probably still a good idea for her to lead the nation's law enforcement efforts and let her secretary tap out her memos.
Thus, the way economists see it, the gain from knocking down barriers is not more total jobs -- the Attorney General and her assistant still have just one job each -- but greater total productivity and incomes.
"I wouldn't say we're creating more jobs than we're destroying -- that's hype," said Jagdish Bhagwati, a trade expert at Columbia University who signed the letter supporting the agreement. "In the long run, trade only reallocates jobs" among different industries within a country.
 
 
Same Basic Principles
 Trade between countries like the United States and Mexico is obviously a good deal more complicated than a simple example of two people. Americans are 11 times as rich as Mexicans. The United States and Mexico produce thousands of products. Labor and capital stream across borders, with American companies setting up businesses in Mexico City suburbs and Mexican factory hands flocking to Los Angeles. The values of the peso and dollar bobble up and down. Nonetheless, economists say, the same principles hold.
The dozens of models used to assess the pact try to build in some of the complications -- especially the fact that America's factory productivity and wages are seven times as high as Mexico's and that the American economy is 20 times as big.
Some models break the two economies into dozens of industries. Other models focus on the dimensions of economic integration that are generally left out of trade models: potentially larger investment by American companies in Mexico and potentially less illegal migration from Mexico to the United States.
To make the models more realistic, economists gather data on other trading relationships: what happened to low-wage workers in the United States in the 1950's and 1960's when American multinationals planted factories around the world and trade with low-wage countries mushroomed; what happened to investment and jobs in Germany when Spain and Portugal joined the European Community; what happened to employment in the United States after Mexico unilaterally liberalized trade laws in the late 1980's.
 What the models do, essentially, is put numbers on theories. In the last year, the middle-of-the-road Brookings Institution, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office and the International Trade Commission, a Federal agency independent of the White House, have reviewed all of the trade agreement studies they could find. What is striking is the broad agreement they found among most of the analyses, despite differences in the models and the assumptions.
Take, for example, the question of how much the trade agreement would, by creating a larger market, raise the competitiveness of American companies -- something the Clinton Administration has claimed. Traditional models suggest that the United States does gain, but only modestly.
No studies suggest that the trade agreement could add much more than a tenth of a percentage point to the United States' gross domestic product over a decade or more. That is $6 billion over more than 10 years -- an amount that Americans spend on health care in a few days or the amount by which the American economy grows every couple of weeks.
To some extent, the results are just common sense. American tariffs on Mexican imports are already low, around 4 percent on average, suggesting that United States companies already face plenty of competition -- most of it from American rivals.
"It's a big deal for Mexico, which is moving from a statist to a market economy," said Sherman Robinson, a University of California economist who is consulting with the Council of Economic Advisers. "It's a small deal for us."
What concerns most Americans, however, is how many jobs the trade agreement would create or destroy. Since trade models focus mainly on overall efficiency gains, researchers have had to go beyond the usual trade models for answers, some of which are consistent with trade theory, and some of which are less so.
 
Different Assumptions
 Typical of the divergence are the conclusions reached by Gary C. Hufbauer and Jeffrey J. Schott, economists at the Institute for International Economics, and Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former trade negotiator now at the Economic Strategy Institute. Both groups used macroeconomic models of the United States economy -- the sort that forecasters use to predict how much the economy will grow in the coming year or so -- that allow them to focus on the near term, to try to calculate the agreement's potential impact on employment. The difference in their results stems largely from their different assumptions.
The Hufbauer-Schott model assumed that Mexico would run a trade deficit with the United States well into the 21st century, as Japan and Korea did for long periods during their industrialization. Mr. Prestowitz, who conditionally supports the trade agreement, uses the same type of model but assumes that Mexico would quickly start to repay its foreign debt and export more to the United States than it imports.
The Hufbauer-Schott study concluded that the trade agreement would add 170,000 jobs to the American labor market of 120 million workers, while Mr. Prestowitz found that it would eliminate 420,000 jobs. While the numbers seem strikingly different, neither amounts to a sizable impact on the overall economy over 10 or 15 years.
That does not markedly counter the conclusion of most economists, who are generally skeptical that the trade agreement would significantly affect American jobs. They say the macroeconomic models ignore the fact that once American unemployment gets down to 6 percent or so -- what many economists consider the "normal" level of unemployment -- a deficit or surplus with Mexico would merely shift jobs around -- not change the number of jobs.
More important, the macroeconomic models do not take future monetary policy into account. "If the economy created 500,000 fewer jobs, the Fed would lower interest rates more," Professor Krugman said. "If there were 500,000 more jobs, it would keep rates higher. Over the course of a decade, there is no reason to suppose that the average level of employment will be any different with Nafta than without."
 
Related Issues

 
 Other important issues in the free-trade debate include whether investment would desert the United States for Mexico, and whether competition with Mexico would force American wages -- especially for less skilled workers -- to fall. In these issues, as in the debate over jobs, most studies suggest that the impact will be slight and that the claims of free-trade critics like Ross Perot are not rooted in realistic economic analysis.
Even without models, economists say common sense suggests that the impact on wages and investment cannot be large. They note that Mexico's economy is roughly the size of Los Angeles's, amounting to no more than 4 percent of the United States' gross domestic product. Just as Los Angeles could not absorb a large portion of the new investment in the United States, neither could Mexico.
What's more, American companies have had a host of opportunties to move plants to nearby areas with lower wages, including Puerto Rico or Jamaica. While some have indeed moved, many others have not.
There were similar worries that with economic integration, Spain and Portugal would drain capital from the rest of the European Community. That has not happened.
 
Benefits Seen for Mexico
 If economists are correct that the impact on the United States will be so limited, and the benefits so slight, why are so many calling for passage of the free-trade agreement?
The answer is that they believe it will be good for Mexico. Another widely accepted economic tenet is that poor nations need to export in order to industrialize. Opening the United States market more would strengthen the hand of a pro-American, pro-free market Government in Mexico, and help Mexico's citizens.
Further, the trade agreement might reduce pressures on illegal immigration. And liberalizing trade with a poorer neighbor would, they say, set a positive example for Western Europe to open its market to its formerly Communist neighbors.

HEADLINE: Japan Unveils a Third Plan To Stimulate the Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Japanese Government today announced its third emergency stimulus package in 13 months, in what economists say is becoming an increasingly futile effort to jump-start an economy whose battery has died.
The program consists of about 6 trillion yen, or roughly $57 billion, of increased public works spending, low interest loans and tax incentives intended to pull the world's second largest economy out of its worst downturn in at least two decades. 
 The new package represents a major test for Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who vowed to concentrate on political reform but who has been sidetracked as business conditions have worsened because of the rise in the value of the yen and an unusually cool and wet summer.
Mr. Hosokawa announced the measures at a news conference, calling them "rather bold."
 
Loosening Regulation
 The Government also announced that it would loosen regulations in 94 areas, from allowing small brewers to make beer to allowing customers to buy cellular phones rather than lease them from the phone company. It also said it would take steps to pass on the benefits of the stronger Japanese yen to consumers by lowering electricity and gas rates and promoting lower prices for imported goods.
Economists said, however, that the new efforts would not be strong enough to rescue the economy. And some business leaders here were disappointed that the package did not contain a big cut in income taxes that they had hoped would have given consumers more money to spend on new cars, televisions and clothing. The Government said today that a commission would recommend changes in the tax system by November, all but eliminating the chance of a tax cut this year.
The measures are also not expected to satisfy Washington, which has pushed Japan to cut taxes. The United States wants Japanese consumers to spend more to help the recovery of the sluggish world economy and to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus by buying more imported products.
Although the new package was not officially announced until the Tokyo stock market had closed for the day, the Nikkei average plummeted 445.64 points, or 2.1 percent, to finish at 20,502.15.
And the dollar fell sharply against the yen, as traders anticipated that a disappointed United States would favor a strong yen as a way of reducing Japan's trade surplus. In Tokyo trading today, the dollar closed at 104.62 yen, down 1.13 yen.
The 6 trillion yen in the Prime Minister's stimulus package includes of almost 2 trillion yen, or $19 billion, in public works spending. Half of that will be spending by the national Government on items like art museums and wheelchair ramps, and 500 billion yen more, or $4.8 billion, will be spent by local governments. In addition, 450 billion yen, or about $4.3 billion, will be spent on recovery from this summer's big earthquake and typhoons.
About 2.9 trillion yen, or $28 billion, is earmarked for increasing low interest loans for home-buying, one of the bright spots of the economy. The rest of the fiscal stimulus consists of incentives for businesses, like loans to help small- and medium-sized companies cope with the rise of the yen.
The new package is only about half the size of two previous programs, -- a 10.7 trillion yen stimulus announced in August 1992 and a 13.2 trillion yen package announced in April. At current exchange rates, those programs together are worth $228 billion.
One reason for the smaller package is that the Government cannot afford to increase spending much more without incurring a budget deficit. But another factor is a recognition that the centerpiece of the last two packages -- increased public works spending -- did not work as well as expected in reviving the economy.
"We've had two packages already," said Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "Why should this one work any better?"
Consumer spending is a far larger part of the economy than Government spending, and building roads and sewers has not led consumers to spend more.
Some analysts say scandals over bidding on construction projects have made local government officials reluctant to undertake new projects, even though the money is available. Finance Ministry officials, however, disputed this, saying public works money is being spent effectively.
Moreover, some economists say, part of Japan's economic troubles are structural, not cyclical, and cannot be cured by pump priming. Export markets for products like cars and VCR's are saturated, and Japan is becoming a high-cost manufacturer, in part because of the recent increase in the value of the yen.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Narrowed 14% in July

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit shrank 14 percent in July, the Commerce Department said today. But while sluggish growth in the domestic economy curbed the appetite for imports, plunging deliveries of aircraft to foreign customers produced a decline in exports.
The overall narrowing of the deficit, to $10.34 billion, was less than half as large as the June surge, which pushed the deficit in merchandise to the highest level in more than five years and roiled world currency markets. 
 Analysts said it was now almost certain that the deficit would surpass $100 billion this year and result in the biggest imbalance since 1985.
"Most worrisome is what's going on with Europe," said Willard Workman, vice president for international affairs for the United States Chamber of Commerce. He noted that American sales in Europe have fallen 8 percent over the last year and that Canada has replaced the European Community as the biggest market for American exports.
The report showed that the American deficit with the European Community rose to $1.6 billion in July from $1.27 billion in June. The shift was offset by a reduction in the deficit with Canada to $638 million from $989 million.
 
A Lack of Competitiveness
 While much of Europe remains in recession, various analysts say the dwindling purchases of American products there reflect a lack of competitiveness as well as a lower point in the business cycle.
Today's report also showed that the nation's trade positions with Japan and Mexico -- two of the most politically sensitive relationships -- showed only modest change in July.
The deficit with Japan widened to $4.74 billion in July from $4.33 billion in June and $4.03 billion in July 1992, the department said.
The American surplus with Mexico fell to $108 million, from $128 million in June, bringing to 53 percent the cumulative drop for the first seven months of the year, compared with the 1992 period.
"This really reinforces our need for Nafta," contended Stephen L. Cooney Jr., trade specialist for the National Association of Manufacturers, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement.
He said the earlier boom in United States exports, aided by Mexican privatization and other economic liberalization, was now on the wane because of a pinch in the ability of Mexicans to buy American goods. "They've gone about as far as they can go without balance-of-payments problems," Mr. Cooney said.
The figures published today covered only goods. The United States has been running a surplus in banking, insurance, travel and other services that offsets roughly half of the deficit in merchandise.
 
Imports Off 4.6 Percent
 Over all, merchandise imports in July fell 4.6 percent, to $47.42 billion, with reductions in cars, trucks, parts and industrial supplies accounting for the largest portion. Imports of various electronics and other consumer goods also eased, however, raising early doubts about the strength of the holiday shopping season.
The reduced imports were more than enough to offset a 1.4 percent decline in exports, to $37.08 billion, and trim the trade deficit from the highest level since February 1988.
Sales of aircraft, big-ticket items that tend to be made in bunches, plummeted more than 60 percent in July, compared with July 1992, an exceptionally big swing. For the year to date, exports of aircraft have skidded more than 20 percent.
The deficit with China, which swelled by $275 million in July, was 26 percent higher in the first seven months of the year than in the comparable 1992 period. The combined deficits with China and Japan account for 72 percent of the total United States deficit so far this year. Deficits also widened in July with Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore.
Reflecting the drop in aircraft sales, trade in advanced technology products showed an American surplus of only $915 million in July, less than one-third the level of many recent months.
On a three-month average, the overall trade gap now stands at $10.26 billion, up from $10.21 billion in June. It was the seventh consecutive monthly widening of the average.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Balance of Trade" tracks imports, exports and deficit, seasonally adjusted, since February 1992. (Source: Commerce Department) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mostly Flat as Dow Slips 2.80

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
A listlessness descended on the stock market yesterday, with mostly flat trading and light volume on the first full day of the Jewish holiday of Rosh ha-Shanah and a day ahead of "triple witching" day.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.80 points to close at 3,630.85. Volume was a modest 229.7 million shares, down from 298.3 million on Wednesday. 
Triple-witching days, the Fridays when three sets of options and futures contracts simultaneously expire each quarter, have historically brought wide swings to the market. Some Thursdays preceding triple-witching days have also seen volatility, but yesterday was sedate.
Analysts said the volatility of Wednesday's trading, when the market sank sharply and then recovered strongly, appeared to have been caused by traders leaving for Rosh ha-Shanah who were starting to limit their exposures in advance.
Broader market indicators were also flat yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dipped 2.17 points, to 459.43. The American Stock Exchange composite index edged down 0.06, to 453.68, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 0.25, to 739.80.
Weakness in the bond market also seemed to be holding the Dow down. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday, as its yield rose to 6.03 percent, from 5.97 percent on Wednesday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
 
Effects of Government Reports
 Two Government reports had little effect on the market: one, from the Labor Department, said the number of first-time unemployment claims filed rose slightly, by 2,000, last week, while the Federal Reserve said that industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the third straight monthly gain.
Most of the market's stories yesterday were not of sectors, but of individual stocks.
Whirlpool, the appliance maker, sank 3 1/2, to 57 1/4, when earnings estimates were cut by analysts after the company said earnings growth would not meet the rate of the first half.
Home Depot, the retailer, closed at 37 3/8, up 1 7/8, picking up some of the losses it suffered earlier this week.
Placer Dome, the gold mining company, closed at 19 1/8, up 1 3/4, on estimates that it has found 4.8 million ounces of gold at a drilling site in Venezuela.
Showboat, the operator of casinos and hotels, got a favorable analyst rating and closed at 19 3/4, up 4.
A.T.& T. lost 1 1/8, to 58 7/8, even though the company said it would seek an increase in long-distance rates to cover increasing costs.
The American depository receipts of London International Group, a condom and photoprocessing chemical maker, sank 4 1/4, to 11 3/8, on the announcement that its chief executive would retire and that it expected first-half earnings to be sharply lower than last year's.
Wellco Enterprises, a maker of combat boots, was up 5 7/8, to 29 1/2, after a gain of 5 3/8 the preceding day, on its declaration of a $6 cash dividend on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: An Idea Whose Time May Have Passed

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
In reaching a tentative agreement on Wednesday night that calls for lower wages for new workers, the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers are turning to a cost-saving measure that seems to have fallen out of favor recently among management and labor negotiators in other industries.
When it came to prominence in the airline and supermarket businesses a decade ago, the two-tier wage system was hailed by some companies as an innovation that would allow them to maintain or expand work forces more cheaply. It allowed unions to make concessions without hurting current members. 
 But the success of the strategy has often come down to this: is it healthy for management or labor if two employees performing the same work are paid sharply different salaries -- with no hope of ever closing the gap?
Faced with morale problems among the rank and file and a recession that has squeezed new hiring, some executives have decided the answer is no.
"Nobody seems to be terribly happy with it," said Al Bauman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "There have been a number of contracts where they have dropped the two tiers or eased them out."
And unions say that instead of seeking two-tier wage settlements, most companies are now more interested in finding ways to control health care costs for all employees, not just new ones. "The dynamic that is driving everything in negotiations is health care," said Greg Denier, a spokesman for the United Food and Commercial Workers union.
Under the tentative three-year deal reached late on Wednesday, new Ford workers will earn 70 percent of current workers' wages and will catch up within three years. But the new workers will also qualify for health benefits sooner than under the previous pact.
The old contract had a weaker version of two tiers, with workers receiving 85 percent of full pay for their first 18 months.
In agreeing to the new settlement, the U.A.W. is apparently trying to protect the pay and benefits of a large number of workers with substantial seniority. As car sales continue to rise and older workers retire, Ford is hoping to use the provision to cut the cost of bolstering its work force.
While saying that the number of two-tier accords seems to have declined, economists point out that it is difficult to collect data on such contracts because they differ widely. Agreements can require two tiers for pay, health care, pensions or vacations.
Whatever the specific provisions, some economists and most union leaders say workers resent two-tier systems. New ones feel underappreciated and their older counterparts often fear that they will be dismissed to make way for cheaper labor.
That was the case at the Hannaford Brothers Company, which runs more than 100 Shop-Rite and Shop 'n Save supermarkets in New York and New England. Hannaford, based in Scarborough, Me., negotiated two-tier contracts for its warehouse workers in the mid-1980's, but then dropped the provisions after tensions increased.
"Although it does save costs, the emotional and psychological toll on the everyday work force is hard to manage," said Walter Stilphen, director of labor relations at the company.
Two-tier contracts were embraced by airlines in the early 1980's after deregulation gave rise to nonunion carriers and intense competition. Companies like American Airlines told their unions that without such a structure there would be layoffs.
Under pressure to preserve pay and jobs, the unions caved in, though they often extracted provisions specifying that the new workers would eventually catch up.
"Most of the major airlines followed American's lead because it was a brilliant idea for the time," said Russell Thayer, a former senior executive at several carriers, including American, who is now a consultant at Airline Economics International in Washington. "But it's come back to haunt them."
He said that when the recession began carving through the industry, many carriers stopped hiring, preventing them from taking advantage of the lower salaries that are part of the two-tier system.
 
May Bbe 'Self-Defeating'
 Many supermarket companies also reasoned that two-tier contracts would help them cut costs because they have a relatively high worker turnover rate. But they too have discovered that in a recession, when many workers cling to their jobs, these provisions are often ineffective.
The American Stores Company, whose supermarket chains include Lucky, Acme and Jewel, had many two-tier contracts in the late 1970's and early 1980's but currently has none, said Meredith C. Anderson, a company spokeswoman.
She said American Stores, based in Salt Lake City, found that it was pushing the union for a concession that was producing few benefits for the company. "It's certainly an option that can be looked at, but in a bad economy, it may be somewhat self-defeating," she said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Hotbeds for Start-Ups;
Where Is Opportunity Knocking the Loudest?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
With big companies shedding workers left and right, where are America's new jobs going to come from? Try Charlotte, N.C., Huntsville, Ala., and Sunnyvale, Calif.
They are three of the winners in a new study of start-ups and job creation called "Entrepreneurial Hot Spots: The Best Places in America to Start and Grow a Company." 
 The study, published today, concludes that the nation's entrepreneurial hubs are determined far more by world-class universities, good roads and proximity to airports than by cheap labor or low tax rates. Yet subjective considerations also play a role, such as being seen as a "nice place to live" and having an entrepreneurial culture.
"The places that are doing well are competing by offering a high quality of life and skilled workers, not giveaways to companies," said David Birch, president of Cognetics Inc., an economic consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Working with a data base of nine million companies, Mr. Birch and his staff ranked states, metropolitan areas and districts by the number of surviving start-ups and growth by young companies in recent years. The index measures growth both in percentage terms and absolute growth.
Most of the sales growth and job generation comes from a comparatively small number of fast-expanding companies -- Mr. Birch calls them "gazelles." In fact, he estimates that 70 percent of the growth comes from this 4 percent of the companies, which typically have between 20 and 200 workers and are expanding at more than 30 percent a year.
Among the 50 largest metropolitan areas, Charlotte comes in first, followed by Atlanta, Indianapolis, Nashville., and Raleigh-Durham, N.C. The least hospitable for entrepreneurs, the study says, are Hartford; Albany-Schenectady-Troy, N.Y.; New York; Boston, and Oklahoma City.
Huntsville heads the small metropolitan areas, followed by Honolulu; Las Vegas, Nev.; Madison, Wis., and Tallahassee, Fla.
Sunnyvale leads the ranking of so-called submarkets within the Government-designated large metropolitan areas. These submarkets are essentially big districts, each employing an average of 100,000 people. After Sunnyvale, the top-ranked districts are the area around Miami International Airport; Norcross, Ga.; Cumberland, Ga., and Morrisville, N.C.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Rises Slightly

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government said today. It was the third straight advance in an economic sector that had been struggling earlier in the year.
The Federal Reserve said the increase in output at the country's factories, mines and utilities followed advances of four-tenths of 1 percent in July and two-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
 Neither the production number nor another report showing a big drop in the trade deficit in July was considered a sign of robust economic activity, but some analysts were mildly encouraged.
"I'm getting the sense that the economy, which has been in a funk for the past three or four months, now is building up to stronger growth," said Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
In another report, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits rose by 2,000 last week, to 324,000. It was the first increase in three weeks but was not considered a significant rise. The less volatile four-week moving average of claims was unchanged at 325,500, the lowest in four years.
In its industrial production report, the Federal Reserve said the production of business equipment and durable goods materials rose sharply.
 
Declines in Several Segments
 However, it said, the production of military and space equipment and of durable consumer goods declined further and the output of energy materials decreased because of the continuing strike in the coal industry. The report also said the production of automobiles and trucks fell 1.1 percent.
The country's industrial sector posted strong gains at the beginning of the year, following strong consumer demand in the final months of 1992.
But that demand slackened in early 1993 and manufacturers put the brakes on output. Production slipped from a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in February to just three-tenths of 1 percent in April, then fell to two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Still, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday that businesses in July reported the biggest decline in inventories in more than two years, which could mean an increase in production as they try to restock their shelves and back lots.
And the Fed reported last week that a national survey showed that production was increasing in many areas. That followed a Labor Department report that both the factory workweek and overtime were rising in August.
The Fed's production report showed that the operating rate of industrial companies was 81.8 percent of capacity, unchanged from July and slightly above the 81.5 percent rate in both May and June. Capacity utilization is closely watched because a reading of more than 85 percent is considered to be inflationary.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Executive's Budget Seeks to Cut Property Taxes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 16

 BODY:
Relying on a sales-tax increase to yield at least $120 million next year, the Suffolk County Executive proposed a $1.56 billion budget today that would cut property taxes for most residents.
After years of deficits, fiscal crises and warnings of layoffs, the Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, also proposed hiring more than 400 new employees, including 340 police officers, and requested raises of 2.5 percent for elected officials, including himself. 
 Mr. Gaffney said that the sales-tax increase of one percentage point, which was to expire at year end until the county extended it by two years this summer, was central to stabilizing the county's finances. He estimated that Suffolk would finish 1993 with a $3.8 million surplus. The county had a deficit of $99.2 million as recently as 1991.
 
'Critical to Stable'
 "If the county government were a patient, its condition would be upgraded from critical to stable," Mr. Gaffney said. Without the sales-tax money, he added, "I would not be saying the county is off the critical list."
Mr. Gaffney's proposal reflected a swift turnaround of the county's fiscal fortunes. Last May he had sought a deficit financing package of up to $90 million through the sale of long-term bonds, to be paid off by sales tax revenues. The county Legislature rejected the package, and instead authorized a one-year note of $36.5 million. Officials said today the budget note had been repaid with current sales tax revenues.
Suffolk's 8.5 percent sales tax is the highest of any county in the state, and is matched only by Nassau County. During the last two years, as local officials throughout New York have struggled with sagging economies and stiff resistance to property-tax increases, 13 of the state's 62 counties have imposed higher sales taxes.
"So many places were maxed out on property taxes, they had nowhere else to go," said Karl E. Felsen, a spokesman for the State Department of Taxation and Finance in Albany.
Critics say the sales-tax increases spare payers of property taxes but place an unfair burden on the poor. But county officials reply that higher sales taxes meet far less organized resistance than property-tax increases.
 
Cuts Are Welcomed
 Mr. Gaffney said the proposed budget for 1994 assumed a 3.8 percent increase in sales-tax revenues next year. Of the 8.5 percent total tax, the county share is 4.25 percentage points.
He said any surplus would be used to pay for refinancing of long-term county debt at lower interest rates.
Donald R. Blydenburgh, a Smithtown Republican and the presiding officer of the county Legislature, applauded the proposed property tax cuts and predicted the spending plan would be well received in the Legislature, where Republicans and Conservatives hold a majority. Hearings on the budget are scheduled next month.
Democratic members had opposed extending the higher sales tax because, they said, Mr. Gaffney had failed to reduce spending enough.
By the county's reckoning, the average taxpayer in four of the county's five western towns would enjoy a property tax cut of $44.80 next year and, in the five eastern towns, $87.94. County taxes account for about one-fifth of total property taxes for most Suffolk residents.
In the Town of Brookhaven, property taxes would increase by $131.76 because of the loss of the $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant from assessment rolls. Under a settlement between Gov.Mario M. Cuomo and the Long Island Lighting Company, the plant was sold to the state for decommissioning.
 
Adding Police Officers
 Mr. Gaffney said that if 340 new police officers were hired, the county force would number 2,629, the highest since 1983. He said the new officers would allow resumption of community-oriented policing, which had been hobbled by budget constraints. The budget proposes a pilot program of competitive bidding for county bus routes and leasing of county cars. Mr. Gaffney said the leasing plan would save the county up to $6 million.
Mr. Gaffney said he would make "no apologies" for heightened dependence on sales taxes. "It's a better way to do it than increasing property taxes," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Yen On Doubts Over Japan's Plan

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday on doubts that a new Japanese economic package would be enough to curb that country's huge trade surplus with the United States.
But the dollar rallied against the German mark, recovering from a 16-week low against the currency, after a large purchase of dollars led to orders to sell marks, dealers said. 
 The dollar began sliding against the yen during Far East trading after unnamed American officials reportedly said that Japan's economic stimulus package fell short of what was needed to pare the trade surplus. Clinton Administration officials have urged Japan to cut taxes and take other measures to stimulate its lagging economy and help increase demand for American exports.
But the stimulus package did not include tax cuts. United States Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen later called the package a "step in the right direction" but said the United States was hoping for more.
 
Renewed Trade Tensions
His comments raised fears that the White House would renew suggestions that it favored a stronger yen as a means of attacking the huge United States-Japan trade gap.
"The market view is that if the U.S. is not appeased by the plan, which seems to be the case, then it will resume its war of words" on the dollar's exchange-rate against the yen, said the head of foreign exchange at an American investment bank in London.
The dollar received little help from a Commerce Department report showing that the trade gap with Japan widened to $4.74 billion in July, its largest level since April.
But talk of a large purchase of dollars for marks and sentiment among some dealers that the American currency was undervalued against the German currency helped the dollar to recover.
The dollar surged to 1.6025 marks in late New York trading, from 1.5955 on Wednesday. Earlier in London, the dollar climbed to 1.6065 marks, from 1.5903 marks Wednesday.
The dollar dropped to 104.15 yen in late New York trading, from 106.00 yen Wednesday. In late Tokyo trading on yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 104.62 yen. Tokyo markets were closed for a national holiday on Wednesday.
The British pound slipped to $1.5330 in New York from $1.5495. In London, it fell to $1.5320 from $1.5515.

HEADLINE: Now Shake Hands With Vietnam

 BODY:
Sooner or later some American President will find the courage to end Washington's now-pointless vendetta against Communist Vietnam. That President might as well be Bill Clinton and the time might as well be now.
The public debate on U.S. Vietnam policy focuses on Hanoi's cooperation in locating the remains of servicemen listed as missing in action since the Vietnam War. But the biggest obstacle to normal diplomatic and economic relations is America's wounded national pride and White House fears of a ferocious backlash. 
 This week President Clinton took the latest in a series of modest steps meant to reward increased Vietnamese cooperation in the search for M.I.A.'s.
George Bush began the process last year by letting U.S. companies prospect for future business in Vietnam. Then Mr. Clinton dropped longstanding American objections to loans for Vietnam from international development banks. He also stationed American diplomats in Vietnam for the first time since the war's end. On Monday the Administration announced that U.S. companies could bid for business financed by the development loans.
These steps are all welcome, but there's no good reason not to go all the way.
Controversial documents recently unearthed from Soviet archives suggest that Hanoi may have understated the number of prisoners it held 20 years ago. But despite the claims of Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire and others, there's no persuasive evidence that any Americans are still being held. Meanwhile, Clinton Administration officials report that Vietnam's Government is actively cooperating in the search for M.I.A. remains.
Even if Americans were being held captive, the chances of discovering them could only be improved by an increased U.S. diplomatic and business presence in Vietnam. If convincing new evidence were found, American sanctions could be reimposed, and allies could be asked to join in.
The embargo did apply effective pressure on Vietnam in the 1980's, when other countries also restricted trade and investment to protest Hanoi's occupation of Cambodia. But most countries dropped their restrictions when Vietnam withdrew its troops and cooperated with efforts to establish an elected Cambodian government.
Now America's European allies, along with the main non-Communist governments of Asia, are forging new links with Hanoi, sustaining its pro-market reforms and encouraging its peaceful integration into the Asia-Pacific region. With the rest of the world investing and trading in Vietnam, the U.S. embargo has little effect. In the small Vietnamese market, America's absent companies are readily replaced.
America's interest in Vietnam lies in successful reform and regional integration, not endless refighting of the domestic politics of the Vietnam War. There may never be a politically smart time to take the plunge. But the right time is now.

HEADLINE: Mr. Rohatyn and a City's Debt

 BODY:
The chairman of New York City's Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix Rohatyn, has held that unsalaried post for nearly two decades, but his real influence goes well beyond the formal title. Using his position as a platform, the outspoken investment banker created a broad and unusual role for himself as the city's fiscal conscience. Now that Mr. Rohatyn has resigned, New Yorkers can only hope that circumstances and luck will conspire to bring them another Rohatyn, a shrewd private citizen with enough patience and guile to prod and guide political insiders.
Mr. Rohatyn came on the scene with the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when Gov. Hugh Carey enlisted him to help save New York City from bankruptcy. That accomplished, Mr. Rohatyn turned himself into New York's pessimistic truth-teller. He could overdo it -- hence his familiar "Cassandra" label. He could anger other players in the city's fiscal drama -- especially labor leaders who resented his hard-edged advice. He could act like a rival to the mayor, bent on making policy for the city. He could fuss over his press coverage. 
 But Mr. Rohatyn also did what nobody else could. He cast a dry eye on his city's fiscal shenanigans and told everyone what he saw. As an unpaid, private businessman, he had the credibility to cry foul when elected officials let the city live beyond its means. They haven't always listened: the city budget is still structurally unbalanced, which means New York continues to burden the future by borrowing now and planning to pay later. But if elected officials sometimes refused to heed Mr. Rohatyn's counsel, they always heard it. So did Wall Street, the credit markets and the public.
The public also benefited in other ways. After helping to create the Municipal Assistance Corporation to borrow for the city in 1975, he turned it into a healthy money-maker. The M.A.C. generated $3.5 billion, which he directed toward education, mass transit and economic development.
Who elected Rohatyn? former Mayor Edward Koch used to ask. Nobody. Crisis invented him and he took care of the rest. New York City is in his debt.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Crux of the Deal

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
It was not altruism or a sudden access of affection for each other that moved Israel and the P.L.O. to the ceremony on the White House lawn. It was self-interest: a realization that making peace with this enemy was better than the looming alternatives.
And self-interest is the key to making the agreement work. It is ingeniously built into the deal, giving each party incentives to do what the other wants. 
 Yasir Arafat and his colleagues have compelling reasons to prevent terrorism or disorder in the small areas they will initially govern. They know that their chance of expanding self-rule in the West Bank -- and eventually of establishing a Palestinian state -- depend on their demonstrating to Israel that they can be a safe and reliable neighbor.
For its part, Israel's Government has every incentive to help the P.L.O. succeed in Gaza and Jericho. Calm and improving societies there would be a vital political justification for the gamble Prime Minister Rabin and his colleagues took.
The United States and other Western countries have their own self-interested reasons for wanting to help the P.L.O. succeed in the interim self-rule plan. Success would be a key to reducing tensions in the entire Middle East, and reducing the threat of the two radical states that have denounced this agreement: Iran and Iraq.
The help that the Palestinians need from the friendly world is economic. The P.L.O. leadership must produce improvements in the quality of life for Palestinians in Gaza and Jericho to have their support.
Gaza is one of the most depressing places on earth: 800,000 people, most of them crowded into miserable refugee camps with no sewage systems. There are virtually no jobs in the Gaza Strip itself; men cross daily into Israel, when they can, for mostly physical labor.
Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States also have strong reasons to help the struggling Palestinian entity. It is not a matter of Arab brotherhood; the gulf rulers have no love for the P.L.O. It is their profound interest in regional stability.
Saudi Arabia has a card of particular importance to play. That is to end the Arab boycott of Israel. Saudis are reluctant to lead. When pressed on this subject, they say the boycott is not much enforced now anyway. But it has great symbolic significance. Ending it would go far toward lifting the sense of isolation that oppresses Israelis, and would give Mr. Rabin more political space to proceed.
Moreover, ending the boycott would help the West Bank. Some Arab countries now bar the meager goods Palestinians try to export from there, on the asserted ground that Israel is involved.
The economic needs of the West Bank and Gaza are substantial but not daunting. And a good deal of planning has already been done. The world bank has its ideas ready. A Harvard University team published detailed proposals in June, prepared with the intense and friendly participation of Israeli, Palestinian and Jordanian economists.
That leads to a point about the dramatic events of the last two weeks. In the Israeli-P.L.O. rapprochement, officials followed way behind what private individuals have done in recent years. Scholars and others from the two sides have been meeting with increasing frequency. Finally one of those meetings, in Norway, led to the official contacts that produced the agreement.
Here a word must be said for those on both sides who for years -- for a generation -- argued fruitlessly for peace. Issam Sartawi and Said Hammami of the P.L.O. were assassinated by Arab extremists for their efforts. Lova Eliav of Israel's Labor Party spent years in the political wilderness. American Jews who made contact with the P.L.O. were denounced as traitors.
They were right. If their views had been heeded long ago, much misery and death would have been avoided.
But even this late there are some reasons for optimism: reasons rooted in self-interest. The president of the American Jewish Congress, Robert Lifton, reports after a visit to Israel that many of his conservative business friends there, who voted for the Likud, now talk excitedly about the economic potential of peace. That potential must be for both Israelis and Palestinians.

HEADLINE: Mexico Takes Giant Steps Toward a New Era;
Things to Come?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am secretary general of a union of Mexicans and Americans who work at the Mexican-American Cultural Relations Institute (Instituto Mexicano Norteamericano de Relaciones
Culturales), founded by Presidents Manuel Avila Camacho and Franklin Delano Roosevelt in 1944. Here, generations of Mexicans and Americans have studied English and Spanish. 
 One would think that on the threshold of a free trade agreement among the nations of North America, the institute would be flourishing. This is not the case. On Aug. 12, it closed its doors without notice for arbitrary and unknown reasons, locking out more than 4,000 students and nearly 100 teachers and staff members.
We suspect that this sudden decision is related to a hidden agenda of the free trade agreement and to the current situation in Mexico.
The teachers and administrative and maintenance personnel of the institute are fully aware that Mexican labor laws are designed to protect our jobs. However, we also realize that big business interests in the United States and Mexico are trying to get around the laws that protect us.
For many years the institute has been controlled by a board made up of a small group of powerful Mexicans and Americans whose business interests lie in Mexico. They know full well what the future holds for Mexican and American workers and their labor laws.
Our union is well aware that one of the reasons the free trade agreement is attractive to American businesses is the low salaries paid in Mexico. We also know that the only defense Mexican workers have is their system of labor laws. What's happening to our institute is an example of how these labor laws can be pushed aside, allowing business free reign to disregard worker rights. The process is simple: shut down the place of employment without warning.
Beginning some years ago the institute began to dismantle departments. Gradually, business fronts were formed. We suspect these have functioned as holding companies to place profits out of reach, thereby evading taxes and diverting funds generated by international sales of teaching materials. These holding companies intend to reopen the institute under another name after doing away with our union. Though they are registered as nonprofit organizations, they have bank accounts in the United States, enabling them to control the segments of what was once the institute.
At the most recent meeting before Mexican Government labor authorities, the institute's governing body refused to reopen our place of employment and offered us 19.5 percent of the severance pay Mexican labor law stipulates. We have rejected this offer as unfair to our members, who have dedicated as much as 35 years of service to the institute. Is this, we ask, a foretaste of the trade agreement?
 
ROSA MARIA VALENCIA
Hamburgo, Mexico, Sept. 3, 1993

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Social Security: Better to Pass at Age 62 to Collect More at 65?

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks

 BODY:
Thousands of people each year must decide whether to start collecting Social Security benefits at age 62 or to wait until 65 or even later.
 Some people, of course, need the money desperately. But others are still working, if only part time, or drawing on other resources. They have to weigh the advantages of having a little more now or much more later. 

 People can start collecting anytime after they turn 62. But by beginning then, their monthly checks will be 20 percent smaller -- forever -- than if they had waited until 65. And if they begin at age 65, their checks will be 20 percent smaller than if they had waited until 70. For each year of delay, the monthly payment rises 4 to 8 percent.
 For example, someone turning 65 this year who is eligible to receive $800 a month would have gotten only $640 by starting at age 62. If he waits until 70, he could increase his monthly check to $960, said Philip Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration. These figures do not include the cost-of-living adjustments made regularly by the agency.
 Last year, more people decided to start collecting benefits at age 62 than at any other age: 48 percent of men and 57 percent of women, according to the agency.
 Of course, many people who wait would not qualify for benefits anyway because they are still working and earning substantial income, Mr. Gambino said.
 Other people are retired but have alternative income -- say, a private pension or interest on investments. Although this other money may not be so great as to make them ineligible for benefits, it fills their current needs, said Laurel Beedon, senior economic analyst for the Public Policy Institute of the American Association of Retired Persons.
 Recognizing that life spans are increasing, these people may wish to keep a higher level of Social Security income in reserve for their later years when other resources have been partly or completely depleted, Ms. Beedon said. Someone enjoying good health, collecting other income and anticipating a long life might choose this approach.
 Another school of thought holds that even if you don't need the cash right away, you should start collecting as soon as possible and invest the money. The discretionary income could be far more valuable today than tomorrow.
 A monthly payment of $640 would generate an investment pool of $7,680 a year (assuming it is not subject to income tax) or $23,040 from age 62 to 65. "If you're good at investing, it could work," Ms. Beedon said.
 The choice, ultimately, depends on individual circumstances. Ask your local Social Security office for an estimate of your benefits or call 800 772-1213 for a referral.
