HEADLINE: Key to Israel-P.L.O. Pact Is Seen in Economic Ties

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN with CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Israeli political leaders have talked this last week of lowering trade barriers and building new roads to create what Foreign Minister Shimon Peres called "a triangle of political triumph and economic prosperity" among Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians.
But if the transition to Palestinian self-government is to succeed, the economy of the occupied territories will have to remain umbilically tied to Israel for at least the next few years, even if it means keeping neighboring Jordan on the sidelines, Israeli and Palestinian economists say. 
 Economists and business leaders here caution that the key to success for the new deal struck by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization lies in rapid economic progress in the Gaza Strip and West Bank. People there will have to see their daily lives improve almost right away, they say.
And to do that, they add, there is no alternative but to maintain and even strengthen the already considerable economic links between the territories and Israel. These ties might be expected to grow anyway, although economists say that nationalist politics among Palestinians could force their leaders into trying to put up barriers with Israel that may not make economic sense.
 
A Pall Over Jordan
 Economists see the close links between Israel and the Palestinians persisting through the next five years of planned self-rule and probably beyond, when the Palestinians may have achieved their hoped-for independent state. This prospect of close Israeli-Palestinian cooperation has cast a pall over Jordan, which fears that it will become the odd man out.
Jordanian officials worry that Israel will continue to enforce a trade embargo that keeps Jordanian products out of the West Bank and Gaza, depriving the hard-pressed kingdom of potential revenues estimated at $300 million a year. In addition, Government planners in Amman view the new Palestinian "entity" that is being born as a possible drain on their own economy, attracting large amounts of foreign aid and investment, perhaps including huge cash flows from Palestinians in Jordan and elsewhere.
Their concerns were not eased by President Clinton's disclosure in a phone conversation with King Hussein on Wednesday that the United States would release $30 million in 1993 aid to Amman that had been frozen, now that Jordan and Israel have signed a negotiating agenda for their part of the Middle East peace talks.
Rather, the Jordanians watch in despair as the United States and Europe talk about raising hundreds of millions of dollars for the Palestinians, and never mention Jordan, which they say is still paying for its pro-Iraq sympathies during the Persian Gulf war.
 
'Wretched Gulf War'
 "I am excluded from the discussion, and have been since that wretched gulf war," said Crown Prince Hassan, heir to the throne. "But you can't continue to ignore us at the same time you expect us to participate."
But in Israel and the territories, economists and business leaders argue that the realities of the last quarter of a century cannot be made to disappear with a finger snap. The economic fate of Gaza and the West Bank has been tied to Israel since the 1967 Middle East war. Those links will have to be maintained and perhaps even thickened, they say, if Palestinians are to see immediate economic benefits that may go far to determine whether the new peace plan succeeds or fails.
Day to day, these experts assert, it means that tens of thousands of Palestinians from the territories must be allowed into Israel to work, even though some Israelis may raise security objections. And cheap Palestinian agricultural products and textiles must have access to markets in Israel, even though Israeli farmers and factory owners are sure to protest a lowering of protectionist barriers that have shielded them from competition.
 
'Like Siamese Twins'
 "To me, the two economies are like Siamese twins," said Danny Gillerman, president of the Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce. "If you separate them, one of them will die, and it is obvious that that one will be the Palestinian economy."
A continuing Israeli refrain to the Palestinians goes like this: Our $60 billion-a-year economy dwarfs yours of $3 billion, about one-third of which depends on income earned in Israel. In short, you need us more than we need you, for at the start you will not have the wherewithal to export products on your own to Europe and beyond. And don't expect much help from Arab countries in terms of jobs and markets, including Jordan, which has a gross national product of only $3.7 billion a year, on a per-capita basis smaller than even that of impoverished Gaza.
"For growth, the Palestinians must have open borders with Israel," said Prof. Haim Ben-Shahar, an economics consultant who supervised a Finance Ministry study on the subject that is likely to become Government policy. "They can compete with Israel in areas like agriculture, textiles and plastics because of cheap labor. That advantage disappears for them if they want to market their goods in Jordan."
In the territories, widespread mistrust of Israel remains, a concern that the Israelis' real goal is to perpetuate through relative economic power the dominance that they have maintained by military force since capturing Gaza and the West Bank in 1967.
Nonetheless, Palestinian economists agree with their Israeli counterparts that the establishment of Palestinian self-rule cannot be accompanied by an economic parting of the ways.
"Linkage in a state of mutual dependency is practically inevitable," said Prof. Hisham Awartani, an economics professor at An Najah University in the West Bank city of Nablus. But results must come quickly, he added.
 
How Much Money Is Needed?
 In the last few weeks, as the peace agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization moved startlingly from implausible rumor to signed reality, considerable attention has been focused on how many billions of dollars will have to be poured -- and from where -- into the territories to meet basic needs like water, housing, health care and sewers.
Housing is especially critical in overcrowded Gaza, a narrow coastal strip with some 800,000 residents, including 350,000 who are squeezed into eight main refugee camps.
The camps have existed for decades, held forth by Palestinians and Arab states as living symbols of their loss of land to Israel when it came into being in 1948. But now that the P.L.O. recognizes Israel, it in effect has acknowledged that those refugees and their children and grandchildren are in Gaza to stay, and therefore the camps lose their significance.
 
Thousands of Apartments
 This means tearing down the camps and building tens of thousands of new apartments, and that will be expensive -- not to mention the cost of other basic elements of infrastructure.
A World Bank report estimates that, in all, $3 billion will be needed over the next eight years for both Gaza and the West Bank. Far more ambitious is a P.L.O. plan that calls for an infusion of $11.6 billion by the year 2000, with $2.5 billion said to be needed right away to invigorate the anemic Palestinian economy.
President Clinton has already begun rattling the cup in front of probable donors like Western Europe, Japan and oil-rich Arab countries to put together an emergency fund of $590 million for start-up costs. Thus far, commitments have been scarce, although Scandinavian countries pledge $140 million in aid over the next four years and the European Community is considering a five-year package of loans and grants worth $600 million.
In the meantime, Jordan worries not only that it will see precious little of this aid but also that Palestinian money will move in a rush from the kingdom to the territories. The Government in Amman is considering restrictions on the amounts that depositors may withdraw from Jordanian banks. And officials there caution that a deterioration in living standards could have dire consequences for a country where unemployment is already at 25 percent and one-third of the 4.1 million people fall below the official poverty line.
In Israel and the territories, economists say that while the aid is obviously needed, it is hardly the sole solution. Professor Awartani and others also question the capacity of the territories -- with a gross national product of only about $1,800 per capita, compared with nearly $11,000 per capita in Israel -- to absorb and administer the bundles of sudden cash being discussed.
"I'm not saying that money isn't important or that infrastructure isn't important," insisted Ezra Sadan, an Israeli economist and former senior official in the finance and agriculture ministries. "But access to markets is the key to the future."
The Finance Ministry draft report prepared by Professor Ben-Shahar says that there should be a free trade zone comprised of Israel and the territories, with no customs posts. This would not apply to Jordan, though, and the Jordanians do not like it.
The draft report also says that Palestinian laborers should be able to work in Israel.
 
Attacks on Israelis
 Left unclear was how many Palestinian workers should be permitted to enter Israel, a sensitive point here because it is linked to another pivotal issue: security.
After a wave of lethal attacks on Israelis in March, Israel closed off the territories, allowing in Palestinians only by special permit. The immediate effect was to cut off 100,000 or more Arab construction and farm workers from their only sources of livelihood.
Little by little, the travel ban has been eased, to a point that about 50,000 Palestinians now commute on weekdays to jobs in Israel. The Finance Ministry report says that one option is to double that figure, although it adds that a reduction is also possible. Either way, its point is that Palestinians must be allowed to work inside Israel.
Left unsaid is what would happen if the result of this free movement is another wave of violence.
"We are living in the Middle East," said Samir Huleileh, a Palestinian economist, "where politics determines most things, and not necessarily economics."

HEADLINE: West Is Welcoming Reformer's Return in Moscow

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Western diplomats and economists today welcomed former Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar's return to government as a desperately needed bolstering of support for market-oriented policies in the badly divided administration.
President Boris N. Yeltsin acted under considerable pressure from the United States and international lending institutions like the International Monetary Fund, the diplomats said. Some wondered whether Mr. Yeltsin was once more responding to a crisis by an essentially symbolic gesture. 
 "But I can't imagine that anyone in the West would be unhappy that Gaidar is back," a senior diplomat said. "There are real problems to be solved, and Gaidar at least can understand them."
The diplomats also expressed relief that the central-planning minded Economics Minister, Oleg I. Lobov, an old Yeltsin friend, is being moved aside. "If Yeltsin had sided with Lobov, it would have been a big step back from Russia's break with Communism," a diplomat said.
Inflation surged to 29 percent in August, up from about 20 percent in June and July, partly because of seasonal agricultural credits. With Mr. Yeltsin seemingly unable to decide on a clear course, the Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, had been widely said to be planning to resign.
 
Western Aid in Balance
 That would have been an enormous symbolic blow and would have caused concern in the West, which is trying to justify giving Russia more than $40 billion in loans, grants and debt relief this year alone. Aides to Mr. Fyodorov said today that he would stay on.
Russian officials said today that the Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, also favored the return of Mr. Gaidar. Mr. Chernomyrdin, an industrialist, is said to understand the inflationary danger of too high a budget deficit, and he was seeking a more respected buffer in the Government against demands from enterprises and Parliament for extra spending. Mr. Chernomyrdin said today that Mr. Gaidar would be part of a team and would have to keep "a single basic line."
Mr. Gaidar, who was dropped as acting Prime Minister by Mr. Yeltsin in December in the face of parliamentary opposition, will become one of three First Deputy Prime Ministers, Mr. Yeltsin said Thursday. But his friends say he will be in charge of economic policy or would not have agreed to return.
The Russian officials stressed that Mr. Lobov would be moved out of Government to an advisory post in Mr. Yeltsin's office. Mr. Lobov has been pushing since May for much more state regulation and the empowerment of his ministry as the chief planning center for the economy.
His proposals have been resisted by the small core of reformers that remain in the Cabinet, especially Mr. Fyodorov, and the Privatization Minister, Anatoly B. Chubais. But even Western diplomats who try to see the bright side of the Russian situation acknowledged that Mr. Lobov's feud with Mr. Fyodorov had created a paralysis in the Government and symbolized the split between Soviet-style central planners and Gaidar-style reformers.
"A lot of work is simply not being done inside the Government, and a lot of issues have been unresolved," a diplomat said. "It's been a form of paralysis."
 
I.M.F. Team in Moscow
 An important team from the International Monetary Fund is in Moscow now, deciding whether to recommend the release of $1.5 billion more in transitional funds to Russia even under a relaxed set of conditions. Fund officials in Washington said they had expected a sharply negative report before the announcement of Mr. Gaidar's return.
Senior United States officials, however, pushing the Fund to be as understanding as possible with Russia, said the new money was still a possibility before the end of the year. "We're trying to create a stepladder of reform and economic stabilization," an official said, instead of "erecting a wall" of impossible conditions.
The next few weeks would be crucial, the senior official said, amidst higher inflation than many hoped and "disturbing signs of further credit growth." Russia's most important task was to limit its budget deficit, he said. Almost as important was to control new credits from the Central Bank. The West also wants significant progress in structural reform, he said, and a reduction of export controls, to enable Russia to earn more hard currency.
But the officials said Russia would not meet an Oct. 1 deadline for a more formal standby agreement with the Fund. That failure would allow Western nations in the so-called Paris Club of creditors to pull back from an agreement to reschedule Russia's $70 billion to $80 billion of debt, most of it inherited from the Soviet Union.
In fact, the diplomats said, creditors would gain little by increasing Russia's debt and making it impossible for Moscow to pay. Moscow is already slow at paying rescheduled debt and American agricultural loans, for instance.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Reviewing Cable TV Rates As Rollbacks Turn Into Increases

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Six months after the Federal Communications Commission promised cable television customers $1 billion in annual rate rollbacks, the agency conceded today that cable rates seem to be rising, as many consumers have argued.
"It's obvious there's a problem, but we'll have to find out the extent of it," said James H. Quello, the acting chairman of the commission. Amid a torrent of complaints from angry consumers and members of Congress, the F.C.C. announced that it would start a detailed survey of the prices charged by the 25 biggest cable companies. 
 The F.C.C. is giving the companies just two weeks to respond, and Mr. Quello acknowledged that the results might force his agency to rewrite the foot-high stack of rules it just finished painstakingly drawing up.
The announcement amounts to a big embarrassment for F.C.C. officials, who until now strongly denied there was any problem. Indeed, in recent weeks Mr. Quello and other officials have issued several blunt statements insisting that any price increases for some customers were more than offset by declines for others.
The new rate regulations, which took effect on Sept. 1, were issued in response to legislation Congress passed last October to rein in price increases and force cable companies to improve their service. Since the cable television industry was deregulated in 1986, cable prices had been climbing at more than twice the rate of inflation -- in part because all but a handful of systems enjoy monopoly franchises.
The new rules set up a complicated system of "benchmark" prices, and F.C.C. officials had predicted that they would force rate reductions of more than 10 percent for about two-thirds of all cable systems.
But it has not necessarily worked that way, as consumers have been discovering in the last few weeks. Virtually reversing what the F.C.C. had intended in writing the new rules, prices for basic and expanded services have gone up at many companies, while the costs of options like additional outlets have gone down.
In New York City, for example, Time Warner Cable shaved the price of its most basic package by 24 cents a month, to $14.71, while increasing the additional charge for its expanded service by 87 cents, to $8.87, according to the city's Department of Telecommunications and Energy. The combined total monthly rate increased to $23.58 from $22.95.
As consumers started to receive the new price lists by mail, they started flooding members of Congress with complaints. Aides to Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who led the House fight to reregulate cable, said they had received 50 to 75 calls a day from consumers in the last few weeks. Even before today's F.C.C. announcement, Mr. Markey had scheduled a hearing on the matter for Sept. 28.
 
 
Legislators Urged a Review
 Mr. Markey and Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican, have been circulating a "Dear Colleague" letter in the House demanding that the F.C.C. revisit its rules. Nearly 100 lawmakers have signed the letter so far.
Congressional staff members said the F.C.C.'s new rate survey was, if anything, overdue. "What this survey shows is that the F.C.C. is at least having second thoughts that this is not working out the way they thought it would," said Gerry Waldron, senior counsel to the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications. "The survey itself will tell us the extent of the problem."
Mr. Quello recently got his own taste of consumer anger. As a guest on a call-in radio program in Detroit this month, he faced a barrage of complaints from residents upset about cable prices.
Officials of Time Warner, the nation's second-biggest cable operator, after Tele-Communications Inc., said they would cooperate with the F.C.C.'s inquiry.
"We think it is perfectly appropriate for the F.C.C. to gather information about how we are complying with the statute, and we will pledge our full cooperation," said Tim Boggs, a lobbyist for the company in Washington.
But it may be hard to determine where rates really stand for the nation's customers. For one thing, the regulations play out differently for each of the nation's 11,000 cable franchises, and the customers of one system may get rate cuts while prices go up for those in an adjacent town.
 
 
A Complicated Approach
 Public anger over cable prices had led Congress to pass the cable bill last year over President George Bush's veto. The law set out a complicated approach to lowering prices. The F.C.C was directed to issue and enforce guidelines that would lead cable operators to charge rates comparable with those in the handful of competitive markets.
To do this, the F.C.C. came up with a staggering collection of benchmark prices, which varied depending on the number of channels offered and the number of customers.
But these benchmarks were total prices for all of the services the companies could offer. As a result, many companies found they could stay within the guidelines by dropping their highest prices for the fanciest level of service while raising the charges for more basic service.
The result has been confusion.
In general, the biggest reductions are going to people who subscribe to the most lavish monthly packages, have more than one cable outlet in the home and rent remote-control devices. Figuring out the net result requires calculating how many customers fall into these rough categories.
Tele-Communications told financial analysts this summer that rate regulation would cost it about $160 million, or 4 percent of its total revenue. Time Warner has said it will give up from $90 million to $100 million.
 Regardless of the new survey's findings, there is a growing consensus that the rules have had at least one unintended result: they seem to be helping relatively affluent people who buy fancy service while hurting the people who buy bare-bones packages, who are likely to be poorer.
Some Congressional critics say regulators may have misfired in their basic calculations.
"The F.C.C. set the benchmark prices too high," Representative Shays said in an interview. "Its own analysis showed that cable systems that face effective competition have prices that are 30 percent lower than those that don't, but the benchmark prices are only 10 percent lower."
Since the rules were adopted, agency officials have acknowledged this point. But they say they had no choice, because the law passed by Congress includes a peculiar definition of "effective competition" that includes cable systems with very low market penetration and systems owned by municipalities.

HEADLINE: Premium Limits In Health Plan Draw Criticism

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office warned today that one of the most important elements of President Clinton's health plan, Federal limits on private health insurance premiums, could harm consumers by forcing a reduction in valuable medical care and restricting access to new medical technology.
More than any other factor, it is the soaring cost that has ignited public interest in efforts to overhaul the nation's medical system. Mr. Clinton asserts that his proposal would control costs primarily by encouraging competition in the health care market. 
 But to guarantee savings, his plan calls for Federal regulation of private health insurance premiums and a national limit on overall health spending, public and private.
 
'Difficult to Design'
 In its report, the Congressional Budget Office said Federal regulation of insurance premiums "could be difficult to design and costly to put in place."
"Experience with price controls in other sectors demonstrates just how difficult it is to anticipate all of the possible market responses to controls and take them into account in developing enforcement mechanisms," the report said.
An Administration official, asked about the report, said, "It is not relevant to the Clinton plan because our proposal includes many safeguards to ameliorate the problems described by C.B.O."
The report was requested by Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, the California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. He asked for the study in December, before Mr. Clinton's proposal crystallized. Several members of Congress, including Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, had already endorsed the idea of regulating premiums.
The questions raised today by the Congressional Budget Office echo the concerns voiced by many economists. They say the Government lacks the expertise to set an overall budget for health care, a rapidly changing industry that accounts for a seventh of the nation's economy.
The Congressional Budget Office said it was not analyzing any specific legislative proposal but was assessing the feasibility of regulating premiums in general.
Moreover, the official, who spoke on the condition that he not be named, said the President's proposal for Government regulation of insurance premiums "is not difficult to enforce." Health plans that charge more than the amount allowed by the Government would have to pay a special assessment, he said.
But in an interview, Mr. Stark said: "I do not believe premium controls will work. If they did work, they might cause problems for patients and could adversely affect the quality of care."
Bill Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, said he, too, doubted that Federal regulation of premiums would work. "I don't think it would be an effective way to hold down health costs," he said. "It's like bombing at 35,000 feet. You don't know whether you're going to hit anything, and you don't know whether it will be friend or foe."
 
Series of Reports
 The report was prepared by economists and health policy analysts at the Congressional Budget Office, an influential, nonpartisan arm of Congress. It is one of a series of reports in which the agency will analyze proposals, by the President and members of Congress, to control health costs and guarantee care for all Americans.
Mr. Clinton will present his proposal in a speech to Congress on Wednesday. White House officials say he has decided not to impose direct price controls on doctors, hospitals, drug companies and other health care providers.
Instead, he will propose Government regulation of insurance premiums, on the theory that insurers will crack down on waste and fraud and limit payments to doctors and hospitals.
If the cost-control efforts of insurance companies reduce unnecessary or inappropriate care, "consumers generally would be better off," the Congressional Budget Office said.
"But," it said, "efforts to reduce unnecessary care would almost certainly have the effect of eliminating some useful services; thus, some individuals might be worse off even if consumers on the whole were made better off."
If limits on premiums are set too low, the study said, insurers and providers may react by restricting access to medical care and to costly new medical technology.
President Clinton's proposal relies on health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care, which seek to control costs through closely supervising doctors and directing patients to selected physicians.
The Congressional Budget Office said that when insurers react to limits on insurance premiums by expanding the use of managed care they may achieve a "one-time reduction in health care costs but may not reduce the rate of growth in health spending over the long run."
 
Premiums' Path
 Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, most people in a particular area would pay the same premium, regardless of their medical problems. The payments would be sent to health insurance purchasing groups, or regional alliances, which would sign contracts with health plans, composed of doctors, hospitals, clinics and insurance companies.
White House documents say that payments to health plans would be adjusted to reflect factors like "age, gender, health status and services to disadvantaged populations."
For example, a health plan would receive more money for managing the care of a person with AIDS than for a young, healthy worker. But the Congressional Budget Office said there was no reliable method of calculating premiums in advance, to take account of the risks presented by various patients.
Consumers Union told the White House today that it was concerned about another facet of Mr. Clinton's proposal. The consumer group said Mr. Clinton offered "too little protection to low-income families and individuals."
In a letter to Mr. Clinton, Rhoda H. Karpatkin, president of Consumers Union, said his proposal might require some people to spend more than 5 percent of their incomes on health insurance premiums.
"At a minimum," she said, "it is essential that families' and individuals' premiums be capped at a level of about 2 percent of income."

HEADLINE: U.S. Housing Errors Take Financial and Human Toll

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The walls cracked, the roof leaked, the foundation sank and the sewage boiled up into the bathtubs.
Rents fell and repair costs rose, but the owners of the sprawling, private apartment complex did not bear the burden. They had a Government-insured mortgage, so when they failed to repay their $9.5 million loan, the Government did so for them. 
 That was in 1975. In the 18 subsequent years, Roxse Homes has become a symbol of the human and financial losses in one of the Government's most troubled housing programs.
It has languished in a netherworld of Federal mismanagement, with its ownership contested, its maintenance uncertain, its court battles unending and many of its hundreds of tenants aggrieved.
 
Many May Follow
 This may be a harbinger. In the next few years, the Department of Housing and Urban Development is expecting hundreds of other apartment building owners to follow suit and default on Government-insured mortgages.
The defaults are expected to cost taxpayers as much as $11.9 billion, and they could bring hundreds of thousands of apartments into the hands of the Housing Department, which, by its own admission, has a track record of watching them sink into slums.
The 13 sad, sagging buildings that constitute Roxse Homes offer a particularly striking example of what can go wrong in the loan-guarantee program after an owner defaults.
After almost two decades, the Government has still not received a penny of repayment from the owner, a nonprofit corporation founded by a group of ministers. The Government has not seized the property through foreclosure, though it has pursued a host of other, failed strategies.
And it has not got what its auditors consider a satisfactory accounting of millions of dollars in rent and rehabilitation money that year after year remained under the owners' control.
 
Deterioration Goes On
 The apartments, meanwhile, have continued to deteriorate, through a blizzard of lawsuits and contested subpoenas, tax breaks to wealthy investors and rent strikes by angry tenants. The Government estimates that the apartments now need at least $15 million in new repairs and millions of dollars a year in new operating subsidies.
Department officials refuse to discuss the case while it remains in litigation, but they have been blunt in acknowledging the problems of the mortgage insurance program in general. Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros has called the management of the defaulted buildings "the single largest problem" in a department rife with neglectful practices.
"HUD's management of its own inventory has been abysmal," Mr. Cisneros told the Senate in a June hearing. By allowing the properties to deteriorate, Mr. Cisneros said, the department had "exacerbated the declining quality of life in urban America."
That is an opinion quickly seconded by some of the Roxse tenants, who fault HUD for letting the situation drag on for decades. "If you own a home and don't pay the mortgage, is the bank going to let you sit there for 20 years?" said Nate Maddox, vice president of the tenant council.
 
To Encourage Lenders
 The mortgage insurance programs are designed to increase the nation's housing supply, by encouraging lenders to make loans they would otherwise consider too risky.
The department now backs $43 billion in such mortgages, covering 15,000 projects with approximately 1.8 million apartments. Because of downturns in the real estate market and its own acknowledged mismanagement, the department expects 27 percent of those loans to default, costing taxpayers $11.9 billion.
The Government insures about 750 apartment buildings in New York City and elsewhere in southern New York State. A recent audit by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand found 33 percent of them in danger of default.
Roxse Homes illustrates the perplexing situation the Government faces after an owner defaults. The department can try to foreclose on the property, seizing it from the owners and reselling it to recoup its losses.
But it seldom does so. That is partly because foreclosure brings hefty financing and management fees. And it is also because a Federal law requires HUD to attach expensive new operating subsidies to foreclosed properties, to be sure that they remain affordable to tenants with modest incomes.
 
Avoiding Foreclosure
 Instead of foreclosing, the Government usually tries to arrange a repayment schedule with the owners, as it did with Roxse Homes. But after 18 years, Roxse's owners have not repaid a cent, arguing that operating expenses consume all its income.
"The project has not produced sufficient income," said James E. Cofield Jr., a Boston businessman who has been the unpaid chairman of the Roxse board since the early 1970's, when he was recruited by the local ministers who founded the nonprofit corporation.
Mr. Cofield blames HUD for the project's problems. He said the department oversaw its flawed construction, resisted rent increases and refused to provide necessary operating subsidies. But a 1989 report from the department's inspector general said that the board had misused Roxse's money, incurred "unnecessary costs" and "did not always act in the best interest of the project."
Roxse was in peril from the start. The construction company hired by the board did not adequately prepare the site, which had been landfill. The foundations settled, causing walls to crack, roofs to leak and sewage lines to rupture.
 
Behind on the Mortgage
 Twenty-two of the project's 364 units were uninhabitable from the time the construction was completed in 1972. As income sagged and expenses rose, the project quickly fell behind on its mortgage payments. In 1975, the bank invoked the Federal insurance, and HUD paid off the $9.5 million mortgage in full.
Roxse then agreed to begin making payments to HUD, though it never did so. Roxse did, however, sue the builder and architect, winning $2.2 million in 1979 to fix the construction defects.
While some improvements were made, the settlement also inaugurated a new phase of financial warfare between the Government and the apartment owners. Mr. Cofield and the board retained control over the money, which was spent not only on roofing and sewer repairs but also on unrelated legal expenses,including a campaign to prevent a highway from being constructed nearby. Mr. Cofield argues that the expenses were proper since the highway would have harmed the quality of neighborhood life.
When HUD sought control of the money, Roxse transferred it into a confidential account kept by the project's lawyer. And when the inspector general subpoenaed documents relating to the expenses, including board minutes and contracts, Roxse fought the effort in court. The court ordered Roxse to turn over some, but not all, of the documents.
Without the documents, the auditors could not complete their work. But their limited inquiry did find that "the project was burdened with unnecessary costs."
 
Accusing the Auditors
 Mr. Cofield accuses the auditors of harassment. "There is no expenditure that we have ever made that we think was improper or not in the interest of the tenants," he said.
As the fight for financial control wore on, HUD was pursuing a new strategy to make Roxse financially viable. In 1984, it gave preliminary approval to a plan to transfer ownership to a pair of California investors.
The partners, James C. Johnson and Barton Schuman, would raise repair money by selling ownership shares to passive investors, who could claim tax breaks. Roxse would contribute $1.7 million of the settlement money. HUD would contribute new operating subsidies.
But the deal began to fall apart when Roxse refused to turn over its share of the money. When a Superior Court judge ordered Roxse to produce documents relating to the fund, Roxse first refused. Then it produced edited documents, including photocopies of checks with essential information, like the bank's name, whited out.
Mr. Cofield said he resisted because the California investors had backed away from a verbal agreement to leave the board in control. "We were in no way trying to hide anything," he said. But citing a "clear violation" of his order, the judge in 1986 ordered the deed transferred to the California investors.
Another legal battle ensued, dragging on so long that the tax laws and HUD policies changed, making the deal less attractive to the investors. In 1990, they gave back the property, leaving Mr. Cofield and the Roxse board in charge.
Roxse, meanwhile, was collecting $1.7 million a year in rent but had still not made any mortgage payments to HUD. Mr. Cofield said the entire amount was needed to pay operating expenses.
In 1991, HUD finally moved to foreclose on the property. Roxse is resisting with a novel legal argument: that if the Government really cared, it would have seized the property long ago.
"If they were so concerned about safe housing, why didn't they do something about it?" said Henry Owens, Roxse's lawyer. The board is seeking to retain title to the property and is asking HUD for as much as $20 million to fix up the buildings, arguing that only the Government has enough money for repairs. "We know HUD is the fat cat in town," Mr. Cofield said.
The Government won a preliminary battle in December, when a Federal court gave it day-to-day control of the project. Though the Government lacks the property deed, this gives it the right to collect rents and pay the bills. The action occurred after the gas company threatened to cut off the heat because of $109,000 in unpaid bills.
Mr. Cofield is vowing to fight on, saying he has only the community's interest in mind. "I have not received one penny in any shape or form in 23 years," he said. "It's just a desire to do something for the neighborhood."
HUD officials say the Roxse fight is lengthy but not unprecedented.
"The projects seem to be caught in an extended never-never-Land," said Nicolas Retsinas, who as the new Federal Housing Commissioner now presides over the loan-guarantee program. In the future, he said, "we need to get off the dime."

HEADLINE: New Missile Defense in Japan Under Discussion With U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Concerned about North Korea's recent tests of a new generation of missiles, Japan and the United States have begun discussions about developing and deploying a new antimissile system on Japanese soil to deter short-range attacks.
Preliminary talks about combining technological talents to build the system, which would be a major expansion of the postwar military relationship between the two countries, were held this week in Honolulu. But Japanese officials say they expect to receive a fuller American proposal next week, during a visit to Tokyo by John M. Deutch, the Pentagon's Under Secretary for Acquisition and Technology.
 
Existing Missile System Aging
 American and Japanese officials say the new system may include major improvements on an existing antimissile system, like the Patriot, combined with some kind of satellite detection system that would warn of an attack. 
 Japan's only missile defense is an aging first-generation Patriot missile system. More advanced versions of the Patriot, the kind used with mixed success against Iraqi attacks in the Persian Gulf war, are not scheduled for deployment until around 1995. Most experts say it would not be very effective against the newly developed North Korean missile, the Rodong 1.
The plan could pose some very tough decisions for the coalition Government headed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. The largest party in the coalition, the Socialists, have historically opposed any expansion of the powers of the Japanese military and never recognized Japan's 33-year-old security pact with the United States.
 
Similar Aid to NATO Allies
 Military experts here say an advanced missile defense system could raise additional political problems. The Japanese Government has always shied away from making use of any kind of satellite detection system -- which it has rejected as a violation of its self-imposed ban on using space for military purposes. The country has no spy satellites of its own; it relies almost entirely on the United States for satellite intelligence.
In Washington, a senior Defense Department official said this week that Mr. Deutch would try to lay the groundwork for an agreement in which Japan would develop its own antimissile defense, known as a theater missile defense system, with American assistance. Similar aid has been extended in the past to NATO allies.
"We would enter a cost-sharing agreement with them, but the point is that they couldn't do this themselves," the senior official said. "This is potentially a very different approach to our security relationship with Japan."
But the Japanese have many reservations about the system, and some suggest that Washington has been pushing the idea far harder than Tokyo.
Recently Shigeru Hatakeyama, the Vice Minister of Japan's Defense Agency, was quoted in Japanese newspapers as saying that a jointly developed missile plan might run afoul of Japan's restrictions on collective security efforts, even with longtime allies like the United States.
 
Concern About North Korea
 "There is obviously great interest in defense circles about this, but Mr. Hosokawa has to be very careful," said Masashi Nishihara, the head of research at Japan's National Institute for Defense Studies. "There will be a lot of opposition, and of course the coalition is very fragile. But of course, there is also great uneasiness on everyone's part about what the North Koreans are building."
During the cold war, Japan had no real missile defenses of its own. The biggest threat was believed to come from the Soviet Union, and the country's deterrent was the American nuclear umbrella. But in the last two years, amid growing evidence that North Korea has been developing nuclear weapons and a missile that could deliver them, Japanese officials have begun rethinking the nature of the country's defense.
So has the United States: the topic was reportedly raised briefly on Thursday when the new American Ambassador to Tokyo, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, met with officials of Japan's Foreign Ministry for the first time. Mr. Mondale took up his post here earlier in the week.
Missile defenses took on new urgency for Japan at the end of May, when North Korea first tested the Rodong 1, a missile it has been developing for years and is reportedly preparing to export to Iran. The test took place along Sea of Japan, with the missile apparently aimed at a buoy off Japan's Noto Peninsula, which juts into the sea on Japan's northwestern coast. American officials say that they have not been able to determine how well the missile performed, but that it flew about 300 miles, or half the distance it is thought to be designed to cover.
Central Intelligence Agency officials have said in Congressional testimony that the agency believes that the missile could be fitted with nuclear warheads if North Korea's nuclear weapons program ever bears fruit.
The Sea of Japan test has become almost an obsession for some Japanese officials, who described it as a direct threat from the country's most unpredictable neighbor. But other Japanese and American officials say that the Communist Government of North Korea intends to sell the missile rather than use it. In the end, they argue, hard currency is worth far more to the nearly bankrupt Communist Government than any offensive power.
Others argue that the missile, if produced, would give the North Koreans another card in their uneasy standoff with the West, creating a way for the North to threaten that any conflict on the Korean Peninsula could spill over elsewhere in Asia.
 
New Satellite Technology
 While several options are being discussed, a new missile defense system for Japan would probably involve a considerable amount of new technology, linking the system to one or more satellites that could detect a launching. Japan studied similar systems in the Pacific in the 1980's, as an adjunct to the Strategic Defense Initiative. This system, in contrast, would be far smaller in scale. "It would still be very expensive," one American official said recently, "and the presumption is that Japan would pay for much of it."
But the Japanese are pleading poverty. With the economy in worse shape here than in anyone's recent memory, the military's budget is not expected to expand more than about 2 percent, and perhaps far less. In the 1980's it regularly expanded 6 percent or more annually. A few military officials here concede that the North Korean threat has given the agency its best argument yet in favor of expanding its budget, and that reason alone could propel talks about building the new system.

HEADLINE: Whitman Finds Her Voice in New Jersey Race

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman has surfaced. After a long and leisurely summer, the Republican gubernatorial candidate has hit the road in her campaign to unseat Jim Florio, trailing a big-name Republican consultant, a staff of exuberant young aides and two unwelcome guests.
"It's just dumb, it's silly," Mrs. Whitman said during a drive to a Mercer County campaign stop this week, talking about the two fresh-faced workers from the Governor's campaign who shadow her across the state, waiting for slips of the tongue. She neglected to mention that Republican workers sometimes shadow Mr. Florio for the same reason. 
 "All I can think," she said, "is that they must be bored, because they hear the same thing in every speech."
Indeed, Christine Todd Whitman is a paragon of consistency on the stump. She may tailor her speech to fit the occasion -- discussing the importance of placing more women in public office with the North Jersey Association of Female Executives, for example.
But the heart of Mrs. Whitman's stump speech is always the same. Often vague, sometimes hard to discern, but always the same:
New Jersey is a great state. Mr. Florio has been a poor Governor. His $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990 devastated the economy, drove business from the state and cost thousands of people their jobs. His administration is pro-tax, anti-business and a barrier to efforts to streamline government. Her administration would be the opposite.
"I believe the only thing we have missed in order to be a leading state in the nation is the leadership that recognizes the fact that we can be that way, but only if we bring everyone into the process," she said to a group of public administrators, government accountants and public managers in Hamilton Township.
"I believe we're at a crossroads," she told about 80 members of the New Jersey Concrete and Aggregate Association at a Holiday Inn in Jamesburg in Middlesex County. "We can continue with a policy of tax and spend, or we can move into a policy that looks to cut and save. We can continue with a policy that says we're putting economic obstacles in the way of doing business, that government is the answer to everything, or move to a policy that says we want business, and government should be a partner to facilitate business."
And, she tells nearly every audience she addresses, "New Jersey is a state that should be No. 1 in the nation -- not in unemployment, not in regulation and not in taxes, but number one in ideas and innovation and growth."
Mrs. Whitman, 46, is an accomplished campaigner though she has undergone only three other campaigns. She twice won election to the Somerset County Board of Chosen Freeholders, and in 1990 she metamorphosed from unknown Republican insider to credible statewide candidate when she nearly upset Bill Bradley, the state's United States Senator, in his re-election bid.
As she did in the 1990 race, Mrs. Whitman hopes to win undecided voters this year by reminding them of their anger over the $2.8 billion tax increase.
But even voters who do not like Mr. Florio say they want to hear more from Mrs. Whitman than a critique of the Governor. They want to know, specifically, what she would do if she were in his chair.
 
Warmer Than Florio
 At the same time, the voters who find she comes up short on details react warmly to her as a person, especially when they compare her with Mr. Florio, who can seem personally unbending.
Mrs. Whitman is personable without being personal, approachable if somewhat removed. Almost everyone who knows her calls her Christie, and many people who do not know her do the same.
On the way to an evening meeting at Cedar Gardens restaurant on Route 33 in Hamilton Township, Mrs. Whitman reviewed her speech, joked with her driver and discussed common acquaintances with her friend Edward Rollins, who ran Ronald Reagan's 1984 'Morning in America' campaign and who hopes to duplicate that success for Mrs. Whitman.
As the car pulled up to the restaurant, Mrs. Whitman waved to a sheepish Greg Orlando, one of the two Florio shadows, and joked, "Well, we know we're in the right place because there's Greg."
At most of her campaign stops, Mrs. Whitman takes pains to shake as many hands as possible, patiently working the room while her young aides hover about, trying to keep her on schedule.
Her typical speech lasts no longer than 15 or 20 minutes, is delivered without notes and lays the blame for everything from too much regulation to failing schools to dying businesses at Mr. Florio's feet without offering many specific solutions.
Consider this segment about education from a speech to the New Jersey Concrete and Aggregate Association:
"We seemed to have introduced politics into absolutely every phase of government. That's part of the problem we've seen in education. I know you've read the newspaper stories of the judges' decision recently on the Quality Education Act that said not only did we fail to solve the problem by throwing money at it, it was also unconstitutional.
 
'We're Cheating Our Children'
 "And you know there is a grand jury investigation going on in this state as to how some of that money was distributed, and was it used for political ends? Again, that's wrong. Because we're cheating our children and cheating our future. And we simply cannot allow politics to play a role when talking about something as important as education. We have got to make those decisions based on what's best for the children and what's best in policy, not what's best for politicians, even though I am the first to say I am one."
The only specifics Mrs. Whitman mentioned in the speech were her proposal for requiring economic impact statements before any new regulation is enacted -- something state agencies already do -- and her criticism of a 7 percent tax on heavy trucks that was included in Mr. Florio's tax plan but later repealed by the Legislature.
Voters are concerned about this vagueness about what Mrs. Whitman would deliver as governor.
"People are still angry with Florio, but people still haven't heard enough from Christie," said Michael Mitschele, who was at the concrete association meeting and who reported that many of his friends are undecided.
 
'So She Has Money'
 At least where Mrs. Whitman chose to campaign this week, people seemed to have little interest in the Florio campaign's attempt to paint her as wealthy and out of touch.
"That's not an issue to me," said Charles Sanders at a Hamilton Township campaign stop. "So she has money. So what?"
"She sounds good," said Loranna Nebel after hearing Mrs. Whitman speak there. "But can she follow through? We need some common sense. People in government don't have any common sense."

HEADLINE: Mayoral Report Credits Administration With Better Crime-Fighting and More Services

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins released his annual management report yesterday, saying the city had made gains in fighting crime and delivering services under his leadership. He used the opportunity to criticize Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to curtail services for some homeless people.
Pressing his re-election campaign against Mr. Giuliani, the Mayor said the improvements cited in the report, in areas ranging from lowering infant mortality to instituting citywide recycling, came despite economic constraints he said were brought on by the Reagan and Bush Administrations. 
 "What is especially noteworthy about this management report is that when economic push came to shove I did not allow the wholesale scuttling of essential service after essential service," Mr. Dinkins said, addressing reporters and top city officials, including several dozen heads of city agencies.
Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that the report cited several setbacks. For instance, narcotics arrests have fallen, ambulance response times have risen, fire response times are up in three boroughs, and there are more homeless people in hotels.
The 856-page report, prepared by Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, and Harvey Robins, director of the Mayor's Office of Operations, used 4,000 indicators to measure the delivery of city services. It covered the fiscal year running from July 1, 1992, through June 30 of this year.
"In bad times, you expect only bad news," Mr. Dinkins said. "But as this report demonstrates, six years of bad economic news has not translated into bad news across the board for city services."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Giuliani's campaign argued that under Mr. Dinkins's leadership, the quality of city government and life has declined.
"Our view is that the Dinkins-Steisel administration has provided one management bungle after another," said Richard Bryers, communications director for the campaign. "The quality of government service has declined, as has the quality of life."
Mr. Bryers said Mr. Giuliani advocated trimming the city's workforce and increasing bonus and incentive pay.
"The Mayor is spending $6 billion more a year than Mayor Koch was," Mr. Bryers said. "I think voters have a legitimate question as to whether that $6 billion is being spent wisely."
One issue of contention between the candidates is how to handle the problem of homelessness. The Mayor's report said the number of homeless families given temporary housing in fiscal 1993 was 5,695, up from 5,229 the previous year. Those in hotels have steadily risen, from 358 in fiscal year 1990 to 1,159 in fiscal year 1993, despite the administration's position that it would prefer homeless people in more permanent housing.
 
Homeless Advocates Upset
 Mr. Giuliani, who released a position paper on the issue Thursday, was criticized yesterday by advocates for the homeless, who were particularly upset by his proposal to limit the shelter stay for many to 90 days.
Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said it would organize a group of homeless people to confront Mr. Giuliani at least once a day at one of his public campaign appearances.
The position paper said the 90-day limit would allow the city to focus more of its limited resources on the "chronically homeless," including people who are drug-addicted, alcoholic, mentally ill and HIV-infected.
Mr. Bryers said the point of the proposal was to force the government to act within 90 days to put people into "appropriate housing and services." Mr. Giuliani was simply trying to get people out of shelters "so they can become independent."
But Mr. Dinkins said the proposal "demonstrates a lack of compassion and concern, or a lack of understanding. I think you will see a speedy retreat from this position by Mr. Giuliani."
Administration officials acknowledged they are still trying to reduce the number of homeless families in hotels. The process has been slowed, they said, by a lack of alternative housing sites, partly due to cuts in federal financing.
 
More Police Officers
 Mr. Dinkins's management report also noted that the number of uniformed police officers has risen above 30,000 for the first time since 1975 and that crime fell 7.2 percent the last fiscal year in the seven major categories monitored by the F.B.I.
But narcotics arrests fell by 4.4 percent to 50,266. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly attributed the drop to a decrease in the number of narcotics officers because of attrition and a diversion of officers to street patrol.
Now, he said, narcotics staffing levels are improving and arrests should go up.
The report also showed that average fire response time rose in Staten Island, Brooklyn and the Bronx, and fell in Manhattan and Queens. The longest response time was on Staten Island, where it was 5 minutes and 25 seconds, up by nine seconds.
The infant mortality rate dropped from 11.4 per 1,000 live births in calendar 1991 to 10.2 last year, the report said. Among the reasons cited was the opening of 12 community health centers.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Holtzman's Response to Loan Inquiry

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Elizabeth Holtzman's response to a New York City Department of Investigation report on an inquiry into a campaign loan to her from Fleet Bank. The report said that Holtzman was "grossly negligent" in failing to ascertain whether Fleet subsidiaries were doing or seeking business with her office.
 
Treatment by Fleet
Comptroller Holtzman got no special treatment from Fleet Bank. There is no finding in the D.O.I. report that either the interest rate on the loan to the Comptroller's Senate campaign or other loan terms were favorable or better than what any candidate for office could obtain. To the contrary, the D.O.I. report lists other campaign loans Fleet Bank made on similar or better terms.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Comptroller Holtzman did not get a favorable loan from Fleet Bank, so under the provisions of the City Charter, she was not obliged to determine if the bank was doing business with the City. Thus, the Comptroller was not negligent, let alone "grossly negligent." 

Terms of the Loan
D.O.I. did not find that the interest rate or other terms of the loan to the Holtzman for Senate campaign were favorable.
In fact, the terms of the loan were onerous. The effective annual interest rate on the loan, considering the original term and the $4,500 fee, was more than 18 percent. Fleet Bank's insistence on a personal guarantee exceeds the requirements of federal election law, which permits loans based solely on fund-raising pledges. Comptroller Holtzman was so opposed to the demand for a personal guarantee that she asked the Senate Campaign to seek another source for the loan. The Senate Campaign would have done so if time had permitted.
The D.O.I. report says that, according to Fleet's internal documents, campaign loans are undesirable. Despite this internal document, Fleet made several other loans similar to this campaign loan, some with lower interest rates.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The report states what the Comptroller has always said, that she was involved only in selecting the senior managers and in ensuring that minority- and women-owned firms were included among the underwriters selected. The report found no evidence that Comptroller Holtzman participated in or influenced in any way the City's choice of Fleet Securities as a co-manager.
The D.O.I. report did not find that the promotion of Fleet Securities was based on favoritism or any improper factor. Fleet, which had been part of the large group that sells the City's bonds, was one of 23 co-managers selected in a joint decision by the Mayor's Office and the Comptroller's Office. The Comptroller's staff recommended Fleet be promoted from the selling group because it sold more bonds than any other bank in its group.
The taxpayers of the city did not lose a single penny because of the selection of Fleet as co-manager. The cost of selling the city's bonds was not affected in any way. In fact, the City's bonds were recently sold at the lowest interest costs in 20 years. Due to innovations initiated by the Comptroller, refundings and lower interest rates, taxpayers have saved more than $800 million.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The D.O.I. report is only part of the process. The report does not include significant facts and also contains some factual errors. Comptroller Holtzman was not allowed to present witnesses, to offer information D.O.I. did not request or to question witnesses. In other words, Comptroller Holtzman was not given a chance to present her side of the story. That is a basic right of due process available to everyone under our democratic system. D.O.I. reports are normally kept confidential in part because, before the process is completed, public officials have not had an opportunity to be heard.
The D.O.I. report is now before the Conflicts of Interest Board (C.O.I.B.), which can accept or reject any part of it. During the C.O.I.B.'s process, Comptroller Holtzman will have a chance to present her side. It is important to understand that the D.O.I. report is preliminary step -- it is not the final determination.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The D.O.I. report relies on Comptroller Holtzman's attendance at a June 12, 1992, breakfast meeting with representatives of Fleet Securities as evidence that she knew that Fleet was seeking to do business with the City. During the summer of 1992, Ms. Holtzman met with well over 100 different groups in a very short period of time. Ms. Holtzman has said that, given that hectic schedule, she is not certain she was aware of the identities of the people at that specific breakfast. There is no finding by D.O.I. that Comptroller Holtzman in any way suggested that Fleet could have businesses as co-manager or special access to city business.
 
Press Release
The D.O.I. report states that "Fleet Securities was identified as one of the firms selected for co-manager in a press release announcing the selection of seior managers and co-managers." D.O.I. did not call as a witness Ms. Holtzman's press secretary, who would have testified that she prepared and issued the release without showing it to Ms. Holtzman.
 
Signature on Statement
D.O.I. mentions that the Official Statement, which is signed by the Comptroller, includes a list of the managers and co-managers on its cover. But it ignores the testimony of the Bureau Chief for Debt Management, who told D.O.I. that he went to City Hall where the Comptroller was testifying at a hearing and gave her the Official Statements to sign, already opened to the last page. Nor did D.O.I. note that the Comptroller would not normally read the long "boiler plate" official documents that accompany bond sales, since most of the language is standard and it has already been carefully checked by the City's and the underwriter's bond counsels. The Comptroller did not ". . . personally approve a 'tombstone,' which also listed Fleet Securities. . . ." The evidence shows that the Comptroller was not shown that "tombstone" -- the cover page of the Official Statement.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
For Municipal Bonds, Scandals Spur Change

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
THE report issued this week finding that Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman of New York City was "grossly negligent" in receiving a campaign loan from a bank she selected to underwrite city bonds was the latest episode in a series of political scandals roiling the $1.2 trillion municipal finance market.
Elsewhere, there have been allegations that Merrill Lynch & Company made illegal payments to a firm close to a top gubernatorial aide in New Jersey, and reports of illegal fee-splitting arrangements in municipal bond deals in Louisiana and Massachusetts. 
 What's a concerned investor to do? Flee the market in disgust?
 Aiming to silence suggestions that the municipal securities market is a corrupt game, the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, which oversees the market, is circulating a draft of two proposals designed to increase investor confidence.
Both proposals deal with disclosure: one requires more disclosure of political contributions by bond underwriters, and the other requires municipal bond issuers to report more to bond buyers about their financial condition.
Because individuals, either directly or through mutual funds, own more than 80 percent of the municipal bonds outstanding, how these proposals will affect investor sensibilities becomes a matter of real concern. Big buyers of municipal bonds say the effort can only help improve investor confidence -- especially among investors who look at more than interest rates.
"We judge each bond on its merits," said Anne Punzak, a municipal bond portfolio manager at Fidelity Investments, which has $25 billion in municipal bonds. "But, as a result of these scandals, there's an illusion of impropriety in the market, and that's not good. It's probably more of an illusion than actual. These rules may help to end it and make the market more liquid for all investors involved."
To be sure, few investors probably make any connection between political contributions and municipal bond investments -- so it is doubtful these rules, which must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, are a front-burner issue with all municipal bond buyers. Political contributions, after all, have nothing to do with a bond's creditworthiness.
Richard Moynihan, president of municipal bond funds at Dreyfus, which has $30 billion in tax-exempt securities, suggests the proposed rules could curtail contributions by bond underwriting firms to local politicians. At the least, he said, the rules would give the investing public "more comfort" that "everything is aboveboard."
The other proposal would oblige municipal issuers to continue providing financial information to bondholders after a bond is issued. "Investors are not receiving as much financial information as they are entitled to, and neither are the dealers selling to them," said Michael E. Dougherty, a partner at Dougherty Dawkins Strand & Bigelow, a Minneapolis bond dealer. "So an investor buying a bond in the secondary maket can have no idea of the current financial status of the issuer."
Christopher A. Taylor, executive director of the municipal rule-making board, said such financial disclosure was "fundamental to the market."
"Investors in bonds want to know what is happening to the bonds they are investing in," Mr. Taylor said. "The more financial information that is available about the underlying issuers in the market, the better the fund market is, too. This will make it easier even for someone as large as Fidelity to do research."
One well-known New York bond dealer, James A. Lebenthal, begs to differ. He contends that the new provisions would "just cut the legs out" from smaller, infrequent issuers -- "some swell little school district," he offers as an example -- that does not have the resources to keep detailed financial records. "There isn't a piece of information that you can't get by picking up the phone and calling the issuer," said Mr. Lebenthal, who heads a company that bears his name. "If there are nonrated mom-and-pop issues, the public has no business getting into these bonds. To get taken in this business, you really have to have a 'kick me' sign on you," Mr. Lebenthal said.
Jerry Jacobs, a vice president at the Vanguard Group, which has about $24 billion in municipal bonds, said, however, that firms like Mr. Lebenthal's would benefit the most from the new rules. "Big mutual funds have the money to pay for big research staffs," he said. "But down the line, smaller mutual funds and smaller investment companies might not have the same resources. This should help them."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lower Demand in London Pushes Down Copper Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Copper prices plunged yesterday to the lowest levels in four months as heavy demand for copper for immediate delivery suddenly eased on the London Metals Exchange.
In London, demand for delivered copper had pushed prices above those paid for future delivery, a situation that traders call a "backwardation." But that demand eased yesterday, traders said. 
 Without the unusual demand from London, copper prices will reflect high stockpiles and slow economic growth, traders said.
"The market is settling down to where the fundamentals indicate it should be," said Robert Lesemann, an analyst of base metals with Resource Strategies Inc. in Exton, Pa.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for December delivery fell 2.40 cents, to 78.65 cents a pound. In London, copper for immediate delivery fell $182 a ton, to $1,754, while December copper settled down $100 at $1,770 a ton.
One reason for yesterday's collapse was a move by the board of governors of the London Metals Exchange to impose a $5-a-ton limit on the amount that delivered copper could trade above copper futures. "It looks like the steps the governors' board have taken are working," Mr. Leseman said.
On other commodity markets, lumber futures shot up as much as allowed in a day amid fears that new duties imposed by the United States on Canadian lumber might escalate into a trade war. Lumber for November delivery gained $10, to $316.70 for 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
The United States imposed duties of 6.51 percent on Canadian softwood lumber in retaliation for Canadian provincial subsidies for producers. That duty rate is now being recalculated, and no one is yet sure what the new rate will be.
Oil prices ended higher, as traders became more optimistic that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would act to control production at their meeting in Geneva next week. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for October delivery gained 24 cents, to $17.07 a barrel. October heating oil rose 0.51 cent, to 51.92 cents a gallon, and October unleaded gasoline rose 0.66 cent, to 48.88 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Investors Await Japan's Trade Actions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies in light trading yesterday as investors waited to see if Japan would take further steps to calm trade tensions that have fueled the yen's advance this year.
Also yesterday, gold prices ended a three-day rally. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery dropped $1.90, to $351.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $350.75 an ounce, down $1.45. 
 Currency brokers said trading was quiet because of the Jewish holiday Rosh ha-Shanah and because the market was still digesting Tokyo's announcement Thursday of a stimulus package meant in part to shrink Japan's trade surplus.
"Right now the market is saying it's highly skeptical" that the package will be enough, said David De Rosa, a director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. He said the yen would remain in a tight range until it became clear whether Japan planned a further economic stimulus and whether Washington was satisfied with the Japanese actions.
 
Back to a Strong-Yen Policy?
 "On people's minds in the market was, 'Is this going to be a return to the strong-yen policy?" asked Win Thin, of MCM Currencywatch, an analysis service in New York.
The yen rose steadily against the dollar this year as traders perceived the United States Government as supporting a strong yen as a way to shrink Japan's trade surplus. A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive and foreign imports in Japan cheaper. In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 104.50 yen, from 104.15 on Thursday.
The dollar also rose against the German mark. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6154 marks, up from 1.6025 marks. Traders say the move may have been influenced by remarks by Guntram Palm, a member of the German central bank's policy-making Central Bank Council, who said German inflation would probably fall to an annual 3.5 percent by the end of the year from 4.2 percent now.
With lower inflation, Germany could drop its relatively high interest rates. Such a move could stimulate its recession-bound economy but would probably cause the mark to fall in value, since mark-denominated investments would earn less.

HEADLINE: A Consumer Index Is Flat

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index was essentially flat in September, edging up to 77.4, from 77.3 in August, people with access to the survey said yesterday.
The tiny gain was below economists' expectations. They expected the index to rise to between 77.5 and 79, said Fred Leiner, market strategist for Continental Bank in Chicago. 
 The index remains well below the post-election high of 91, in December. The index is based on 100, set in 1966. As consumers become more pessimistic about the economy, the monthly reading drops further below 100.
The university also reported that its preliminary September index of consumer expectations, which measures how people feel about their future, fell to 64.3, from 65.8 in August. The early September index of current economic conditions rose to 97.9, from 95.1 in August.
Since 1966, the record high for the sentiment index is 101, set in March 1984.

HEADLINE: Bonds Recoup Some of Early Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices bounced back from early losses yesterday as bargain hunters emerged once again when prices hit a daily low.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond ended down 5/32 point, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, edged up to 6.04 percent, from 6.03 percent on Thursday. 
 But the 10-year Treasury note gained 4/32 point while its yield slipped to 5.37 percent from 5.39 percent.
Intermediate Treasury maturities also rose by up to 4/32 point, while short-term Treasury prices were unchanged to 1/32 point higher.
Prices sank early in the session in what analysts said was a follow-through to some selling late Thursday.
But renewed demand from investors, particularly mutual fund portfolio managers, helped to arrest the price declines yesterday.
"There was some retail buying earlier in the morning when we got down to the lows; people started bottom fishing," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc.
Mr. Ricchiuto said investors largely shrugged off a University of Michigan survey showing that consumer confidence was virtually unchanged in early September. But some analysts said the confidence report was gloomier than expected and helped ease fears of rising inflation.
Those fears were fanned on Tuesday when the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent in August, the biggest increase since a rise of four-tenths of a percent in April.
"It looks like consumer spirits remain grim, and that's brought some buying into the market on a scattered basis," said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
Prices in the bond market have fallen and yields have risen through most of the week in a partial reversal of the recent powerful rally. The yield on the 30-year bond is still about one-half percentage point lower than it was six weeks ago. "The market is trying to catch its breath because the rally was so swift and pronounced," said Douglas Schindewolf, money market economist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
The rally's impact on interest rates elsewhere in the economy is still filtering through. Yesterday, two Midwestern banks, Harris Trust and Savings Bank and United Missouri Bancshares Inc., cut their prime lending rates one-quarter point, to 5 3/4 percent. Their moves brought to four the number of banks that have cut their prime rates this week.
Next week, the Treasury market digests its first auction of intermediate maturities in more than a month. The Treasury Department plans to sell $16 billion in two-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion in five-year notes on Wednesday.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index was unchanged yesterday at 1,329.20.
The discount rates on Treasury bills were also unchanged, with three-month bills at 2.94 percent, six-month bills at 3.06 percent and one-year bills at 3.25 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 105 1/8, down 1/16 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.46 percent, up from 5.45 percent.
