HEADLINE: Health Cost Payment in Ford Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The tentative labor contract negotiated this week between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union contains a provision under which workers would forgo a small portion of their wage increases partly to help pay for their health care.
According to one estimate, the change could be worth about $180 million to Ford over the life of the three-year contract, and $400 million to the General Motors Corporation should a comparable provision be negotiated there. Last year, Ford spent $1.5 billion on health care for its blue-collar workers. 
 Health care was one of the most hotly contested issues at the bargaining table this year. Owen F. Bieber, the U.A.W. president, repeatedly said the union would not ask its members to begin paying deductibles or co-payments toward their care, but Ford officials were equally adamant about finding a way to limit costs.
 
Taken From Quarterly Raise
 Union officials say they recognize that high health care costs impose a competitive burden on the Big Three.
As a result, the bargainers agreed to use an arcane maneuver common to recent agreements: essentially, the company keeps a few pennies from hourly wages that would otherwise have been paid as part of a quarterly cost-of-living increase.
The result is an overall savings to the company on its cost of labor. Union officials said, however, that part of their purpose in giving up the money was to defray the rising cost of health care.
Asked after announcing the agreement late on Wednesday whether the union had preserved its health care benefits, Mr. Bieber referred to his past statements on the subject, implying he had achieved his aims. He added, "I'll look at putting a couple of notes together" for the U.A.W. council that will review the agreement. "I won't have to spend a lot of time in some areas," he said.
Under the tentative agreement, the money will not come directly from workers' pockets, which makes it an easier concession to sell to U.A.W. members, who are expected to vote on the contract in the next two weeks.
"If it's money you didn't have before, you didn't give up anything," said Dan Luria, a senior fellow at the Industrial Technology Institute in Ann Arbor, Mich. "The implicit quid pro quo is that this was the trade for no co-pays or deductibles for current workers' health care."
According to Mr. Luria's calculations, the change works out to a savings of roughly $1,870 a worker over three years. That breaks down to about $52 a month -- the size of a reasonable copayment.
Aside from cost-of-living adjustments, the new contract calls for wage increases of about 3 percent a year. At Ford, an assembly-line worker now makes about $17.01 an hour.
The 1990 contract also had a cost-of-living giveback, but it was far smaller and had no explicit purpose. In 1973, the union gave back part of its cost-of-living raise to help pay for a new dental care benefit.
According to officials familiar with the provision, the savings to the company will amount to 32 cents an hour for each worker by the end of the three-year agreement.
Under the pact, the company would keep the 10-cent cost-of-living adjustment earmarked for each worker for the quarter just passed. Then it would keep 4 cents a quarter beginning the first quarter of the contract and another 4 cents beginning the quarter after that. Beyond that, the company would begin keeping another 2 cents for each of the next seven quarters.
Workers' wages would still have protection against inflation because a large portion of the Consumer Price Index, which is used to calculate the cost-of-living adjustment, reflects health care costs. Because health care is now fully paid by the company, the worker does not need inflation protection against that cost.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
The Dalai Lama, whom Tibetan tradition considers an incarnation of a divine figure, the Buddha of Compassion, is both a temporal and a spiritual leader.
Many people who meet him are unsure what protocol to observe. One visitor, explaining his nervousness to a young Buddhist monk some years ago, was reassured by the reply that the Dalai Lama "is a very laid-back deity." 
 And so he is. Two weeks ago, in a penthouse suite at the Palmer House in Chicago, the Tibetan spiritual and political leader was giving a handful of interviews. Monks stood in attendance, amid chairs and couches upholstered in a pale echo of their own dark maroon robes. Assistants in business suits spoke into cellular telephones and distributed copies of the Dalai Lama's letters to the Chinese Government.
As the Dalai Lama went from one interview to another, it would be inaccurate to say he moved in a pool of tranquillity. The special atmosphere of this Buddha of Compassion feels more like a gentle eddy of whimsy.
That was certainly true the evening before, when he spoke at an open-air session closing the Parliament of the World's Religions before 10,000 people at Grant Park. Like the Pope, he seemed to absorb and return the enthusiasm of a crowd. Sometimes he stumbled in his broken English and engaged his translator in amusing byplay. People who have heard the Dalai Lama frequently say that these riffs are not always as spontaneous as they appear.
His impishness on some issues drew laughter where the Pope might have prompted howls of protest. At one point the Dalai Lama began to discourse on birth control. All life is precious, he said, but "precious lives -- too many now." (Was that a shadow passing over the face of Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, seated on the stage?)
Of course, said the Dalai Lama, we must have "nonviolent birth control." For example, the Tibetan leader said, "more monks and more nuns."
Cardinal Bernardin joined in the laughter.
To an interviewer from an Indian television station, the Dalai Lama talked politics. No, he said, "The world is not forgetting Tibet." The Tibetan resistance has worldwide support because it is nonviolent, he said, and "this kind of freedom struggle must succeed so other people can adopt it."
He was asked, as he regularly is, about his feelings toward the Chinese Communists, who in 1949 enforced with troops what they claimed was a historical sovereignty over Tibet. The Communists exiled the Dalai Lama in 1959 after a national uprising and over the years have killed and imprisoned thousands of Tibetans, obliterated much of the land's religious patrimony and exploited its resources.
He answered as he always has: It is not only possible to overcome hatred, it is essential. "If our mind is dominated by hatred," he said, "the brain cannot make long-term and short-term judgments."
The Dalai Lama is convinced that China cannot resist the demand for freedom that swept away Communism elsewhere. Tibet, he believes, will not only be liberated but become a spiritual resource for post-Communist China.
These are hopes that fly against the immediate prospects. The Dalai Lama acknowledged that despite years of contacts with the Chinese Government, his diplomatic overtures have produced no results. The Dalai Lama has said that Tibetan people and their culture are being swamped by China's movement of ethnic Chinese into Tibet. Tibetans in exile assert that this policy of "demographic aggression" has recently been stepped up.
One of the Dalai Lama's greatest concerns has been the preservation of Tibetan Buddhist faith and culture in the face of oppression and exile. So how would he advise other religious leaders who believe that their communities, too, live in a kind of exile and confront a kind of oppression -- not of armed force and political ideology but of seductive materialism and cultural derision?
The Dalai Lama paused a long time before speaking. "I don't know how to answer," he said. "I always take the essential part of religion and culture -- what is truly useful in our daily live." This must be distinguished, he said, from "the ceremonial part and from social habit." The latter can change, he said. Indeed, he added, "in some cases it must; it must be transformed for new circumstances."
"Young Tibetans change their hair style, their behavior," he said. "I don't care, as long as they keep the spirit of Tibet and religion."
But what would he say to a growing number of religious leaders in the West who fear that without clear lines of demarcation, without a strong sense of a particular religious identity -- Catholic, Jewish, Presbyterian, Muslim, whatever -- their own traditions would be assimilated out of existence?
The Dalai Lama did not alter course in replying. "In my experience, there is too much emphasis on what is minor and not on what is essential," he said. And what is essential involves "being able to transform the individual from within." He called the strong feeling of "my" religion a danger and "the source of fundamentalism."
Perhaps the Tibetan spiritual master underestimates the other dangers nagging religious leaders. His people in diaspora remain tightly joined by language, culture, memory, family, economy and politics.
Nonetheless his answer was clear. Religious leaders determined to preserve their traditions should be less anxious about defining boundaries and more concerned about their faiths' power to bring about personal inner transformation. This was not mere whimsy.

ACROSS THE BRIDGE: Stories, by Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $19.) In these 11 lucid urban stories, most of which are set in Paris or Montreal, Mrs. Gallant's wit and exactitude subvert her old-fashioned material.
"DADDY'S GONE TO WAR": The Second World War in the Lives of America's Children, by William M. Tuttle Jr. (Oxford University, $30.) A historian finds that some "home front children" still feel indoctrinated in fright and hate, while others believe the war enhanced their understanding of this country and its culture.
EPSTEIN: Artist Against the Establishment, by Stephen Gardiner. (Viking, $35.) This polemical book defends at every point a major artist who all his life defied bourgeois conformity yet managed to die the proprietor of a knighthood.
HENRY JAMES' MIDNIGHT SONG, by Carol De Chellis Hill. (Poseidon/Simon & Schuster, $23.) A grand, ebullient novel, set chiefly in 1890's Vienna, where James, Freud, Jung and Edith Wharton are up to some naughty conduct.
LET THE SEA MAKE A NOISE ... : A History of the North Pacific From Magellan to MacArthur, by Walter A. McDougall. (Basic Books, $30.) Lively narrative, bold analysis and prodigious research adorn this popular history of a vast sea surrounded by mutually mistrustful peoples.
MUDDY BOOTS AND RED SOCKS: A Reporter's Life, by Malcolm W. Browne. (Times Books/ Random House, $23.) The memoir of a bold foreign correspondent who has seen 20th-century mayhem from Indochina to the Persian Gulf.
NEW YORK DAYS, by Willie Morris. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Mr. Morris's memoir of his star-crossed romance with Harper's Magazine, where he became editor in chief in 1967, just in time for the weirdest part of the 60's, and held on till 1971.
NO OTHER LIFE, by Brian Moore. (Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday, $21.) A brilliant meditative novel about a place that is and is not Haiti and a visionary who is and is not Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's once and future President.
NOT WHERE I STARTED FROM, by Kate Wheeler. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) This first collection of stories is about searchers shopping for enlightenment and the cross-cultural dislocations that come from such a hunt.
SECOND SIGHT, by Robert V. Hine. (University of California, $20.) A splendid personal account by the recipient of a miracle, a historian who slowly lost his eyesight and suddenly got it back.
A TIDEWATER MORNING: Three Tales From Youth, by William Styron. (Random House, $17.) The author's memory plays upon the painful moments of his life at the ages of 10, 13 and 20; the result is a trio of stories, each of whose sadness is multiplied by the presence of the others.
A VERY LONG ENGAGEMENT, by Sebastien Japrisot. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) In this evocative, outlandishly realistic French novel, a young woman pieces together how her fiance became a casualty of World War I.

HEADLINE: Boksburg's Goofy White Smiles

BYLINE: By Bill Keller; Bill Keller is the Johannesburg bureau chief for The New York Times.

 BODY:
IF YOU COLLECTED THE MOST outlandish caricatures of white South Africa and wrapped them in blue robes, the result, many South Africans would tell you, would be the Boksburg City Council. It is hard to imagine a more typecast assembly of unrepentant racists and sanctimonious ultrapatriots than the right-wing majority elected in 1988 to run this suburb on the eastern edge of Johannesburg's urban sprawl, and still running it three years into the era of F. W. de Klerk's reforms.
There are moderates on the Council. But they are barely audible in the company of such showmen as Beyers de Klerk, a real-estate agent and auctioneer who carries a pistol at his side and a Bible in his briefcase, copiously underlined to highlight the passages that prove God was against mixing the races. (He disavows any relationship to the other de Klerk, joking that the President's initials stand for "Farewell, white man.") 
 Councilman Koos van de Merwe is a bald prankster who, after President de Klerk announced the phasing out of apartheid, was caught defacing traffic signs to read "STOP F. W." Van de Merwe was also accused of being involved in the detonation of a mine in a crowded commercial bazaar last Easter. (The councilman said that he thought the bombing was a fine idea, but that he didn't do it.)
The women on the Council's right wing are less flamboyant but just as reactionary. Gloria Bosch led a campaign this year to prevent black athletes from using the city stadium. Stephanie Greyling tried to persuade the city to spurn a $200 million windfall from Taiwanese investors who chose Boksburg as the site for a Chinatown housing and commercial complex. Greyling worried the city would be overrun by tong cutthroats. "If I had my way, I'd send them all back to China," she says.
And so when Boksburg's most famous black resident was gunned down in his driveway on April 10, the last thing anyone expected from the City Council was a dignified response. Chris Hani was, after all, the leader of the Communist Party. While to blacks he was a charismatic figure, second in popularity only to Nelson Mandela, in the right-wing precincts of Boksburg he was regarded roughly the way Abu Nidal is in the Jewish wards of Brooklyn.
Boksburg, however, chose not to live up to its reputation. At the first Council meeting after the assassination, Koos van de Merwe rose and, to gapes of amazement, suggested a minute of silence in honor of the slain black leader. Then Beyers de Klerk convened the management committee and permitted black leaders to hold a memorial rally in the Old Town Hall. Until recently, blacks could not hold a wedding reception in the Town Hall, let alone a political rally.
"We looked at it from a business point of view," Councilman de Klerk explains-1. "If we hadn't said yes, there would have been chaos. If we had not given them the civic center, they would have pulled the place apart."
And besides, de Klerk says, Chris Hani was "a son of Boksburg."
In the days to come, it was as if blacks had finally claimed a small place in the political landscape of Boksburg. On the day of Hani's funeral, they streamed through the municipality again to bury the fallen Communist in a cemetery at the southern city limits. They assembled outside the courthouse to watch his accused killer, a Polish immigrant with no ties to Boksburg, arrive for arraignment.
For some Boksburg whites, those with money and passports from other places, the spectacle of black protest was the cue to put their houses on the market and join the exodus known here as the "chicken run." Others rushed to the gun shops or enlisted in the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, the paramilitary brigade that in June lay siege to the convention center where the end of white rule is being negotiated. (The negotiations are taking place just a rifle shot from the Boksburg city line, in Kempton Park.)
But the lesson of Boksburg is that most whites have nowhere to go and little will to fight. They have jobs and mortgages and children in school. While not exactly embracing the new order with enthusiasm, whites have already begun to adapt to it with a sense of resignation embodied, by prescient accident, in Boksburg's city motto: "Respice Finem" ("Heed the End").
A FEW WEEKS AFTER HANI WAS killed, I met Beyers de Klerk in his office in the new Boksburg Civic Center, a concrete tower that looms above the old, low-rise downtown in a style someone described as Riot Gothic. De Klerk is descended from Flemish and Scottish forebears, the first of whom landed in Cape Province in 1688, giving a certain weight to his claim that Africa is his birthright. With his jowls covered in gray bristle and a nose knocked askew during an amateur boxing career, de Klerk, who is 50, looks the part he relishes -- the good-natured outlaw.
In Boksburg, many people regard Beyers de Klerk as a one-man embodiment of the white dilemma. He is a separatist by conviction, but as a businessman he knows the price of isolation and so he has acquiesced in the onslaught of democracy -- up to a point. Recently, moderates have begun to hold up Beyers as an example of a man who has come to his senses, a born-again realist. Right-wingers like Gloria Bosch huff that he is a traitor, a man who has sold out his country for the sake of his real-estate franchise.
De Klerk says that he is just as alarmed by the country's drift as are his right-wing tormentors. As we chat, a woman from the bank drops by with a check for him to sign and he presses her to tell the visiting foreigner how she feels about the new South Africa. Like most whites, she speaks not of blacks and whites but of savages and the civilized.
"If Joe Soap from Soweto wants to move in next to me, O.K.," she says. "But the cannibalism has got to be taken out of them. They've got no respect for human life."
The councilman nods in sympathy.
"It's not a question of living together," he says. "Each white in this country has been living with a black in his backyard since day one -- his servants. I have no problem eating with blacks, living with blacks. Why? Because we rule. But it changes when you don't rule."
So much for theory. We boarded the councilman's black BMW and set off on a tour of the city that calls itself "the gateway to Africa."
BOKSBURG, LIKE MANY CITIES strung along the great geological reef called the Witwatersrand, was a gold rush town. It was founded in 1887, on an ugly, treeless plain populated mainly by jackals and wild ostriches, and named for Willem Bok, who as the Secretary of State for what was then the Transvaal Republic was the man who registered the gold claims. East Rand Proprietary Mines Ltd. still extracts ore from several shafts and its hulking slag heaps dominate the plateau like squat volcanoes. But the city has long since spread and diversified.
Today, Boksburg's gold mine is Jan Smuts Airport, just to the north of the city. Proximity to the country's biggest airport has brought multinational industry. Boksburg's booming precincts are Jet Park, a spanking new region of warehouses and light industry, and the southern hemisphere's largest shopping center, the East Rand Mall. Housing tracts have marched south from the city center deep into the cornfields.
The racial demarcations are essentially those established in the 1960's by the ruthless sorting out of apartheid. Until then, blacks, most of whom came after World War II to work in the new factories, had lived in a central township called Stirtonville or in mine hostels, where they slept in concrete bunks, racked like wine bottles, 48 to a room. In 1964, some 40,000 blacks were uprooted and relocated 10 miles south to a township called Vosloorus, which is now believed to house 250,000 people. Thereafter, blacks came to Boksburg as outsiders, to buy their food and sell their labor. Except for domestic servants and a smattering of middle-class families who have bought into formerly white neighborhoods, they still do. The mixed-race residents known as "coloreds" were collected from around the area and deposited in Stirtonville, now called Reiger Park, population 27,000. Indians were shooed away to nearby Benoni. That left about 87,000 whites as the sole proprietors of Boksburg and the sole beneficiaries of its industrial tax base.
When David Goldblatt, one of South Africa's most respected photographers, set out 14 years ago to document white South Africa, the place he settled on as his Middletown was Boksburg. His pictures show a people smug and secure. The races intersected only in the most formal of contacts -- master-servant, employer-laborer or the patronizing relationship of well-intentioned do-gooders toward the poor natives. Goldblatt's portrayal of all this was so cruelly honest that his book is not stocked in the Boksburg city library.
But the politics of Boksburg took a vicious right turn in the elections of October 1988, when the white supremacists of the Conservative Party won 12 of 20 Council seats. Boksburg was the largest of 104 municipalities in South Africa to fall into Conservative hands.
Many now recall that election as a fluke. The previous Council had been beset by scandals and mismanagement (one councilman was arrested for assaulting his wife with a hammer) and the Conservative Party was well organized to capitalize on the popular backlash.
"On a scale of 1 to 10, liberal to conservative, Boksburg is probably a 5," says Phillip Frankel, a political scientist who has polled extensively in Boksburg. "Its reputation far exceeds the reality. This isn't a town full of Nazis -- no more than most others."
Frankel's polls from the time show that Boksburg's whites were deeply worried by the erosion of the racial barriers that was already under way -- well before F. W. de Klerk had formally repudiated apartheid -- but no more so than whites generally. In reality, Boksburg was, and still is, something of a Middletown, an ordinary place that had somehow elected its anxious id to the City Council. Egged on by the Conservative Party's national leaders, who were thrilled by their victory, the new Boksburg majority set out to make their city the Alamo of apartheid.
At its first meeting, the new Council decreed that it would begin rigorously enforcing the Separate Amenities Act, a by-then largely ignored law that established whites-only toilets, parks and sports facilities.
"The ultimate aim was to show that there are a million right-wing voters who also want to live separately," recalls Beyers de Klerk. "We are not bloody fools. We know you can't wish away the blacks, you can't wish away the coloreds. They're here. But we also feel we have a right to Africa."
As the first Mayor selected by the new majority, and as a member of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, de Klerk enacted the role of frontier patriarch for the world's cameras, discoursing on God's plan for Boksburg and posing with his Bible. Perhaps, he concedes, he made a fool of himself, "but it was good fun."
Not to the city's other residents.
In the mixed-race township, Reiger Park, residents retaliated with a consumer boycott of white merchants in Boksburg. They found enthusiastic corporate support, especially from a number of multinational companies in Boksburg. Companies like Colgate-Palmolive, American Cyanamid and Unilever had opted to remain in South Africa in spite of international sanctions, claiming that they could do more good for South African blacks by staying. Here was a chance to prove it. They provided buses to ferry shoppers to stores in neighboring towns, canceled expansion plans and ran advertisements denouncing the racist Council.
De Klerk's real-estate franchise was singled out for special attention. The first stop on our tour of Boksburg was his comfortable split-level house, which he was forced to sell when the boycott pushed him to the brink of bankruptcy, but later bought back.
"It cost me close to one million rand [about $300,000], that boycott," he says. "I had to sell buildings under cost. I lost the family business. I lost my house and I lost a lot of friends."
By February 1990, when F. W. de Klerk announced plans to repeal all the remaining apartheid statutes, Boksburg had all but surrendered. Later, Beyers de Klerk quit the Conservative Party caucus and declared himself an independent. After the Hani killing, he joined F. W. de Klerk's National Party. It was not inconceivable to him that he might someday take the final step and join the African National Congress.
"My heart tells me one thing," he says, "but my educated brain tells me you cannot have what your heart wants."
To illustrate how he has been chastened, the councilman drives me through the downtown shopping district, blocks of shoe stores and appliance dealers and liquor outlets, to show me the Council's latest achievement "for our black brothers."
In the center of downtown, the city has built a new depot for the minivan taxis that transport "coloreds" from Reiger Park and blacks from Vosloorus. It has shelters for waiting passengers, public toilets and hoses for drivers to wash their vehicles while they wait.
"At the end of the day, I had to stop being a Boere-Boere Mayor and I came back to being a businessman," he says. "It's all rands and cents. We've changed here because we were forced to change."
IN 1991, TOKYO SEXWALE WAS just a year out of jail and rising fast through the political structure of the newly legalized African National Congress. After 15 unsettled years as an exile, an underground A.N.C. operative, a guerrilla warrior and finally a political prisoner, Sexwale was looking for a house. A real-estate agent suggested a middle-class subdivision called Dawn Park, at the southern fringe of Boksburg, in an area still devoted more to cornfields than housing tracts. It was so new it had no schools, no stores or filling stations, no churches. So there were bargains to be had. A few blacks had already moved in since the lifting of the Group Areas Act, which prescribed which races could live where. Sexwale made a down payment on a house in Dawn Park, and a few months later persuaded his closest friend in the A.N.C., Chris Hani, to buy in, too.
"It was a laugh, yes," Sexwale says, recalling the reaction of friends when two of South Africa's most notorious black insurgents moved into the country's most famously right-wing municipality. "But it had nothing to do with politics. Chris was just back from exile, and I was from prison. It was just a place to put our heads down for sleep."
The two men soon found that there was more to Boksburg than its theatrically racist image.
Among Boksburg's blacks, they found that the great boycott had been not only a political victory but a psychological turning point as well. Nonwhites who once moved furtively through town, who stood deferentially aside while shopkeepers waited on white customers, now acted as if they had a right to be there.
More surprising was the reception Hani and Sexwale got from Boksburg's whites. In Dawn Park, they found an openness that was part simple neighborliness, part curiosity, part craving for reassurance, part, Sexwale sensed, shame for the past. "They came to our houses, gave us cakes and cards," he says. When the two black radicals jogged through the suburb, defying the recommendations of their security guards, they were stopped every block by gregarious neighbors.
"We ended up doing very little jogging and a lot of talking," says Sexwale, who is now chairman of the A.N.C. region centered on Johannesburg. "Someone would say: 'I'm a cop. How safe will I be under the new Government?' "
When they ventured downtown or to the East Rand Mall to shop, he says, they were often mobbed by curious whites. Hani, one of the A.N.C.'s biggest celebrities, drew crowds like a Hollywood star. Sexwale, on his outings to the Spur Steak Ranch restaurant, presented an even more astonishing spectacle, because his wife is a white Afrikaner. A few whites glared their disapproval, but most fumbled to act normal or radiated goofy smiles meant to convey acceptance.
When Beyers de Klerk broke with the Conservative Party, Hani sent him a fax congratulating him on his good sense. Sexwale called the councilman on the phone and listened with amusement as de Klerk pitched one of his favorite pipe dreams, bringing the Olympics to Boksburg.
"Beyers is trying to be something, but he's held by the past," Sexwale says. "He epitomizes the confusion within the Afrikaner communty as we see it today: the fear of the future, the guilt for the past, the stubbornness."
Sexwale was among the first on the scene the Saturday morning that Hani was shot in his driveway. He cradled his friend's body and wept. But it never occurred to him, he says, to blame Boksburg for the crime. The neighbor who called in the killer's license number was an Afrikaner. So was the constable who made the arrest. So was the neighbor who fetched a sheet to throw over the body.
In the weeks after Hani was killed, I found only one person who suggested that Boksburg was in some way to blame for the black leader's death. That was Alfred Woodington, the chairman of the Boksburg A.N.C., who said the town was so friendly it caused Hani to let down his guard.
EVERY SCHOOL MORNING A Volkswagen minivan careens through the black township of Vosloorus, collecting teen-agers who stand in the coal-smoke haze wearing trim black uniform blazers and pullovers. The students crowd into the van, chattering above the rhythm of a gospel tape as the driver turns north toward the Boksburg suburb of Sunward Park. They are among the first blacks to be admitted to the white schools of Boksburg, and in the eyes of their hosts they are lucky pioneers of the new South Africa.
But as they answer questions about Boksburg, it becomes clear that this daily voyage is no easier for them than it would be for their white classmates to venture into the black township -- the difference being that no white children ever venture into Vosloorus.
On its way north this day, the minivan passes posters advertising a rally of the racist Afrikaner Resistance Movement. To the black students, the posters scream with the force of pornography. The A.W.B.'s bellicose leader, Eugene TerreBlanche, is a buffoon to many whites, but he looms large in these black teen-agers' image of South Africa, and of Boksburg in particular.
"It's a racist town," declares Nkale Motaung, a 16-year-old who is, if anything, the optimist on the bus.
At school, the white kids -- not most of them, but some, enough to hurt -- call them "kaffirs" and "chocolates." One white boy likes to wear an A.W.B. T-shirt under his uniform and flash it for the black kids when no teachers are looking.
I ask if, after a year and a half at Sunward Park, they have friends among the white students. All but one or two shake their heads.
"Most of them, they don't want to mix with us because we're black," says Molebatsi Tuka.
"They also think we're stupid," chimes in Tshepiso Mokoena. Similar comments tumble from the teen-agers until the van pulls up at Sunward Park. Then the students gather up their book bags and compose themselves into a stoic silence. They assume the European aliases most of them wear for the benefit of white classmates and teachers -- Nkale becomes Charles, Molebatsi turns into Patience -- and they enter the heart of whiteness.
Like most white public schools in South Africa, Sunward Park has become a "Model C" or "state subsidized" school. The state still pays teacher salaries, but a board controlled by the parents now owns the property and raises the remaining expenses through tuition. Technically, schools may not discriminate on the basis of race, but in practice parents control admissions by other means. They can turn away applicants who live outside their immediate area, who fail to pass entrance exams or who cannot afford the fees.
In Sunward Park, an affluent, English-speaking community that votes for F. W. de Klerk's National Party, parents last year decided overwhelmingly to admit black students. But like most whites coping with the collapse of the old barriers, they insisted that integration be on white terms. Black enrollment would be limited to 10 percent, a ratio the school figured would pose no serious threat to academic standards and that could allow the school, as principal David Cawdry put it, "to maintain an ethos."
The black students who commute to Sunward Park have competed for the privilege and they are the cream of Vosloorus, children of serious, motivated families able, often with much scrimping, to pay the $450 in annual fees plus the cost of the daily commute. All the same, the black students come from the other side of the apartheid looking glass. They come, most of them, from underfinanced, overcrowded black schools that teach geography without maps, biology without microscopes, reading without library books -- schools educationally inert but politically charged. They have older brothers and sisters who have lived in exile. All of them know someone who has died or had a house torched in factional violence.
Their politics tend to be African National Congress. Their heroes are Nelson Mandela and Chris Hani. They are, one might think, a treasury of information about the black world where much of South Africa's newly enfranchised majority lives, the world that is about to be merged with Boksburg's world. But this is a resource Sunward Park High has chosen not to tap.
After Chris Hani was murdered three miles away in a suburb that sends many children to Sunward Park High, the school organized no discussion of the event. Black students said the only acknowledgement of the killing was the taunting of white classmates, who joked that Hani, in his concrete-lined grave, would start "an underground movement."
"We know something about Boksburg because we go there to the shops," Nkale Motaung says. "They know nothing about the township, except the misinformation they get from their parents. Even if they pass through, all they see is shacks and they don't know what goes on inside."
Some of the more self-aware white kids are also distressed that the worlds barely touch. "We don't know much about how they live," admits a 16-year-old, Janene Fourie. "We don't know anything. I haven't learned much from the black kids in my school about what it's like in the township. I'm too scared to go there, and nobody ever tells me. I have black friends, but we don't talk about these things. Also there are still racist white kids at Sunward Park, and some of them are my friends, too. I guess I'm afraid of what they would think if saw me getting too serious with the black kids."
ON A NIPPY evening in June, Camille Burger called together the members of the city Planning Committee in the upstairs chamber of the Old Town Hall. The theme of his hour-long presentation was "Quo vadis?" ("Where are you going?"), a Latin phrase much in vogue these days in South Africa.
Burger is the Boksburg town planner, heir to a profession rendered absurdly simple by the social engineers of Grand Apartheid, but now suddenly promising to become very complicated indeed. When he helped draw up Boksburg's latest master plan five years ago, he could readily ignore Reiger Park and Vosloorus. Now there is every chance that by the end of this year the mixed-race residents of Reiger Park and the black multitudes of Vosloorus will be merged with white Boksburg.
Here is where the real battle over South Africa's future will be fought. If whites are intent on maintaining the standards and "ethos" of their schools, not to mention their neighborhoods and hospitals and roads and sewers, then they must be willing to help upgrade the black townships like Vosloorus.
"You can take this plan and throw it out the window," Burger tells the 20 white men who listened attentively. "The playing field has changed."
Burger, a conservative but a realist, readily concedes the absurdity of the "artificial land use pattern" apartheid wrought upon his map.
To the south, for example, are the low-income satellite communities of Windmill Park and Villa Liza, which Boksburg conceived and built in the closing years of the old order. Windmill Park was among the first communities in South Africa to be exempted from racial restrictions, though it was built mainly for "coloreds," people of mixed race. Villa Liza was designed for Indians. Both are tracts of doormat-size lots topped with shabby, look-alike boxes, isolated in the weedy prairie -- far enough from town that transportation costs were sure to eat up the advantages of a cheap mortgage.
Under apartheid, such communities appealed to their intended buyers with a compelling logic: this is the only place available to the likes of you. In the new South Africa, where the market takes over from the Group Areas Act, who would want to live in such places? As the hundreds of vacant lots testify, no one.
"If the private sector had done this, that company would have been bankrupt long ago," Burger tells the Planning Committee.
Another matter not envisioned in the town plan was squatters. It is one of Boksburg's great boasts that the city is unmarred by the shantytowns that encroach on other communities. "No squatter camps!" Beyers de Klerk announced to me half a dozen times as we surveyed the city from his BMW. "We don't allow them!"
I later discovered Boksburg has hundreds of homeless blacks who camp in the mine dumps and industrial wastelands that abut the settled areas. They do not coalesce into communities because when their campsites grow too settled the police come and chase them away, sometimes building bonfires of their Red Cross blankets. But they are there -- Burger's estimate is 1,600 -- and as blacks continue to drop off the edge of a shrinking economy, more will come.
What racial politics created, Burger hopes, economics will preserve for a time, protecting the Boksburgs against being overwhelmed by black expectations. "The Government can scrap a law in a day, but we cannot move a black town the next day to a new, more desirable location," he says. "We cannot, like the politicians, say let's forget about the past. The past is there."
Burger's strategy is containment. He wants to develop a new industrial park across Boksburg's south, just north of Vosloorus, to employ blacks closer to home, and simultaneously provide them with better incomes to upgrade their areas. "It's easier to move one factory than to move 200 families, and factories can afford it," Burger reasons.
He also proposes to provide sites for the homeless in the south, what South Africans call a site-and-service scheme by which the state provides empty sites with water and toilets where the most abject poor can erect their own shelters. This belt of employers and low-income housing sites across the south, he figures, would prevent the city from being engulfed: "The idea is to end up with a plan that is not that strict, but where we will definitely protect vested interests."
Burger understands that in this day of multiracial, multiparty negotiations, such questions will not be decided by a roomful of 20 white men in business suits. The next meeting, he tells them, must be broadened to include black leaders, even militant black leaders. "It's not easy to swallow, but we have to talk with these guys," he says. No one objects.
A few days later, I describe the meeting to Alfred Woodington, the chairman of the local A.N.C. branch, as we chat in his home in Reiger Park. He fumes, spooning sugar into his tea. "I hadn't heard about that meeting," he says. "Who was there?" I tell him. A slow wince passes across his face.
"We'll have to put most of those things on ice," he says. "They have white prints all over them."
But in their thinking about the future of Boksburg, Woodington and Burger are not all that far apart. At first blush, Woodington says, the idea of creating jobs in the south made sense to him. And, somewhat to my surprise, he predicts that in the end most people will remain in neighborhoods with their own people. He describes friends who had moved into white areas only to find they missed the townships.
"In a few years, they will see how uncomfortable it is to live among people they have never lived with before," he says. "You will still have your right-wingers being right-wingers, your racists being racists. Integration will be painful. It already is. In these white areas, there's an uproar when you slaughter a beast, which is traditional. But when it comes to townships, nobody cares whether you keep goats or not. And you can't have a real party in a white area. I mean, when we have a party, we have a party."
TO THE QUESTION "Quo vadis?" Beyers de Klerk sees three possible answers.
"One, you negotiate a shared Government," he says. "If that doesn't work, you emigrate. Or you have a civil war -- boom, two-thirds of the population wiped off the face of South Africa."
De Klerk talks up Option 3, since in Boksburg anything that smacks of optimism marks you as a lily-livered liberal, but he prays for Option 1.
"When they did away with apartheid, I thought the sky would fall," he says. "But I don't think it's that bad. Each one still keeps to his own kind, more or less.
"The thing is, there's still a fear of being ruled as a minority. So you have your elections next April. If the A.N.C. wins, they'll put so much thumb on the rest of us that we're going to have to stand up and fight. If the other guys win, no way the A.N.C. won't fight. As I read it, I can see only chaos."
Tokyo Sexwale, whose job in the A.N.C. consists partly of reassuring whites, says he is sympathetic to white fears, within limits.
"Naturally the mosaic is going to change," he says. "The tempo is going to change. The allocation of resources is going to change. Boksburg will be subject to the dictates of a new Constitution. Yes, there's going to be some pain.
"We will try to ease this new Constitution in, to get people to understand the new ball game. Of course, if what you're getting is not genuine misunderstanding but open revolt, you may have to ram it down their throats."

HEADLINE: A World Tour In 96 Minutes. No Narration.

BYLINE: By LAUREN DAVID PEDEN

 BODY:
In September, Hollywood begins rolling out its highbrow fare. In keeping with this tradition, the Samuel Goldwyn Company is releasing what could be the most challenging movie of the year. "Baraka," which opens Friday, is a wordless paean to what its director, Ron Fricke, calls "humanity's relationship to the eternal."
More specifically, it is a 70-millimeter film that shows -- without benefit of titles -- such sights as the city landfill in Calcutta, Mount Tramserku in the Himalayas, the Helmsley Building on Park Avenue in Manhattan and a factory in Bang Pa-In, Thailand. The movie's title comes from an ancient Sufi word meaning "blessing" or "breath of life"; the director describes the undertaking as "guided meditation." 
 While some of the sequences are self-explanatory (time-lapse footage of pedestrians moving en masse in New York and Tokyo, various religious and tribal ceremonies), others will probably make viewers wonder: Where are we, and what's going on here? It was these questions (asked in a larger context) that prompted Mr. Fricke and the producer Mark Magidson to make the film, which, predictably, posed a marketing challenge.
"I find those kinds of issues interesting to contemplate," says Mr. Magidson, who had collaborated with Mr. Fricke several years ago on another wide-screen, nonverbal project. "How long are our lives, and what's come before us, and what are we doing here? That's what the film is about. Once you start explaining what's going on, it becomes this intellectual experience, like an informational, documentary-type film."
Yes, but will moviegoers find those issues compelling enough to spend 96 wordless minutes listening to New Agey, transcultural music and contemplating their collective navel? Mr. Magidson answers, "If you go to the opera and don't know the story line, you could still find it beautiful . . . hopefully."
The movie is ostensibly about global connectedness, and to capture its we-are-the-world feeling, Mr. Fricke and Mr. Magidson, accompanied by a three-man crew, traveled to 24 countries over a 13-month period. Some of the scenes, like those of Turkish whirling dervishes, were coordinated in advance; others were shot on the spur of the moment.
"We had sections of the film that were blocked in," says Mr. Magidson, "but in most cases we would choose locations based on the weather or local economic factors." In other words, where shooting was cheap.
With their whirlwind itinerary -- which included Tanzania, Brazil, China, Kuwait, Cambodia, New Mexico, Iran and Nepal -- their greatest feats were never losing so much as one suitcase, and never getting sick. Mr. Fricke says, only half-joking, "Pepto-Bismol was really the glue that kept us together."
Mr. Fricke and Mr. Magidson have been working together since 1985, when they joined forces to make "Chronos," done in the large-scale IMAX format. It presented the history of Western civilization through its monuments, such as the Parthenon, Notre Dame and St. Peter's Cathedral. The movie, which cost about $1 million, played for five years in Los Angeles.
But the film makers believed that the IMAX format was too restricting; the screens are found primarily in museums, which limits the audience, and the preferred type of IMAX film is a short documentary, with, needless to say, narration. With "Baraka" Mr. Fricke and Mr. Magidson hope to reach a mass audience through the medium of 70-millimeter film, the same format used for such movies as "Lawrence of Arabia" and, more recently, "Far and Away."
Though he had a grand (albeit hard-to-describe) premise and required only $4 million, Mr. Magidson spent more than five years seeking backers. "It's very hard to finance a film like this based on a written treatment, as you can imagine," he says ruefully. "It's hard to say who's going to want to see this film. It doesn't have sex appeal, or whatever the criterion is for a traditional studio film."
Eventually, he persuaded several independent sources (whom he steadfastly refuses to identify) to support the project. Once the film was completed, it took another year to find a distributor.
So what prompted Samuel Goldwyn to sign on? "That's what we do," says Richard Bornstein, who is in charge of worldwide marketing for the company. "We take chances on projects and people. I think for every specialized film there's a certain segment of the population that says, 'There's no way I'll ever see a movie that has subtitles,' or 'I'm not going to a movie based on Shakespeare.' "
But, he added: "How many people are saying, 'I'm waiting for the next film that doesn't have any words'? It's definitely a marketing challenge."
So far, Goldwyn has targeted several possible audiences: film buffs, college students and what Mr. Bornstein describes as the "general specialized audience who are used to seeing offbeat films."
Goldwyn has also prepared a 35-millimeter version, which will be able to play in more theaters and at a less expensive price. "The logistics of playing only 70-millimeter houses are overwhelmingly expensive," says Mr. Bornstein. The film is opening in two theaters in 70 millimeter, and the following week will open across the country, primarily in 35 millimeter.
"The average Joe may not give it a chance," says Mr. Bornstein, "but there are a whole lot of people out there who aren't the average Joe."

LENGTH: 2390 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
Latin Music Crosses New Borders

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
As befits a pop music idol whose last record sold more than 4.5 million copies, Luis Miguel chose to do things on a grand scale when it came time to release his new album, "Aries," early this summer. Reporters and disk jockeys from all over the United States and as far away as Argentina were flown here to hear the 23-year-old singer discuss the making of the record (reported to have cost more than $1 million), watch him perform at a pair of sold-out concerts and see the premiere of a lavish, romantic music video, shot in three versions by three different directors.
Three months later, Luis Miguel, now in the midst of an American tour that took him to Madison Square Garden earlier this month and will peak in December with a five-day engagement at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., has proved to be worth every penny of that investment. Some 1.5 million copies of "Aries" have flown out of record stores throughout the Western Hemisphere, and the album's first single, "Ayer," can be heard on radios everywhere Spanish is spoken. Once again, Luis Miguel -- a Mexican born in Puerto Rico of Spanish-Italian parents whose full name is Luis Miguel Gallego -- has been confirmed as Latin heartthrob numero uno, the Julio Iglesias of his generation. 
 Just five years ago, success of such magnitude would have been inconceivable for a Spanish-language performer. But the Latin music business in the United States is being transformed by forces both cultural and commercial, and the lesson has not been lost on the multi-national record companies that have increasingly been making their presence felt in the market.
"This is now a big business," said Jose Behar, president of EMI Latin, a branch of the EMI conglomerate that did not even exist five years ago. "It's no longer a matter of going down to Pico Boulevard" -- a Los Angeles street lined with the mom-and-pop Latin music retail outlets that were once typical of the business -- "and visiting your three customers. This is an age in which it pays to have global vision."
But the success of Luis Miguel and bright new stars like Juan Luis Guerra, Gloria Trevi, Jon Secada, Selena, La Mafia and Jerry Rivera who appeal to a young audience looking for more driving rhythms than the crooners of the past could offer is, Mr. Behar and other industry executives are betting, merely a taste of things to come. Already a formidable market of more than 25 million people, Hispanic consumers in the United States are expected to overtake blacks in the next decade as the nation's largest minority group. Their numbers are being fed by continuing immigration from Latin America, but rising incomes and education levels have also created a young and vibrant bilingual Latino middle class that has billions of dollars to spend and a desire to maintain its cultural roots.
At the same time, growing economic integration with Mexico, culminating in the North American Free Trade Agreement that Congress could vote on this fall, is knitting the North American and Latin American markets closer together. With that has come an international explosion of media outlets, including television networks like Univision and Telemundo and cable channels like the new MTV Latino, designed to carry the process toward its logical conclusion: a single market of more than 400 million people united by a common language and heritage.
"Musically, the Latin American market and the United States Latin market have never been separate, even though the means of communication were divided," said Andre Midani, head of the Latin unit of Warner Music International, the worldwide music division of the Time Warner conglomerate. "Radio, television and the press were always local, and therefore their interests were local. But the taste of the public was universal, and with the advent of media conglomerates, obviously those barriers are fast disappearing. Latin America is at long last truly becoming a continent."
Latin music last year accounted for about $150 million of the $9 billion in records sold in the United States. Growth would be greater, industry executives argue, were it not for the resistance of the mainstream pop market, record stores and record buyers alike, to a style that often seems foreign to them. Nevertheless, Hispanics have proved to be unusually enthusiastic and loyal music consumers.
"On a per capita basis, Latin people all across the board, from Puerto Rico to Mexico, have always been heavier purchasers of music" than the American population at large, said George Zamora, general manager of Sony Discos, the Latin music division of the Japanese entertainment company. Add Latin America, which bought more than $700 million worth of recordings last year, and Spain, and the result is a market that spends a billion dollars a year on records and wants to buy more as its income rises. "As economic prosperity becomes a reality, obviously people are spending more money for their leisure," Mr. Midani noted.
 
The Image Makers
From 'Bad Girls' To Moonlit Beaches
 Many in the industry see MTV Latino as the vehicle that will accelerate that process. The Spanish-language version of the music-video channel is scheduled to begin broadcasting from Miami Beach on Oct. 1, with a format that will mix Spanish with English pop and rock.
"I think it's going to be great, because it'll give us an excuse to produce videos," Jorge Martinez, who works on sales and promotions for BMG Records' Latin division, said. "Right now, we can spend $40,000 on a video, and where do we send it? Maybe to a couple of clubs, and the two major networks, but they don't play videos regularly, so there is a question of getting your money's worth."
For the pop singer and actress Gloria Trevi, whose image as "the Madonna of Mexico" has been fed by her decision to pose for cheesecake calendars, and her BMG label-mate Alejandra Guzman, another performer who cultivates a "bad girl" image, MTV promises to be a major career boost. "She has color, sensuality, talent and good music, everything that MTV calls for," Sergio Rozenblat, general manager of a rival label, WEA Latina, said of Ms. Trevi. "It adds up to a natural for them."
Luis Miguel, with his leading-man good looks, silkily seductive voice and a repertory that runs from romantic boleros to electronic dance-pop, can be expected to loom even larger on the horizon. And Sony's stable of handsome young salsa singers and balladeers, including Rey Ruiz, Jerry Rivera, Chayanne, Ricky Martin and Luis Enrique, is also likely to benefit from exposure on MTV.
"You're going to see a lot of videos with these guys taking romantic walks on the beach with a beautiful girl, complete with lingering kisses," predicted Alfredo Alonso, who is the owner of Radio y Musica, regarded as the main trade journal of the Latin music business.
But Spanish-language radio, traditionally the principal means by which Latin music is promoted, is also changing rapidly and losing its barrio mentality. KLAX-FM became the top-rated station in Los Angeles after shifting in August 1992 to a format called "banda" -- a dance-oriented style that takes brass-heavy Mexican hillbilly music and modernizes it with synthesizers and electric guitars. In San Antonio, KTNX-FM has also become No. 1 in its market with a format that emphasizes more traditional Mexican-based genres.
The striking emergence of KLAX-FM, which two years ago was near the bottom of the ratings, has startled the radio industry and advertisers alike, because the station has attracted a young Hispanic audience that had grown up listening to rock and funk but now seems to be returning to its roots. That phenomenon is sure to hasten the entry of other stations into the Latin music market, especially since Hispanic entrepeneurs are looking to snap up FM stations as they go up for sale.
Thanks to the emergence of singers like Gloria Estefan and a wave of Latino writers and artists whose works have met with commercial success, a Latin influence has already crept into mainstream American culture. But many of the new Latin pop stars reverse that process, often striving for the glossy, dance-oriented sound of 90's Anglo pop by recording in Los Angeles or London with the same studio musicians and producers responsible for the hits at the top of the Billboard charts.
 
The Players
Divvying Up The Territory
 Leading the charge to capitalize on the Latin-music market, not surprisingly, is Sony Discos, the Latin music division of the company that is already a dominating force in every other aspect of entertainment around the world. Traditionally strong in "tropical" music -- the pulsating, eminently danceable salsa and merengue sounds developed by Cubans, Puerto Ricans and Dominicans -- and the pop ballad field that Julio Iglesias and Roberto Carlos exemplify, Sony has broadened its sights by moving into Mexican-based music with groups like La Mafia and even reggae and rap in Spanish. "We're aggressive and will continue to be aggressive, so we can be dominant in our market segment," Mr. Zamora said in an interview at the company's headquarters here.
Each of the other major multinational record companies is also seeking an esthetic and commercial niche. WEA Latina, a division of Time Warner, has Luis Miguel as its big moneymaker, but it has also made a large investment in Spanish-language rock and pop with acts like Mana, Cafe Tacuba, El Tri and Fito Paez. BMG, part of the German Bertelsmann conglomerate that also includes the RCA and Arista labels, has done likewise, signing up groups like Maldita Vecindad and Caifanes and financing a Mexican punk-thrash label called Culebra.
"The beauty of pop and rock is that they are much more universal and not a regional style," said Maribel Schumacher, director of marketing for Latin music at Warner International. "It's difficult to sell salsa on the West Coast or banda music in Miami."
For the smaller independent labels that have traditionally been the backbone of the business, the expansion by the multi-national companies means they must change or be engulfed. Fonovisa and Rodven, for example, both have affiliations with the powerful Mexican television network Televisa, whose programs are broadcast in the United States and 20 other countries but will need all those resources to compete with the major labels.
"The labels have drastically changed their way of thinking and become much more mainstream," said Mr. Alonso, who recently became general manager at WSKQ-FM radio in New York. "They are spending a lot more on advertising, and will send their artists out for radio promotions and tours. You didn't see that four or five years ago."
 
The Doubters
Spanish Is Still A Foreign Language
 Notwithstanding the transformation of the Latin-music industry, important barriers remain in place and show few signs of weakening. Despite the occasional novelty hit in Spanish, like Los Lobos' 1987 version of "La Bamba," the mainstream pop audience in the United States has repeatedly demonstrated that it does not enjoy songs in any language other than English. So while Jerry Rivera can tour Japan, sing only in Spanish and appeal to the same consumer who likes Mariah Carey or Guns 'n' Roses, he cannot do the same on the American mainland. That means a Latin artist's chances for a "crossover" hit, where the really big money is to be made, are much more limited than those of a black performer.
In addition, many record stores, especially those in areas without a large Hispanic population, still resist the idea of setting aside space for Latin music. "The Anglo chains are beginning to realize the magnitude of this market, but they really haven't come to the party the way they could," said Mr. Rozenblat of WEA Latina. Retailers, he continued, still need to be convinced that "you can bring in the consumer by having Latin product. It's no different than a supermarket having Goya foods and Colgate too."
In the face of that reluctance, some Latin performers are focusing their attentions southward, particularly toward Mexico, whose 90 million people account for 40 percent of all the money spent on music in Latin America. La Mafia had been a regional act, its popularity largely confined to Texas, until it began playing concerts and dances all over northern Mexico. Its stepped-up version of traditional Mexican styles appealed to audiences there, and the group sold more than 500,000 copies of its last album in Mexico. That, in turn, sparked interest in the group in California and other parts of the United States with large Mexican-American populations. As a result, even Puerto Rico and South America began to show curiousity about the group.
"We've always felt that the United States is an extension of Mexico, and vice versa," said Mr. Behar of EMI Latin. "Musical tastes are very similar, and a big pop hit in Mexico is likely to be a big pop hit here."
Other Hispanic performers who feel comfortable singing in both English and Spanish are taking another approach, seeking to establish, in the words of the Cuban-born singer Jon Secada, "dual careers." Mr. Secada released his first album, which contained the hit "Just Another Day Without You" and has sold more than five million copies worldwide, in English. He then recorded the same songs again in Spanish and sold another 600,000 copies in the United States and Latin America.
Gloria Estefan made her mark purveying Latin-flavored pop to English-speaking audiences, but recorded her latest album, "Mi Tierra," in Spanish, opting for a sort of reverse crossover. Linda Ronstadt also struck gold with two albums of Mexican mariachi music and one of Caribbean-flavored boleros.
Impressed by Mr. Secada's success, EMI Records is, in fact, encouraging some of its other bilingual artists to record in both languages. Even a few non-Hispanic artists have experimented with that approach, including Bryan Adams, Jon Bon Jovi and Motown's Boyz II Men, who have a Spanish-language single due this month. "To a certain degree, there is always going to be a certain separation between the two markets, but I've had much greater success than anyone could have imagined," Mr. Secada said. "There is still a lot of untapped territory out there, and it is going to become more and more important."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
42d Street Plan: Be Bold or Begone!

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Forty-Second Street now!, the long-awaited "interim" plan to revive New York's tarnished boulevard of dreams, is a smoothly choreographed step in exactly the right direction. As the word interim suggests, the plan is no more than a step. A decade hence, 42d Street could well be straddled by the kind of gigantic tombstone skyscrapers that were originally planned to rise here. Though a faltering real estate market put that project on hold, it has not vanished from the horizon.
And even the interim plan faces some hurdles before it is officially adopted. The private developers in this public-private venture have yet to approve the plan, and it will be the subject of public hearings this fall. With luck, however, this wonderful plan will be accepted and the ideas percolating through it will influence whatever follows. The plan is important not only because of the historical significance of the site but also because it breaks ground for a fertile exchange between corporate and popular culture. 
 "Main Street is almost all right," Robert Venturi wrote in 1966, and that is the guiding idea behind the 42d Street plan. Mr. Venturi's remark was aimed at modern city planning. He sought to puncture the prevailing assumption that whole streets and neighborhoods should be torn down to make room for urban renewal. Forty-second Street may not be your average Main Street, but it, too, is almost all right. In fact, it is almost fabulous. And the virtue of the interim plan is that it will encourage the dormant genius of the place to shine. The goal of the $20 million plan is not so much to overhaul the street physically as to reconstruct people's perception of it.
And don't think that goal doesn't call for engineering every bit as elaborate as would be needed to rebuild the street from top to bottom. A lot of time, money and public relations have gone into constructing the image of 42d Street as a squalid corridor of horrors that can only be redeemed by ripping it apart. Of course, that image is not unconnected to reality. The decay, crime, drugs, pornography and prostitution are real, and no one thinks that these are civic assets.
Still, even in its most blighted state the street continued to draw people who came to enjoy the bright lights, crowds and budget movie tickets. And it has never been clear that real estate development is the ideal deterrent to squalor or crime. But a deal had been signed, the city and state had made commitments to the developers, and the street's seamier aspects became the continuing pretext for the massive public and private investment. In truth, it was the perceptions of public officials that needed the most extensive renovation. There is no evidence that the public was clamoring to see Times Square and 42d Street remade into a barren office canyon and a tasteful retail mall. Nor is Broadway sufficiently robust to contemplate conversion of the street's theaters into legitimate playhouses.
Forty-second Street Now!, a project of the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the city's Economic Development Corporation, makes one thing clear: public officials have been looking at 42d Street with open eyes. The plan is a very Venturian document. In the spirit of "Learning From Las Vegas," the 1972 study by Mr. Venturi, Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour, it could be called Learning From 42d Street. It is not a design but rather a set of design guidelines, extrapolated from an analysis of the street's distinctive features, that must be followed by individual tenants in 34 building sites between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. (Compliance with the guidelines will be enforced by U.D.C.).
The design team, lead by the architect Robert A. M. Stern and the graphic designer Tibor Kalman under the inspired guidance of Rebecca Robertson, a U.D.C. official, state that their goal is to create an "enhanced version" of 42d Street. Their proposals range in scale from the small and practical (open-mesh security grilles over shop windows, to enliven the street at night) to the big and fantastic, like a rooftop "billboard park," a pop rococo fountain gushing ads instead of water.
Overall, the plan is devised to reinforce the street's existing characteristics. The layered accretion of forms over the past century. The mix of styles and scales. The lack of visual coordination. In short, the aim of the plan is to produce a street that looks unplanned. But this seeming paradox is in the very logic of the marketplace itself, here celebrated in all its raucous splendor as a delirious public spectacle.
While master plans typically mandate uniformity, the 42d Street plan prohibits it. Instead of providing commercial tenants with an approved chart of coordinated colors, the plan urges them to chase their own rainbows. Instead of lining the streets with matching theme banners, the plan encourages tenants to create their own spectacular signage. And the plan's emphasis on the diverse and heterogeneous extends to the tenants themselves. It envisions a mix of retail stores (chain shops as well as local entrepreneurs), restaurants at different price ranges, nightclubs and state-of-the-art amusements, like computer golf. Six of the street's nine theaters, to be renovated under the auspices of the New 42d Street, a nonprofit organization, would offer a mix of movies, commercial and nonprofit performance, and rehearsal and television production studios.
The plan does include some unifying features. Theatrical lighting, for example, will play over the upper stories of buildings along the block. Transparent, not tinted, glass is required for shop fronts. Above all, the street will be unified by the prominence given to signs: video screens, painted billboards, theater marquees, faded murals from the past, LED strips, holograms -- an uninterrupted commercial interruption. (If this were any other street, the plan could easily pass for an apocalyptic preview of what things would look like if all public spaces succumbed to privatization.)
Though partly conceived in the spirit of architectural preservation, the plan is also a brake to prevent too much preservation from turning the place into an antiquarian version of itself. Some buildings, such as the Rialto on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street, will be shorn of shabby accretions, while the ditsy paneling added in the 1950's to the Candler Building, a mid-block office tower, will be retained as an integral part of the urban collage.
The character of 42d Street owes much to the dynamic interplay between fixed forms (theaters, billboards, the news "zipper" sign at One Times Square) and their ephemeral contents (movies, ads, headlines); and the composition of the design team replicated that interaction. While the entire project was a team effort, it is probably fair to credit Mr. Stern with the plan's solid stewardship of the street's architectural heritage, while Mr. Kalman's mission was to insure that the past doesn't clog the flow of fresh pop.
The designers use the analogy of the English garden to describe their strategy of planning a place to look unplanned, but a more apt metaphor might be a supermarket display. Grand Union does not dictate the look of Tide, Pepsi or McIntosh apples, but the management can create a lively atmosphere by keeping the shelves stocked, the floors polished and the produce fresh. If something doesn't sell, move it around, or move it out. The 42d Street plan is about trial and error, not perfection. It is about discovering the scale on which it is possible to take the kind of risks that make a place come alive.
OF COURSE, A PLAN IS A PLAN, even if it calls itself an "unplan." Banners or no banners, an "enhanced" 42d Street may well shock those who have only known the raunchy, unenhanced version. And, for connoisseurs of urban complexity, that earlier version is not something to be casually tossed aside. For some, John Rechy's gritty "City of Night" can arouse a nostalgia as potent as that evoked by Cole Porter's "Love for Sale." The book's anxious ramble with love and death speaks of a city as richly textured as the subconscious, and of a 42d Street where it could be seen that the marketplace embraces bodies as well as pop songs, novels and plots of land. Now "the Deuce" will offer commercial sex only in the denatured form of Calvin Klein's towering simulation of it.
Inevitably, given the history and economics of this project, some will view the entire plan as a gigantic simulation, an ersatz, corporate urbanism similar to Universal Citywalk in Los Angeles. Well, the 42d Street plan is corporate. But in a city where recent real estate development has tended to drive people apart, there is something almost quixotic about the plan's ambition to reunite them beneath the umbrella of popular culture. And at a time when pop's technology (VCR's, Walkmen, virtual reality) tends to reinforce spatial isolation, a public space built on pop is practically a Utopian proposition.
And the fact that the plan is corporate may be the most idealistic thing about it. For it suggests that the corporate and the heterogeneous need not be foes. They can be allies. Indeed, they already are. Five hundred cable stations will bloom not because of altruism but because the expansion will be profitable. Multiculturalism may be the bane of the academy, but in the marketplace it's a boon. Dr. Dre sells records, Amy Tan sells books, and Tibor Kalman wasn't hired by Benetton because they hoped his multi-culti graphics would put the company out of business.
Whatever follows the interim plan ought to build on that idea. The problem with the original Johnson-Burgee designs for the center's four skyscrapers was not that they were corporate but that they had nothing enlightening to say about the modern corporation. They expressed accurately enough its potential for daunting uniformity but left out its capacity for diversity. The interim plan, too, leaves something out of the picture. It creates a place attuned to the diversity of consumers. What Times Square Center could provide is a similarly plugged-in place for the producers.
