HEADLINE: The Home-Buying Decision of a Lifetime

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE powerful force of a home sales market substantially below the price levels five or six years ago is asserting itself in the lives of thousands of families in the metropolitan area.
For many who bought starter houses in the middle 80's, the fall in prices has forced the postponement of purchase and relocation decisions that are essential to long-term family well-being. Unable to recover all their equity if they sell, these families are unable to buy and "move up." 
 Yet necessity has led many other families to take what they can get and move on. For those that are selling a house bought before the mid-80's, there may be a significant equity build-up. Even if they must accept a price lower than they would have gotten a few years ago, they may well be purchasing at a price that is lower than it would have been then.
If they are at the stage of life when they find themselves eager to make a long-term housing decision -- choosing a house in which they hope to stay for most of their working years -- the current market presents unusual opportunity.
Mortgage rates are more favorable than at any time in the last 25 years. Buyers have the benefit of wide choice. Availabilities are great in many locations. Some buyers talk of having seen 50 properties before choosing. The house they select may be one they would have found unaffordable a few years ago.
The catchword among brokers and successful buyers and sellers alike is "realism." Realistic pricing is what bring sales, they say. The process of selling and buying may be weighted with vicissitudes and disappointments, but it is also bringing out flexibility in the participants.
"The woman whose home we bought became more realistic," said Elaine Simon, a buyer in Woodmere, L.I. "She came down $70,000. But we as sellers also became more realistic. We were asking $230,000 to $250,000, but we ended up selling for $180,000."
Mrs. Simon and her husband, Donald, closed in February on a center-hall colonial on Midwood Road, having sold a side-hall colonial in Lynbrook. They had lived there for 12 years.
In Larchmont, N.Y., Mark and Elizabeth Liscio tried off and on to sell their three-bedroom Tudor house for a year and a half. "Then we put it back on last spring and settled on a price that we had rejected before," said Mr. Liscio, a banking lawyer in Manhattan. He accepted $385,000. The initial listing price was $425,000.
But the sale made it possible for the Liscios to buy a four-bedroom colonial on Walnut Avenue in the Larchmont Manor neighborhood, where many houses are marketed at $700,000 and more. Mr. Liscio declined to disclose his purchase price, but he said it was almost 20 percent below the seller's asking price. The Liscios and their two young children moved in July.
Interviews with move-up buyers throughout the metropolitan area elicited again and again the theme that the buyers were in search of stability of place, especially during the period when children are in school.
They are selecting, not merely settling, and having selected, struggling to sell their old house.
"We don't want to ever move again," said Michael Levine, a musician who moved in August with his wife, Laura Baer Levine, a magazine art director, and two children into a three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath colonial on Mendl Terrace near Watchung Road in Montclair, N.J. The home buying and selling process took a year and a half.
The need to sell their two-family house in North Bergen dominated the process, he said. In September they had an offer and in turn made an offer on a house in Montclair. "Our buyers tried from September to December to get a mortgage but were turned down, and then we had to get out of our deal in Montclair," he said. The contract hinged on the Levines' ability to get a mortgage, which they could not do without selling.
THEN a second offer in North Bergen resusciated the Montclair deal, but the buyer eventually backed out. In June the Levines went into contract with a third buyer who closed in August, giving the couple a "small profit" on a house they had purchased in 1985. The profit didn't include improvement costs.
Mr. Levine said he was struck by the difference between the market when he was looking last, in 1985, and the market today. "Then the market was hot," he said. "There was competition for the house you liked. You couldn't negotiate prices down. Now the buyer has more power. We also learned that the real-estate agent is incredibly important in saving you time and taking care of a lot of little things before the closing." The Levines used Bergdorf Realtors in Montclair.
Another couple who were selecting for the long term also engaged in a lengthy search process. "We wanted to buy a 30-year house," said Elaine Newman. She and her husband, Steven Brill, a lighting designer in Manhattan, looked off and on for three years before closing in July on a nine-room colonial on Old Colony Lane in Great Neck, L.I.
The search perhaps took so long because the couple was choosing a location as well as a house. When buyers know their neighborhood and want to stay within it, decisions can be reached more quickly.
So it was with Philip and Tracey Alampi, a couple in their early 30's living in Glen Ridge, N.J. The Alampis moved five doors away in late August, from a house at 30 Claridge Court to a larger house at 579 Ridgewood Avenue. Mr. Alampi is an accountant in Montclair, the neighboring town. The couple have three children, 4 years old and under.
"I grew up half a mile away," said Mr. Alampi. "It was important to us to stay in town because we want our kids to use these schools." He said he had wandered almost by accident into an open house real-estate brokers were giving even before the house was advertised and found himself in contract within two weeks. The seller, an estate eager to sell, quickly accepted $325,000.
"We priced our own house to sell quickly," Mr. Alampi said. Within two weeks he had accepted $262,000 for his house, he said, after listing it for $269,000. The house had been purchased four years ago for $242,000.
The Alampis are proceeding to invest significantly in their new house, initially in new patio paving, central air-conditioning and the replacement of three of the five bathrooms. The kitchen will be replaced in the spring.
Next to location, the condition of the house is most important in bringing about a sale, many brokers say. Some consider condition of greater importance. "Buyers are very discriminating," said Ilse Appelman of the Appelman-Lerner agency in Great Neck. In that community the average sale time for a well-priced house in good condition is two to three months, she said. But the normal sale time is three to six months.
Michael Stoff, a 37-year optician in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, mentioned "move-in condition" as a factor in leading him and his wife, Paula, to buy a single-family house for $475,000 on Carroll Street, a block away from his shop on Seventh Avenue. The couple moved from the Mill Basin section last month. i
"I walked in the door at 11 A.M. with my broker on a Tuesday morning in July, and I saw the woodwork and I was in awe," he said. "I called my wife, and said, 'Get down here,' and we made an offer that very day.' " An agreement was reached within 48 hours and the couple closed in five weeks.
In the case of Ming Tao and her husband Howard Lam, a database administrator for Salomon Brothers, the state of the market provided an unexpected opportunity to buy a single-family house rather than the two-bedroom Manhattan condominium they had planned on. With help from Mr. Lam's mother they bought a house on Borage Place in the Forest Hills Gardens section of Queens.
"When we first saw the house in the spring of 1992 the price was too high -- $425,000 -- and we didn't even bother to make an offer," she said. But when the price fell below $350,000, they bought. "It was the best of all the houses we had seen since we started looking two years ago." The couple sold a co-op on Bleecker Street six years ago and had been renting ever since.
The quality of local schools is frequently mentioned by move-up buyers as a deciding factor in the housing choices. So it was for Gianni and Tilde Giacche , who moved with their three young children last week into a gray clapboard colonial on Ridgeway Street in Mount Vernon, N.Y. "It was built by the previous owner and it was in mint condition," said Mrs. Giacche. But she also was attracted by the heterogeneity of the Mount Vernon population, and wants her children to be exposed to it in school.
"I GREW up in an affluent upper-class community, in Old Brookville, L.I.," she said. "I'm used to that homogeneity. I opted for something different." Mrs. Giacche's late father was Adolph Mariani, who founded Asti's restaurant in Manhattan, now run by his children.
Stability as a housing goal also has financial implications. It encourages buyers to think in long terms about the financing of the house, and to integrate that planning into other long-term family needs.
With interest rates at about 7 percent, the move-up buyer with sufficient equity from a sale to put into buying the new house may be able to afford the monthly payments of a loan with a 15- rather than a 30-year term, brokers say. "Some people are even taking 10-year loans today," said Gene Russo, president of the Logistics Funding Group, a mortgage brokerage firm in Manhattan.
By paying off the mortgage in 15 years, the family with young children may be in a stronger position to afford college expenses when the time comes. Many homeowners refinancing the mortgages at current lower rates are also reducing the loan period.
But since the monthly payments are lower on a 30-year loan, most purchasers of move-up housing are apparently choosing the longer term. "About 80 percent of the people are going 30 years," said Mr. Russo. Many of these buyers cannot handle the higher payments of a 15-year loan, though some buyers apply additional payments to principal in their 30-year loan in order to pay it off sooner. Other buyers, more interested in the tax deduction than in freeing themselves of debt, also choose the 30-year term, with its longer period of deductible interest payments.
A $200,000 30-year loan at 7 percent interest carries a monthly payment of $1,332. That comes to $479,520 over 30 years, before tax deductions for mortgage interest. With a 15-year loan, probably at a half-point lower rate, or 6 1/2 percent, the monthly payments are $405 a month higher, or $1,742, before tax deductions. But when the loan term ends, in 15 years, the borrower will have paid only $313,560 before tax benefits instead of $479,520, a difference of nearly $166,000.
NEVERTHELESS, most buyers are taking the 30-year loan because they cannot afford the higher monthly payments of shorter-term loans. "In many cases people have almost no equity in the co-ops or condos they're selling," said Patrick MacCarthy, a loan officer in the West Nyack, N.Y., office of Margaretten & Company, a national mortgage banking firm. "Many put only 10 percent down with loans up to $400,000."
For move-up buyers in such Brooklyn areas as Midwood, Mill Basin and Manhattan Beach, the typical pattern is to put 20 to 25 percent equity into the newly bought house and get a mortgage of 75 to 80 percent of value, said Michael Sarrel, of the Mortgage Gallery in Sheepshead Bay. Mortgage lenders can work out detailed financial analyses to show buyers what they can in principle afford, based on various assumptions.
Starting with the assumption that the move-up buyer can make a down payment of $52,000, a buyer with annual household income of $80,000 would normally be able to borrow $210,000 on a 30-year 7 percent loan, making possible the purchase of a house costing about $262,000, according to Joseph Taranto, senior loan officer in the Tarrytown, N.Y., office of Columbia Equities Ltd., a mortgage banking firm. This also assumes annual property taxes of $6,000 and annual insurance costs of $720, he said.
But qualifying for a bank loan by keeping housing debt-to-income ratios within the lender's standards is not the only issue for the buyer. The prudent buyer also must be aware of other housing expenses, not to mention nonhousing costs. Utilities may cost $4,000 a year, and upkeep and maintenance can vary widely, but normally range between $4,000 to $8,000. Adding all these in, total housing costs might come to 45 to 50 percent of gross income, before deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes.
STEVEN BRILL, the lighting designer who bought a house in Great Neck, did his own calculations of affordability on a computer before purchasing. He figures, using assumptions similar to Mr. Taranto's and putting the buyer in an over-all 40 percent tax bracket, that with a 20 percent down payment and a 7 percent 30-year mortgage "a $90,000 income can afford the $300,000 house and the $135,000 income can afford the $450,000 house." This assumes that the buyer in this tax bracket accepts net housing costs of about 30 percent of income.
As for the pace of current sales, it is "not bad" this summer, said Karl E. Case, professor of economics at Welllesley College and a producer of real-estate price indexes. Sales generally are exceeding the levels of the 1990-through-1992 period, although price levels appear stable rather than rising.
Statewide figures for New York from the National Association of Realtors show that total sales of existing single-family homes (including co-ops and condominiums) are running at an annual rate of 134,600 this year, based on second-quarter sales. Last year total sales were 136,000 units. That was up from 127,000 in 1991 and 125,000 in 1990.
In New Jersey, existing single-family home sales are running at a rate of 125,000 for the year, compared with totals of 132,000, 118,000 and 114,000 in 1992, 1991 and 1990, respectively.
Connecticut is showing a pick-up this year. The annual rate is 45,700, based on second-quarter results, compared with sales of 40,000 last year and 37,600 and 34,300 in the two preceding years. There has been a noticeable increase in sales in Fairfield County, and more recently in Hartford and New London Counties, said Chip Kunde, executive director of the state's Board of Realtors in Hartford. "But prices are still going down in some places," he noted.
For the metropolitan area as a whole, the median single-family resale home price in the second quarter was $176,000, up marginally from $175,400 in the second quarter last year, the National Association of Realtors says. Three years ago the median second-quarter price was also $175,400. Six years ago, in 1987, it was $183,000.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Mark Also Rises, Mr. Soros

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to the German mark, even George Soros may have gotten it wrong. In June, the Hungarian-American investor predicted publicly that the German currency was bound to fall. Mr. Soros, who has had a nearly impeccable investing record of late, was joined in his view of the currency's prospects by most economists and speculators.
For a while he was right, but three months later the mark is showing a pronounced strengthening against the dollar. From a low point of about 1.75 to the dollar in late July, the mark was trading at 1.61 to the dollar on Friday. When Mr. Soros made his prediction in June, the mark was at 1.625 to the dollar. 
 In the long run, the logic behind Mr. Soros's prediction -- that Germany would have to lower interest rates substantially to stimulate its moribund economy, and that rates in the United States might even edge upwards -- may well prove correct.
A narrowed interest-rate differential would lead yield-sensitive investors to move out of the German currency, putting downward pressure on its value.
Yet economic events have taken a few sharp turns that not even Mr. Soros could foresee. And while the mark may eventually sink to the levels many prognosticators envisioned earlier this year -- as low as 2 to the dollar -- economists said it was first likely to test 1.56 to the dollar or maybe even higher.
"The interest-rate differential scenario has completely changed around in favor of the D-mark," said Henry Wilkes, the head of foreign exchange trading at Bank Julius Baer in London.
Behind the turnabout are fundamental shifts in the market's expectations for the economies of Germany and the United States. Throughout the first seven months of the year, the consensus was that Germany's economy was in a slide that would require the Bundesbank to reduce rates steadily. But by late summer there was evidence that the worst might be past, and that the economy was poised for recovery, lessening the pressure on the Bundesbank to cut rates.
At the same time, another source of pressure on the Bundesbank was lifted. The near-collapse of the European exchange rate mechanism at the end of July, and the introduction of a substitute system under which the European currencies can float 15 percent either way, gave France and other recession-bound nations freedom to lower their rates without waiting for Bonn.
Freed from the restraints of the monetary system or not, the German central bank made clear that it was in no rush to cut rates while there were still signs of incipient inflation. Not until Sept. 9 did it cut its discount rate by half a point, to 6.25 percent.
While investors were absorbing the news that the German economy might be rebounding sooner than expected and the rate cuts might not come so quickly, they were also seeing signs that the pace of the American recovery was slower than predicted, and that interest rates, far from being pushed up by the Federal Reserve, might have to be cut. With yields low in the United States, and American stocks at high valuations, investment money has been flowing out of the country -- and much of it has gone to Germany, where yields remain relatively high, and the stock market has been booming.
If the shifting economic fundamentals were not enough to strengthen the mark, a key technical factor was also at play. A number of European nations, having drained their foreign-exchange reserves in an unsuccessful attempt to defend their currencies within the Exchange Rate Mechanism this summer, have had to rebuild their mark holdings, pushing the mark even higher.
Within Europe, the mark remains the anchor by which other nations measure their currencies. Despite the near-collapse of the European monetary system, most, including France, have maintained stable exchange-rate policies, even at the cost of keeping rates high and stifling growth.
France, for example, has not reduced its benchmark lending rate since the monetary system crashed in mid-summer, for it is trying to keep the franc trading at a level that is relatively constant, but still well below its old E.R.M. minimum versus the mark. But unemployment is continuing to rise, and business executives and politicians are increasingly asking whether currency stability is worth the pain of high interest rates.
Economists expect France, Belgium and Denmark, among other nations, to change course soon and put its new exchange-rate flexibility to work by cutting rates.
"The European economies are still in recession, and the prospects for 1994 are not that good," Goldman Sachs International said in a report this month. "In response, we would anticipate that Europe's leaders will increasingly come to realize the need to relax their interest rate grip in coming months."
What will happen in Germany is less clear. Chris Turner, an economist with Barclays de Zoette Wedd in London, said the perception that the German economy is past the worst might prove to be premature. If so, the Bundesbank may be forced to cut rates more quickly, and more deeply, than many investors now expect. "We don't think there's been enough loosening yet to guarantee a recovery," Mr. Turner said. "Until you get a few bad economic figures out of Germany to change the market's perceptions, the Deutschemark may well remain strong," he said. "But on a 6- to 12-month view, we're still bearish on the D-mark and are looking for a move back the other way, with the dollar going above 1.75."

HEADLINE: Changing the Fortunes of the Medical Business

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Remember that callous wisecrack about the people the Wall Street crash of 1987 put out of a job? Question: "How do you call a stockbroker?" Answer: "Waiter!" In the 1990's, the unwitting targets of such gallows humor could well be surgeons, hospital workers, health-insurance brokers and pharmaceutical researchers.
Under President Clinton's health proposal, which would light a fire under a number of trends already happening, a lot of Americans in the medical business, many of them well paid, would be looking for new and often less lucrative lines of work, or at least seeing their incomes fall substantially. Others, however, would adroitly seize new opportunities and come out far ahead. 
 While the health proposal will touch all Americans, it most affects the 11 million people who earn their livelihoods in this $900 billion business -- a business that has grown so large that it consumes one in every seven dollars the nation spends and is sometimes referred to as the medical-industrial complex.
The President's plan, which he is expected to announce formally on Wednesday, aims to guarantee comprehensive health coverage for all, control medical costs by reducing waste and excesses in the system, and improve the quality of health care to boot. Mr. Clinton hopes to prove wrong the experts who have argued that it's possible to accomplish any two of those three goals at once but not all three.
Under the proposal, regional "health alliances" -- essentially giant insurance-buying pools -- would collect money from employers and individuals and in return offer them a variety of competing health plans. A National Health Board would control the regional alliances' budgets and prevent them from raising insurance premiums more than a certain amount. At its simplest, the proposal implies a lot of new pressure on medical providers to hold down their costs without sacrificing quality, or lose out to others who do.
While any plan that emerges from Congress next year may bear little resemblance to what Mr. Clinton is proposing, it seems clear that many of the concepts he is endorsing are already here to stay. If some Americans still harbored hopes that the cost-conscious approach known as managed care might be just a bad dream, they likely abandoned them after the President's endorsement.
 
The Physician's Lot
 Among the winners under Mr. Clinton's proposal would be physicians who join a health plan's medical network that assures them a steady stream of patients. The price they pay: a loss of some of their prized autonomy, as medical reviewers scrutinize the way they treat patients and the fees they charge. Those who refuse to play by these rules could be excluded by the health plans, and find it increasingly difficult to find patients. For many resentful physicians, George Orwell was only a decade off in predicting Big Brother would rule in 1984.
Primary care physicians -- family practitioners, internists and pediatricians -- could be big winners, as the "gatekeepers" whose approval is required for referrals to specialists.
By contrast, many medical specialists would be losers as primary-care doctors follow rules that keep the "gates" shut more of the time and some specialists are frozen out by health plans that deal with only a select group of doctors.
Lawyers may also be winners. The new limits on the historically independent practice of medicine could produce many a legal battle. "There are very few losers in this world who aren't going to use whatever legal rights they think they have," said Kirk Johnson, general counsel of the American Medical Association.
Consulting firms also expect to prosper by keeping employers abreast of the latest rules and helping physicians and hospitals play the managed-care game.
Many hospitals, long on empty beds, will be losers. They'll be out of business unless they can ally themselves with the medical networks that increasingly control hospital admissions. But nursing homes and home health care companies could be winners if Congress approves a tax break for long-term care insurance and Federal money to help states pay for more home care.
Pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical-device companies could be losers. They contend that price controls on drugs and limits on overall medical spending would hobble their ability to finance research, which would mean fewer innovative life-saving products.
Then again, most large drug and technology companies have profitable operations in foreign countries that already regulate both spending and prices.
Although medical technology may be set back, computer technology could be a winner. Medical networks are increasingly relying on elaborate software to analyze mountains of medical information. The results are used to determine whether patient care is not only medically appropriate but cost-effective.
Health maintenance organizations have been the model for the managed-care health plans to be offered under the big regional alliances. The big H.M.O.'s seem sure to be winners, unless the Government clamps down on their prices.
Small insurance companies, which do not have enough capital to set up and operate managed-care networks, will lose out, deserted by many of the customers for their traditional health insurance products. Many small health care companies can be expected to pool their resources in alliances and mergers.
Even the five proudly independent teaching hospitals affiliated with the Harvard Medical School are "talking about coming together," said Thomas O. Pyle, the new head of health plans for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. "For those hospitals to even sit and talk about that suggests that the world has changed."
Following is a closer look at some of the winners and losers in a changing medical business.
 
Physicians
Generalists Gain, Specialists Lose
 Family practitioners, internists and pediatricians will be winners. Health maintenance organizations, group medical practices and many hospitals are frantically recruiting them for their networks to serve as gatekeepers who oversee patients' care and refer them to specialists when necessary.
Prosperous medical specialists -- heart surgeons, urologists and radiologists, for example -- would fare less well. Many health care experts say that while there is a shortage of primary-care doctors, there are too many specialists, performing more tests and operations than are medically justified. Cost-conscious medical networks make fewer referrals to specialists and entirely exclude specialists they don't need or want. Those who get lots of work will do so only if they accept discounted fees.
Under the Clinton proposal, some specialists could suffer especially deeply. Not only would certain benefits not be covered under the guaranteed health package, but also their cost would ultimately be taxed as income for the employee receiving the benefits. So demand for such things would fall. Examples: adult eyeglasses, hearing aids and in-vitro fertilization.
Some medical groups are so worried about their prospects that they are selling their offices to investor-owned companies like Caremark International and Phycor Inc., which pay for new buildings and equipment that the doctors will need to compete for managed-care business.
Under the Clinton plan, Government-appointed councils would order more graduate training slots in teaching hospitals for primary-care physicians, and fewer for specialists. There would be a Federal program to encourage specialists with dwindling practices to retrain in primary care.
As managed care spreads, a rapidly growing percentage of physicians are also coming face to face with an unsettling practice called capitation -- receiving a pre-arranged fee for each person enrolled in an H.M.O., rather than a payment for each service rendered. "Capitation is an incentive to provide less care," said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association. "There are no benign incentives in health care."
 
New Insurers
Medical Networks With Big Dreams
 Big health maintenance organizations are likely winners in a new system in which capitation payments would finance most medical care, replacing traditional fees for each service. Among the H.M.O. businesses likely to gain: those of Aetna, Cigna, FHP, Humana, Kaiser Permanente, Metropolitan Life, New York Life's Sanus unit, Pacificare, Prudential, Qualmed, Takecare, Travelers, United Healthcare and U.S. Healthcare, and big Blue Cross networks including those in California, Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan, Illinois and Kansas City.
The big H.M.O.'s have already organized large networks of doctors and hospitals, and many have deep pockets to finance expansion.
Smaller or financially shaky health plans are disappearing into mergers with or acquisitions by larger managed-care insurers and hospitals. For example, Humana Inc. recently bought Group Health, a nonprofit H.M.O. in Washington; United Healthcare acquired H.M.O. America of Chicago, and Qualmed Inc. bought Health Net, California's largest for-profit H.M.O.
"H.M.O.'s will do well, with or without reform, unless Washington screws it up with tight price controls," said Mr. Pyle of Metropolitan Life. He criticized the President's proposal to tie increases in health-plan premiums to the general inflation rate. He said tight price controls would stymie efforts to increase quality and cost-effectiveness.
Prodding H.M.O.'s to move faster to improve, consumers and employers will be able to comparison-shop for a health plan on the basis of standardized measures of performance, like how long it takes to get an appointment with a doctor and time spent in the waiting room.
 
Traditional Insurers
Pity Small Firms With Old Ways
 Hundreds of small health insurance companies with tens of thousands of independent insurance salespeople expect to lose their customers for traditional health coverage as managed care gathers steam.
"There are many more sellers than buyers," said Lee Zinzow, an actuary and broker based in Winston-Salem, N.C., who helps small companies sell their traditional major medical insurance lines. "Values have dropped dramatically. The majority are not willing to pay anything at all."
Some of these companies are switching to disability insurance, or planning supplementary policies for features like adult dental care and eyeglasses that would not be covered under the Clinton plan. Others are developing niches that they hope will be overlooked by big independent H.M.O's and the insurers that are strong in managed care. One small company, Medical Benefits Mutual Life, based in Newark, Ohio, is helping rural hospitals "create their own private-label health plans," said Doug Freeman, the president.
 
Hospitals
So Many Beds, So Few Patients
 Many hospitals will be losers. They are already viewed as the most expensive caregivers, where patients go only as a last resort. With more than one-third of their roughly 1 million beds standing empty, hospitals increasingly have to accept hard bargains. As they do with doctors, a growing number of health plans pay the hospitals in their networks a fixed fee for each person covered, sick or well. If the cost of care exceeds that amount, it's the hospital's problem.
Many smaller hospitals face a struggle simply to survive. Some will merge or become partners with others, or be acquired. Chains like Columbia Healthcare typically buy several at a time, seeking to dominate a market. Then they close the least-efficient hospitals and offer doctors incentives like ownership of stock in the remaining hospitals to encourage them to send their patients there.
Trying to make themselves more attractive in the world of managed care, strong hospitals are already creating systems that include walk-in clinics, home care and nursing homes. Henry Ford Health System in Detroit recently announced a partnership with Michigan Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the Mercy hospital chain and several thousand doctors. New York Hospital, the teaching hospital of Cornell University, created a network that includes six hospitals in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens (including Gracie Square Psychiatric), two nursing homes and three outpatient clinics.
Hospitals, which once pampered specialists, are now wooing primary-care physicians with offers of free office space and, in some cases, even acquiring practices. Sutter Health, a Sacramento, Calif.-based hospital group, recently added two large group medical practices.
But not all the news is bad for hospitals. President Clinton's plan to cover 59 million Americans who are either uninsured or inadequately covered could sharply reduce the bad debt that leaves 6 percent of hospital charges unpaid each year, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.
As hospitals slim down or close, thousands of registered nurses are moving to new jobs in H.M.O.'s, clinics, home-health agencies and nursing homes, where the demand for nurses is growing. The Clinton proposal to make health-education classes and preventive services like immunization shots a standard benefit would mean even more jobs for nurses.
The outlook is much less bright for some of the 3.2 million hospital workers who are not nurses. Some large teaching hospitals like Rush Presbyterian St. Luke's in Chicago have already announced large dismissals.
 
Nursing Services
A Chance, Finally, For More Coverage
 Nursing homes and companies offering home health care could be winners as more people join managed-care networks, in which doctors and nurses move patients from hospitals to less-expensive settings as soon as possible. Under the Clinton proposals, the current Medicare benefits for home or nursing-home care for the disabled and people over 65 after a hospital stay would be extended to people of all ages.
New tax breaks would encourage people to buy private insurance for long-term care for chronic illnesses like Alzheimer's disease.
 
Medical Technology
Hurt by the View That Less Is More
 Tougher times are ahead for makers of medical technology, the overuse of which may account for as much as $135 billion a year in unnecessary health care spending, experts estimate. For example, a study published last week raised questions about the medical value of hundreds of thousands of routine ultrasound checkups for pregnant women, at $200 a test. The list of potential customers for everything from artificial hip joints to million-dollar scanners could shrink from thousands to mere hundreds if the 6,000 hospitals and thousands of physician groups are folded into tightly managed medical networks that control purchasing.
There are already "tremendous pressures" to decrease use of the equipment, said Dr. William Straub, a University of Pittsburgh radiologist who is a senior technology analyst with the Jackson Hole Group of health policy experts. For example, when doctors receive a per capita fee to minister to a group of patients, they can no longer add income by running tests in their own office lab.
There will still be a premium on breakthrough devices like Medtronic Inc.'s new implantable defibrillator to restart faulty hearts, said Mr. Abramowitz, the analyst. And the emerging medical networks will need technology to differentiate themselves from competitors, added Fred Abbey, a partner at Ernst & Young. But they won't be ordering as many machines in a given city.
Cost-effectiveness is the watchword. "Unless you are developing technology that lowers your customers' costs, it will not be accepted in the market, except in very niche circumstances," said John Trani, president of General Electric's GE Medical Systems unit, the world's largest maker of diagnostic imagers. Prices of the company's magnetic resonance scanners have dropped to $800,000 for a basic model, from $2 million for the early, more limited versions in 1985. The company, whose 1992 sales exceeded $3 billion, is urging budget-obsessed buyers to buy extra features for existing scanners or models with fewer bells and whistles.
Official advisory committees in a number of places, including Minnesota, Maine and Rochester, N.Y., are already looking at proposed big-ticketpurchases of equipment in their communities. "Do we really need this?" they are asking. "If so, how many?"
 
Pharmaceuticals
More Customers, Lower Margins
 Most brand-name drug makers are trimming their earnings estimates as a growing number of managed-care buyers insist on discounted prices. But drug-company gloom also has to do with unpromising research pipelines as patents are expiring on blockbuster products.
"The change in the market is private-sector driven," said Paul A. Brooke, a pharmaceutical analyst at Morgan Stanley. He cited managed-care plans that use electronic systems and mail-order pharmacies, both of which routinely order the lowest-priced product.
Makers of generic drugs should thrive, at least until heavy competition rachets down their already narrow profit margins.
The good news for the pharmaceutical companies is the Clinton proposal to add coverage of outpatient drugs for people eligible for Medicare and make the drugs a standard benefit for all health plans, so that they would be tax deductible. The added drug benefits would cover 70 million potential customers.
The bad news in the Clinton proposals is in the cost restraints: 15 percent rebates to the Government on sales to the 30 million Medicare patients, who are the main users of prescriptions. A further rebate would be required on products whose prices rose faster than general inflation. And the Clinton plan proposes a requirement to "negotiate" with Federal officials over the prices of new drugs, under the threat of rejection for Medicare reimbursement.
Fighting criticism that they charge too much, most drug companies are trying to show the cost benefits of their products. Merck & Company, for example, produces numbers to argue that its Proscar treatment for enlarged prostate glands that are not cancerous is an economical alternative to an $8,000 to $10,000 operation.
The big drug makers are also scrambling to develop over-the-counter products, which are not included in most health coverage and so can be sold at whatever price the market will bear. Warner-Lambert and Wellcome P.L.C. are the latest to form a joint venture to share marketing of over-the-counter drugs.
A number of brand-name drug makers also make low-priced generic drugs. And in a move that astonished most analysts, Merck, the world's largest drug maker, announced this summer that it would become a managed-care player by acquiring Medco Containment Services Inc., the largest mail-order pharmacy and discount-drug distributor.
Another loser, at least for now, is biotechnology companies working on new drugs. Uncertainty over where the Government is going on health care has dried up access to capital for these companies, which typically have few cash-generating products to support their research budgets.
 
Consultants
Many Questions, Many to Answer
 Employee-benefits consultants, who occupied a hot corner of the consulting market in the 1980's, are expecting explosive growth in the health care revolution.
Some large firms, including William M. Mercer, Foster Higgins and KPMG Peat Marwick, are offering their managed-care expertise to hospitals and physicians' groups as well as employers -- and plan to do so for regional health alliances promoted by Mr. Clinton.
The American Medical Association is offering an "800" number that members can call for names of 80 consultants eager to be "physician advocates," who could advise doctors on business arrangements many will be making for the first time.
 
Lawyers
New Constraints, More Lawsuits
 Many members of the medical community might end up losers, but many lawyers, particularly in the field of health law, could be winners. The new constraints on a historically independent profession could lead to all kinds of battles.
Alice Gosfield, a Philadelphia lawyer who is a former president of the National Health Lawyers Association, ticked off some of the issues. Lawyers will be called in to advise on business-law and antitrust questions as hospitals and medical groups merge and regional purchasing alliances are formed.
There will also be disputes involving increased efforts to combat fraud and abuse, and over the rights and obligations of small businesses, which would be obliged to buy health insurance for their workers. There will be lawsuits by doctors and hospitals who have been excluded by a health plan. Doctors and hospitals that get low marks on health care "report cards" may claim breach of confidentiality, defamation and unlawful interference with a business. Patients and doctors will sue to get paid for care that a health plan has rejected as inappropriate.
"As large plans exclude physicians or reduce reimbursement or coverage, physicians and patients call lawyers and file lawsuits," said Mr. Johnson of the American Medical Association. "Trial lawyers will come out real well," he added.
Although unhappy patients would have to submit disputes to mediators appointed by each health plan before suing, they could still file malpractice lawsuits seeking unlimited damages for pain and suffering. Legal experts said the system would create even more work for lawyers, who would represent patients in the mediation.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1659 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 12-17

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Ford Looks Out for No. 2; G.M. Is on Its Own 

Detroit's auto industry is often seen as a monolith as it deals with unions, say, or Japanese rivals. But that image has less and less to do with reality, a fact made starkly evident in Ford's tentative contract with the U.A.W. last week. The No. 2 auto maker is doing just fine these days, as the union well knew in choosing it to set a bargaining benchmark. Ford gave the union higher wages and pensions, and even as companies nationwide force workers to pay more for health care, Ford will keep footing the whole bill. It did get the union to agree to lower wages for newly hired workers, with the pay gap to last longer. That works fine for Ford, which plans big hiring. But for G.M. -- now under great pressure to accept similar terms -- such a contract would be a disaster. It desperately needs to cut its costs, and the Ford deal gives it no way to do so, because the last thing it could possibly do in the near future is hire anyone.
 
Viacom, Paramount . . . Diller?
 
In an age that almost makes a deity of communications, media companies keep joining forces to get their fingers in every pie. Time and Warner put their acts together several years ago. Then last week came news that Viacom would buy Paramount, the last of the big independent studios, for $8.2 billion -- putting it second only to the $14 billion Time Warner deal. Viacom is a power in cable television, with such channels as MTV and Nickelodeon, and Paramount is all over the place, with publishers and sports teams, as well as movies, so the new company will cover just about every media base. If, that is, the deal happens. These things are never simple, as Time and Warner learned. And sure enough, rumors arose that Barry Diller, head of QVC, might put in his own bid for Paramount now that someone has put the idea in his head. It could become interesting.
 
Gerstner Under a Microscope
 
The Gerstner watch continues. Louis Gerstner has one of the most daunting jobs imaginable -- saving I.B.M. from going the way of its dinosaur cousins -- so every time he sneezes, all eyes shoot to him. Can he do it? Last week he gave a big hint of his vision, creating an executive committee aimed at smoother operations and less bureaucracy. So, it seems, he's not about to remake the company from scratch or sell off big chunks of it. Eight of the 11 panel members, after all, are longtime I.B.M.-ers, so he's doing what he can with what he's got. One interesting note: minicomputers and mainframes will be overseen by a single panel member, a sure sign of the shrinking role of these big machines in a world made tiny by the microchip.
 
Did Kmart Cross the Line?
 
An employer has a legitimate interest in much about its employees' lives -- whether they use drugs, say, or whether they were once convicted as ax-murderers. But there is a line where employers' rights screech to a halt, and workers in Illinois sued Kmart last week, saying the retailer had tromped well across that line. Kmart confirmed that it had hired a detective agency, but insisted that its purpose was to break up a theft ring at a distribution center. But workers contend that the agency's report included things like employee opinions on unions, their fishing habits, who was shopping at (horrors!) Wal-Mart, even who lived with whom. After working hours, one worker said, "it's none of their business."
 
Airlines in Search of a Flight Plan
 
Airlines just can't seem to decide how big they want to be, or how much they should charge to ferry a restless population from city to city to city. Yes, fares are going up, as they must if the big airlines are to stop losing their shirts. But last week the airlines turned around and staged a clearance sale, marking down fall travel as much as 45 percent -- if, of course, you bought your tickets quickly. Beyond that, strategies differ. Delta, United and Continental seem inclined to follow Southwest (funny how often that upstart crops up as a role model) into the world of quick flights, low fares and no frills. But American is sticking to its hub-and-spoke system -- funneling passengers to a hub city, then shuffling and scattering them. American also said last week that it planned 5,000 jobs cuts and a smaller fleet.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Just How 'Green' Is Nafta?
 
On many issues, those who call themselves environmentalists present a fairly united front. Not so with the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has split this movement deeply. Last week the split erupted into a shouting match, with the pact's defenders -- generally big groups like the Environmental Defense Fund -- accusing critics of "feeding off misinformation." For their part, the pact's critics, including the Sierra Club and Greenpeace, say that supporters are too cozy with big business. In a way, it's a trickle-down/trickle-up dispute. Critics insist that the accord would lower environmental standards to accommodate Mexico's economy, while backers say Mexico needs help to deal with its environmental problems. In other words, will a rising lake lift all canoes, or will a falling one ground them? We won't know unless the dam comes down.
 
Israel's Peace Dividend
 
Last week's Mideast truce, if it holds, will, amazingly, end an agonizing chapter in world history. But you know that. Among the unknowns, though, is this: Will Israel's war-weary economy be able to kick its boots off and its heels up? The answer: yes and no. First, one might expect a quick swords-into-plowshares transformation. Not necessarily. For one thing, those swords will still be needed, though for different purposes. In addition, a lot of those swords are American, and Washington may be less inclined to send them to a more peaceful land. But here's where peace will help greatly: in drawing outside investment from nations that, quite understandably, have been leery of putting money into a country constantly at war.
 
Yeltsin Gambles on Reform
 
Boris Yeltsin is apparently putting all his chips on economic reform. Last week, in a surprise move, he brought back Yegor T. Gaidar, the young economist who as Mr. Yeltsin's economic adviser two years ago had pushed strongly for a market economy in Russia. In December Mr. Gaidar was forced out as Acting Prime Minister after strong opposition from conservatives to his radical approach. So for Mr. Yeltsin to bring him back now shows that in spite of the opposition, his mind is set on reform.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Surprise! Rates Can Go Up, Too
 
Just when it seemed that inflation would be relegated to ancient-history books and interest rates would shrivel nearly to extinction, two reports came along last week to stir things up. Retail sales for July posted their fifth straight rise, and retail prices rose 0.3 percent, and suddenly rates were bounding up again, with 30-year Treasury yields back above 6 percent. Maybe below that level traders get nervous. "I think the train overshot the station at 6 percent," said one economist. "The market is very sensitive."
 
Take a Risk, Pay the Price
 
Some people don't see starting a business as especially risky. You dream a big dream, spend a little money, borrow a lot. If you crash, there's the warm, comforting blanket of bankruptcy. Someone else picks up the bill. But not everyone has it so easy. Some daredevils will soon have to pay, up front, for their gambles. The National Park Service, tired of spending big money to rescue stranded hikers, plans to require mountain climbers and others "who intentionally engage in high-risk recreation" to buy insurance to cover rescues. The first sites: Mount Rainier and Mount McKinley.
 
DeBartolo Looks to the Public
 
Back when interest rates were visible to the naked eye, people put money in banks -- and banks put money in real estate. Then real estate crashed, scaring banks away, and rates crashed, sending people looking for other places to invest. So now, again proving that the shortest distance between points is a straight line, the real estate folks are going right to investors for cash. Last week such dealings hit a peak when the Edward J. DeBartolo shopping center empire announced a $600 million offering to become a real estate investment trust, the biggest REIT ever.
 
Health Reform: It Will Happen
 
It's official. Health care reform has achieved bandwagon status -- for even Bob Dole, so often the pesky Coyote to the Clinton Road Runner, has jumped aboard. Congressional Republicans as well as the American Medical Association vowed last week to help President Clinton fix the health care mess. They have, to be sure, their own ideas: "Our proposal is dramatically different," Mr. Dole said. He would not, for instance, force employers to pay for health care. But it's becoming clearer that it's gotten so bad -- the momentum for change so strong -- that something will be done, that within a year or so all Americans just might be guaranteed medical care. If that really happens, could a cure for the common cold be far behind?
 
Taming the Temple of Glitz
 
Trying to civilize Times Square is a bit like trying to tame a hurricane: it often seems that that temple of gaudiness and filth is a force of nature. A decade ago, the talk was of hulking office towers -- swoop in with cranes, usher in the oh-so-civilized office workers, blast the grime away. That was an unsettling prospect for those who felt an odd attachment to this monument to seediness, and a poor real estate market killed the idea. Last week state and city officials presented their latest vision of 42d Street, of noise and lights and glitter -- and renovation, not razing. "We're going to re-create the old Times Square," Governor Cuomo said. "All that blight, all that obscenity, is going to be gone." Good luck when the hurricane speaks.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Dissecting the 90's Workplace

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
THE American workplace may not yet be in a nasty and brutish Hobbesian state of nature, but employees know better than anyone else that it is in a disagreeable and unnerving state of turbulence. As a result, says a far-reaching new survey, employees increasingly have doubts about the value of company loyalty and increasingly are putting their own needs and interests above their employers'. Moreover, employees are more and more often willing to trade traditional compensation carrots like wages and benefits for flexibility and autonomy, job characteristics likely to allow them to balance their lives at work and at home.
The startling implication, especially for employers who have been depending on a workforce made tractable by fear: Companies that fail to factor in quality-of-employee-life issues when imposing total quality management or "re-engineering" or any other of the competiveness-enhancing, productivity-improving schemes now popular may gain little but a view of the receding backs of their best people leaving for friendlier premises. 
 "Workers care about the quality of their work environment," said Ellen Galinsky, director of the National Study of the Changing Workforce, the results of which were released earlier this month by the Families and Work Institute in New York.
The study, which researchers plan to repeat every four years, is the most ambitious effort to learn about employee-employer concerns since the Labor Department's 1977 "Quality of Employment Survey," research that is now dated by changes in the American economy.
The new, privately funded research was done last year with a randomly selected national sample of some 3,400 employed men and women. Among the findings:
* Over all, 42 percent of the workers -- the average of workers at small, medium and large companies -- report that they are at companies undergoing downsizing or permanent workforce reductions. At large companies, more than half the workers are in the midst of downsizing, and 40 percent report cuts in the numbers of managers.
* Almost 9 of 10 workers live with family members, and nearly half care for dependents, including children, elderly parents or ailing spouses.
* There are no differences between women and men in the tradeoffs they are willing to make for help with dependent care.
* Despite the flood of women into jobs outside the home, their domestic responsibilities have not changed much. "This is true even in families where women contribute half or more of the family income, and where workers are young," the survey said.
* Younger workers are no more likely to be personally prepared to work in a racially and technically diverse environment than older workers.
* Men and women of color and white women view the chances of advancement for white men as higher than do white men.
* Workers see little difference between male and female managers. However, managers, male or female, with childcare responsibilities are seen as more sympathetic to employees with family-related conflicts. "A good manager can stand in the worker's shoes and in the manager's shoes and come up with a solution," Ms. Galinsky said. "This conflicts with the stereotype that people with kids will be too consumed to do a good job."
* Conflicts between work and family tend to be resolved in favor of the job, usually to the detriment of the family and the worker.
THIS last observation surprised some work-family experts. Companies tend to view their work-family programs as a way to improve productivity by "keeping family problems at bay," Faith Wohl, director of human resource initiatives at Du Pont, said. "I still think it's a problem of productivity. But the workplace itself may be a problem. It may be intensifying the fragility of the family. The worker brings an additional set of problems back into the workplace."
One of the survey's most surprising results is how low salary and benefits rated -- both in the bottom half of 20 possible reasons -- for employees who switched jobs in the last five years. Highest rated were: "Open communication," "effect on personal/family life" and "nature of work." Only 35 percent rated wages as a very important reason for taking the job. One explanation is that the range of salary options for most workers is narrow; another is that workers really do want more control over their destiny and, up to a point, will sacrifice cash to get it.
The research provides evidence that job burnout is widespread, in part because workers forced to make a choice are more likely to sacrifice time for themselves than time for work and family. "Carving out some time for oneself represents an investment in mental health and well-being that may well offset occasional or modest reductions in attention to work and family," the report said.
In other words, steal away for an hour or two once in awhile and don't even think about feeling guilty.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
At This Taystee, Opportunity Rises

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
For many New Yorkers, the name Taystee conjures up the Flushing bakery vacated in July 1992. But 14 years earlier, the bread company left its factory on West 126th Street, a complex now at the heart of a project to assist small businesses in Harlem.
Under an "incubator" plan for fledgling businesses sponsored by the Harlem Restoration Project, three buildings between Amsterdam and Morningside Avenues that were part of the Taystee factory will be remodeled to house 40 small manufacturing and service businesses, from clothing designers and building contractors to artisans and accountants. The buildings are to offer low rents (about $800 a month) and meeting rooms, office machines and even clerical help. 
 In addition, the Harlem Small Business Center at Pace University will provide counseling and hands-on help with business plans, financial packages and management. The center will also move to the site from the State Office Building.
Most of the plans come from a survey of 400 small businesses in Harlem. The buildings' financing -- $5.2 million -- comes from public and private sources.
Despite the trend toward service-oriented business, Mr. Schwartz says the restoration project wants to encourage manufacturers because they tend to create more jobs.
The Harlem Restoration Project bought the former Taystee buildings in 1980 and built its office and a thrift shop in a former Taystee outlet for day-old bread on 125th Street. The group rented out some of the empty factory space to local businesses, and so, for the next few months, they will be cleaning their former tenants' debris so that construction can begin early next year.
Although he does not expect the building to be completed until 1995, Mr. Schwartz plans to begin recruiting tenants. So far, a dried-flower arranger, a children's book publisher, and importers of electric buses and exotic African woods have expressed interest. Anyone can apply, but applicants will be reviewed by a board to insure that their plans are sound and that they will be adding jobs to the area. EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
The Next Tidal Wave? Some Call It 'Social Computing'

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
PERHAPS without knowing exactly what it will all mean, everyone seems to be talking about the impending convergence of computer networks, groupware, telephone services, handheld electronic devices, cable television, the Internet and other on-line information services, mixed in with the entertainment industry, traditional news media and other communications technologies.
Such was the buzz last week in Boston at Forrester Research Inc.'s Technology Forum, where business executives gathered to exchange ideas about what they called social computing. Social computing, a communications-rich brew, is expected to create new ways for businesses and their customers to communicate, over new types of wireless as well as wired pathways, using new types of computers called personal communicators. The rise of social computing is expected to shift the emphasis of computing devices away from simple number crunching and data base management to wider-ranging forms of business communications. 
 "Within five years," said William M. Bluestein, a senior analyst with Forrester, "a barrage of new technologies will radically change your relationship with customers, product features and service delivery, and the structure of manufacturing, sales, service and distribution."
"A technological shock wave is about to strike society and the workplace," Mr. Bluestein said. "In the last six months, computer hardware manufacturers, software providers, cable TV operators, and phone companies have been caught up in a frenzied mating dance."
Of course, we've heard all this sort of breathless rhetoric before, and we've seen that some companies are not very good dancers. But Forrester, which is often given credit for coining the term and defining the idea of client-server computing back in 1987, sees social computing as the next big wave. Where client-server broke away from mainframe-based systems and distributed computing power to everyone in the organization, social computing goes the next step and, riding atop client server for a while, extends the distribution of computing power to a company's customers and suppliers.
The word social is important, the Forrester executives believe, because the same technologies that will enable better communication between companies and their workers will also spread rapidly to the consumers of a given company's products and services.
One way to think about this new era is to think of the past. The history of computing in businesses started with a giant central mainframe and has inexorably moved outward, to the department, to the desktop, to the briefcase. Computers have gotten smaller and cheaper and more powerful along the way. It is difficult to construct a scenario that would change this relentless move outward from the core of the business. Taken to the next step -- and this is what social computing is all about -- the computing power will move into the pockets of the workers and eventually into the homes and pockets of the customers.
Another way to look at this era is to forget the past. Forget Citibank's horrible experience with home banking. Forget the shop-at-home-via-cable TV networks, even though it's a $2 billion business already. Forget even such recent services as paying bills by computer, even though it is a billion-dollar business.
Instead, think of Federal Express and U.P.S., which are already involved with computing systems that enable a worker to encode and track packages from hand-held, wireless computers. Think of movie theaters in Boston that earlier this year sold 40 percent of their tickets to big hits by telephone, using touch-tone services.
Think about the way you want to work with other businesses. If you're shopping for a car, you can already log on to Compuserve, request a printout of the make and model you're considering, and get a printout of the actual dealer invoice from the factory.
Some rudimentary examples of social computing are already beginning to appear, and it's not too early to start thinking about how this big cloud of gas will affect your company when it coalesces into a star.
Colin Crook, senior technology officer of Citibank N.A./Citicorp in New York, noted in a presentation at the gathering that formidable barriers must be overcome for social computing to take hold.
The hurdles are regulatory (the Government has to determine whether the pathways are public or private, and who gets the bandwidth), legal (in the form of copyrights), financial (how is the cost of the new services to be shared?), cultural (if you can't program your VCR, why would you buy insurance over a wireless Newton Message Pad?), and, of course, technical (Apple won't even let me touch a Message Pad until I've flown to California for a few hours of indoctrination, which is hardly a good sign for something that is supposed to be a consumer product).
"A lot of technology planets have to come into line before this will happen," acknowledged John C. McCarthy, head of technology research for Forrester. But in recent weeks what seemed like a hydra of disconnected activity now appears to be converging, including new types of telephones, television, handheld electronic devices and wireless and traditional networked services.
Before long, the proponents of social computing contend, companies will routinely exchange information with suppliers and manufacturers using a combination of private and public information networks. Customers will gather information, place orders and handle purchase orders and invoices electronically.
On a retail level, businesses will offer their products and services over the emerging social computing network. Forrester says some companies are already aggressively developing services for interactive television, smart telephones and wireless personal communicators, citing such well-known names as ABC News, A.T.&T., Home Box Office, Mastercard International, Newsweek, Sony and United Parcel Service.
Forrester says it has identified many more companies -- hotels, airlines, financial houses, insurance companies and so on -- that are quietly developing services for these new devices and networks. Such companies are keeping a low profile, the researchers said, in part because they see how these technologies have given a huge competitive advantage to pioneers including Federal Express and U.P.S.
On the consumer level, if and when the proper networks fall into place, information is likely to be available electronically for a broad range of products, including household appliances, vacations, computers and software, furniture, insurance, clothing ("you're tuned to the L.L. Bean Channel") and perhaps even homes (you've been transferred to Seattle and want to see some houses before flying out to meet the real estate agent).
The consensus among the executives at the Forrester conference, who included John Sculley of Apple Computer, George M.C. Fisher of Motorola and Robert M. Kavner of A.T.&T., is that it will be 1996 or 1997 before the regulatory and technical hurdles are cleared for truly widespread social computing.
But companies can certainly begin taking steps now to prepare for the era.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;
Flower District Is Staying, After All

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Plans to transplant Manhattan's Flower District to the Bronx, with the city's help, have stalled.
Complaining of congestion and other problems in Manhattan, the four largest flower wholesalers announced at the beginning of the year that they would move to an abandoned rail yard in the South Bronx. The city offered grants and tax credits for the move, and the rest of the $70 million flower industry was expected to be swept into the Bronx. 
 But none of the other 14 wholesalers signed on, and one of the original four dropped out of the project.
That wholesaler, Mitchell Vlachos, said that 28th Street was a major hub and that "moving to the Bronx would mean sacrificing clients in Brooklyn, Manhattan -- especially Wall Street -- South Jersey and Staten Island."
Many people did not know how their employees could go to work at 4 A.M. on public transportation, he said. "Above all, people weren't ready to make such a drastic change, particularly in these tight economic times."
While admitting that the Bronx deal had problems, Victor Rallis, the leader of the original group of four wholesalers, said he still hoped to leave Manhattan.
But the other wholesalers and most retailers have formed a vigorous lobbying group, the Floral Industry Association, with help from City Councilman Thomas K. Duane.
"What we're telling the city is, you've got to recognize that the flower industry is a vital sector and gives us basic support," said Jim Weisse, the vice president of the floral association. "There are a number of real options in Manhattan." Immediate requirements include additional parking, friendlier traffic enforcement and more security, Mr. Duane said.
So very early one morning last week, Wallace L. Ford 2d, Commissioner of Business Services, led a cortege of officials from several city agencies through the maze of exotic flowers and greenery, buyers and sellers, tourists, and doubled-parked trucks, vans and cars that clogged the area along 28th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway and along the Avenue of the Americas between 26th and 29th Streets.
"I wanted to get a firsthand sense of traffic, security, sanitation and environmental problems at peak trading time," Mr. Ford said. The purpose of the outing, he said, was to see if a task force should be established to help the Flower Market at peak hours. The commission runs such a task force at the Fulton Fish Market.
And Mr. Duane said the Flower District may eventually move -- but not far. He said there were potential sites around Houston Street. MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
In the Rag Trade, They Also Serve Who Pleat

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
THE BUSINESS of putting pleats into skirts, dresses and sleeves is under siege. The aggressor? In a word, pants. "There's nothing worse for pleating than pants," Anthony Bonanno, owner of the S.F. Pleating and Stitching Company in Brooklyn, said gravely.
In the rag trade, people read hemlines the way fortune tellers read tea leaves. Sudden changes, in this case up or down, bode ill for business. But even worse for the handful of pleaters still in operation these days are the mixed messages designers have sent over the last few seasons. The ambiguity -- is the style long or short or a hybrid? -- has left women standing on the sidelines in pants. 
 The resurgence of the pant and its impact on the pleating business is a measure of how fickle business can be for those serving New York's garment industry. As critical as they are, no businesses are buffeted more by fashion trends and economic weakness than "findings," the collective name for the small businesses that supply apparel makers with everything from buttons and zippers to elaborate embroidery, stitching and pleats.
For the most part, the apparel manufacturers lining Seventh Avenue and Broadway are really assemblers of pieces and parts. They select fabric woven by someone else and hire contractors to cut it, others to sew it, and still others to finish it, press it and pleat it. "The only reason there's any apparel business left at all in New York City is because of the findings industry," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller. "The common perception is that a dress is two pieces of fabric sewn together. The reality is that 67 pieces and processes went into it."
When zippers become popular, purveyors of buttons and buttonholes go out of business. When boning is in favor, those who sell elastic tighten their belts. And when pants start becoming feminine staples, pleaters hunker down to wait for women to liberate their legs.
"If it's not one thing, it's another," said Robert Meyer, sales manager of Stanley Stitching and Pleating, which was founded by his father, Stanley, in 1957.
Or as his competitor Mr. Bonanno puts it, "Either way it's crazy. It's crazy when it's busy because you've got to get it out faster than you possibly can. Or it's crazy because you haven't got enough business and you've got to manage your overhead, and everybody's singing the blues and trying to squeeze you for something. That's the kind of crazy it is right now."
Pleating is one of the few businesses left in the garment industry that has not been overtaken by technology. It still largely involves labor-intensive handiwork -- detailed calculations, pattern-making skills and folding the pattern into an accordion.
Where machines are used, mostly to press tiny pleats like mushroom, crystal or Fortuni (made famous by the designer Mary McFadden) into fabric, workers are still required to feed them with fibrous paper and material. Skill is needed to change the machines' settings to accommodate, say, georgette instead of silk, and it can take anywhere from 10 minutes to two hours.
"Machine pleating is more expensive and requires many fine-tunings," said James Pi, owner of Sew Fine Associates, a pleating business on West 38th Street in Manhattan.
The bundles of cut pieces stacked in Mr. Pi's shop are hand-pleated in long cardboard patterns -- two interlocking pieces between which fabric is sandwiched. More than 3,000 patterns for over 200 different pleat widths are tucked into makeshift shelves.
To make a pleat, workers spread a length of fabric over the bottom half of a pattern, which looks like an open handmade fan. The fabric is laid out smoothly, then the top half is laid over it and secured with weights. A worker gently nudges one end of the pattern so that it slides up like an accordion, top into bottom, securing the fabric between. The pattern with the fabric pinched inside is then rolled up in yet more stiff paper and put into a steam bath or autoclave for anywhere from 3 to 30 minutes. It is removed and dried, and when the fabric emerges from the rolled-up pattern, it is pleated.
Mr. Pi, one of the few pleaters who is busy these days, has actually had to subcontract out some work. Mr. Bonanno is also churning out machine pleats for lingerie and fancy evening dresses. He has a large order for the latest rage in fashion: long, flowing skirts in floral fabric stamped with narrow "broom twist" pleats, which are twisted and tied while drying. The result are pleats that look as if they've been slept in; they were big sellers this summer, and retailers are reordering them in ocher tones for the fall.
STILL, business isn't what it was three years ago, when every woman in America seemed to want at least one pleated skirt in her wardrobe. Then, Seventh Avenue kept 25 shops busy pleating garments. Now there are about 15 shops, and although no one has any idea what revenues are for the industry, only six or seven shops are said to have steady work. Mr. Bonanno estimates that pleating runs in seven-year cycles, which means three or four more years before their shops are humming.
As apparel manufacturers shifted production overseas in the late 1970's and early 1980's, many pleating shops in the garment district went out of business. But those who have stayed alive are hoping that the trend toward manufacturing closer to home will reverse the decline.
Some are also offering clients other services, like tucking, finishing, stitching or assembly. Mr. Meyer has expanded into embroidery, which is enjoying a resurgence. "To have stayed in the pleating and stitching business only would have been like suicide," he said. "So we've invested in new equipment and gone into embroideries. Hopefuly, when embroidery slows down, stitching and pleating will pick up."
Still, Mr. Meyer said he hoped it didn't pick up so much that competition increases. "On the one hand, I hate being under the gun," he said. "But on the other hand, let it stay. Right now, I'm one of the only games in town."

HEADLINE: Ownership In a Recession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on the "Trials of Home Ownership in a Recession" (Aug. 8) very nicely highlights the financing problem "negative equity" creates for owners of co-op apartments.
But there is a tangential, perhaps more serious, problem in a building where the units are not substantially sold and where the underlying mortgage is coming due -- the reluctance of lenders to refinance underlying mortgages where a large number of units are owned by sponsors or investors. 
 Lenders are concerned that such units, which are rent stabilized, probably are not able to earn enough in rental income to cover maintenance and financing costs. This endangers the financial viability of the co-op corporation -- and, of course, directly impacts on the ability of a unit owner to obtain a loan for his or her individual unit. Without the ability to obtain such financing, all sales in a co-op building will virtually come to a halt. Literally hundreds of co-op apartment buildings in New York are confronted by this problem.
 
EDWARD T. BRAVERMAN
Manhattan
 
The writer is head of Braverman & Associates, legal consultant to co-op buildings in New York City.
