HEADLINE: THE NATION;
This Time, Race Is A Murkier Issue

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
NEARLY four years ago, David N. Dinkins took office as the first black man to lead New York City, winning by just two percentage points but pledging to be "the Mayor of all the people." Today, it is increasingly clear that not nearly all the people want him to remain in power.
In 1989, Mr. Dinkins was a triumphant challenger who brought New York's politics in line with its demographics: It was the last of the country's 10 largest cities to elect a black, Hispanic or female mayor. Now he is a wounded incumbent, struggling to keep from being the first black mayor of a major American city to lose his first re-election bid. 
 What happened?
The short answer is: not much. To be sure, Mr. Dinkins has been dented by a bruising recession that has repeatedly forced him to allocate losses and steer a listing ship, not sail on healing waters -- the promise that helped elect him. But he is also confronting the same demographic, political and personal dynamics that made it so hard for him to win last time against Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican former prosecutor, who is running again and, this time, leading in some polls.
Polls also now show New Yorkers more pessimistic about the state of race relations and about any mayor's ability to improve them. And while most New Yorkers believe Mr. Dinkins is more likely to treat all groups fairly, he has been loudly accused of siding with blacks in several charged incidents, from clashes between blacks and Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to the black-led boycott of a Korean-owned grocery.
"I don't think most people really feel he's delivered on his promise," said Thomas H. Kessner, a historian at the City University Graduate Center. "But then again, how does one transcend race when race played such an important role in defining who you are, and in defining the country and the city?"
It is no accident that Mr. Dinkins won by the closest margin in a New York mayoral race since 1905. For while non-Hispanic whites are no longer a majority of the city's population, exit polls suggest that they are a bit more than half the voters in a typical election, while blacks are less than a third. That means no one racial or ethnic group can assure the election of its candidate, but also that black candidates have a particularly tough time.
Democrats nominally outnumber Republicans 5 to 1, but have often switched sides when the issues were race and liberal ideology.
Last week, Mr. Dinkins won easy renomination in a desultory primary -- the turnout was the lowest for such a race since World War II. But in white conservative neighborhoods where he has never been popular, Roy E. Innis, the black chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality who is a conservative on gun control and favors arresting panhandlers, got 25 percent of the vote. That was seen as a sign of the intensity of anti-Dinkins feeling, though he did better than he did four years ago in some liberal white areas he badly needs.
Polls show that Mr. Giuliani, his prosecutor's image softened by a media campaign portraying him as a warm family man and inveterate Yankees fan, has made big inroads among the liberal whites and Hispanic voters who were vital to Mr. Dinkins's 1989 victory on a promise to heal the city's racial bitterness after 12 years of the fractious Edward I. Koch.
"Four years ago, there was a sense of 'He's a decent guy, let's give him a chance,' " Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College, said of Mr. Dinkins. "You could almost hear the sigh of relief: 'Thank God the black people have come up with such a dignified guy.'
"But he just hasn't been able to solidify his coalition," he added. "We liked the idea of his being a gentleman. But gentleman just wasn't enough."
That and deep budget problems have helped Mr. Giuliani frame this election as a referendum on who is the best manager, a strategy that tries to give voters a race-free excuse for voting against Mr. Dinkins. Meanwhile, Mr. Dinkins cannot count on another high turnout among the black voters who were energized by his first-time candidacy and Jesse Jackson's 1988 Presidential bid.
The twist is that Mr. Dinkins -- in contrast with other cities' mayors who made a point of acting as spokesmen for black aspirations -- won precisely because of his low-key approach to racial pride. And in office, he has changed his style not one iota. Moreover, he has managed some real successes in the face of the recession. He has kept the city's budget balanced (as required by law), won new taxes to hire thousands of police officers, extended library hours and seen crime decline.
"It's not a bad record, considering the horrible circumstances," one of his advisers said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "To be frank, if the city had known what he'd face, I'm not sure they'd have elected him, because this is not what he was elected to do."
As a campaign slogan, that would sound a bit like "You sweat less than any fat person I ever danced with." But Mr. Giuliani has been notably gauzy about just what he would do differently, and the Dinkins camp hopes the Mayor will do better when he's not running against the "perfect mayor" ideal.
Black mayors have given way to white ones in Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Chicago, though because of death or retirements, not defeats. The stakes are high for black New Yorkers' political aspirations since black population growth is declining here relative to that of other minorities. Most experts foresee a future of shifting coalitions, in which various ethnic groups take turns in power.
If Mr. Giuliani is elected, that could change,depending on how he wins, and performs.
"It may well be that the electorate that Giuliani puts together could last for the next dozen years," Professor Hacker said. "I don't think there's a large enough critical mass of white liberals out there to assure the election of a black candidate, and it's not clear where one would come from."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Good Economics Meet Protective Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"THIS is a debate," President Clinton said at the White House last week, launching his campaign for Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, "about whether we will embrace change and create the jobs of tomorrow, or try to resist those changes, hoping we can preserve the economic structure of yesterday."
That was the Bill Clinton talking who has mastered the fundamentals of economics like no other President in the 20th century. But good economics are not necessarily good politics. On no other issue before the country is there such dissonance between scholars and politicians. 
 Since the time of Adam Smith more than 200 years ago, Western economists have been trained in the principle that unrestricted trade is the best policy. On paper it is. When all the benefits and all the drawbacks are set side by side, free trade comes out ahead in almost every circumstance. Three hundred economists representing almost every point on the ideological compass have signed a letter to Mr. Clinton supporting the agreement, which would remove all trade barriers between the United States, Canada and Mexico over the next 10 years.
But the accord is in serious trouble in Congress, because politics is fueled by votes, not theories. The voters who think they might be harmed are much louder and better organized than the proponents. That is because the disadvantages of the trade pact would be concentrated and felt immediately. The advantages, while probably greater in the aggregate, would be diffuse and incremental. The potential losers have names and faces and jobs. The prospective winners, for the most part, do not even know who they are.
Asked why so many of his usual allies in Congress are opposed to the trade agreement, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who is a strong advocate, said in an interview, "What you lose is always more vivid than what you gain."
Consider what happened in Massachusetts. For a century, it was the center of textile manufacturing in this country. Then, in the 1920's, the textile companies moved South in search of cheaper, nonunion labor. Gradually, the state's economy was transformed into the one based on high technology that exists today.
By every measure, Massachusetts is much more prosperous now. Per capita income, now the third highest in country after Connecticut and New Jersey, has more than tripled since the late 1920's after adjustments for inflation. But the promise of prosperity two generations down the road would hardly have been solace to the thousands of textile workers who saw their jobs disappear or to the politicians they elected. 
The opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement among manufacturing workers and the unions and politicians representing them is grounded in the fear that their factories will shut down like those in Massachusetts did, that their jobs will go to the cheaper, nonunion labor in Mexico and that their towns in the 21st century will resemble Massachusetts towns like Lawrence and Fall River, which never recovered. This anxiety is what brought Ross Perot and so many protesters to a rally yesterday in Lansing, Mich.
Economists say these factories will close and the manufacturing jobs will go abroad regardless of whether the trade pact is approved. No doubt they are right. But this inevitability makes it harder rather than easier for politicians to vote for the trade agreement.
If the accord does go into effect, then for years to come it will be blamed, fairly or not, every time a plant closes. The politicians who voted for the agreement will be held accountable for the job losses. By contrast, no one who plans to vote against the agreement believes the vote will jeopardize his or her re-election.
So where does this leave Mr. Clinton? In many political respects, his support of the free-trade measure, which was negotiated by George Bush, represents one of the most courageous acts of his young Presidency. He did not back down or compromise in the face of political opposition the way he did on the budget, on gays in the military and on help for the Muslims in Bosnia. He is opposed by most politicians in his own party. He could have set the measure aside, saying he wanted to devote his entire attention to health care. But having decided on the basis of his grasp of economics that the agreement was best for the country, the President has not wavered. In his speech at the White House Tuesday and on a trip to New Orleans the next day, Mr. Clinton promised to go all out to win Congressional approval.
He may well fail. A small but solid majority of Senators -- most of the Republicans and a handful of Democrats -- seems prepared to support the President, but they may never get to vote. The Constitution requires legislation involving tariffs to be considered first by the House of Representatives. There, as matters stand now, the Clinton side is dozens of votes short.
Mr. Clinton has promised measures to retrain workers who lose their jobs, but that was not what he and the members of his Cabinet who testified before Congress last week emphasized. Money does not seem to be available for an expensive retraining program.
Instead, Mr. Clinton and his advisers argued that the pact would create hundreds of thousands of new jobs. On talk shows, Mr. Perot responded that it would throw more than 5 million Americans out of work, destroy the American middle class and cause the country's tax base to collapse.
Economists see such claims as sheer hyperbole. No mainstream economist is predicting a gain or loss of more than a few hundred thousand jobs by the end of the decade -- a mere blip to economists in a country with 104 million workers, 18 million of them in manufacturing.
But again, politicians are parochial. Four hundred thousand jobs may mean nothing to a macroeconomist. No Congressman would vote for a measure that lost 10,000 jobs in his district.
Even more important to the politicians, and trivial to most economists, is the way the trade agreement seems somehow to stand for the creeping erosion of the assembly-line jobs that were once the cornerstone of the American middle class. "Nafta has become a symbol for other things," said Senator Bradley, "a lightning rod for people's anxieties about changes in their lives they have no control over."

HEADLINE: THE GIFT;
Having the Dream Is Hard. Living It Is Harder.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVER since Franklin D. Roosevelt mused, at the height of World War II, that he might someday try to make peace between Jews and Arabs, every American President has fantasized about his own chances of reaching that goal.
Now it's Bill Clinton's turn to dream. 
 Last week, the President was present at the creation of a new Middle East. With arms outstretched like a graceful impresario, he coaxed Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasir Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin into a handshake that sealed their awkward reconciliation.
"It feels like a gift to me," Mr. Clinton said of this first agreement between Palestinians and Jews, in an interview two days before the ceremony. "I felt that it was in the stars, sort of, but I couldn't imagine how."
A gift perhaps, but also a burden.
The American imprimatur that he put on this quest for peace is the diplomatic equivalent of flying American flags on Kuwaiti ships to protect them against attack during the Iran-Iraq war. It commits the United States to the process, legitimizes it, helps insure international support and bolsters the confidence of the signatories. And it includes the United States among the risk-takers.
But how different this is from Camp David. Then, Jimmy Carter spent 13 days with Menachem Begin and Anwar el-Sadat, negotiating a peace that sprang from a personal conviction that if America could overcome hatreds between blacks and whites, it could craft compromises for Arabs and Jews. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, is to the Middle East what George Bush was to the fall of Communism: The events unfolded, serendipitously, after previous Administrations laid the groundwork.
In making foreign policy -- not Mr. Clinton's strong suit, at least not yet -- the President likes to play to his strengths. So it is not surprising that his first public appearance after the signing ceremony was at a town meeting for prominent American Arabs and Jews. Lobby in Congress and in the Middle East to make this agreement work, he exhorted, as if addressing worker bees in a political campaign.
Playing the pitchman is a comfortable role for this President. But mobilizing domestic support is only one of many tasks facing him. A second will clearly be raising money to underwrite the accord.
In the 1970's, the 1974 disengagement agreements and the 1979 Egyptian-Israeli accords were American-made deals that the United States underwrote. In 1969, Israel and Egypt together received 2.7 per cent of American military assistance. By 1979 the figure was 82 percent. In the same 10 years, their share of bilateral economic assistance went from 1 percent to 42 percent. Since then, foreign aid to every country except Egypt and Israel has been cut.
It was necessary back then. In 1993, however, the United States does not have the money to pay for a comprehensive Middle East peace by itself. On the other hand, it will not have to -- at least not right away. A World Bank report estimates that the Israeli-occupied territories will need $3 billion over the next eight years to meet basic needs like improving water and health care. The European Community has pledged $1 billion over five years, the United States just $25 million in the coming year. "This is not like what we are trying to do in Russia," said Mr. Clinton.
In a third role, the United States sees itself as conciliator. Mr. Clinton intends to press Islamic and moderate Arab countries to accept Israel politically and economically. During the coming United Nations General Assembly, Mr. Christopher will work to break the 42-year Arab economic boycott of Israel. And the United States will try to further isolate states and groups intent on undermining the accord.
Among some Arab states, another kind of fence-mending is needed. King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, for example, has assured Mr. Clinton that the Saudis will help pay for Palestinian self-rule. But the dominant image of Mr. Arafat in the kingdom remains him kissing Saddam Hussein in Baghdad during the gulf war.
For the moment, at least, the United States will not be directly involved in implementing the Israeli-Palestinian agreement, because the two sides seem to want to arrange for that themselves. Rather, the Americans are better able to play a fourth role, that of a confidence-builder.
Compared to the Israeli-Palestinian agreement, Camp David, hard as it was, seems easy, the textbook peace process. It involved two strong leaders, one relatively unimportant piece of territory -- the Sinai -- and American money to make the Israeli and Egyptian Governments feel secure.
This time, peace is messy. It involves deeply divided political communities, territories of historical and religious importance, a concept of peace that means different things to different people, the prospect that Syria could sabotage it, and an inherent tension between the logic of what the two sides have put on paper and aspirations they have set aside to discuss later.
The United States finds itself in the peculiar position of not knowing exactly where it fits as this process unfolds. Mr. Christopher said in an interview Saturday: "They have broken through the psychological barrier. That has been breached. Compared to that obstacle, the rest should be more achievable." The United States, he said, "stands ready to help manage the relationship to help the parties if they get off track."
The most crucial -- and difficult -- role for the United States will be to serve as a catalyst for securing the Israeli-Palestinian accord by pressing for a comprehensive peace. That means dancing a tense diplomatic tango with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad.
Mr. Arafat made his peace with Israel separately, without telling the Syrian leader. Last week, Mr. Assad had to watch from the sidelines while Mr. Arafat was center stage.
 
His Friend Assad
 Mr. Clinton is embracing Mr. Assad as a serious partner to keep him both supportive of the Israeli-Palestinian deal and interested in making a separate peace. The President's speech on Monday included a not-so-subtle message of friendship. "A peace of the brave is within our reach," Mr. Clinton said, echoing words Mr. Assad has uttered himself. Yet Mr. Clinton is also keeping Mr. Assad at arm's length, both to satisfy Israel's desire to move slowly on that front and to register displeasure over Syria's support of radical Palestinians intent on scuttling the accord.
Mr. Clinton is willing to help broker a deal between Jerusalem and Damascus, but there is an ambivalence about the extent of American involvement. Mr. Christopher says he is convinced that the Palestinian-Israeli peace will hold only if there is a comprehensive settlement in the region, but he does not see himself aggressively pressing unwilling partners together the way his predecessor Henry A. Kissinger did in the days of shuttle diplomacy. "We will be available for the parties to facilitate, to intermediate -- when they are ready," he said. "That will be a major task if and when they are ready. We can't impose ourselves on the parties."
But if Mr. Clinton wants to be the President who brings peace to the Middle East, he and his Secretary of State will have to be diplomatic arm-twisters as well.

LENGTH: 1487 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Revisiting Immigration and the Open-Door Policy

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
WITH the immigrant influx at its highest level since the early years of this century and the economy stumbling, American ambivalence about immigration is again painfully obvious. The masses of tired and poor, whether Mexican, Chinese or Haitian, find themselves less and less welcome in this nation of immigrants, as the chorus of voices calling for further restrictions grows larger and louder.
"We can no longer allow compassion to overrule reason" was the way Gov. Pete Wilson of California, which absorbed nearly half of the influx of the 1980's, phrased the issue in an open letter to President Clinton last month. But the debate over the impact of the estimated 1.25 million immigrants who enter the country legally and illegally each year is anything but reasonable. 
 Once again, as in earlier periods of economic or political insecurity, questions are being raised as to whether immigrants are a source of strength and vitality or a debilitating force that drives down wages. Once again, immigration's critics are saying that the newcomers are a burden, not a boon, overusing public services for which they do not pay taxes.
 
A Net Plus
 But the evidence put forth to support these assertions is questionable at best. Unlike the first decades of the 1900's, when the nation went through a similar influx and debate about immigration, there is now a significant body of research tracking immigrants from the moment they arrive. Most academic and government studies conclude that the presence of immigrants has some overall benefit; few say they harm the economy.
Yet perceptions die hard. Black leaders and labor unions argue that the job market is swamped with cheaply paid workers. Spokesmen of the nativist right see the newcomers swelling the welfare rolls. Disputing them, Jeffrey S. Passel, head of the immigrant research project at the Urban Institute, a research group in Washington, said "places that got immigrants during the 1980's generally did better in terms of wage growth than places that didn't." Immigrants, said Gregory De Freitas, an economist and immigration expert at Hofstra University in New York, "help expand the demand for labor and increase the number of jobs, which tends to outweigh any negative effects they may have."
During the 1980's, average wages for native-born workers hit a plateau, and those of recently arrived immigrants declined slightly. When David Card, an economist at Princeton University, examined the impact of the arrival of 125,000 Cubans in the 1980 Mariel boatlift, which increased Miami's labor force by 7 percent in an overnight expansion rarely seen in recent American history, he found that "the Mariel influx appears to have had virtually no effect on the wages or unemployment rates of less-skilled workers," whether white or black.
One recent study by the Urban Institute concluded that immigrants actually help create more jobs in urban areas than does the native population, especially in the non-manufacturing sector. Some other studies show that immigrants are more likely than the rest of the population to be self-employed and start their own businesses.
 
'A Multiplier Effect'
 "The question always seems to be phrased in terms of immigrants taking jobs from Americans, when lots of Americans have jobs because of the impact of immigrants on the economy," said Mr. De Freitas, who wrote "Inequality at Work: Hispanics in the U.S. Labor Force." "Immigrant restaurants and businesses pay taxes, and their workers buy clothes and food and homes in neighborhoods that were formerly dead. There's a multiplier effect, but that doesn't always get captured."
In fact, a 1991 study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that the male immigrant "faces on average significantly higher rates of average taxation than do natives." Julian Simon, author of "The Economic Consequences of Immigration" calculates that during their first three decades in the country, immigrant families typically pay more taxes than their native counterparts and on average contribute about $2,500 a year more in taxes than they obtain in public services.
But the Federation for American Immigration Reform, citing other scholars, says that such conclusions are based on outdated assumptions. George J. Borjas, author of "Friends or Strangers: The Impact of Immigrants on the U.S Economy" and an economics professor at the University of California at San Diego, argues that the new wave of immigrants is not as skilled as its predecessors. As a result, he concludes, the newcomers are more likely to become a burden on the state than those who came before.
Yet data from the 1990 census indicate that while the education gap between native-born workers and immigrants may have widened, newly arrived immigrants are on the average more educated today than at any time in the past.
"There is absolutely no evidence that the quality of immigrants, which is really just a measure of education, has declined," said Marta Tienda, a sociologist and demographer at the University of Chicago. Mr. Borjas responded, "A rise in absolute levels of schooling is meaningless unless you compare it to something, and my base of comparison is with natives, who are clearly more skilled than immigrants."
Nor does it appear that immigrants make use of services like welfare or unemployment benefits with significantly greater frequency than natives. "The reason is that these people for the most part are migrating for labor, and when the jobs are not forthcoming, there is a strong tendency for return migration," said Douglas Massey, a University of Chicago sociologist who studies immigration from Mexico, the country that supplies the largest number of new arrivals. Most of those who are here illegally are afraid of any entanglement with government, researchers say. Legal immigrants waiting for their green cards know that use of such programs can lead to deportation or jeopardize their chances of sponsoring relatives for immigration.
 
Allocating Funds
 Nevertheless, to Governor Wilson and his allies, the foreigners who come here are "drawn by the giant magnet of Federal incentives" that reward immigrants "by requiring the states to provide and pay for the exploding costs of their health care, education and other benefits." Those arguments echo the findings of a study published late in 1992 by Los Angeles County, which concluded that immigrants had in the previous year incurred costs of $947 million for social services ranging from health care to public housing, while contributing revenues to the county only $139 million.
Immigration advocacy groups and scholars have been critical of the study and its methodology, however. For instance, the study defined immigrants as the 2.3 million people who had arrived, legally or illegally, since 1980, and lumped earlier arrivals with the rest of the population. Research has shown, however, that "the longer immigrants are in the country, the more they contribute to the economy," and the more prosperous they become, Mr. De Freitas said.
Still, even under the narrow definition used by the Los Angeles authorities, a closer look at the study finds inconsistencies, including data showing the county's immigrants gave more than they took. The county study concluded that immigrants paid $4.3 billion in taxes in 1991, but used only $2.5 billion in public services -- a net contribution of $1.8 billion to government.
The real problem, it would appear, is that most of the taxes immigrants pay end up in the hands of the Federal government, with little of that bonanza actually returning to the areas where immigrants live. "The solution to that is to change the distribution policy, not blame the immigrants," Mr. Simon, a professor of business at the University of Maryland, said. "Get the people in low-immigrant areas to cough up their unwarranted gains."
That imbalance illustrates a point about immigration often forgotten: while the debate is national, the flow is concentrated in a few places. There are scattered pockets of new arrivals -- Colombians in Central Falls, R.I., for example -- but more than three quarters of all legal immigrants live in six states: California, Florida, Illinois, New Jersey, New York and Texas. Add illegal immigration, and the proportion in those states rises to perhaps 90 percent, demographers say.
Yet until Governor Wilson spoke out, the members of Congress leading the charge for restrictions on immigration came from places like Wyoming and Kentucky, which have little direct experience with immigrants. All of which suggests that the immigration policy the nation ultimately chooses is likely to be dictated more by emotion and politics than logic or hard numbers. As Robert Reich, now Mr. Clinton's Secretary of Labor, wrote in 1990, when it comes to immigration, "economics is no help at all in telling us what we should do, or why."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Shantytowns, Bulldozers, And Patience: A Dilemma

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
IN the Depression's early days, residents of Fifth Avenue were not happy about the tarpaper shacks topped with smoke-spewing stovepipes that went up in clusters around Central Park. But few complained. Sympathy ran high in the first cold winter of the Hoovervilles.
"Effort is made in virtually all the villages to preserve the decencies of life, to maintain the spirit of self-respect that surrounds a home or the lowly semblance of one," this newspaper wrote in March 1933. "Hooligans are few. The life of an honest squatter is too austere for their kind." 
 Today, homelessness is more complex. Though times are tough, there is no one villain like the Depression. A decade of proposed solutions has yielded little but pessimism. And sympathy for the dispossessed has flagged. In the past few years, the authorities have torn down nearly every large encampment -- ones in or near Columbus Circle, the United Nations and, most recently, "the Hill," an idiosyncratic grouping of a teepee and 15 or so sturdy shacks by the Manhattan Bridge.
What survive are smaller, often temporary batches of shanties dispersed around the city. And what has happened in New York is being repeated around the country: Even as the authorities try to eliminate them,more encampments are popping up than at any time since the Depression, notably in Los Angeles, Dallas, Santa Monica, Calif., and Aurora, Ill.
In at least three cities -- Miami, Dallas and Orlando -- "safe zones" have been proposed, where the homeless would live in designated areas or in a city-sponsored pavilion without police interference.
It is not clear why subway grates, park benches and refrigerator boxes are giving way to shacks, tents and other hardier places to sleep.
"What the building and structure suggests to me is the passage of time without an adequate response," said Maria Foscarinis, director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty in Washington. "It's a response by homeless people themselves."
To be sure, there have been shantytowns on the fringes of large cities for centuries. In developing nations, they are a way of life; Rio de Janeiro has 628,000 people living, largely in squalor, on the city's outskirts, said Ganti L. Rao, director of the North American Office of the United Nations Center for Human Settlement. There are others outside Lima, Peru; Caracas, Venezuela; Calcutta and Bombay, India; Nairobi, Kenya, and Johannesburg. Most of their inhabitants are rural people seeking work in the city, Mr. Rao said, and tolerated because of the deep poverty and stark lack of housing.
By comparison, American shantytowns are tiny. During the Depression, scores of Hoovervilles rose; the largest in New York was beside the East River at Ninth Street and in 1933 housed some 450 men. In 1991, an encampment in Tompkins Square Park was home to about 200 people until it was bulldozed.
 
Follow the Money
 Patterns of settlement have also differed. Third world shantytowns are usually on public land at a city's edge, often at the end of a long commute for its workers. But the American homeless congregate in very central locations -- in Manhattan, for example, near the Port Authority bus terminal, Columbus Circle and public parks -- because services and money are there.
"In the business districts, there are a lot of opportunities for panhandling, for food, for churches," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University. "Once a group gets started, it encourages others to join in."
Though the United States has its own troubles building enough affordable housing, shantytowns are barely tolerated here because they are homes not to a city's laborers and domestics, but often to its alcoholics, drug abusers and mentally ill.
The authorities are rarely willing to let them remain -- because of fire safety and public health, but also because of political pressure. The administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins has consistently torn down shantytowns in Manhattan, though officials say there is no set policy on when or why to act.
"There isn't any one deciding factor," said Sam Szurek, a spokesman for the Department of Homeless Services. "Sometimes it can be a fire hazard. Sometimes it can be a security problem, like at the United Nations. Sometimes it can be a transportation hazard. The policy is that we are constantly reaching out and we don't encourage people to live in the streets."
At Tompkins Square, for example, the encampment was in the center of a three-block-long park that was virtually the only patch of green for much of the Lower East Side. The neighbors had complained for years about the tents, homeless men in the playgrounds, campfires and music. The police called it a major drug center.
"The Hill" was bulldozed after it had several fires, one of which killed a resident. Drugs and local complaints were also an issue.
But advocates say that the homeless are being deliberately forced to the city's fringes to be forgotten. Many oppose the "safe-zone" concept for that reason. The paradox, said Richard C. Wade, a professor of urban history at the City University of New York, is that tearing down either slums or temporary shanties actually makes the problem more visible.
"In the old days," he said, "we had more people living in substandard housing, but you didn't see them. Now they are sleeping on Fifth Avenue. That's what drives people crazy."

HEADLINE: SIDE AGREEMENTS TO TRADE ACCORD VARY IN AMBITION

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The environmental side agreement that President Clinton negotiated to the North American Free Trade Agreement is much broader and ambitious than the companion labor agreement, one reason why many environmentalists now support free trade with Mexico and Canada while labor leaders are united against it.
Final legal texts released this week by the White House have made labor unions even more unhappy. They show that while the environmental pact will create a powerful three-nation bureaucracy to pursue a wide array of environmental problems, the labor pact will create a much smaller and tamer apparatus limited in its enforcement powers to a narrow range of specific issues. 
 The free trade agreement is intended to create a common market in North America by gradually lowering trade barriers between the three countries. The side agreements on labor and environmental issues are intended to prevent each country from gaining a competitive advantage in trade by failing to enforce labor and environmental laws. The pacts were negotiated primarily because of concerns about Mexico's enforcement measures, but apply to the United States and Canada as well, a prospect that alarms some American businesses and Republicans.
 
Reasons for Broader Pact
 Just one of the reasons the environmental agreement is the broader pact is that Mexico and Canada staunchly resisted any loss of control over their labor markets. In addition, environmentalists were more willing than labor unions to support free trade in exchange for specific provisions in the side agreements.
The Clinton Administration also had to walk a political tightrope during the negotiations. Congressional Republicans, most of whom have long supported free trade, say that they warned the White House this summer that they would not vote for the free trade agreement if the side agreements created extensive new international bureaucracies that would infringe on American sovereignty or burden American companies.
Each agreement creates a commission, composed of the labor or environmental ministers of all three countries, and a secretariat whose staff will be protected from pressure by national governments through rules that will make it hard to dismiss them. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will represent the United States.
But the North American Labor Commission will be limited at first to a staff of 15 people, while there are no limits on the size of the North American Environmental Commission. And the labor commission can research cases of lax Government enforcement only after receiving permission from two of the three countries' labor ministers. The environmental panel, by contrast, can investigate any case of lax enforcement unless explicitly banned from doing so by two of the three countries' environmental ministers.
 
Penalties Are Limited
 All types of environmental problems are subject to fines and trade sanctions. But in labor cases, such penalties are limited to those involving worker safety, child labor and minimum wages. On other labor issues, like Mexico's many restrictions on labor unions, the ministers of the three countries can only discuss the problems without taking action.
Administration officials explained the fine print to A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials on Friday, and the union officials were appalled. "We certainly believe that the rights of workers were shortchanged in this agreement, and it is clear that even the imperfect environmental accord is stronger," said Mark A. Anderson, the director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Task Force on Trade.
"It is difficult for me to believe that 15 people, however qualified or energetic they may be, can examine problems across the continent," he said. "This sounds like it isn't going to be much more than an office with a fax machine and some telephones."
The labor pact allows each country to set up a separate office in its capital to investigate labor abuses in all three countries. The size of these offices has not been determined, although Administration officials say that they will give the United States office adequate resources.
Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist, said that the labor side agreement might look weak on paper because the size and political independence of the national administrative offices have not been defined. "What's in the text is not the full story on the labor side," he said.
 
Unions Not Impressed
 But American unions have been unimpressed.
"It's clear that the environmental agreement is tighter and stronger, and I think that's largely a function that large environmental groups played a large and effective role in shaping that agreement," said Robert A. Pastor, the director of the Latin American and Caribbean program at the Carter Center in Atlanta.
Mr. Pastor contended that the weaker labor agreement partly reflected the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s reluctance to offer support for the North American Free Trade Agreement unless the side pact addressed two dozen union concerns, among them higher wages in Mexico. But the Mexican Government resisted concessions on labor issues, people who were involved in the negotiations said.
Mexico has much stronger labor laws on its books than the United States, but many are not enforced. Mexican officials were reluctant to be required, in effect, to raise their country's labor standards abruptly, in some cases above American standards. Enforcing all of these laws could have jolted the Mexican economy.
Administration officials said last spring that the United States wanted the three-nation labor and environmental commissions to be nearly identical. But an Administration trade official said that American negotiators were unable to persuade Mexico and Canada.
"We were able to get more of a consensus with respect to environmental issues than with respect to labor issues, which in many respects are regarded as more political and more within the control of each nation," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. Canada and Mexico "weren't really willing at the outset to contemplate tri-national or supranational arrangements, but as things moved on, it became clear that people were more willing to try things out in the environmental area."
Mr. Katz of the Labor Department said that veterans of international labor issues were more skeptical of international institutions than environmentalists and more willing to put their faith in national institutions.
Another difference between the two side agreements that has upset labor involves the data used in investigations. The labor agreement restricts the international secretariat to using publicly available information from each country's government. By contrast, the environmental agreement allows the use of information gathered by the staff, nonprofit organizations, public conferences and even outside specialists hired by the secretariat for specific investigations.
Mr. Anderson said that he would not trust official labor information from the Mexican Government. "These are the folks who claim they have 2 percent unemployment," he said.
But, the national offices in each capital, which would be separate from the secretariat, would also be allowed to use information from staff, unions and outside specialists.
In contrast with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., national environmental groups that agreed to support the Administration have been rewarded with a variety of special deals. The National Audubon Society, for example, was one of six large environmental groups that endorsed the North American Free Trade Agreement this week based on the side agreements. Peter A. A. Berle, the president of the society, said in an interview on Thursday that the group's support was partly based on an assurance from the Administration that an agreement on migratory birds in the Western Hemisphere would be added to a list of environmental pacts protected from legal challenges by the the free-trade agreement.
Ms. Browner of the E.P.A. told reporters on Friday that the Administration was in the process of adding the migratory birds deal to the list.
 
Local Opposition
 Many state and local environmental groups oppose the side agreement, saying it does not go nearly far enough to protect the environment. Those groups were not involved in the hundreds of meetings between Administration officials and executives of large environmental groups. The Sierra Club and about 300 of the smaller groups condemned the side agreement on Monday. In an odd twist, nearly a dozen local chapters of the National Audubon Society were among these 300 groups.
The ability of the Administration to pursue ambitious side deals was constrained by complaints from Republican members of Congress concerned about the possible effects on American sovereignty and companies. Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, who is the ranking minority member of the Ways and Means Committee, had warned the Administration against one broad legal provision that did not appear in the final texts.
"Clearly they could have stepped a step farther and lost me," Mr. Archer said.

HEADLINE: A Faith Reviving: Jews in Russia/A special report.;
In a Less Arid Russia, Jewish Life Flowers Again

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Ilya Drutz, an agile, round-cheeked boy of 12, was calmly describing his decision to become circumcised. Last summer, he attended Moscow's first Jewish camp.
"Before I went to the camp I knew nothing about my religion, and I felt very uncomfortable," he said. "My father is a writer and my mother a librarian, and religion wasn't talked about at home." 
 When a mohel, who does circumcisions, came to the camp, Ilya said, "I started to think of who and what I am, and finally I decided that if I'm a Jew, I should follow the customs of my people."
"When the mohel left, I felt sorry," he said, "and I decided that if he came again I'd be circumcised. When he came I was the first in line."
Around him, nine young men, all wearing yarmulkes, listened with varying degrees of respect or discomfort. They had taken a break from a class at a private Jewish school that had just moved into a Moscow city building 10 days before. It had long outgrown its premises in the central Moscow Choral Synagogue.
It was the first time the city had given over a school to a Jewish group, in this case the Orthodox Chabad Lubavitch Jews. About 200 boys and girls, ages 6 to 16, are attending classes as workmen hammer and saw around them. Some 100 others want to join, said the headmaster, Zev Kuravsky, a 45-year-old physicist who taught his two sons at home when they were abused at school for being Jewish.
As the number of Jews emigrating from the former Soviet Union continues to drop, this school is another indication of the blossoming and institutionalization of Jewish life in a more democratic Russia, where religion of all kinds -- and especially Russian Orthodoxy -- can be openly embraced. The Soviet state ideology of atheism and organized anti-Semitism has all but disappeared.
The Jewish question has long been a barometer of life in Russia, going back to the pogroms under the czars. In the Soviet period, the status of Jews became a major cold war and human rights issue, with American trade restrictions imposed by Congress tied to the level of Jewish emigration.
Anti-Semitism remains and is manipulated by ultranationalist politicians on the fringes, and it is more open now in its expression than it was in the Soviet Union, with placards on walls, petty vandalism and some anti-Jewish articles in a freer press.
But anti-Semitic acts are few, and many Russian Jews feel that the dangers can be exaggerated in the West. Some young Jews like Ilya Drutz and his classmates say that their open profession of belief has even earned them some respect among their non-Jewish friends, sometimes among the same boys who persecuted them earlier.
 
Emigration
Jews Find a Niche And Exodus Slows

Through July, said Alexander Libin of the Israeli Embassy's Migration Department, about 38,000 Jews had left the former Soviet Union for Israel this year, and emigration continues at about 5,000 a month. But these Jews are mostly from Central Asia or the war-ravaged hot spots like Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Georgia.
Those numbers are down considerably from earlier years when the Soviet Union finally opened the gates. In 1989, some 13,000 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel; in 1990, 185,000 went and the following year 170,000.
But by 1992, the figure was back down to only 64,500, in large part because of stories of crowded housing and unemployment in Israel. Some Russian Jews have even returned, finding Israel too difficult.
In the former Soviet Union, there are now 2 million to 2.5 million Jews, said Tankred G. Golanpolsky, editor and publisher of The Jewish Gazette, a Russian-language semimonthly with 42,000 circulation. By official statistics in 1985, there were 1.8 million Soviet citizens with their nationality listed as "Jewish" in their passports, but many found it advisable to try to assimilate. Perhaps 600,000 Jews have left the former Soviet Union since the late 1980's, Mr. Golanpolsky said.
In Russia now, he estimates, there are some 1.7 million Jews; 180,000 live in Moscow, the second-largest minority after Ukrainians.
 
Jews Acknowledged Openly
 "The diaspora in Russia will remain for a very long time," Mr. Golanpolsky said. "Jews here have found themselves a niche. They wanted to be acknowledged openly and they are; they are not hindered in their jobs. They wanted to be able to make money and not be accused of stealing, and now they can.
"They wanted to travel, and now they can. We may have a lousy apartment, but it's better than the one offered in Israel. We may have a lousy car, but it's ours, and we know our way about."
But there is less willingness among Jews to be Jewish in the traditional sense, he said. Moscow's three synagogues, all Orthodox, were full on Wednesday evening, the beginning of the Jewish New Year. But on a normal Friday at the central synagogue, he said, "you'll see fewer than 20 Jews, many of them from the Caucasus."
There are also various groups who gather in private homes to pray. But the vast majority of Russian Jews, he said, are not religious. "It's very hard to overcome 70 years of socialism in three years," he said.
On Wednesday evening, at the Moscow Choral Synagogue, Vadim, a 25-year-old banker, said he thought too many Jews had left. "There are some Jewish centers forming now," he said, "but how long they last depends on how many Jews leave." Life was better in Russia now, he said. "Now you can earn money in Russia, not in Israel."
The real question today, Mr. Golanpolsky said, is "how to bring about a Jewish revival in Russia, especially among the youth."
 
'Real Community' Needed
 Many Jews will stay in Russia, he and others said, and needed a real community. Even if all Russian Jews left in the next 10 or 15 years, Mr. Golanpolsky said, "in order to come to Israel and feel at home, a Jew must understand what it is to be Jewish, and that must be taught here."
The same arguments come separately from Rabbi Berel Lazar, a 29-year-old Lubavitcher, born in Italy, who has been instrumental in finding new quarters for this Jewish school.
"More and more Jews in Russia are not planning to leave," Rabbi Lazar said. "They have lives and businesses here, and even if they feel it may be dangerous, there's nothing for them in Israel. More and more people are getting used to the idea they can have a religious life in Russia."
 
Jewish Life
Network Is Forming As More Seek Roots
 The name of this school is Achei Tmimim, or Fully Brothers, and in addition to the regular curriculum, students are given daily 40-minute classes in both Hebrew and Judaism. They pay a token tuition of about $3 a month; most of the teachers take minimal salaries.
Rabbi Lazar has raised about $50,000 here and in the United States to support the school, though he is not sure how they will pay to fix the leaky roof. "Even when Jews make money here," he said, "they don't know what it is yet to give money."
Some Jews suggest privately that the Lubavitchers, a proselytizing sect, are "buying souls," but Rabbi Lazar said the school was Lubavitch "only in the sense that it is run by people close to Lubavitch." Many Russian Jews who knew enough to teach have already left for Israel, "and many who stay are close to us."
Like almost all rabbis here, Rabbi Lazar is foreign trained, here on contract. Even the Chief Rabbi, Adolf S. Shayevich, was trained abroad, in Hungary.
 
Unversed in Judaism
 Russian Jews know little about Judaism, Rabbi Lazar said. "So many kids know absolutely zero," he said. "Many have never met another Jew. I'd say many non-Jews in America know more about Judaism than many Jews here."
Though only beginning, a network of Jewish schools, organizations and even restaurants is developing, often with Western help. There are many non-Lubavitcher schools in Moscow, including a few secondary schools, and Sunday schools. But the number of students remains small, probably fewer than 1,000.
In addition to The Jewish Gazette, there are two monthlies: Moscow Jerusalem, a Zionist paper that reprints Russian-language Israeli articles and has about 10,000 readers; and Jewish News, published by the Central Synagogue for about 2,000 members. The Reform movement sends in a paper, Rivulet or Source, with about 8,000 readers, for special holidays. The Lubavitchers have their own publication, L'Chaim.
There is also the Lubavitcher summer camp, which last summer took 600 children; seminars for adults; women's groups; lectures, and circumcision ceremonies. Sometimes, fathers and sons take part on the same day.
Much is going on outside Moscow. Svetlana A. Yakimenko, a teacher, runs the local office of Project Kesher, Connections in Hebrew. Working with an American from Illinois, Sallie E. Gratch, whom she met on a 1987 peace march from Odessa to Kiev, Mrs. Yakimenko helps small groups of Jews all over the Soviet Union to make contact with one another, as well as with organizations abroad. The project makes special efforts to help Jewish women.
 
A Project for Small Towns
 Deliberately staying away from major capitals like Moscow and Kiev, Project Kesher has made connections in Belarus, Ukraine and even Yakutia, in Siberia, and Magadan, the center of the Far Eastern gulag, including towns with fewer than 200 Jews. It has organized a Jewish Association of Small Towns in Ukraine.
"Jews are now a respectable part of society," Mrs. Yakimenko said. "We don't touch the issue of emigrating; that's for people to decide. But they live here now and want to learn their history, culture and traditions, which were denied to them, even if they are not religious."
"Many people still plan to emigrate," she said. "But a lot stay, and they want to have their lives here and restore their Jewish roots. That's how we help."
Mrs. Yakimenko, who married a non-Jewish Ukrainian, is not a practicing Jew. Where she lives, 40 miles outside Moscow, there are only three Jewish families, and no synagogue. Her two daughters, 15 and 10, consider themselves Jewish, she said.
She paused. Her sister has gone to Israel, she said. "Maybe we'll leave," she said. "But life is now more open, and for now we want to be part of it."
Vera A. Dreznina, a 69-year-old painter wrapped in a long purple scarf, is more typical of her class and generation. "We think about leaving" after a life of persecution both petty and vicious, she said, "but generally those of my class and circle have stayed."
 
'Being Jewish Was a Fact'
 She is of a central Moscow family, Jewish but assimilated, with a long history of education and artistic achievement. "Deep in my soul I have the feeling I am not a Russian, though we grew up on Russian culture," she said. "Being Jewish was a fact, but not much discussed." Her husband, now dead, served in the military but was forced to leave after World War II in a bizarre case that stemmed from his Jewishness, she says.
Still, she has stayed, and she admits that snobbishness is the main reason. "Some say there are too many Jews in Israel," she said, laughing. "For me, Moscow is the capital, the center, and it's important to me that I live here. If I emigrate, I couldn't live in a second-rate city in one-story America or in some grassy English province. Here I feel I'm someone; there, I'm nobody."
Even so, she said, Russian Jews are divided into those who have decided to leave and those who haven't yet decided, and the two can barely talk to one another. There is a third group, she said, which has decided "for sure" not to go, but she imagines it to be small. "More are like me," she said. "I wouldn't say I'll never decide to leave, but we try to find arguments for staying."
 
The Choice
Young Are Building Lives in Russia
 Igor Bukharov, 33, has found his reason. He has opened Moscow's first kosher fast-food restaurant, Gamburger. His father was a Soviet Army officer "who always avoided the topic of religion," but for some reason, at 15, Mr. Bukharov had the idea of opening a Jewish restaurant in Moscow.
"I even became a little Zionist," he said. During the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, he said, "I made paper planes with the Star of David on them and threw them in class."
He became a chef, and convinced his workers' collective, none of them Jewish, to turn their newly privatized restaurant, near the Kazan railway station, into a kosher one, serving salads, vegetable burgers and a decent, if slightly greasy, falafel in pita bread.
But Mr. Bukharov, too, is not especially religious, and he has not had his his 8-month-old son circumcised.
"There's a strong residue of the past," he says. "But I'm not like my father, who is a thoroughbred Soviet Jew." Meaning? "A Jew persecuted all his life, aggravated by all the complexes of a Soviet citizen, with a willingness to refuse his true self."
'Enough Will Stay'
As for emigration, Mr. Bukharov said, young people are making their lives and livings here. "Enough will stay, I'm sure, to build a community."
Mr. Bukharov, like a number of Russian Jews interviewed, is wary about Israel's recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the foundations of a Palestinian state. "I don't think it will lead to peace," he said. "Look at Lebanon, where the Muslims can't even get along. But time will show us." Many new Russian emigres to Israel are living in the occupied territories, and the agreement may thus make Israel less attractive to Russians worried about housing.
But Russians brought up on propaganda about Zionism and racism will also have less reason to criticize Israel or feed anti-Semitism. For Mr. Golanpolsky of the Jewish Gazette, who is being sued for libel by the far-right organization Pamyat for calling it anti-Semitic, Russian Jews still have a reasonable fear of Slavic xenophobia and persecution.
"Fear is in the genes," he said, adding tht anti-Semitism in Russia today is abstract. "It's a certain metaphysical concept floating over Russia, but not landing, thank God. For the masses, Jews today are not the face of the enemy. The enemy is in the market, where Chechens and Azeris are selling tomatoes for high prices, or sitting in the kiosks and selling Snickers for 400 rubles, which they can't afford. And if the pot overboils, they will break down the kiosks and beat those faces."
 
Fewer Than 200 Refuseniks
 Even the long, tortured problem of the "refuseniks," Jews whose applications for emigration were denied on the basis that they knew state secrets, has improved considerably, though it has not disappeared.
Boris L. Altschuler of Movement Without Frontiers, part of the Moscow Research Center for Human Rights, said the number of refuseniks was now fewer than 200, though resolved cases are often replaced with new ones. A Government commission to investigate each case is making progress, Mr. Altschuler said.
"The reality is that many people are applying to leave who earlier never thought of it because they were working in secret institutions," he said.
Today the only legal restriction on free emigration is knowledge of official or scientific "secrets." The biggest difficulty for ordinary Russians who are not Jews or Germans, with a special right of return, is getting another country to take them.
As for young Ilya Drutz and his friends in school, they are confused about whether to stay or go. Leonid Perlov and Aleksandr Usorok are arguing about it.
"I decided not to tell everyone I'm Jewish, because Russians don't like Jews, and I probably won't live here," Leonid said.
 
'Lucky in Your Friends'
 "Not all Russians," Aleksandr said. "And we know life in Israel is very hard."
"All my friends know I'm religious and a Jew," Ilya said. "I wouldn't say they care or laugh at me."
"You're lucky in your friends," Leonid said.
And what do Ilya's parents think? Do they think he has chosen a difficult path for himself? The boy rubbed his ear. "My father thinks I probably won't be able to handle it," he said quietly. "Though he wasn't actually against it. My mother thinks it'll be O.K."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
The Gorilla in the Living Room: New Jersey's Annual Budget Gap

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 17

 BODY:
With Election Day six weeks away, Gov. Jim Florio and his rival, Christine Todd Whitman, are fully engaged in baiting and bickering over one thing or another. But they have yet to grapple publicly with the phantom that will haunt the next administration, no matter who runs it: New Jersey's annual dance of the budget deficit.
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, has talked about jobs: how he has created them or helped attract them. Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, intends to talk about jobs, when she puts forth her own economic-stimulus program next Tuesday. Legislative leaders on both sides of the aisle are eager to talk about jobs too. Jobs bring revenue, they say, and revenue will enable the Governor and the Legislature to avoid quick fixes or gimmicks to close gaps in an annual budget that has grown beyond $15 billion. 
 Talking about job growth is easier and more optimistic than talking about debt, especially in a year in which all 120 legislators face the voters. Talking about neither is even better, especially when any serious discussion of taxes and spending runs into the reality of four years of recession that cost New Jersey one job in 12.
Next year's budget is already $1.5 billion out of balance, according to most estimates, in large part because previous budgets have been balanced by pulling one-time-only rabbits out of the hat. Even if officials are successful in working other temporary budget magic, some additional big bills may come due over the next four years:
*A recent court decision said the state must come up with $450 million more for school aid in poor districts. The State Supreme Court will rule on this soon. It could tell the state how to solve the problem or it could just order it to do so. Waiting for the court gives the candidates a good excuse not to talk about school aid. That topic, and any discussion of how the state allows schools to be run, could run afoul of the state's most powerful lobby, the New Jersey Education Association.
*Medicaid, a $2 billion item in the current budget, tends to increase between $200 milion and $250 million a year. Luckily for the candidates, waiting to hear how much the Clinton health plan will cost automatically propels health care issues onto the shelf for now.
*Corrections and law enforcement, one of the fastest-growing segments of the budget, is $635 million now and likely to grow under New Jersey's mandatory sentencing laws. With both candidates wanting to appear tough on crime, this is a tough line item to reduce.
*Public employee benefits, already $1.2 billion and scheduled to rise by $150 million in the next budget, might be a popular topic for the Republicans, who have complained about big government getting bigger. But taking away jobs or cutting salaries and benefits is not useful before Election Day.
In fact, it could be politically suicidal for the candidates to put forward a budgetary repair scheme, general or specific. Nobody would want to suggest tax increases. Nobody would want to put forward a plan that relies on an unpredictable economy. Nobody would want to face six weeks explaining a program too vague to be defended or too complicated for voters to understand.
Mr. Florio, in particular, would like to make voters forget that, despite the nearly $3 billion in new taxes he rammed through the Legislature in 1990, in part to help close a deficit left by his Republican predecessor, the state still has to scrounge for income.
"I'd ask the candidates what they would cut," said David Kehler, director of the Public Affairs Research Institute, a nonpartisan policy analysis group in Princeton.
 
No Takers
 In an election year that's a question no one really wants to answer. So the Governor, a Democrat, and the Legislature, which has veto-proof Republican majorities in both houses, have all but decided to ignore the matter.
"It was such when the Republican-controlled Legislature agreed with the Democratic Governor to take these issues off the table," said Clifford Zukin, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers. "In a sense, the Governor has shared power with the Legislature in the last two years," he said.
A good thing, too, said the Assembly Speaker, Garabed "Chuck" Haytaian: "It's better for him since he started working with us over the past year. He came to the realization that we had the ability to govern if he didn't want to."
Because the budget is everybody's problem, it has become nobody's problem. It could stay that way if the Florio camp continues to succeed in controlling the campaign debate.
"It is a function of how to run the campaign," said Neil Upmeyer, president of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton. "It is an indication of success on Florio's part and a failure on her part that it is unfolding the way it is."
In the last few weeks, the Florio campaign has hammered away at the Governor's success in banning assault weapons, after overcoming a threatened veto by the Legislature. In television ads and in speeches, he has painted Mrs. Whitman as wishy-washy on the issue.
 
Florio's Welfare Proposal
 Earlier this month, Mr. Florio introduced proposals to tighten requirements for welfare checks, prompting an outcry from Mrs. Whitman. The Governor would require a welfare mother to provide the name of the father before she could be eligible for payments, and he would channel welfare checks to teen-age mothers through a parent or guardian.
When Mrs. Whitman protested that to do so seemed reminiscent of Nazi tactics of publicly identifying Jews during the Holocaust, the Florio campaign rallied support from Jewish leaders who called Mrs. Whitman insensitive for appearing to trivialize the Holocaust.
"The welfare story was what we were all thinking about this week," Mr. Upmeyer said. "Florio got a twofer. He not only controlled the message, but he was very fortunate in having her react, and than dragging the issue of Holocaust victims into it.
"What does that have to do with the issues?" he said. "It's a play to the emotions of a certain class of voter with a very specific interest and little to do with the direction of state government."
Mr. Upmeyer called it a stratetic decision as well. "It says, 'Vote for me.' There is little he can do to endear him to the voters of New Jersey, except to demonstrate to them that there is no clear-cut or attractive alternative to re-electing him."

HEADLINE: With Leaders Leaving Office for Jail, Kentucky Works to Refurbish Image

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 17

 BODY:
As in many states, the spoils of office -- jobs, appointments, contracts -- are an integral part of politics in Kentucky, handed out and accepted with the wink of an eye and a knowing nod.
But over the last 18 months, two Federal investigations have suggested that Kentucky's spoils system, unlike those in many other states, is characterized more by major corruption than the usual petty excess. 
 Fifteen top state legislators, lobbyists and other public figures, including the former Speaker of the Kentucky House, have been convicted or face trial on various charges of bribery, extortion, fraud and racketeering.
They were snared in an investigation into the Legislature's regulation of horse-track betting and hospitals, the most serious corruption inquiry of any state legislature in recent years.
 
Undercover Operation
 Day after day for the past year and a half, Kentuckians have been embarrassed, and transfixed, by a relentless stream of testimony about pervasive payoffs and greed. Many of the ethical lapses were captured by hidden cameras and microphones as part of a sting operation code-named Boptrot, a word play on the name of the House Business Organizations and Professions Committee, which deals with horse racing.
"Things somehow got out of hand," said the Speaker of the Kentucky House, Joe Clarke.
He is new to his job, the most powerful legislative post in the state. The previous speaker, Don Blandford, was caught on camera in the Boptrot inquiry taking a bribe from a lobbyist who wanted to kill a bill that would have limited the type of betting some tracks could offer.
"Bless your heart," he told the lobbyist as he stuffed the money into his pocket. Mr. Blandford was convicted last April on charges of extortion and racketeering and is awaiting sentencing. He is appealing the verdict.
The investigation continues, with Federal prosecutors promising more indictments.
The latest person arrested in Boptrot was George Atkins, a lobbyist who is a former State Auditor and one-time candidate for Governor. He was arraigned here in Federal District Court on Thursday.
 
$10,000 for Crucial Vote
 "Guilty," he replied when asked for his plea to charges that he had paid a state legislator $10,000 in exchange for a crucial vote on a bill to allow Humana, the national medical-care conglomerate, to expand operations at its headquarters in Louisville.
In return for his guilty plea, Mr. Atkins will receive a reduced sentence of no more than a year in prison and will cooperate with investigators.
Most of the other legislators and lobbyists charged in the investigation have also negotiated pleas and are awaiting reduced sentences and calls to testify at future trials.
Humana, which dismissed Mr. Atkins when he was arrested, has not been accused of any wrongdoing.
In the other investigation that has raised disturbing questions about public corruption in Kentucky, Dr. William Collins, a dentist who is the husband of former Gov. Martha Layne Collins, has been charged with extortion. He is accused of demanding almost $1.7 million in payments from bond underwriters who sought to win $1 billion in state financing and development contracts from 1983 to 1987, the years that his wife held office. Among the underwriters was Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the large New York firm.
Dr. Collins, whose trial is under way here in Federal District Court, describes the money he got from the underwriters as voluntary investments in his horse-breeding enterprises. He also contends that there was nothing amiss when Lufkin & Jenrette picked up a $35,000 bill for a piano he had handcrafted for his wife in Germany.
Prosecutors see it far differently. "These people were making their investments so they could get these contracts," Assistant United States Attorney John Compton said at the opening of the trial. "These were extortion payments."
None of the bond underwriters have been accused of wrongdoing. But the investigation continues and the case is being cited as another example of the freewheeling, lightly regulated way bonds are sometimes marketed in this country.
Taken together, the two Kentucky scandals are regarded as the worst bout of public corruption in a state since Federal investigators descended on the South Carolina and Arizona capitals two years ago, arresting more than a dozen public figures in each on bribery and extortion charges.
Specialists in state government and politics say there is no real evidence that corruption in state legislatures is on the rise throughout the country.
"We don't see any national net increase," said Rich Jones, who follows such issues for the National Conference of State Legislatures. "We believe legislatures and legislators are at least as honest now as before, and probably even more so because more and more are passing ethics laws and the media is watching more closely. But now and again, people try to slip one by and investigators move in."
They moved in when they received information that Bill McBee, a former State Representative turned lobbyist, might be involved in bribery to win approval of track regulation. A secret microphone picked up the details of the scheme and Mr. McBee was arrested and pleaded guilty.
The image of lobbyists and legislators and former legislators in the dock is far from the one Kentucky has long sought to cultivate.
It is a state with a considerable history of poverty, illiteracy and clan violence, one struggling to hold onto its population and improve its economy. But it is also the state of blue grass, thoroughbreds and mellow bourbon, and it prefers to be thought of as a place of gentility, not venality.
Government witnesses have told of a cozy legislative world in Frankfort, one of the smallest capital cities in the country, in which the level of corruption slowly grew in recent years as the Legislature, which historically has not been as powerful as Kentucky's governors, determinedly became a greater force in ruling the state.
 
A Cozy Relationship
 "Lawmakers and lobbyists here just got too cozy over the years," House Speaker Clarke said.
The one good thing to come out of the scandal is that surviving lawmakers have passed a strong ethics-in-government law aimed at preventing any future malfeasance. A legislator is now forbidden to take "anything of value" from a lobbyist, excluding food and drink, and a lobbyist may buy a legislator no more than $100 worth of food and drink a year.
"It's reached the point that I don't even let a lobbyist pay for my coffee these days," Speaker Clarke said.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Florio Forced to Retreat After a Hasty Charge

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
There are two fruit farmers in Burlington County, N.J., named William Haines, and because of that, the normally hard-charging campaign of Gov. Jim Florio found itself in the unfamiliar role of retreating last week.
In Atlantic City on Thursday to accept the endorsement of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Florio used the occasion to heave a barrage of criticisms at his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman. Among them was that Mrs. Whitman's adviser on agricultural issues was facing fines over a string of violations on a farm he owns. 
 The Florio campaign machine then issued a 10-page news release that detailed the charges:
"Farms owned by State Senator William Haines Jr. -- who Whitman named July 14, 1993, as the chair of her Council for Economic Recovery's Agriculture panel -- have been cited by the Federal Government for failing to provide farmworkers with toilet or handwashing facilities and face $30,000 in state fines for improper use of dangerous pesticides."
While the State Senator in question -- a Republican from Mount Laurel who answers to C. William Haines and grows peaches -- is contesting pending fines against his farm, he is not the William S. Haines, cranberry farmer and county neighbor but not kin, who is working with the Whitman campaign.
The two farmers are frequently mistaken for each other, so much so that those who know the potential for confusion refer to them as "Cranberry Bill" and "Peaches Bill." Given the charges and that they came in the thick of a gubernatorial campaign, it bloomed into a not-so-mild embarrassment for Mr. Florio and allowed Mrs. Whitman, for one of the few times in the campaign, to chortle over a gaffe.
 
A Run-In With Miss America
 It was not the only case of mistaken identity for the Florio campaign last week.
After addressing a teamsters convention on Tuesday at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, the Governor was leaving the meeting room with a phalanx of security guards and state police when they ran into a cluster of women blocking the hallway.
"You'll have to step aside," one member of the security party ordered politely, as others stepped forward to herd the group to a side of the corridor.
That set off a clatter of explanations that began to rise in pitch as Mr. Florio neared. A potential public-relations nightmare for the Governor was averted when a petite woman in the group was able to rivet the security detail's attention by declaring, "But I'm Miss America!"
That brought the Florio party to an abrupt stop and led to a brief conversation between the Governor and Leanza Cornett, whose reign as Miss America ended last night.
 
Reinvesting in South Africa
 New Jersey is moving toward lifting the ban it imposed eight years ago on state investments in South Africa.
Assemblyman Willie B. Brown, a Democrat from Newark, introduced legislation last Monday to repeal the state's divestiture laws and reinstate business trade with South Africa and companies doing business with it. Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a Republican, is a prime co-sponsor of the bill.
State Senator Peter A. Inverso has said he will introduce similar legislation in the Senate.
Mr. Brown, who returned two weeks ago from a visit to South Africa, said he introduced the legislation at the urging of the African National Congress and its leader, Nelson R. Mandela.
Mr. Brown sponsored the original divestiture bill, which took effect on Aug. 27, 1985. When Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed the legislation, $2.1 billion of New Jersey's $10 billion in public employee pension funds was invested in companies doing business with South Africa. The divestiture was the largest by any state.
