SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2822 words

HEADLINE: America Unplugged: Entering a Wireless Era -- A special report;
F.C.C. Clearing Airwaves For Phones of the Future

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
America is about to start coming unwired.
A decade after cellular telephones first captured the hearts of the hurried and the well-to-do by letting them stay plugged in without being pinned down, the Federal Government is about to clear the airwaves for an expansion of wireless offerings more sophisticated than anything available today. 
 On Thursday, after four years of work, the Federal Communications Commission will adopt rules that will create three to six new wireless networks in every city and town. Bringing stiff new competition and probably a steep plunge in prices, these services are expected to reach millions of new customers and could eventually replace phones anchored by copper wires.
The first of these new wireless networks could be working in less than two years, and could offer prices half those of cellular. Over the longer term, many industry experts predict, the wireless phones could replace a high percentage of those now tethered to copper wires.
 
More Than a Phone
 That could be a mixed blessing, freeing people from their desks yet chaining them to their jobs. Indeed, cellular companies are already building computerized systems that can automatically track a person's movements anywhere in North America, so the same telephone number will reach a person's desk phone or pocket phone wherever he or she roams. People will run, but they may not be able to hide.
But more than mere phones are on the horizon. Using the digital electronics of computers, the new "personal communications services" will be capable of sending data, images and perhaps even video to an expanding family of nomadic computing devices -- palm-size computers, electronic notepads and what some people call mutant devices that combine the features of a telephone, computer and pager.
To be sure, the risks are also huge: no one knows just what consumers will be willing to pay for; the technology is still very new, and it will cost billions to build the new networks nationwide. But virtually every big communications company is angling for position and lining up capital. The list ranges from media conglomerates like Time Warner Inc. and newspaper publishers like the Washington Post Company to long-distance carriers like A.T.& T. and MCI Communications, all the regional Bell companies and, of course, the current cellular industry.
"We are about to launch a huge industry in the next week," said Scott Schelle, the vice president of American Personal Communications, a small company that is 70 percent owned by the Washington Post Company and has built one of the first experimental personal communications services systems in the United States. "The timing is important because communications, computers and media are converging just as the wireless revolution is coming of age."
Indeed, many industry executives and experts said they believed wireless networks might replace much of the current wired phone network, relegating wall jacks to a place alongside the telegraph key and canal barge as antiquities of communications and commerce.
If the rapid growth of the $8 billion cellular business is any gauge, with 11 million subscribers already using cellular phones and an additional 9,500 signing up each day, the market for new forms of wireless communications could be huge. Tests of personal communications services, or P.C.S., in Washington, Pittsburgh, Tampa, Fla., and other cities, have indicated that tens of millions of people are eager buyers -- if the prices are right and the services ubiquitious.
Arthur D. Little, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., has estimated that personal communications services will generate 60 million customers in the United States by 2005.
Billions of dollars are on the line. For the first time ever, the F.C.C. will grant radio licenses by auctioning them off to the highest bidders, rather than through lotteries or merit-based comparative hearings.
The first auctions could begin as early as next May. The Clinton Administration estimates that these auctions will generate as much as $10.2 billion in revenue for the Federal Government over the next four years, and Wall Street investment bankers are already beginning to plot bidding strategies.
The technology for advanced wireless services has been tested at considerable length, and computer companies are already rushing to market with handheld devices that communicate over cellular frequencies. The limiting factor has always been a shortage of free space on the airwaves, because almost all of the radio frequencies that can be used easily are already occupied. That is why the F.C.C.'s action, which comes after a tortuous effort to reallocate a big chunk of the spectrum, is so central.
At the meeting this week, the commission is to announce its final decision on how many licenses to issue in each market, how much territory each license will cover and how to conduct the auctions.
 
The Incentives
Greater Access And Lower Prices
 The expansion of the wireless services coincides with advances in computers and miniaturization in electronics. Even now, laptop computers and hand-held devices like Apple Computer's Newton Messagepad and A.T.& T.'s EO Personal Communicator are placing enormous power to manage information in the palm of a person's hand. At the same time, the number of electronic mail services and data bases that are accessible from remote locations -- from the Library of Congress to ticket services for sports events -- is growing almost daily.
"There is a convergence of events," says John Major, the director of spectrum standards and software at Motorola Inc., a leading provider of wireless communications equipment. "Before laptops, it didn't matter whether you had an untethered link. Now, people find it annoying to have to plug in their computers."
Perhaps the most immediate impact of personal communications services will be to push down the cost of mobile communications. Today, despite their popularity, cellular services remain forbiddingly high for most customers. A typical local cellular call costs about 40 cents a minute, about double the price of a regular long-distance telephone call between New York and Los Angeles.
 
A Limited Capacity
 The high prices are partly the result of limited competition, because the F.C.C. authorized only two cellular companies to operate in each city. But cellular calls are also expensive because the networks use an aging technology that sharply limits the number of conversations they can carry.
Many experts believe that the new wireless networks will be much more economical. Using newer technology, P.C.S. systems may be able to serve up to 20 times as many customers as a cellular network, meaning that costs can be spread over a much bigger group of customers. Some industry experts, in fact, contend that wireless networks are now actually cheaper to build than those linked by copper.
American Personal Communications is planning to offer service at about 22 cents a minute, or half the price of cellular, and officials say the price will probably decline even further in years to come.
"The economics are indisputable," said Peter Huber, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute who has studied the telephone industry. "Wireless access is already competitive with wired. If you were starting out from scratch today, you would use radio in preference to copper for much of the country."
 
A Move to Modernization
 Indeed, that is already occurring in some other countries, like the Czech Republic and Hungary, which are building cellular systems as the fastest way to modernize their antiquated phone systems. And in the the small town of Quitague, Tex., the GTE Corporation said several months ago that it would replace part of its aging copper wire network and link many homes over a wireless connection.
Officials at Time Warner, which has teamed up with the regional Bell telephone company U S West Inc. to build what they call "full service networks" that offer wireless services, estimate that the cost to serve a P.C.S. subscriber system could be one-fifth the price of cellular service and even be competitive with conventional telephone service. And unlike most of today's cellular and telephone networks, the new P.C.S. systems will use the digital electronics of computers, offering clearer and more precise signals than older networks, which rely on analog transmissions that mimic sound waves.
"We intend to provide a substitute in the home for the land-line phone," said Dennis Patrick, a former chairman of the F.C.C. and now the president of Time Warner's telecommunications unit. "But because we will be digital from the get-go, we will be able to operate in a multimedia universe. Our technology will be able to handle voice, video and data."
 
The Technology
Computer Clarity From Cell to Cell
 Like today's cellular telephone systems, P.C.S. networks will consist of radio relay stations or "cell sites" -- each typically a few short antennas and a receiver-transmitter -- scattered across many locations in a city. These antennas pick up signals from wireless telephones, and they are linked together by wires or microwave transmissions into a network that can route calls from one place to another.
The networks are connected directly to the local telephone company, which can then link a wireless caller to a person speaking on a conventional plug-in phone. As with cellular systems, the key for personal communications networks is to set up a number of different cell sites that each cover a different part of the city. Using many cell sites makes it possible to use the same frequencies in several places at the same time.
But the P.C.S. systems will be different in several respects. While cellular systems employ a few huge antennas that are almost as big as television towers, the new networks will scatter hundreds of antennas in a large city like New York that are small enough to fit on a window ledge or even on a lamppost.
 
Better Sound Quality
 Because wireless signals will travel much shorter distances, customers can use handheld units that are cheaper and lower powered than cellular phones. The greater number of cell sites will also enable the carriers to re-use the same radio frequencies throughout the city, allowing for more customers.
And because the P.C.S. networks will transmit signals in digital form, the quality of the sound should be better for voice conversations and the transmission of computer data will be much more efficient than with today's analog wireless systems.
Although the cellular companies are slowly converting to digital systems as well, they cannot stop serving customers that use telephones based on older analog technology. In the meantime, however, they are trying to roll out a new technique for sending computer data by mixing it in between the voice-signals of cellular traffic.
 
The Impact
Why No Company Can Go It Alone
 Almost every communications company has something to gain or something to fear with the expansion of wireless and next week's new rules. "This will shake the foundations of the entire telecommunications industry," remarked Alfred C. Sikes, who served as the chairman of the F.C.C. under President George Bush and is now the president of Hearst New Media and Technology, a unit of the Hearst Corporation.
Cellular companies, facing head-to-head competition and fearing that the Government will keep them from bidding on the new licenses, have been actively lobbying on this issue. And local telephone companies, which all own cellular franchises as well, face the prospect of more competition in their core wired business.
But by far the most aggressive companies bidding to enter the new wireless market are cable television companies, most notably Time Warner , Cox Enterprises of Atlanta and the Comcast Corporation of Philadelphia.
Cable television executives are convinced that their networks of coaxial cable, which has much greater capacity than copper telephone wire, are ideally suited to be the backbone of the wireless networks by tying together the radio cell sites scattered around a city. The concept was first tested by Cox in an experimental system it set up in San Diego two years ago.
 
An Idea Catches On
 Since then, the idea has caught on throughout the industry. Time Warner, already in league with U S West and seeking to assemble an even broader consortium to enter the P.C.S. business, has been in active discussions with the largest cable company in the country, Tele-Communications Inc., among other possible partners. Last week another big cable company, Viacom Inc., said it would join a consortium of about 150 companies led by MCI, the second-biggest long-distance carrier in the United States.
Long-distance companies like American Telephone and Telegraph, MCI and Sprint will be affected in two big ways. For starters, all three are convinced they must offer wireless service as part of a comprehensive package of nationwide services. Beyond that, the long-distance carriers see local wireless networks as a way to reach their customers without going through traditional local phone companies and paying them billions of dollars in access charges.
 
Ahead of the Crowd
 A.T.& T. sent seismic waves through the communications industry last month when it announced it was buying the leading cellular company, McCaw Cellular Communications, for $12.6 billion. A.T.& T. can create a powerful new system by endowing McCaw's local cellular networks with the computerized intelligence of A.T.& T.'s long-distance network. Thus armed, A.T.& T. officials arebetting they can beat the crowd of new competitors to the new wireless frontier of P.C.S. services.
While many details of the F.C.C. plan are still being decided, the broad outlines are becoming clear. The most contentious lobbying has been over whether the existing cellular companies should be allowed to bid on the new licenses. Last year, many officials of the agency were worried that the cellular companies would simply snatch up frequencies and stifle new rivals.
Now the agency's officials seem ready to let cellular companies bid on at least some frequencies in their existing markets. But the officials also appear determined to create a seedbed for competition by issuing at least three new licenses -- and possibly six -- in each city.
"It turns out we found we could assign more spectrum than we originally thought" said Thomas N. Stanley, the chief engineer of the F.C.C. "If you have a bigger cake, you can give more people a slice."
 
The Caveats
Uncharted Markets And New Machines
 For consumers there may be a few possible drawbacks to this corporate gold rush. If dependable old local telephone service suffers or becomes more expensive from a market upheaval, a whole host of new wireless services may seem a bad deal. And if consumers thought that choosing a long-distance company in the 1980's was a headache, wait until they contemplate the sales pitches of a half-dozen wireless companies.
But the far bigger risks are for the companies that will have to pay the billions of dollars to bid for the licenses and build the networks.
Technology could also pose problems. Many leading proponents of P.C.S. services are betting on a transmission system called code division multiple access, which makes it possible to pack as many as 20 voice conversations in the bandwidth now needed for just one. Developed primarily by Qualcomm Inc. of San Diego, the technology has won praise throughout the industry. Still, some industry executives and other experts have warned that it has not been fully tested and could prove balky in some settings.
 
New Technical Challenges
 And then there are the new technical challenges of keeping track of millions of messages in which the recipients must be tracked down. With today's wired telephone network, although traffic control is a major consideration, most of the routing is like dispatching freight trucks by tracing the roads that lead to the customers. Wireless communications, where the customers are always on the move, is more comparable to air-traffic control at an airport: there are no stationary routes. The hardware and software for keeping track of all those airborne wireless messages is only now being tested.
Finally, cellular executives and their rivals worry about the inevitable industry shakeout if a slew of new carriers try to do battle. William Weiss, the chairman of Ameritech, a regional Bell telephone company that is active in cellular and hopes to find a role in personal communications services, sees grim times ahead.
"If the F.C.C. persists with the idea of creating three or five new providers in every market," Mr. Weiss grumbled, "there's a substantial question in my mind about whether anybody will make any money at it."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Less Cost vs. Less Care

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
As President Clinton prepares for Wednesday's prime-time presentation of his plan for overhauling health care, his proposed ceiling on medical spending has emerged as one of the plan's most hotly debated aspects, prompting warnings of a degradation in the quality of care or even rationing.
Braking medical spending as sharply as the President proposes -- cutting annual growth by more than half of what it has been in recent years -- could force strapped medical groups to shortchange patients, denying them useful tests and treatments, some doctors and insurance executives maintain. While these critics also fear for their own incomes and profits under the Clinton plan, their warnings are echoed by many economists.
 
Safely Squeezable
 Nonsense, Administration officials say. They and many medical experts portray an American system so replete with inefficiency, duplication, overcharging and overuse of procedures that huge sums can safely be squeezed out for many years to come. 
 Right now, health care consumes 14 percent of the gross national product, up from 10 percent in 1981. Under the Clinton plan spending would be allowed to bulge in the next three years as uninsured Americans were covered, reaching 17 percent of the economy, but it would reach a plateau at that level for years to come.
 
'Bizarre on Its Face'
 Without the Clinton overhaul, Government experts predict, medical spending in the year 2000 would reach 19 percent of the gross national product -- with tens of millions of people still not covered -- and would keep climbing.
"When an American physician tells you that at 17 percent of the G.N.P. we'll have to ration, that seems bizarre on its face," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University and an expert on European health systems that spend far less.
But Dr. Reinhardt added, "The issue is the speed of the slowdown in spending, not the ultimate level." If the transition to a system dominated by lean, efficient health maintenance organizations is too rocky in some regions or does not incorporate proper safeguards for consumers, he said, he could foresee "bad outcomes here and there, rationing in effect."
Even as some critics warn about pressures to scrimp on needed care, others fault the President for avoiding more explicit discussion of medical priorities, of the need to start making hard choices amid an unending flow of costly new technologies that could drain society's resources.
Some advocates of planned rationing, like Daniel Callahan, director of the nonprofit Hastings Center in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., which studies medical ethics, even say the President's plan may be too generous.
"I feel that 17 percent of the economy is absolutely excessive," he said, predicting that it would rob other social needs, like education and investment in jobs, for trivial gains in health.
 
World's Costliest Treatment
 Even many doctors say the nation should find a way to curb hugely expensive intensive care for patients who have only a slight chance of survival. But White House officials, already facing a tortuous political fight over health care, do not want to provoke debate on such divisive questions.
While the medical structure they have proposed is designed to help weed out senseless treatment, these officials insist that talk of overt rationing of care is premature.
Mr. Clinton seeks to halt the rise in medical spending by encouraging stiffer market competition and, if that fails, by imposing mandatory controls that would keep health costs in line with the expansion of the economy.
Even so, under the President's proposals, American medical spending would continue to dwarf that of other industrial nations that have high medical standards.
 
'Huge Cushion of Inefficiency'
 In 1991, the latest year for which international data are available, health spending accounted for more than 13 percent of the American economy but only 10 percent in Canada, 9 percent in France and Germany and 7 percent in Japan and the United Kingdom. Most other nations have controls in place to keep spending from rising much above the 10 percent range, if that.
Paul Starr, a senior White House adviser and an architect of the Clinton plan, said large savings would come through reduced administrative costs and a large-scale shift of consumers into health plans that provide good care for less.
Mr. Starr predicted that competition among medical groups, something already happening in parts of the country, would keep spending in most regions below the proposed caps anyway, but that "it's also important to create certain expectations about spending."
"I don't think that 17 percent of the G.N.P. is all that tight," Mr. Starr said. "We have been through a period of enormous growth in health costs, and I think we have built up a huge cushion of inefficiency."
That view is shared by Dr. David M. Lawrence, chief executive of Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Calif., the nation's largest and oldest H.M.O. and a model for the kinds of medical groups the Clinton plan would encourage.
"Our position is that the way to live under the proposed constraints is through improving the quality of care," said Dr. Lawrence, whose nonprofit company serves 6.6 million patients in 16 states. "You can only do that so long before you finally reach the limits. But I'd suggest that the American health care system isn't even close."
Experts say the best H.M.O.'s are already trimming costs while improving care, by negotiating lower prices for goods and even for organ transplants, by stressing preventive measures and by carefully studying how their doctors make decisions.
 
Aggressively Monitoring Costs
 Compared with standard American medical practice, H.M.O.'s use more primary care doctors, who provide most care and serve as "gatekeepers" to costly specialists. This not only holds down bills but also reduces the level of unneeded surgery and other procedures. As an indication of the potential savings, Dr. Lawrence and other H.M.O. executives point to research like that done by Dr. John E. Wennberg of Dartmouth Medical School, which found huge variations in surgery rates around the country with little impact on patient welfare.
Applying these methods aggressively since 1990, a year in which Kaiser's costs jumped by 15 percent, the H.M.O. kept premium increases to 9.6 percent in 1992 and 6.8 percent in 1993, well below the double-digit growth still experienced by traditional medical plans.
"We're on a very steep learning curve in terms of understanding where all the levers are to keep improving the costs," Dr. Lawrence said. But while H.M.O.'s are poised for rapid gains in efficiency, he said it was "an open question" how quickly the rest of the medical system could reorganize.
David F. Simon, executive vice president of U.S. Healthcare, a for-profit H.M.O. based in Bluebell, Pa., that serves 1.5 million patients in the Northeast, said a broad transition to H.M.O.-type care could reduce total medical spending quickly and dramatically: "We'd estimate in the 15 to 20 percent range, perhaps even more."
 
Too Much, Too Little
 But Mr. Simon said his company was concerned about "an overlay of bureaucratic and regulatory controls" in the health plan that would hamper competition. "I don't think you'll see the kind of savings they are projecting," he said. "If the budget caps kick in, a byproduct could be the need to ration care, or cut back on benefits."
If traditional medicine offers financial incentives to do too much, H.M.O.-type plans have an incentive to minimize treatment, raising fears that patients could be shortchanged.
H.M.O. leaders insist that their companies would suffer losses if they allowed their patients' small problems to grow into big ones. But Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor emeritus of The New England Journal of Medicine, noted that some groups reward individual doctors directly for ordering fewer tests and referrals, and he warned that a financially troubled for-profit organization could take a short-term view of patient welfare.
 
Wrenching Choices Are Seen
 The White House thinks that publication of data about the performance of each health plan and about the incentives each offers its doctors will help consumers protect themselves; plans that scrimp will lose customers. Dr. Relman would go further by strongly encouraging the development of nonprofit H.M.O.'s run by salaried doctors and their patients rather than investor-owned medical plans.
Economists like Joseph Newhouse of Harvard University argue that given the steady march of useful, expensive medical technologies, any spending limit will necessarily involve sacrifices over time. And they argue that such sacrifices should be openly admitted and discussed.
Many medical ethicists say American society must decide when to withhold expensive care or technologies. Some of the most wrenching examples involve expenditures of hundreds of thousands of dollars in the earliest or latest days of life: saving extremely premature babies who have high chances of severe disabilities even if they survive, or putting patients with advanced cancer, for example, on life-support systems to gain at most a few months more of life.
To some degree, the medical structure offered by the White House may take care of these issues implicitly, Dr. Reinhardt said. "That's the beauty" of a system of medical groups working within fixed budgets, he said. "It hides the rationing, makes it ad hoc, keeps it in the obscurity of the H.M.O. They are not going to say, 'Sorry, we're over budget,' but they might say, 'Gee, it's inhumane to continue treatment.' "
And, provided that the right guidelines and ethical controls were in place and doctors were not being rewarded directly for cheating patients, he said, "It could be a good thing."

The Economy
The Federal Government is about to clear the airwaves for an expansion of wireless communications more sophisticated than anything available today. The Federal Communications Commission will adopt rules on Thursday creating three to six new wireless networks in every city and town. Bringing stiff new competition and probably a steep plunge in prices, these services are expected to reach millions of new customers and could eventually replace phones anchored by copper wires. [Page A1.]
Top Administration economists have stoutly rejected suggestions by Fed officials that the central bank not consider cutting short-term interest rates because of fear that this could fuel an unwanted speculative bubble in stocks and bonds. The economists said near-record stock and bond levels in no way constituted a bubble, but were rather a justified response to lower interest rates and President Clinton's deficit-reduction efforts. [D1.]

Honda plans to make all Accords and Civics for sale in the United States at its plants in Ohio, eliminating exports from Japan of those models. The move is part of a long-range revamping that has been accelerated by the rise of the Japanese yen. [D1.]
Chrysler's experience cleaning up a plant site prompted Michigan to adopt rules that have made the state a national leader in reversing what some say are negative consequences of well-meaning environmental policies. [A12.]

HEADLINE: Rules Easing for Urban Toxic Cleanups

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
In 1990, when the Chrysler Corporation proposed building a $1 billion Jeep plant in Detroit, the site it chose was in a neighborhood of old houses, industrial plants and abandoned lots. But as in much of Detroit, the soil was contaminated with traces of gasoline and some heavy metals, environmental studies found.
The state was adamant that Chrysler clean up the 283 acres to pristine condition before building. But Chrysler officials said the cost of that would have rivaled the value of the new plant. 
 So the state and the automaker compromised on a $25 million project to contain and stabilize the contaminants rather than completely remove them, and the new plant was able to open in January 1992, employing 3,100 people, most of them members of minorities.
Chrysler's experience prompted Michigan to adopt new rules in 1991 intended to make hazardous-waste cleanups less expensive, especially in urban areas where old industrial properties are common. The rules have made Michigan a national leader in reversing what business executives and some conservationists say are three unintended consequences of well-meaning environmental policies.
 
"We Just Have to Get Real'
 First, the costs of complying with rules for toxic cleanups help drive employers away from cities, contributing to economic and social deterioration. Second, the rules are encouraging the development of factories and buildings in uncontaminated forests, fields and meadows. And third, such development beyond the suburbs is causing more urban sprawl and, ultimately, more air and water pollution as workers and their families move or drive to the new job sites.
"What we have is a program that is not working as it was supposed to," said Russell J. Harding, the Deputy Director of the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. "We can't get our old industrial sites redeveloped. We're losing jobs and tax base in the cities. And if the laws aren't adjusted, our green spaces will become gray spaces. It's not what a lot of people want to hear, especially some people in the environmental community, but we just have to get real on this stuff."
Kathy Milberg, the executive director of the Southwest Detroit Environmental Vision Project, a group in the Corktown section of Detroit, is among the environmentalists whose thinking on toxic waste has changed.
"There are a lot of environmental groups, who do their work in the suburbs and the rural areas, who say all land must be cleaned up to pristine standards," she said. "But they don't live here. They aren't losing their kids to economic death. We are literally losing lives because of the unavailability of employment opportunities. There should be allowances made in environmental rules for the city of Detroit to make it easier to reuse property and redevelop."
 
No Cleanup, No Business
 One of Ms. Milberg's friends is Bill Spaulding, who wanted to expand his family's electrical contracting business in Corktown. But Mr. Spaulding'sDetroit bank refused to lend him the money to build an addition where there was an employee parking lot, worrying about the legal liability and whether he would face a regulatory wringer over traces of oil, antifreeze and fuel that had seeped into the ground.
Mr. Spaulding ended up erecting a new building on undeveloped land in Port Huron, 60 miles north of Detroit.
"That was 10 jobs that could have stayed here," Mr. Spaulding said. "Cleanups are expensive and take forever, and those are two of the main reasons banks won't lend money and businesses are not developing in Detroit."
The problem is not confined to Michigan. Studies by the Northeast-Midwest Institute and Resources for the Future, two policy research groups in Washington, found that cities in Indiana, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and other states were experiencing similar problems.
 
Strict Laws Blamed
 Studies in Michigan and Washington said the primary culprits there were the Federal Superfund law, enacted in 1980 to clean up the nation's worst pollution sites, and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1984. The first set up a rigidly controlled process for ridding a site of contamination, and the second established expensive requirements for disposing of chemical wastes, principally at incinerators, treatment centers and landfills, many of them built in the last decade in rural regions.
Many states, including Michigan, also enacted their own waste-management laws, in some cases stricter than the Federal statutes, like the Michigan law that stood in the way of the Jeep plant.
All the laws were intended to reduce threats to health and the environment by toxic compounds. But in case after case, say state officials and some scientists here, the levels of contamination found are tiny, and even after millions of dollars are spent on cleanups, particularly in urban areas, it is virtually impossible to measure whether anything improved.
Faced with a program that they were convinced was backfiring, businessmen and city officials called for changes in the state law.
If contamination is slight and in an area, like Detroit, where it is not threatening drinking water or blown in the wind, Michigan law now allows companies essentially to seal in the contaminants with fresh soil or clay.
Michigan also now allows the Attorney General to promise buyers of old industrial properties that the state will not sue them for the cost of cleaning up old contamination. And the state set up a $45 million program to help cities pay for investigating and cleaning up old industrial sites.
Aides to Gov. John Engler, a Republican, say the Department of Natural Resources has been slow to put the more flexible rules into effect, a criticism that Mr. Harding of that department does not dispute. One reason, said Mr. Harding and other state environmental officials, is that many of his staff members do not agree with the approach.
In interviews, state employees who spoke only on the condition that they not to be identified, said they worried that the new rules opened the door to weakening other environmental laws, like cleaning up messes left by underground gasoline and oil tanks that leaked. The employees also said strict hazardous waste rules and companies' potential liability for contamination had been a deterrent that made business executives more careful about managing wastes.
But many city officials in the state say such thinking is hurting their chances to attract new jobs. Monroe, the only Michigan port on Lake Erie, has tried to lure industry to a 400-acre site where sand used in steel casting was once dumped. The sand is slightly tainted by heavy metals, and in some areas, traces of more toxic chemicals, like PCB's, have also been found.
Port executives have commissioned scientific studies that indicate that containing the chemicals where they are would protect public health and the environment. But the state officials are still undecided on how to proceed.
Thomas Russow, the lawyer for the Port of Monroe, said one company interested in buying or leasing property was American Resources Recovery Inc., a Canadian concern that recycles tires. It proposed more than two years ago to build a $12 million plant on 10 acres that would employ 30 people full time and 15 people part time.
But as delays have mounted, company executives have now told Mr. Russow that unless a waiver of liability for past pollution is granted, they are likely to build the plant outside of Monroe in a rural area of the county.

(Photographs by Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
White House Aides Reject a Fed Rate View

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Top Administration economists have stoutly rejected suggestions by Federal Reserve officials that the central bank not consider cutting short-term interest rates because of fear that this could fuel an unwanted speculative bubble in stocks and bonds.
The economists said near-record stock and bond levels in no way constituted a bubble, but were rather a justified response to lower interest rates, which they said were fostered by lower inflation and President Clinton's deficit-reduction efforts. 
 "We at the Treasury have not been concerned about speculative bubbles," Alicia Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, said. "It's true stock prices are high, but if you look in the real estate area, commercial values are way down and family homes are down in value. You don't see an economywide speculative bubble."
 
Higher, Not Lower, Rates
 In interviews last week, David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, expressed fears that further rate cuts could cause a surge in investment that would push financial markets to unjustifiable levels, setting the stage for a plunge. But Mr. Mullins said that current stock and bond prices did not appear inflated.
Traders said the central bankers' remarks helped push down the bond market late last week because the comments hinted that the Fed's next move might be to raise, not lower, rates.
J. Bradford De Long, a Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary, said: "I was surprised people would talk about a speculative boom in the bond market. They were saying things I would not expect people to say."
Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Econmic Advisers, also dismissed the idea of a speculative bubble, saying, "Given the gradual nature in the rise of the stock market with the gradual brightening of U.S. economic performance and the lowering of long-term rates, there doesn't seem to be a great disjuncture between stock market values and economic fundamentals."
Mr. Blinder also said the bond market had "risen for very sound fundamental reasons," including the prospects of a lower Federal budget deficit and the "gradually dawning realization that we're living in a low-inflation world."
 
A Tug of War
 In many ways, the argument is a tug of war between conservative Fed officials trying to build a case against lower rates, and perhaps for higher ones, and the Clinton Administration, eager to reduce unemployment, trying to build a case against higher rates. The debate is more than academic because the Fed's main policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, is to meet Tuesday.
"We seem to be showing steady growth with no signs of inflation," said Ms. Munnell, who used to be chief economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. "It seems we'll be able to continue at this growth rate or somewhat higher for the foreseeable future. That should bring down unemployment, which is our goal, without increasing inflation."
Mr. De Long of the Treasury denied there was a bubble in the bond market. He said the spread between long-term and short-term bond rates had been high for two years but returned to normal levels when long-term rates fell recently.
"I was surprised anyone would think long bonds were overpriced," he said. "And the stock market is where it should be, given the decline in long-term bonds. Remember, money flows out of the bond market into the stock market when interest rates fall."
 
Shadow Group's Influence Seen
 Some economists said Mr. Mullins and Mr. Lindsey were influenced by the Shadow Open Market Committee, an independent group of highly conservative economists who say the amount of currency and bank reserves is growing so fast that the prices of stocks and other assets have been artificially inflated.
But the central bankers might have made their comments, several economists said, to deflect criticisms from these conservative monetarists as well as from liberals. With inflation falling and growth remaining lackluster in recent months, more and more liberal economists have urged the Fed to cut interest rates.

HEADLINE: Arabs Say Prompt Aid Is Crucial for Self-Rule

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JABALIYA, Israeli-Occupied Gaza Strip, Sept. 17

 BODY:
In a sight that seemed unthinkable only a month ago, once-forbidden Palestinian flags are flying these days from nearly every building in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip as well as from cars, bicycles, donkey carts, tractors and even the minarets of mosques in East Jerusalem.
But while Palestinians in the occupied territories have greeted the Israeli-P.L.O. peace accord with jubilation, there is a growing sense of the difficulty in creating some form of government and an economy virtually from scratch, in a complex relationship with a powerful, dominant neighbor. 
 "It is good to raise the flags," said the imam of the main mosque in a sermon on Friday at this litter-strewn Palestinian camp, where a strong undercurrent of opposition to the accord among Islamic fundamentalists is evident on the streets. "But after raising flags, what is the next step? The solution is not just raising flags."
So swift has been the rush toward peace, and so deliberately vague many of the terms of the accord, that no one seems sure how the economy or the new Palestinian governing authority in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho will function. What's more, it will be years down the road before there is any discussion of the status of Jerusalem and the fate of Palestinian refugees from Israel's founding in 1948.
 
Crucial, Immediate Steps
 "They must do something fast," said Ziad Abu Amr, a Palestinian political scientist at Bir Zeit University on the West Bank. "Both Arafat and Rabin need to show their respective constituencies there are gains."
Among the crucial first steps are economic efforts to create steady jobs and business opportunities and to improve living conditions at the squalid camps. Some Palestinian analysts, like Rashid Khalidi, director of the Center for Middle Eastern Studies at the University of Chicago, warn that failure to do so quickly could be a "catastrophe" for Palestinian self-rule.
"You are taking a shattered Palestinian economy and binding it quite tightly to a robust, rapidly growing Israeli economy," Dr. Khalidi said."It's not going to lead to the kind of economic takeoff that's necessary."
With the immediate needs of the occupied territories estimated at $3 billion by the World Bank, supporters of the accord on interim Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho are scrambling to put together an aid package for schools and basic services like electricity and sewage removal.
Israeli and Palestinian technical teams are to meet in Tunis on Monday to discuss issues ranging from security to sewage, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher is expected to announce a special conference of donor countries to pledge money for projects to further Middle East Peace.
Officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization are hoping for a big infusion of aid to build schools and houses here in the next few months. Such a program could create construction jobs in the territories, which have an unemployment rate of 60 percent and have provided Israel with a pool of cheap labor.
Aside from the economic doubts, there is considerable uncertainty about how a new political order will meld Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., and other of its officials from Tunis with prominent local Palestinians who played an important role in the six-year uprising against Israeli rule, like Faisal al-Husseini and Sari Nusseibeh.
P.L.O. officials will also face the challenge of coordinating with new political organizations that emerged during the uprising and with traditional village and clan structures in a political culture that has been shaped by a quarter-century of occupation.
 
'Not a Love of Authority'
 "You don't have a tradition of government here," said Dr. Khalidi, an American-born adviser to the Palestinian delegation to the peace talks. "There is not a tradition of large bureaucratic institutions, not a love of authority. The social structure is not terribly developed."
He continued: "There will be a fine line between the authority of the elected government and the authority of the P.L.O. There will have to be all kinds of deliberate balances. Any corruption, any inefficiency, any bureaucratic snafu, any mistakes, and people are not going to be forgiving."
One immediate source of tension between Palestinians has eased with an agreement between the P.L.O. and its main hard-line fundamentalist opponent, Hamas, to respect each other's demonstrations and not to attack each other. The pact between the two movements was announced last week in mosques throughout the Gaza Strip.
Hamas firmly opposes the accord with Israel. For the signing of the pact last Monday, the two Palestinian groups hastily worked out a truce in which the Gaza Strip was shut down in a protest strike in the morning and open for celebrations in the evening.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Continued Volatility Seen in Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market is perverse in many ways. It thrives on bad news, like a sluggish economy and declines in jobs. It even turns reassuring cliches upside down. For example: No news is bad news in the bond market for the next several weeks.
With prices and yields apparently locked in a trading range after the sell-off last Tuesday caused by a higher-than-expected jump in inflation in August, new economic data are needed to provide a sense of direction for the market. 
 But no high-impact data are due until the Labor Department releases the September jobs report on Oct. 8. That will be followed by retail sales and the Producer Price Index on Oct. 14 and the Consumer Price Index on Oct. 15. Only after those reports will traders and investors have the kinds of economic signposts they want. And only if these data are reassuringly sluggish on growth and low on inflation will long-term yields be able to tilt downward again.
 
Looking for Signs
 So, between now and then the market ought to continue to be volatile, reacting to minor economic reports like the housing starts and durable- goods data due this week, and bouncing up and down wildly during the day, as it did last week.
While they await the big-league data, the economists will be sifting through smaller bits of information to see if there are any signs that the economy, which grew at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the first half of the year, is building up some steam. And as they do, they will debate whether there is enough growth to worry the bond market by raising new concerns about inflation.
Richard Berner, the chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said he had seen several indications of growth recently. These included the signs of an upturn in consumer spending, as reflected in anecdotes from car dealers, data on sales at department stores and the small rise in retail sales last month. "It is not a spectacular boom, just steady gains," he said.
A decline in weekly claims for jobless benefits and the rise in the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's manufacturing index seemed to point to a better job performance for September, with nonfarm employment likely to rise to the 150,000 range, a contrast to the surprising decline of 39,000 last month.
 
Demand for Business Equipment
 There is also the small gain in industrial production for August, including signs of good demand domestically for business equipment.
These signals point to growth that will show up in the fourth quarter of the year rather than the third quarter, Mr. Berner said. Unexpectedly slow auto production, which is holding back growth in the current three-month period, is expected to bounce up with the new model year, giving a lift to the last three months of the year.
He translated this into an economy growing at an annual rate of 2 percent, after adjustment for inflation, from July through September, and a 3.5 percent pace from October through December.
While this is nothing spectacular, it is possible that indications of such a pickup toward the end of the year could worry traders and investors. With long-term yields already at 25-year lows and securities very expensive, buyers may lose their nerve even if data showed the economy was just a notch above sluggish.
 
Prices Held Back
 But Mr. Berner said he did not agree. He said he expected inflation to remain around its current 2.9 percent rate, and added that there were plenty of forces holding prices back, including oil prices, cuts in air fares and the slowing of the pace of health care price increases.
"It may have a little bit farther to go," he said of the decline in long-term interest rates.
But he said the stronger growth at the end of the year could have an impact on shorter-term interest rates, which are likely to be the focus of a lot of speculation this week as the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meets to set the central bank's policy on interest rates for the next several months.
Stronger economic growth data in the near future would be sure to confirm the expectation that the Federal Reserve will not lower its short-term interest rate target of 3 percent, which has been unchanged for a year. That puts an upward bias on short-term rates.
 
Gauging the Fed's Intentions
 Analysts said they did not think the Fed committee, which will meet tomorrow, will make any change in its 3 percent target, especially because the data for retail sales and industrial production for August were a little stronger than expected.
What analysts are looking for is a more subtle sign of the Fed's intentions: whether the Fed will change from a bias in its policy-making mechanism toward higher short-term interest rates or move back to a neutral stance. The move to a bias toward higher rates was made in the May meeting, when consumer prices were rising at an annual rate of 4 percent. The bias was not changed in July, and analysts said they expected that it was not changed in the August meeting, the minutes of which will be released on Friday.
Darwin L. Beck, the director of the economics department at the First Boston Corporation, and David Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said they thought the Fed would hold its ground. "The Fed is much more worried about the possibility of accelerating inflation than declining growth," Mr. Jones said. Mr. Beck added, "There is nothing forcing them to change."
If there is no change in this indicator of central bank intentions, a little more upward pressure might be added to the short-term interest rates. But, at the same time, the refusal to change might re-emphasize the central bank's anti-inflation credentials, which would help longer-term interest rates inch lower.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Delays $1.5 Billion Loan to Russia Because Reform Is Stalled

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund has decided to delay a $1.5 billion loan to Russia because of Moscow's failure to cut its inflation rate and carry out other promised reforms.
But United States and fund officials said they were encouraged that the Russian Government has shown what they see as a stepped-up commitment to reform during the last few days, for instance in the appointment of former Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar as a First Deputy Prime Minister. 
 In recent weeks, the International Monetary Fund and the Clinton Administration have told Russia that they were concerned that inflation had ballooned to 29 percent monthly in August and that Moscow was not doing enough to reduce its budget deficit.
 
$44 Billion Aid Plan Approved
 But after visiting Moscow on Tuesday and Wednesday, Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said he was more encouraged about the Russian situation than he had been in mid-summer.
"The recent inflation rate has been too high, but I am encouraged by Russia's official plans to get financial conditions back under control," he said today. "It is crucial that these plans be implemented as a basis for economic growth in Russia and for the full effectiveness of Western support."
The United States and other leading industrial nations have approved a $44 billion aid package for Russia, including a stretching out of $16 billion in debt repayments. Much of that aid is not expected to be affected by Russia's failure to carry out certain reforms.
But the more than $10 billion that would come from the I.M.F. and World Bank or be funneled through them could be delayed for months if Russia fails to bring inflation and the budget deficit under control.
A senior fund official told reporters this weekend that his organization was unhappy with Russia's backtracking on reforms during the summer. He said: "Important measures in the budget field have not been taken, and credit discipline has been relaxed. This has put their reform program off track."
The I.M.F. appears to be dangling the delayed $1.5 billion loan as a carrot to push Moscow to gets its economic house in order. The senior fund official, who insisted on anonymity, said the loan was being delayed indefinitely, but he hinted that Moscow might receive the loan by the end of the year if it displayed a strong and renewed commitment to reform.
An American official said, "Our message is, if Russia's policies continue to get out of control and inflation continues to go up, it will be difficult for the multilateral aid package to continue."
 
Yeltsin in Battle
 The Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin has been forced into a gridlock by a battle between those who want to push ahead with painful market-oriented measures, including sharp cuts in credits to floundering enterprises, and others who favor more state regulation and planning and doling out more credits to keep enterprises afloat. American and I.M.F. officials are optimistic that the appointment of Mr. Gaidar will help tilt the balance in favor of the first bloc.
A senior Administration said, "We're very encouraged by Gaidar's return and by indications from the Russian Government that they now see the need for a rapid turn toward stabilization and reform."
Last spring, the I.M.F. established a new loan program to help former Soviet bloc countries make the wrenching transition toward a market economy. The fund committed itself to lending Russia $3 billion. Russia received half in June, and was scheduled to receive the second half this month.
The World Bank has also delayed a planned $600 million loan to Russia.
 
Progress Is Seen
 Despite these delays, Administration officials said Russia's economy was not in desperate shape and had made considerable progress over the last year.
"The Russian economy looks good relative to what observers might have expected in the September of 1990, 1991 or even September of 1992, despite the 29 percent inflation in August," a senior Treasury Department official said. "Output has stopped contracting. Coal prices have been increased. The exchange rate has stabilized. And dollar incomes are up substantially."
Another encouraging sign is that after the burst in inflation in August, Russian inflation simmered down during the first two weeks in September to just 3 percent a week.
The sense among American officials is that after weeks of dismay during the summer, when Russian reformers seemed to be losing ground, an important turn for the better is in the offing.
The senior I.M.F. official said the Fund would do everything it could to assist Russia to help prevent the scheduled loans from being seriously disrupted. But he said it was important to remember the immense political and economic difficulties that Russia's reformers face.

HEADLINE: In Mideast, Tourism Heats Up

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Luz A. Beltran, a Roman Catholic from Indianapolis, has made pilgrimages to shrines at Fatima, Portugal; Lourdes, France, and Our Lady of Guadalupe in Mexico City, but her fondest wish has long been to visit the Holy Land.
"I was afraid to go, though," she said, "because there always seemed to be trouble in the Middle East."
But about a week ago, as a peace treaty between Israel and the Palestinians seemed imminent, Mrs. Beltran set aside plans to visit Greece and signed up for an eight-day tour next month of religious sites in Israel.
 
Rolling Out the Welcome Mat
 Tour operators, hoteliers, airlines, cruise lines and governments in the region are racing to roll out the welcome mat, certain that millions of tourists from throughout the world will feel the same way. 
 With stunning speed, a region that was widely thought of in terms of terrorism, air raids and besieged people in gas masks is being transformed into a land of milk and money, boasting not only archeological digs and ancient civilizations, but also beckoning beaches, luxury hotels, desert safaris and an unsurpassed blend of tradition and modernity.
Governments that had been mortal enemies are signing agreements to promote tourism in one another's backyards, and the transformation seems to be taking place less because of marketing and advertising hype than the realization that what until recently seemed forever forbidding is now possible and potentially risk free.
"I still can't believe it," Mrs. Beltran said on Friday about her forthcoming visit. "I thought I would never get to go to the Holy Land."
 
A Gradual Reassessment
 The public's reassessment has come gradually, as a tide of terrorist acts that horrified the world has ebbed in recent months. Two years ago, an Australian tourist was shot and killed at point-blank range in East Jerusalem and, in 1990, a Canadian tourist was killed by a pipe-bomb explosion on a Tel Aviv beach.
Religious militants also crippled Egypt's tourist industry by their attacks on tour buses and cruise ships, killing three tourists last year and wounding dozens of others.
But while many people, Americans and foreigners, caution that a recurrence of terrorist acts could undo all that has been accomplished by diplomacy, it has not escaped them that the Middle East may now actually compare favorably in the minds of the safety-conscious with American destinations like Florida, where nine tourists have been killed within a year in headline-grabbing murders, many of them committed during bump-and-rob incidents.
In any case, in the Middle East, except for Egypt, tourists have only rarely been the specific targets of terrorist acts.
Executives of travel-related companies as well as government officials who would like to see the region's desert-like service economies bloom caution against raising hopes too high too fast. But for now those warnings are being lost amid widespread euphoria, as various Middle Eastern governments sense a fundamental shift in attitudes about the region and brace for a flood of new business.
"The reaction has been absolutely phenomenal," said Jim Adair, president of Regina Tours in Chardon, Ohio, which specializes in Holy Land tours for Catholics. "We usually average 100 tourists in November, but this year it'll be in excess of 600. Our phones haven't stopped ringing."
Other tour operators and travel agents report a similar surge in demand.
"I've been involved in travel to the Holy Land for over 30 years, and this is the biggest event connected with tourism in my lifetime," said James Ridgway, president of Educational Travel Services in Lakeland, Fla., "Tourism to the region is going to explode and prosper."
 
Israel Expected to Benefit
 Israel, which already plays host to 1.75 million visitors a year, one quarter of whom are Americans, is expected to benefit the most initially. Government authorities expect a 25 percent increase in visitors in the next year. But "the sky's the limit," said Uzi Michaeli, Israeli tourism commissioner for North America.
"The first thing that will move into the region will be tourists, then economic development, then you'll have a Middle East common market," he said.
In anticipation, El Al, Israel's national airline, recently decided to keep two Boeing 747's it had planned to unload after delivery of two new 747-400's next spring, and it plans to train additional airline pilots.
Arkia, Israel's second-biggest carrier, is determined not to be left behind. According to trade press reports, it is considering starting flights to Amman, Jordan; Beirut, Lebanon; Damascus, Syria, and Cairo.
 
Hilton Building in Region
 There could be other winners, too. Hilton International is placing big bets in Saudi Arabia and Egypt, where it is building hotel and resort properties, in addition to the new deluxe hotel it is erecting in Jerusalem across from the walls of the Old City.
Hoping for a piece of the action, Emirates, the airline of the United Arab Emirates, recently opened sales offices in New York, Washington, Houston and Los Angeles in an effort to woo American visitors.
"We're also forging marketing agreements with American carriers to fly passengers to European gateways," said James Baxter, Emirates' vice president for North America.From there, Emirates, which does not fly to the United States, would carry passengers to the Arab Gulf states.
To handle the expected influx, Marriott is expected to open a 224-room hotel in Dubai in the United Arab Emirates next Month, complete with a sports bar, an English pub, health club and spa. Like many Middle Eastern countries, Dubai already receives many business travelers from Europe and weekend tourists from countries in the region. But the arrival of Western amenities is absolutely vital if the area is going to attract visitors from farther away, in the view of Ed Fuller, the managing director of Marriott international properties.
 
Infrastructure Needed
 "Until there is more infrastructure, the whole region won't have as many tourists as Paris," he predicted.
Government officials are more confident that if they build the rooms, the curious will come.
"Tourism is still a nascent industry, but it's growing and there is great potential for growth," said Dr. Edmond Ghareeb, press attache of the United Arab Emirates Embassy in Washington. "This country can easily absorb hundreds of thousands of new tourists, and with people no longer feeling fearful, we and the rest of the region will benefit."
Other countries may have a tougher time attracting tourists' dollars. Yemen, for example, a poor country on the southern border of Saudi Arabia, recently opened its ports to small cruise ships. And a few months ago, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, a country off-limits to Americans, proposed that Libya encourage mass tourism. Yet, neither country has been able to make much headway with American visitors who are being constantly reminded by the State Department of the potential dangers.
 
A Switch in Attitudes
 Perhaps most remarkable is the way that once standoffish neighbors are suddenly cozying up. Israel and Greece, for example, recently signed an agreement to stimulate travel between the two countries. And several weeks ago, Israel, Egypt, Greece, Turkey and Cyprus agreed to cooperate in promoting tourism and invited Lebanon, Jordan, Syria and Morocco to join them, according to Mr. Michaeli.
Andy Duncan, a London-based director with PKF Consulting, said that while many Middle Eastern countries were actively courting visitors, Western tourists should nevertheless keep in mind that there will always be holdouts in every country who harbor lingering hostility toward their former enemies.
"I was in the Gulf recently," he said, "and I wasn't allowed to enter any Arab country because I had an Israeli visa in my passport. Hopefully, that's going to change."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Selling a Health Proposal: Catchwords and Humility

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's toughest problem in selling a health care overhaul to the American people will be boiling down into a single evocative slogan a highly complex plan that will have very different impacts on businesses, individuals and families.
White House officials said today that if they had to distill their message to a bumper sticker, it would be one word in capital letters: SECURITY. The point, they argue, is that the Clinton plan, above all else, offers people the security of knowing that if they change jobs, if they lose their jobs, if they suffer a catastrophic illness, if hospital costs skyrocket, they will always have the security of their health care. 
 "First and foremost will be the theme of 'security,' " said a Presidential adviser, George Stephanopoulos. "That is the emotional core of this plan. It speaks to people's deepest fears. The idea is that no matter what happens to you -- if you lose your job, if your wife loses her job, if you switch jobs, or if your company goes under -- your health care will be nationally guaranteed."
Having learned from its botched, and nearly fatal, effort to sell its economic plan to Congress this summer, White House officials say they are approaching health care with a very different strategy. The hubris that the President knows best will be replaced with a demeanor of humility in which Mr. Clinton will invite others to contribute their own ideas. Instead of letting its opponents frame the issues, the Administration, even before the President delivers the plan to Congress, is already combating their claims with advertisements and public appearances.
 
Teaching as Well as Selling
 And the initially partisan approach to the President's economic plan is being eschewed for an avowedly bipartisan, come-one-come-all strategy for winning passage on Capitol Hill.
At its broadest level, Administration officials say, their health care strategy will aim at doing two things at once: educating the public about the issues, while trying to sell the Clinton solution over all others.
"This is an issue that is a kitchen table issue," said Mandy Grunwald, an Administration political strategist. "People really care about it. As a result, the amount of information that people want is far more than on any other policy issue, like the deficit. That is why the biggest task will be public education on simply what is in the plan."
A unique aspect of health care education, Ms. Grunwald said, is that the wealthier a person is, the less he or she tends to know about the vagaries of health care. Focus groups run by the Administration consistently reveal that it is the working classes and unemployed who have the most awareness of the limits, pitfalls and intricacies of the current health care system.
 
Already Battling on Television
 "It gives us a more difficult selling job with elites, but a wonderful basis of communication with the general public," Ms. Grunwald said.
For a skeptical middle class, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, which includes many people who fear that the Clinton plan means less health care for more money, rather than more health care for less money, the message will be: "You are going to still have a choice. You are going to get a plan at least like the plan you have now, or better, and for most people it will cost less."
Both that middle-class message and the aggressiveness of the Administration in trying to shape the debate were apparent on Saturday, when the Democratic National Committee began running an advertisement in response to one begun last week by the Health Insurance Industry of America. That ad, picturing a couple at the kitchen table criticizing the President's proposals, argued that the plan would limit consumers' choice of doctors and other health care providers.
The Democratic Party commercial says: "The insurance companies may not like it -- but the President didn't design it for them -- he designed it for you." It goes on to say that "after years of denying people coverage and jacking up prices," the insurance industry is now scrambling to protect the status quo.
 
Batter Up: Hillary Clinton
 The sales campaign begins in earnest immediately after the President unveils his plan on Wednesday before a joint session of Congress. Mr. Clinton, his wife, Hillary, Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, most of the Cabinet, many members of the President's health care task force and a host of industry experts supporting the Administration will hit the road with everything from town hall meetings to bus trips to sell the plan while educating people about its contents.
Mrs. Clinton, in particular, will be featured by the Administration, because it is felt that she has very high credibility in general and because women tend to make most of the health care decisions for their families.
The other day James Carville, a Clinton strategist, was speaking to a convention in San Francisco when a questioner rose and asked him whether the Administration's health care numbers were really credible. He answered that he had asked Mrs. Clinton the exact same question last week, and she assured him that they were.
"And when Mrs. Clinton tells me its Easter, I start dying eggs," Mr. Carville said.
 
Plain Folks, Not Experts
 With the Clintons and Gores, the Administration strategy is to frame their public appearances in settings where they can both educate and sell, but always using "real people," not experts, to make their point.
"People are hungry for change, but scared when they get right up to it," said Kevin Anderson, spokesman for the Administration's health care operation. "It is like when your child begs you to take him swimming, but when he gets right up to the pool's edge he freezes. So part of the strategy is just patience. What we are about here is having a long conversation with the American people that will go on for many months as this works through Congress."
With Congress, the strategy is to build on the bipartisan base for health care reform that is already there.
While there are still myriad differences between the Administration's health care plan and the Republican version offered Wednesday by Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the two agree on the bedrock points, said Ms. Grunwald: that the final destination should be universal coverage with a comprehensive benefits plan, and that in the debate over who should pay -- a single government payer or the private sector -- the answer has to be some kind of mix.
 
'Not All or Nothing'
 Mr. Stephanopoulos said: "The President is going to approach the debate with humility. His demeanor will be: 'I have a plan. I think it is a good plan. I think it meets the basic needs. But I want everyone involved. It is not all or nothing. I will take good ideas, as long as my basic principles are met.' "
These are the basic principles that the President, his wife and the Administration have begun to enunciate and will hammer home in the next year:
*Security -- that the plan has to make both the uninsured and the insured feel more secure, not less.
*Simplicity -- that the plan has to produce a simpler health care system that people can understand and use, not added complexity (even though that is exactly what skeptics have noted about the President's plan).
*Choice -- that consumers be given a choice each year of different plans.
*Savings -- that any plan must slow the rate of growth in health care costs, now $900 billion a year.
*Quality -- that if the public does not believe the plan will result in better quality care it will never pass.
*Responsibility -- that patients, hospitals, doctors, insurers, small businesses and large, will each have to contribute a fair share.
"Within those broad principles I think you will find the President being very flexible," said Ms. Grunwald. "The only line in the sand is that when this is over every American should have a health care security card and comprehensive benefits."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Lesson in Politics: Role of Credibility

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"THERE are two things that are important in politics," Senator Mark A. Hanna of Ohio once said. "The first is money, and I can't remember what the second one is."
Nor, perhaps, could New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman when, to pay for a frantic television attack on an opponent a year ago, her campaign borrowed $450,000 from a bank whose sister securities company was aggressively lobbying to get more business from the Comptroller's office. 
 "Gross negligence" was how the city's Department of Investigation characterized Ms. Holtzman's "failure to inquire whether Fleet Bank or companies related to it were doing or seeking business with her office."
The investigation evokes twin tenets of government: personality can affect a public figure's performance, and a cover-up can be even more damaging than an original indiscretion (although voters only find out about cover-ups that failed).
Ms. Holtzman has gamely assembled a lawyerly defense that might well wash in court. Technically, including fees and annualizing the interest rate, the loan was not preferential and therefore was not subject to the city's conflict-of-interest rules.
Skeptical investigators found no hard evidence that she had been told specifically that Fleet was seeking to become a co-manager of borrowings. Straining credulity, though, Ms. Holtzman said she had not read a news article that mentioned Fleet's application and also quoted her goal of involving more companies owned by minority groups and women. "Reading what I have already said," she testified, "is not particularly interesting to me."
Nor have investigators proved that she personally directed her staff to choose Fleet Securities as one of 23 co-managers. In addition, there were valid reasons for including Fleet: it had a good record for selling city bonds and participated in comptroller's office loan programs for small business and affordable housing.
But the allegations, and how Ms. Holtzman has handled them, probably cost her last Tuesday's Democratic primary. And the unresolved charges may all but end her promising political career as she faces a runoff against Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi a week from tomorrow in the comptroller race.
That Ms. Holtzman has often been regarded as rigid and self-righteous made some critics all the more eager to gloat once her moral compass appeared to have wavered momentarily and then was recalibrated by self-justification and an unshakeable faith in her own innocence.
She never got along by going along. In Congress, she was one of only 10 members who voted against reinstating Robert E. Lee's United States citizenship. For years, she refused to concede to Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican who defeated her in the 1980 Senate race.
Arguably, her personality has cut two ways. She single-mindedly pursued objectives regardless of personal cost. Some of her goals may have been harder to realize because the collegiality that government often demands has not been her strongest suit. (Still, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal mayoral candidate and former Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, praises Ms. Holtzman's cooperation in joint investigations when she was Brooklyn District Attorney.)
But right makes might, as in maybe. And while nice guys or gals don't always finish last, being not nice is no guarantee of finishing first. Two women who worked for Fleet -- an officer who was asked to approve the loan to Ms. Holtzman and another who was solicited for a campaign contribution -- balked because they opposed her politically.
Ms. Holtzman did not seem very nice in the Senate primary last year when she vigorously pursued legitimate questions, coupled with innuendo, about the business relationships of Geraldine A. Ferraro and her husband in Little Italy in Manhattan, where the family owns and manages property. The questions cost both candidates the nomination. But full and frank responses by Ms. Ferraro might have spared her; indignance and denial did not work.
For Ms. Holtzman, too, the Fleet case could have been a cathartic. She could have said something like: "I desperately needed money because our system of campaign financing stinks; banks have always given politicians preferential treatment; I should have checked whether Fleet was seeking city business; I made a mistake; I'm sorry; but the bottom line is there is no evidence that I had any role in the selection of Fleet as a co-manager or that the officials in my office who chose Fleet knew that the bank had loaned me money or contributed to my campaign." She may have said this in bits and pieces but never seemed to completely come clean.
In "The Moral Sense" (Free Press), James Q. Wilson writes: "For people to be impressed by your honesty, you must either be honest all of the time (in which case you will have to stop taking advantage of the many opportunites for cheating, and so you might as well stop being greedy altogether), or you will have to be honest in some very conspicuous, highly dramatic fashion, such as telling the truth even when it costs a lot of money to do so."
Preaching is easier than practicing. "The best answer to a smear," Richard M. Nixon said in his Checkers speech, "is to tell the truth."
Truth is elusive. Credibility is even harder to come by. But it may constitute that second important aspect of politics, which Mark Hanna couldn't remember and Ms. Holtzman may have forgot.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Retrenching In Law Firms

 BODY:
Almost half of the nation's 250 largest law firms cut their number of lawyers this year, according to a survey published today in The National Law Journal.
The firms that shrank from 1992 lost an average of three lawyers, the weekly trade magazine reported. 
 The decline in lawyers was greater in the Southwest and West than in the Northeast and Southeast, said Doreen Weisenhaus, the journal's editor in chief.
"It seems to mirror a lot of what happened in the economy this year," she said.
Ms. Weisenhaus said the firms that had grown had generally concentrated on the practices they knew best. Among the areas of specialty showing the greatest gains were regulatory practices based in Washington and corporate and financial practices based in New York.
 
Top Three Keep Rankings
 The three largest firms kept their rankings in 1993: Baker & McKenzie of Chicago (with 1,662 lawyers, up 58 from last year); Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue of Cleveland (1,066, down 117), and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom of New York (1,021, up 45).
Moving from 10th place to a tie for 4th was Weil, Gotshal & Manges of New York, which the magazine called "the real success story among the top 10 firms." Weil, Gotshal has one of the largest bankruptcy practices, a category that has recently flourished.
The going rate for starting salaries at leading firms in New York was $83,000, for the fourth straight year. New law graduates hired by the top firms received $60,000 in Atlanta and $70,000 in Los Angeles and Chicago.
