HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
How an Opera, Guaranteed to Fail, Can Be Seen as a Moral Triumph

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
The New York City Opera's production of Michael Tippett's "Midsummer Marriage" was not a success, but its very existence is a moral triumph of sorts. In the midst of a 50th-anniversary season more apprehensive than celebratory, Christopher Keene, the company's general director, has made room for the new, the neglected, the unusual and the troublesome. Mr. Keene has only occasionally had the resources, concrete and human, to do these operas well. He also knows they are bad for business.
So in one way or another, the failure of "The Midsummer Marriage" was built in from the start: either failure in terms of operatic quality or failure in terms of audience response, and in this case both. Admirable goals and self-defeat have been frequent partners during the City Opera's history. To use the old expression, the company can't win for losing, and to reverse the thought, losses like this one can be made to seem like victories. 
 If many of its successes have been ambiguous, one is clearly not and that is the house's ability to nurture young American singers and send the truly gifted among them off to larger international careers. One of its major problems is straightforward too: the New York State Theater, which is unsuited for opera and even less so for most of the American musicals the house puts on. The public space is too big to permit intimacy. Stage, wings and backstage are too small, stifling opera's need to breathe with appropriate grandeur.
High in this company's unwritten charter is the obligation to provide modest productions of old favorites. Five of this season's 14 operas are by Puccini; "Carmen," "The Mikado," "The Student Prince" and "Le Nozze di Figaro" surround them. Professional singers gain experience. Newcomers to opera receive the proper introductions. Aficionados on low budgets look and listen affordably. Yet barely 100 yards away are the same operas sumptuously produced by the Metropolitan Opera. Comparisons that ought not to be made inevitably are. As a result, intentionally modest productions are criticized for not being more than they were meant to be.
Daily grind, underrehearsed second casts and routine repertory produce sleepy performances, and they in turn can send potential converts to opera fleeing from the hall. But Mr. Keene has wisely addressed the "old chestnut" syndrome by re-outfitting popular favorites with brighter productions. In the case of the original-version "Madama Butterfly," in which Puccini's ugly Americans are restored to their original nastiness, the company has created something fascinating out of something shopworn.
A less solvable problem at the City Opera is the intransigent mediocrity of its orchestra, which can be induced by the right conductor to play familiar music fairly well, but which, when faced with Mr. Tippett's uneven metric movement, is either unable to play together or does not care to. The house's administration has quietly addressed this anomaly for years but is largely frustrated by a militant musicians' union that fights dismissals fiercely. Thus the No. 2 opera company in what may be the cultural capital of the world is automatically diminished no matter how good the singer or how effective the production.
Most Broadway shows are lost in this cave of a theater. Players onstage are remote, and the antidote, swollen electronic amplification, turns solutions into new problems.
Now look at the rest of this season: the brave world of Hugo Weisgall's "Esther," "Marilyn," by Ezra Laderman, and Lukas Foss's "Griffelkin," all world premieres of American works. There have been Busoni's "Doktor Faustus" and Schoenberg's "Moses und Aron" in the recent past and this year "The Midsummer Marriage," a piece not many of us have seen before.
"The Midsummer Marriage" is not an important opera, but it is sometimes a beautiful one. Its marriage of orchestral movement to stage movement and its delicate, economical instrumental sound date from an earlier phase in Mr. Tippett's career and remain blessedly distant from his heroic if clumsy struggles with huge musical forces and cosmic moral schemes.
"The Midsummer Marriage" is an opera of ideas -- or better, of spiritual impulses. Not much happens. So its Manichaean debate between light and dark can hold our attention only with vivid, precise orchestra playing and with brilliant stage pictures. The libretto straddles the border between high-minded whimsy and silliness. Only first-class execution can rescue it from the latter.
A Tuesday performance -- five days after the first -- was, not surprisingly, ill attended. Fear of (or boredom with) the new may have discouraged general audiences, and there was at least one devastating review of opening night's performance. The City Opera depends perhaps more heavily on reviews than the Met or the New York Philharmonic across the plaza.
To sit amid the empty seats was to move from sympathy to gratitude to sadness and finally exasperation. Francesca Zambello's frugal production could not summon the resources to keep this fragile piece aloft. Despite Act II's interesting dance sequence, sensory deprivation -- a hardscrabble dullness -- discouraged Mr. Tippett's attempts at magic. The orchestra's playing in Act I was crude to the point of rebelliousness. Mr. Keene, a better visionary than he is a conductor, seemed scarcely in control. One was torn. Was it better to see and hear this opera in failed circumstances or sit at home and imagine what it might be?
Having settled that question, listeners might move on to ask themselves this: Who else in this great musical headquarters of the world is going to put on "Die Soldaten" or "The Midsummer Marriage"? The tiny Manhattan companies operating hand-to-mouth out of of high school auditoriums might have attempted the latter 10 years ago, but these frail organisms dwindle with every year. Who else in New York is going to give a middle-income opera public the basic repertory?
The faults in these enterprises must be seen clearly and acknowledged. But we might also look beyond the intractable structural problems and the lapses in quality; mix understanding with esthetic rectitude. The New York City Opera stands between us and a large blank space in New York's musical life. It is what we have and we might learn to cherish its failures as much as its successes.

HEADLINE: The Art of the Outdoors: The French Celebrate A Garden Renaissance

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHAUMONT-SUR-LOIRE, France

 BODY:
On deftly sculptured grounds overlooking the Chateau de Chaumont and the Loire Valley, 27 landscape architects from around the world have created modest-sized gardens that reveal the variety and imagination -- and outright artistry -- of garden design today.
Open to the public until Oct. 15, the second annual International Garden Festival here is more than a feast for flower-lovers, as one might gather from the film makers, ceramists, architects and painters among its designers. It is a bold statement about the transformation of landscape architects from humble craftsmen into artists, creators of a new kind of installation art who in some cases enjoy cult followings. It is the latest manifestation of a public enthusiasm for gardening that has spread from Paris to this region in central France and will in November give birth to an ambitious new gardening conservatory on the grounds of the chateau farm. 
 Not least, it is testimony to a dramatic increase in support for gardening and historical garden restoration by the French Ministry of Culture in the Socialist era, an interest that has been redirected slightly by the present recession, but which the current Gaullist Government shows little signs of abating.
 
Responses to Problems
 The range of gardens on view is dazzling. Seven of the gardens are holdovers from last year, including a sunken grotto by Emilio Ambasz; a Moorish temple in wood perched above a floral field by Fernando Caruncho, a Spaniard, and a remarkable tunnel of curved bamboo strips by Hiroshi Teshigahara, better known as the director of Japanese films including "Woman in the Dunes" and "Rikyu."
This year's festival theme, which has generated 20 new gardens, is "The Imagination in Crisis," encouraging landscape architects to express their reactions to the world's economic, social and political problems. Each gardener has a limited space (about 2,000 square feet) and budget (about $15,000) and is obviously constrained by the terrain and climate of central France, but otherwise has complete freedom.
Mark Rudkin, a Paris-based American painter who last year designed the gardens at the Palais Royal in Paris, contributed a garden of humble, inexpensive flowers. Two designers interwove flowers with symbols of industrial and environmental decay: Stephan Tischer of Germany evoked the rusting collapse of industries in the eastern part of that country, complete with factory parts and a heap of coal, while Pierre Culot of Belgium created a collapsing ceramic wall in a stagnant pond.
For Peter Walker of the United States, the response was a series of solar panels powering pumps that sustain a field of sunflowers. In a field of smelly white tobacco flowers, the Atelier Phusis of France placed a telescope trained on architectural mediocrity in the distance. Shodo Suzuki's "Archipelago," a rock garden with shiny marble surfaces and surrounding floral groupings, was like a hidden refuge from crisis.
 
Artists, Not Adjuncts
 The 1992 festival, only two months long, attracted 60,000 visitors, and this summer's installment, which opened on July 1, is expected to lure more than 100,000. For Mr. Rudkin, who has lived mostly in France for nearly 40 years, the last decade has seen a sharp increase of French interest in gardening. "People are far more knowledgeable and sophisticated," he said in an interview at his Paris home. "They travel to see gardens now, to England and Italy, which they didn't used to do."
As an art form, gardening existed in ancient China, Egypt and Rome and has flourished in Japan over the last millennium. There have been great Western gardens since the Renaissance. Still, Mr. Rudkin added, only recently have more than a few Western landscape architects (those who have degrees) and gardeners (those who don't, like Mr. Rudkin) felt the kind of freedom that would allow them to think of themselves as artists in the modern sense.
"Most of them feel they are adjuncts to architects," he said. "They would like to think of themselves as independent artists. Of all the landscape architects that are cranked out every year, most end up working for architectural firms or in government offices in the provinces, doing plants for new buildings, which by its very nature is limited. It's rare that somebody comes along and says, 'Make me a garden.' "
That is just what Jean-Paul Pigeat has done at his Chaumont festival, and what the French Ministry of Culture and its patrimony division have encouraged in recent years. The French state has commissioned a host of highly visible gardening projects, including Mr. Rudkin's in the Palais Royal or the forthcoming redesign of the Tuileries, scheduled for completion in 1996.
 
Suddenly, There's Money
 The state budget for gardens has doubled since 1988, when Jack Lang returned to power as the Minister of Culture after a two-year conservative interregnum. The total for this year is nearly $20 million. Three-fifths of that has gone to state-owned gardens and the rest to local and regional authorities, and even to private citizens and corporations. This influx has also led to the establishment of highly successful programs, particularly the Garden Month every June, intended to encourage the French public to visit the country's many gardens.
Local and regional officials, caught up in the gardening enthusiasm, have contributed additional funds. Mr. Pigeat is a former administrator at the Pompidou Center in Paris and garden consultant in the Lang Ministry of Culture. It is no accident that Mr. Lang is the Mayor of Blois, the nearest large city to Chaumont. The prevailing political winds in the Centre region -- where Blois, Chaumont, Orleans and Tours are situated -- are conservative, not socialist. Yet Mr. Pigeat's conservatory and festival draw most of their support from regional, not national sources.
Mr. Lang's successor at the Ministry of Culture, Jacques Toubon, seems supportive of gardening policies, although general belt-tightening by the Gaullist Government has led to some cutbacks. For instance, Mr. Rudkin is not being asked to maintain his Palais Royal garden, at least on a regular and formal basis.
 
Restoration as a Priority
 Maryvonne de Saint Pulgent, who took over the Patrimony department within the ministry two months ago and hence is the responsible state official for gardens, affirmed Mr. Toubon's continued interest in the field. She even said in an interview that contrary to the recessionary trend, her own department's budget will rise slightly for 1994.
Mrs. de Saint Pulgent created something of a scandal in 1989 when, writing in the French magazine Le Point, she quoted Mr. Lang as saying that personally, he detested gardens. She now attributes the rise of interest and budgetary outlay under Mr. Lang not to him, but to the "spirit of the times" -- the public's own waxing interest in gardens -- and to the personal interest of Mr. Lang's boss, President Francois Mitterrand.
Her own interests seem more directed toward restoration than the sort of flamboyant expansions of gardening's practice and image that typified the Lang era. She did stress that garden restoration was a more fluid, flexible field than the restoration of historical monuments: "There is a less clear distinction with gardens between restoration and creation," she said. But she seemed unenthusiastic about Mr. Pigeat's friskier ideas.
 
The Next Celebrities?
 Mr. Pigeat's festival has occasioned some grumbling from more traditional landscape architects, who denounce what they see as its gimmickry. He has also had some trouble convincing large landscape-architecture firms that freeing up promising innovators on their staffs to build something as frivolous and impermanent as a summerlong garden installation was worth the firms' time and money.
At the same time, he seemed apprehensive about the very forces he has helped unleash. Landscape architects are now feeling their artistic oats. From forelock-tugging servants, akin to court composers of the 18th century, they are becoming socially lionized, media-celebrated stars. "If landscape architects become like our chefs have become, it will only harm their development," Mr. Pigeat worried.
Still, he seems determined to press forward, stretching the very idea of gardening in the way he has illustrated in his recent book, "Contemporary Parks and Gardens." New forms, he said, involve not only artistic expression but also cosmopolitan interchange among the world's gardening traditions and a new-found environmental and social sensitivity. From Sept. 27 to 29, there will be a weekend seminar at Chaumont to discuss the "Imagination in Crisis" theme. Next summer, there will be a competition to encourage young gardeners, although already this year's festival is full of work by students and even children.
Cosmopolitanism can be seen in the pervasive influence of Japanese gardening -- one of the most piquant examples being a garden by an Indian, Savita Upalekar, who was trained in Japan -- and in a cross-blending of European national styles. Mr. Rudkin said the influence of English flower gardens is particularly strong in France, which is certainly evident in his own Palais Royal design. Mr. Pigeat stressed the innovations of Americans and their "freedom from tradition."
For Mr. Rudkin, what will distinguish Mr. Pigeat's new conservatory will be its willingness to combine the formal abstraction typical of the French with a new-found enthusiasm for the practicalities of the art.
"Things have become too abstract," he said. "You have to actually go out and work in the dirt."

HEADLINE: Health Care Relief for Consumers

 BODY:
President Clinton's health care proposal, leaked to the press 10 days ago, remains confusing and worrisome. Consumers aren't sure how they will buy insurance or choose their doctors. Mr. Clinton will begin to provide answers when he addresses Congress on Wednesday night.
His answers won't please everyone. Nor will they be the last word. Congress intends to make lots of changes. Some political controversies have already surfaced. 
 Who's covered? The Clinton plan would require everyone to buy -- with the help of employers and the Federal Government -- a generous package of benefits covering doctor and hospital bills, preventive care and prescription drugs. It would limit a family's out-of-pocket costs to about $3,000 a year.
Universal coverage makes the Clinton proposal as startling as the advent of Social Security in the 1930's or the War on Poverty in the 60's. Poor children would be treated by family doctors, not physicians in hospital emergency rooms. Families would not go bankrupt paying medical bills. Yet the proposal is expensive, leading some in Congress to propose trimming the benefits.
That would be a blunder. Mr. Clinton's policy is a declaration of values that shouldn't be surrendered. Besides, a less generous package could leave many Americans worse off under reform -- sending Mr. Clinton's bill to a quick burial.
Who pays? Under the plan, employers would be required to pay about 80 percent of the average policy offered to workers; workers would pay the balance. Workers who chose more expensive plans would absorb all of the extra cost. Federal subsidies would be provided to help low-income workers, the self-employed and unemployed buy insurance.
The employer mandate has set off a political outcry. Small employers who are not now providing insurance would face paying thousands of dollars for each employee. The fear is that they will lay off workers or go out of business.
The threat is real, but exaggerated. Mr. Clinton would phase in the mandate, providing time for employers to lower wages to offset higher medical premiums. He would cap how much businesses would have to pay for health insurance and subsidize small companies with low-paid workers.
Though mandates pose risks, there's no credible alternative. A bipartisan group in the House would scrap the mandate and require people to buy insurance, with subsidies for the poor and near poor. But the idea is sure to ignite fierce opposition because it would require middle-class families to spend thousands to buy a policy they used to get from their employers. Besides, the proposal is probably too complicated to administer.
What about choice? Choice is becoming the fighting word of the President's opponents. Technically, Mr. Clinton's plan preserves choice. People would choose an insurance policy from among those made available by a regional purchasing cooperative. They could sign up with health maintenance organizations, which restrict enrollees to a fixed panel of doctors. Or they could choose fee-for-service coverage, which provides a wide choice of doctors but at considerably higher cost. There would also be hybrid plans that charge one price for using staff doctors and a higher price for using outside specialists.
Would families be able keep their doctors? Yes and no. If, as expected, fee-for-service care becomes increasingly expensive, families will flock to H.M.O.'s and many doctors will be forced to follow. Families could keep a family physician by choosing the right H.M.O. But complete freedom to choose specialists would disappear.
The Clinton plan would steer consumers toward plans that control costs. It would also open plans to everyone, without discrimination. This means that young, healthy individuals -- who used to pay the lowest rates -- would have to pay more; but the poor, the ill and workers in small businesses would gain access to the same low-cost plans that have been available only to employees at larger companies. And every plan would be required to collect and report data on treatment practices and medical outcomes -- the key to improving quality.
There are parts of the Clinton proposal -- having to do with tax policy and price controls -- that need to be changed. On the important consumer issues, however, the burden is on his critics to come up with better solutions. So far they haven't.

HEADLINE: 8 Are on Ballot Tomorrow in Scramble to Be Boston's Next Mayor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
This was not supposed to be an election year, but the departure of Mayor Raymond L. Flynn to become Ambassador to the Vatican has left the race to succeed him wide open.
Eight candidates, including a former nun, a sheriff and a talk-show host, are on the ballot for the nonpartisan preliminary election on Tuesday. The top two finalists will face each other in November for a four-year term. 
 Boston has had only four mayors, all Democrats, since 1947. With only two candidates of Irish descent, James T. Brett and Francis M. Roache, running this time, Boston could soon have its first non-Irish mayor in more than 60 years.
 
A Field of Newcomers
 Mr. Flynn held sway here for 10 years, swamping the opposition in the 1991 election to win 75 percent of the vote. But he has not endorsed any hopeful from his posting in Rome, and his political organization has split among several candidates.
And in a city where incumbents have had a virtual lock on the job, none of the candidates have run for mayor before.
With all eight candidates, seven of them Democrats, agreeing that the next mayor of Boston must reduce crime, improve public education and stimulate the economy, they had little to fight over during the summer. But as the Red Sox's hopes for a pennant cool, the mayor's race is beginning to heat up.
 
Too Close to Call
 Polls say the race is too close to call, but they divide the field into four front-runners and four long shots. These are the top candidates:
*Thomas M. Menino, who is running on his record as Acting Mayor -- all 69 days of it. As president of the City Council, he automatically became Mayor when Mr. Flynn stepped down in July. During his brief tenure he spent $500,000 of the city's emergency fund to create summer jobs for teen-agers, and he voted against a teachers contract that he said was too expensive. He is one of the two candidates endorsed by The Boston Globe.
*Rosaria Salerno, a City Council member since 1987 who was once a Benedictine nun. She emphasizes crime prevention and education. "I believe in Boston we have two ways of doing business in politics," she says. "The political way or the right way."
*Mr. Brett, a state representative who has an uncanny resemblance to the actor Jack Nicholson and is trying to capitalize on his experience without appearing to be an insider. If the election could be won by lawn signs, he would be a shoo-in. His blue posters can be seen across town from his native Dorchester to Beacon Hill.
*Robert C. Rufo, the sheriff, who is running a law-and-order campaign that hopes to capitalize on voters' oft-mentioned concerns about crime. He says Boston is better at tracking down drivers who have outstanding parking tickets than it is at capturing criminals with outstanding warrants, and he vows to change that as mayor. He was endorsed by The Globe and The Boston Herald.
 
Hope for Long Shots
 The polls say that roughly a fifth of the voters have not yet made up their minds. This statistic keeps this second tier of candidates in the race:
*Christopher Lydon, a former New York Times reporter who is now a public-television talk-show host in Boston. One of his election promises is to go to a public school every day. "You can mark me absent if I'm not there," he said. He also says he wants to bring in the National Guard to rid the city of guns.
*Bruce C. Bolling, the only black candidate, who lost an election for an at-large City Council seat two years ago but was appointed to the post when another Council member died. His campaign calls for creating jobs to reduce crime. But black groups in a town that is 25 percent black have been split about his candidacy.
*Mr. Roache, who likes to remind voters that he reduced the crime rate as Police Commissioner. His opponents like to remind them that a city report called him a poor manager who should not be reappointed.
*Diane Moriarty, a Republican lawyer with no experience in government, who is perhaps the longest shot in this most Democratic of cities.
Interest in the race has only recently begun to perk up. Perhaps it got a little too heated last week at the second televised debate, when the discussion degenerated into a shouting match.
"Do we have a moderator here or what?" Mr. Bolling shouted above the yells of his rivals.
 
Dukakis Turns Tables
 The moderator, Kirby Perkins, could not even quiet the candidates when the time came to sign off. "Ladies and gentleman -- Mr. Brett, please," he implored. "As you can tell, it has been a very spirited discussion here today between the mayoral candidates. I would like to tell you that we can end on a quiet, civil note, but clearly they are not inclined to do that."
As the lights dimmed in the studio and the sound faded, Mr. Bolling got in the last two words: "Oh, baloney."
The next debate was held at Mr. Lydon's old station, WGBH, and was moderated by Michael S. Dukakis. The former Governor and 1988 Democratic Presidential nominee clearly relished his role grilling the former interviewer. When Mr. Lydon got off track in his response to a question about residency requirements, Mr. Dukakis pressed him: "I want an answer to the question."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 23, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the Boston mayoral election misstated the number of Irish-Americans among the eight candidates in the race. There are four; Christopher Lydon and Diane Moriarty are Irish-Americans, as are James T. Brett and Francis M. Roache.

HEADLINE: U.S. TO CONTRIBUTE $250 MILLION IN AID FOR PALESTINIANS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced yesterday that the United States would provide $250 million over two years to help carry out the Israeli-Palestinian accord and called for an early international conference to more than match the American pledge.
The $250 million is only a preliminary estimate based on hasty conversations with Congress over the weekend, other senior Administration officials said. The United States is expected to present a more comprehensive five-year aid package at the conference, which is tentatively scheduled for Oct. 1 in Washington, they added. 
 About 60 percent of the aid will be in grants for public projects in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and the rest in loans and loan guarantees to spur private investment.
 
World Bank Assesses Need
 A World Bank study estimates that the Palestinians will need a minimum of $300 million a year over the next decade for public projects, a figure that also reflects how much money a nascent Palestinian infrastructure can absorb. The bank has not estimated how much money will be needed or available for private investment.
The Palestine Liberation Organization, by contrast, has drawn up a far more ambitious plan that calls for an immediate infusion of $2.5 billion in aid and $11.6 billion by the year 2000.
The Administration is hoping to raise $2 billion at the international conference for the next five years, including the American contribution,
In a speech at Columbia University yesterday in which he unveiled the Administration's strategy for the Middle East, Mr. Christopher emphasized the importance of providing money for Palestinian projects as soon as possible, both to maintain the momentum of the diplomatic breakthrough last week and to insure that the Palestinian experiment with self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho succeeds.
 
Who Will Be Invited
 With Russia as co-sponsor and the World Bank handling much of the coordination and aid, Mr. Christopher said, the United States will invite foreign and finance ministers representing Europe, Japan, Canada and the wealthy Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, Israeli and Palestinian officials, and others, whom he did not name.
"The international community must move immediately to see that the agreement produces tangible improvements in the security and daily lives of Palestinians and Israelis," Mr. Christopher said in his address, which was jointly sponsored by the School of International and Public Affairs and the Council on Foreign Relations. "If peace is to be achieved, the agreement must be translated into results quickly and vividly."
In particular, Mr. Christopher said, money must be available immediately to curb unemployment "that robs families of hope and fuels extremism," build housing and roads and help develop the groundwork for public administration, tax collection and social services.
 
'Needs Can Be Met'
 Other officials said the money would also pay for technical help for holding elections, strengthening credit institutions, aiding farmers, organizing food imports and making it easy for foreign investment.
"Given the number and commitment of our international partners, we are confident these needs can be met," Mr. Christopher said. "And we will stimulate these supporters by our own example. Working with the Congress, we expect to assemble an initial two-year package worth $250 million."
Senior Administration officials said they hoped that the world community could deliver at least $100 million to $200 million for "showcase" projects in the next two to three months. At the same time, they cautioned that the Palestinians must develop the administrative structures to receive and dispense the aid.
President Clinton will appoint a special coordinator to manage Palestinian aid and a task force of Jewish- and Arab-Americans to help the Administration develop joint projects and private investment, Mr. Christopher said.
But Mr. Christopher did not say and other officials could not explain why the United States was not being host to a more ambitious global conference that would include economically healthy countries with the ability to contribute aid, like Brunei, Singapore and Korea, as well as poorer countries that over the decades have embraced the Palestinian cause and could offer symbolically important contributions.
 
$150 Million in Grants
 The United Nations held a largely symbolic global conference of donors in 1986 to raise money to revive devastated African economies, although none of the donor nations made specific commitments on aid and debt relief.
About $150 million of the $250 million in American aid in the first two years will be in outright grants; the remainder will be in loans, loan guarantees and political risk insurance from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government agency, to help American businesses invest in Gaza and Jericho.
By contrast, the United States gives Israel $3 billion and Egypt $2.1 billion a year in aid -- more than one-third of the entire American foreign aid budget. Much of this aid is military.
In lobbying for an ambitious aid package for Russia in recent months, the Administration was faced with a growing chorus of lawmakers who suggested that Israel and Egypt might have to sacrifice some of their aid, which has remained fairly constant since the 1979 peace treaty between them.
But both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher have vowed to maintain aid to Israel and Egypt at the current levels, and since last week's Israeli-Palestinian agreement, the sentiment on Capitol Hill is to pour more, rather than less, money into the region.

HEADLINE: ASBESTOS IN THE SCHOOLS;
Disorder on Day 1 in New York Schools

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
Most of New York City's public schools reopened smoothly yesterday amid a general sense of relief that the asbestos delay was over, but for thousands of students still locked out of class and for their beleaguered parents, the day brought deep confusion, disappointment and frustration.
More than 100 school buildings remained closed, representing 10 percent of the system, more than double what officials had expected. Ninety others were on reduced or rearranged schedules because so many rooms had to be sealed until asbestos inspections or cleanups could be completed.
 
Telephone Service Affected
 Two school districts -- District 12, in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, and District 19, in the East New York section of Brooklyn -- decided not to open any of their schools despite entreaties from central headquarters. But District 12 announced last evening that only 3 of its 28 schools would remain closed today. District 19 said that 2 of its 27 schools would not open. 
 Of the city's one million schoolchildren, an estimated 60,000 were either out of school or in different schools -- a number that alone would form a respectable city school district, about the same size as San Francisco's. The sheer magnitude of disruptions in the nation's largest school system was such that telephone service was erratic into the 718 area code yesterday as thousands of parents called the school board's asbestos information line.
The opening was the most tumultuous since the consolidation of schools in 1898, officials acknowledged. Not only was the 11-day delay the longest in 25 years, since the bitter teacher's strike in 1968, never before have so many schools been partly or fully closed.
 
Some Chaos
 The worst mayhem that some had imagined never happened as parents answered the challenge of the new Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, and pitched in everywhere -- creating command posts in newly painted cafeterias for their small armies of tots and establishing telephone relays to distribute the latest information. "It exceeded what I believed we as a community could do," Mr. Cortines said.
He emphasized that the degree of normality was a relief. "I think that in more than 90 percent of the schools it was not chaotic," he said. "When there was chaos, it was real chaos."
There was one violent incident, but school officials said it bore no relation to the asbestos crisis. An 18-year-old student was stabbed in the neck in a stairwell at Seward Park High School, and was in critical condition. A 17-year-old student surrendered and was charged with murder.
Many thousands of students -- from kindergarten children to autistic teen-agers -- arrived at school yesterday to find their school buildings closed. Some were bused to other schools, while others were sent to libraries, offices, auditoriums, churches and social clubs. In one Bronx school, 125 kindergarten children were herded into rooms that were bare but for a piece of carpeting; the last-minute disruptions delayed a furniture delivery.
The board has prepared teaching materials and a videotape about asbestos for presentation to students and teachers in school classrooms.
At Junior High School 168 in Queens, dozens of teachers and students showed up only to learn the school would not open after all. Instead, they are to crowd into nearby Intermediate School 237 today.
Jane Evans, a social-studies teacher at J.H.S. 168 , said: "They're pretending that this is going to be education, but it's not. This is baby-sitting."
Across the city, children with new shoes and backpacks were accompanied by parents or grandparents, aunts or uncles, arriving at school in the sunshine of a crisp autumn morning. In the schools that were opened, students caught up with friends, checked their class schedules and found their lockers. Many seemed grateful to be in school.
"I wanted to come back so badly," said Danelle St. Agathe, an 11-year-old, who returned yesterday to classes at Public School 234 in TriBeCa. "At home you really have nothing to do, but at school there are things to keep you busy."
 
'We've Been Duped'
 As a general sense of relief spread through most of the city, the scenes of confusion were widespread and deep. One of the most chaotic was at P.S. 27 in Brooklyn's Red Hook section, which school officials ordered closed on Sunday. The school's students were bused to P.S. 15, where they learned they would be sitting in an auditorium, doing no work.
"I think we've been duped," said Beatrice Byrd, a teacher at P.S. 27 when she heard of the plan. "We're educators, but we're standing here feeling ignorant."
Rosemarie Negron, whose 9-year-old daughter Shalimar was to enter the fifth grade at P.S. 27, said the worst part was the uncertainty.
"We're not sure yet when or where they'll start classes, how they'll get there, or even when the repair work is going to begin," Ms. Negron said. "We have no idea at all. Its very frustrating."
The asbestos crisis emerged Aug. 6, when investigators announced that previous inspections of all the city's schools were unreliable.
Asbestos particles can cause cancer when inhaled in high concentrations over decades, but some health experts have questioned the severity of the hazard posed by asbestos in buildings. Nonetheless, Federal laws require strict inventories and management of asbestos in schools, and Mayor David N. Dinkins ordered every school rechecked before the opening day of school. The enormousness of the task made that impossible.
Some 1,015,500 students enrolled to attend the public schools this year, about 20,000 more than last year. It was the first opening day in 16 years that more than one million students were registered, said Frank Sobrino, a board of education spokesman.
There were no estimates of how many attended classes yesterday, an important issue since attendance is used to calculate state aid, which comprises $2.9 billion of the city's $7.9 billion school budget this year. If average attendance drops, the city could lose some state money, said Pat Keegan, a spokeswoman for the State Education Department.
Almost overlooked amid the asbestos crisis were the inaugurations yesterday of 32 new specialized high schools, a sweeping addition to the city's secondary system that has drawn national attention. They included additions like the El Puente Academy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where students are to study science by organizing a vaccination campaign, and the High School for Economics and Finance in Manhattan, where classrooms will simulate a corporate office.
A total of 110 schools failed to open yesterday, most of them elementary and junior highs, officials said. Of those, 50 were in Districts 12 in the Bronx and District 19 in Brooklyn. An additional 44 were lower schools scattered across the city's other 30 community districts. Two were high school buildings: Concord High School on Staten Island and the old Stuyvesant high school in Manhattan, which houses three secondary programs. Fourteen were special education schools.
Some 32,000 students enrolled at schools that were closed were bused to alternate sites, Mr. Sobrino said.
The volume of calls to the special telephone numbers set up by the central Board of Education was so heavy that most callers got only busy signals in the hour before school began. The board had hired 40 operators, but they were swamped.
Some of the 110 schools will be opening today, but officials could not specify which ones. Others, however, may take significantly more time. Mr. Cortines said that most of the schools that failed to open yesterday would open within two weeks.
 
A Late Decision
 District 12 and District 19 were the only entire districts that failed to open. In both cases, local school boards voted late Sunday to keep their schools closed. In District 19, the vote came after more than 100 parents rallied at district headquarters. "The parents were frightened about the asbestos, and didn't want the schools to open," said Corinna Grant, a school board member.
The late vote left no time to notify the district's parents, and yesterday morning large crowds of muttering, confused parents gathered outside many of the district's schools.
"It wasn't in the papers, it wasn't on the news," said Keith McCrae, who brought his 5-year-old son to register at P.S. 158 for kindergarten. "I feel terrible."
Another school that failed to open -- also at the last minute -- was P.S. 42 in Chinatown, where officials discovered extensive asbestos deposits in wall plaster early Sunday. A nonprofit community group, the Chinese Consolidated Benevolency Association, offered to lease space for 750 students in a nearby private school until the cleanup can be completed.
"People responded in the good ways that New Yorkers respond when there is a crisis," said Andrew Lachman, a spokesman for Manhattan's District 2.

HEADLINE: Angola's Return to War Scars Its People, and Now Its Cities

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The most arresting evidence of Angola's agony is anecdotal.
It is the grasshopper-thin children of war-encircled Malanje lining up for soybean gruel at under-supplied relief kitchens. It is the shrieks and whimpers in the trauma ward of Luanda's biggest hospital, where doctors stitch wounds without painkillers. It is the legion of limbless men and women maimed while foraging for food in fields now salted with land mines. 
 The scale of the catastrophe is impossible to know, but by almost all accounts the suffering since Angola returned to civil war last October exceeds anything in its previous 16 years of factional conflict.
 
War Touches the Cities
 While the earlier fighting between the rebels of Jonas Savimbi and the Government of Jose Eduardo dos Santos was predominantly a guerrilla bush war, this time the victims are residents of towns and cities where the earlier fighting rarely intruded.
Besides killing an estimated 50,000 people, mostly civilians, the last year of war has inflated food prices beyond the reach of people once considered middle class, and has dismembered parts of the economy that functioned through the earlier years of war, throwing a potentially prosperous country back into an age of subsistence farming and barter.
The breakdown of ordinary commerce is compounded by pervasive corruption that diverts much of the food and medicine intended for the needy, and by the skewed priorities of the Marxist Government, which recently spent $500 million of its desperately scarce cash importing Volkswagens and Audis to sell to its generals and ministers at a fraction of their cost.
The waste is so brazen that even the official press cannot ignore it. After the automobile giveaway, state television took to describing the Parliament as the "Audi-torium."
Relief workers here, competing for the Western world's limited attention, liken the suffering to Somalia and Bosnia.
Alouine Blondin Beye, the United Nations special representative here, says at least 1,000 people, mostly civilians, are dying each day of the war's consequences, including hunger and disease, and two million more to face the danger of famine.
With much of the country cut off from view behind rebel lines, relief officials concede, no one really knows if these guesses are accurate.
The universal lament of officials and relief workers here is that the West, which invested so much in arming Angola during its years of civil war, now pays little attention to its pain.
For many years the United States and South Africa sponsored Mr. Savimbi's guerrillas against a Government aided by the Soviet Union and Cuba. In May the United States recognized the dos Santos Government as legitimate on the basis of elections last September, but Mr. Savimbi has refused to accept his defeat in that vote.
 
Not Enough Pledges
 Mr. Beye said the United Nations budgeted $226 million for humanitarian relief this year, but member countries pledged only $88 million. The largest donor is the United States, which has earmarked about $60 million.
The pervasive corruption has added to the reluctance of potential donors, who fear what they contribute will be diverted to the war effort or looted from the docks of Luanda to reappear in this city's Roque Santiero market, a vast pirate bazaar named for the rascally hero of a popular Brazilian soap opera.
In the fly-blown wards of the country's main hospital, a pillared colonial hulk overlooking Luanda, doctors are so short of medicine that instead of writing prescriptions, they write shopping lists. Patients with money pass the lists to relatives, who then search for stolen antibiotics or bandages in the stalls of Roque Santiero market.
A capsule of painkiller costs two days' pay for someone lucky enough to have a job. But many of those writhing in filthy sheets in the trauma ward have been airlifted in from besieged areas where no payroll has arrived since January.
Luis Upeme, a 57-year-old truck driver who stepped on a land mine while scavenging for roots outside the town of Menongue, lay sprawled on a blanket in a crowded corridor cradling the stump of his left leg.
Although Menongue is surrounded by rebel guerrillas, he said disgustedly, he has begged the doctors to send him home.
"In Menongue, we had beds," he said.
Some of Angola's victims are direct casualties of a war that, in its current phase, has little sympathy for civilians.
Each day Mr. Savimbi's rebels shell the city of Cuito, where a small army garrison has held out since January. Each day the Government sends MIG fighters to rain bombs on the city of Huambo, Mr. Savimbi's headquarters. Both cities, capitals of neighboring provinces in Angola's central highlands, are symbolic prizes of little military value.
In the early months of renewed fighting, the most desperate victims were the refugees uprooted from the highlands and forced to flee, often for weeks on foot, to the twin coastal cities of Lobito and Benguela. There they sought shelter in tent cities run by foreign relief agencies.
But recently relief workers discovered a startling paradox.
"One day we woke up and we saw the people in the cities were in worse condition than those we were supporting in the camps," said Philippe Borel, director of operations in Luanda for the United Nations World Food Program, the main supplier and logistical backbone of the foreign aid network.
In October, after Mr. Savimbi denounced the elections as rigged and returned to war, his rebels blew up all the bridges that had been rebuilt during 16 months of peace, paralyzing the railroad, Lobito's huge port, and most of the industry in the two cities.
Relief workers have now opened soup kitchens for city dwellers suffering from malnutrition because they had no money.
Of the areas reached by reporters and relief workers, the most shocking is Malanje, unmolested in the earlier civil war but now cut off to all traffic except by air.
The World Food Program has been airlifting in food for 50,000 people, but the population has swollen to 250,000 by villagers fleeing the war. It is the one city where it is common to see famished stick-children like those of Somalia or Sudan.
In other cities that have been isolated by rebel attacks, such as Luena and Menongue, the hunger is less dramatic so far, but refugees from the cities say the threat of starvation is growing.
About a third of Angola's 12 million people live in rebel territory, where only the Catholic relief agency, Caritas, is allowed to operate.
Oscar Bragga, the Catholic bishop of Benguela Province and president of Caritas, said based on his sketchy reports the situation is worse in rebel-held areas.
"Unita has no supplies, and in any case the rebels have never supplied the civilian population of areas under their control," he said. On the contrary, Unita is famous for living off the local population, and then destroying as much as possible when it is forced to evacuate.
 
Hazards of Agriculture
 With an estimated 2 million Angolans displaced and great swaths of land mined, much farmland is going unplanted. Even digging for manioc root, a starchy African staple, is hazardous.
In cities not directly touched by the war, like Luanda and Lobito, raging inflation fueled by war spending and money-printing has created a sense of economic desperation.
For a low-level civil servant earning 400,000 kwanzas a month -- about $8 -- a 25-cent loaf of bread begins to look like a luxury.
About the only true bargain is gasoline. The Government, which controls the oil-rich Cabinda Province, is reported to have sold its future oil income for the next three years to get money for weapons, but it still sells gasoline to motorists at about 13 cents a tankful.
Unable to slow inflation, the Government has concentrated on making it less cumbersome. A newspaper ad this week boasted that a new 100,000 kwanza bank note, coming soon, would provide "more value, less volume."
Mercedes Sayagues of the World Food Program said many of the agency's local employees have asked to be paid in food, because the money is worthless.
"The Angolan economy has disappeared," she said. "It's all barter."
Amazingly, people get by. They pick over garbage piles. They buy 110-pound bags of corn and resell it by the cupful to those even poorer. Thievery is commonplace, from orderlies who steal pills from patients' bedsides and dock workers who stuff their pants with corn, to the disappearance of entire shipping containers.
"The worst shortage," said a Russian doctor in Lobito, "is a shortage of honest people. And what else can you expect in a place where people are hungry?"

HEADLINE: Japanese Say They Plan to Relax Restrictions on Foreign Lawyers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
When Japanese talk about what's wrong with America, they usually list crime, urban decay and a proliferation of lawyers. A total ban on foreign lawyers here was eased six years ago, with little ill effect, but members of the Japanese bar still say they have visions of being overwhelmed by overpaid talent who would pollute the Japanese system with an oil slick of litigation.
As a result, foreign lawyers operating here have been forced to navigate a forest of obstacles. They have been barred from hiring Japanese lawyers, giving their clients advice on Japanese law, or even arguing cases in court. 
 But now, after years of haggling and growing international pressure, the Japanese Government and its powerful bar association say they are close to lifting many of the restrictions on foreign lawyers, even paving the way for Japan's roughly 14,000 lawyers -- fewer than you can find on some city blocks in Washington -- to team up with the invaders.
 
Partnerships to Be Allowed
 For example, under the new rules, which will be announced next week but not formally adopted by Parliament until next year at the earliest, foreign law firms will be allowed to form partnerships with their Japanese counterparts. That, in turn, will enable them to hire Japanese lawyers and to advise clients on the worldwide legal implications of business deals.
Some American lawyers suggest that these changes do not go far enough, because American firms will still be barred from hiring Japanese lawyers on their own rather than as part of a joint venture.
"There are still major restrictions, especially on Japanese lawyers who want to become partners in multinational law firms," said Donald Morgan, a partner in the Tokyo office of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.
The treatment of American and other foreign law firms here has been a major source of trade tension between Washington and Tokyo for years and recently an issue in the Uruguay round of international trade talks.
Some of the biggest and most influential Wall Street firms haved argued that they have been kept from fully competing for the most lucrative legal business in Japan, while Japanese lawyers have a far easier time practicing in the United States.
 
Fear of Competition
 The powerful Japan Federation of Bar Associations has expressed fears that its members would be overwhelmed by high-powered American and British firms, which they say would bring a combative, litigious culture to a legal community that operates, at least on the surface, by a different tradition. But some Japanese lawyers concede that the real issue is one of competition.
It is unclear whether the new rules will reverse the fortunes of the large American firms here. Many are believed to be losing money on their Tokyo offices, especially in a time of economic downturn. But by allowing foreign and Japanese firms to form joint ventures, the new regulations may make it possible for the foreigners to offer "one-stop shopping," no longer forcing them to refer clients to a separate Japanese firm for advice on how their real estate deals or business ventures are affected by Japanese law.
"There have been demands for liberalization, and we think that this will be a very important step toward the deregulation of the legal system," said Osamu Horino, the secretary general of the bar association group.
Until 1987 foreign lawyers, with a handful of exceptions, were barred from practicing in Japan at all, except as "trainees" to Japanese companies or law firms. Since then several dozen firms have been accredited, most from the United States and Europe.
 
Continually Changing Names
 But the relationship between the foreign lawyers and the Japanese bar has been an uneasy one. American firms, for example, have not been permitted to identify themselves by name. Instead, they must go by the names of the lawyers from the parent firm who have been admitted to practice here.
Thus, the Cleary Gottlieb office is known as Morgan Beller Terai Gaikokuho Jimu Bengoshi. The first three names are the names of the lawyers in Tokyo; the last three words mean "foreign business lawyer." Every time a lawyer moves in or out of the office, the local firm's name has changed.
Under the new regulations, firms will be allowed to use the same names they use elsewhere in the world.
But if the name issue has been an annoyance, the restriction on hiring has been a major impediment. Some Japanese lawyers have said they fear that American firms will lure away young Japanese lawyers with offers of high salaries.
And they argue that Japanese lawyers come from a different tradition. For example, the Government pays for the legal education of anyone who survives the grueling bar exam here, which has a pass rate of less than 2 percent. It also controls that education: there is one national law school, and all of the nation's lawyers and judges must pass through its doors.
While some Americans cite the small size of Japan's bar as a competitive advantage for Japanese businesses, the numbers are misleading.
Though there are slightly more than 14,000 bengoshi, or lawyers who have passed the bar exam, tens of thousands of other professionals do work that in the United States only lawyers would be qualified to perform.
By contrast, the American Bar Association estimates that 845,000 to 850,000 lawyers practice in the United States.
Japanese Government officials said they hoped to be able to present the new rules during trade negotiations, and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa was reported in the Japanese press to be ready to discuss the issue with President Clinton next week.

HEADLINE: Many Experts Say Health Plan Would Fall Far Short on Savings

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
A wide range of experts, including economists, consultants and members of Congress, say President Clinton's health care plan will not cut costs nearly as much as the Administration hopes and will actually increase the Federal budget deficit instead of cutting it, as the Administration promises.
In a series of interviews, the experts, both Democratic and Republican, used terms like "not credible," "difficult," "wildly optimistic" and "illusory" to describe the President's plans. 
 Critics say the only way the Administration could achieve such savings is through broad cuts in medical services -- which they say would probably be politically unacceptable. They assert, for example, that much of the planned $124 billion in Medicare cuts are politically and technically impossible to carry out by the year 2000.
 
Checked and Rechecked?
 "It's very ambitious," said Henry Aaron, an economist and a health policy expert at the Brookings Institution. "My feeling is they're reaching a long way for cost containment. Technically, it's not impossible. The question is whether it's politically achievable and sustainable."
But Administration officials argue that there is so much inefficiency, waste and fraud in the system that huge savings can be squeezed out with more competition and efficiency. They assert that their financing estimates have been put together in good faith, contain line-by-line spending cuts and have been checked and rechecked.
"If you look at these numbers, they come from a process that is unprecedented," Hillary Rodham Clinton told reporters today. Earlier today, she met with more than 200 members of Congress and told them that major savings could be made in Medicare and Medicaid. [Page A18.]
 
Attacking the Deficit
 A draft of the plan given to members of Congress shows that by 1998 the Administration plans to slash in half the growth in the nation's overall health care spending -- government and private -- which is rising by 9.4 percent a year.
The plan also projects roughly $350 billion in new Federal health spending from 1994 to 2000 but estimates that the Government will raise $441 billion in the same period, through new revenues and cuts in existing programs. This would leave $91 billion to cut the Federal budget deficit.
A vigorous debate has erupted over the health care plan even before President Clinton presents it in a speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. Administration officials said they were still deciding details of the plan, including how it would be paid for.
Many of the experts interviewed were skeptical, based on what they know so far, that the Administration could achieve the savings it envisions. The draft of the plan also promises to cut the growth in private health care spending in half by 1999 and to slash by more than half the 11.6 percent annual growth in the Medicare program for the elderly from 1994 to 1998.
"It seems like an awfully big bite over that period of time," said Lawrence S. Lewin, chairman of Lewin-VHI, a health-policy consulting firm. He said he was sympathetic with the Administration's proposals but suggested that it was promising too much too fast.
 
Moynihan Weighs In
 A failure to hold down health costs as much as projected could erase any planned deficit reduction stemming from the plan.
On the NBC News program "Meet the Press" on Sunday, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, questioned the Administration's promise to hold down Medicare and Medicaid spending and cut the budget deficit, calling it "fantasy."
Today he voiced confidence that Congress would approve health care legislation. "We're going to do this," he said. But he added, "We could spoil it all by saying, 'And in addition, we're going to have $91 billion in deficit reduction.' "
Administration officials responded that even if the plan does not achieve the $91 billion in deficit reduction, it will still pay for itself.
One fear is that lower-than-expected savings would cause health insurance premiums to rise, forcing the Government to pay far more than the $160 billion in subsidies it plans for low-income workers and small businesses from 1994 to 2000.
Several health care experts said the amount of cost containment planned would be more credible if the Administration planned to make the cuts over a dozen years, not in half that time.
Expanding on his "fantasy" description Sunday, Senator Moynihan said: "These numbers all come out of their computer in that way. They won't last, they mustn't last."
Mrs. Clinton vigorously defended the credibility of the plan's finances when she met with Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill last week. A participant at the meeting quoted her as saying, "We have looked at the numbers very carefully, we have been relentless, including checking our procedures and our modeling methods."
 
Memories of Reagan
 In discussing the Clinton health changes, some economists sound as skeptical as they did when President Ronald Reagan pledged to increase Pentagon spending, cut taxes and reduce the budget deficit all at once. These economists wonder how Mr. Clinton's plan can extend health coverage to 37 million uninsured Americans, offer important new services like long-term home health care and still promise to reduce the deficit by $91 billion from 1994 to 2000.
"The deficit reduction piece is the ultimate touch of chutzpah in what is one of the most unrealistic financing schemes I've ever seen," said Gail Wilensky, a health care expert who administered the Medicare and Medicaid programs under President George Bush. "I expected a more modest benefit package and a real but not too painful tax increase, or else more expensive benefits linked to a larger, more painful tax increase. I was surprised when they proposed big benefits but little in the way of taxes. The financing isn't credible."
The Administration says its plan will hold down the increase in Medicare and Medicaid spending by $238 billion from 1994 to 2000 and save $47 billion in other Federal programs. The plan anticipates collecting $105 billion in taxes on tobacco and possibly alcohol and $51 billion in higher income taxes. Officials say those tax revenues will result from a rise in wages that is expected to occur because companies will in theory have more money to pay workers, thanks to lower health care costs. All told, this comes to $441 billion in savings and revenues.
Over the same period, the plan calls for $80 billion for a new long-term care program, $72 billion for a new prescription drug plan and $29 billion for administration, mainly to set up and run regional health alliances to provide health coverage in all 50 states. The plan's big hope is that these alliances will squeeze down costs by driving hard bargains when they purchase health care from networks of doctors, hospitals and insurers.
 
Subsidies Called For
 The plan also calls for $169 billion in subsidies for companies and low-income workers who cannot pay their share of the cost of insurance. All this means $350 billion in new Federal spending from 1994 to 2000.
Several economists said they would feel more comfortable about the financing if the Administration relied less on ambitious cost-cutting and more on taxes. But if President Clinton learned anything from the bruising budget battle, it is that the public has little appetite for new taxes. In many ways, the Clinton plan is promising just what the American people want and have grown used to: more services than they are willing to pay for because of their disdain for taxes.
Administration officials say they have done hard-headed economic analysis showing that they can cut overall health care spending by 9 percent by the year 2000, to $1.49 trillion from $1.63 trillion. They argue that huge savings are available by infusing more competition into the system and by reducing inefficiency, waste and abuse.
At the same time, by extending coverage to all Americans, the plan is expected to create 6 to 10 percent more demand for health care services. By offering more services and still reducing overall spending, the plan thus aims to squeeze actual costs by at least 15 percent.
"The savings we project are perfectly reasonable when you recognize that health care provided by H.M.O.'s is 15 percent cheaper than regular fee-for-service," said Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Probably the area that health care experts are most skeptical about is the Administration's plan to cut Medicare spending by $124 billion from 1994 to 2000. Some said the Administration would be lucky to cut it by half that.
"They are suggesting that they would cut Medicare growth, after inflation, to 0 or 1 percent by 1996," said Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, a California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee's Subcommittee on Health. "Politically, that will be difficult after we've already cut $60 billion out as part of the budget package. But even if Congress approves, it's unrealistic to think they can cut it that much. I would argue we could get Medicare down to 5 or 6 percent a year in spending growth."
Senator Moynihan was also skeptical of the Administration's ability to bring Medicare's double-digit spending increases down to zero by the end of the decade. To make such a prediction, he said, "is to have lost touch with reality."

HEADLINE: Deflate Government? Helium Didn't

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 17

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration set out to streamline government, a lot of budget watchdogs said there was no better place to start than at the helium reserve here, a cluster of mines, pipes and cooling vats that was $1.3 billion in debt and 100 years ahead on the supply curve.
But when President Clinton's National Performance Review finally focused on the cold-war-era complex this month, it suggested that Congress cancel the program's debt and issued a vague call to "increase efficiencies in helium operations." 
 Rather than becoming a model of "reinvented" government, the helium reserve -- begun in the 1920's to inflate blimps and used today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in its spacecraft -- became instead a model of how politics and economics can sometimes converge to spare seemingly unnecessary programs.
 
Talking About Helium
 The politics was simple. Amarillo's Congressman, Bill Sarpalius, a conservative Democrat who proved to be a crucial vote in favor of the President's budget bill last month, spoke to Mr. Clinton four times on the day of the vote, repeatedly bringing up his concern about preserving the program, which provides 220 jobs in Amarillo, in the Texas Panhandle.
"Sure I talked to the President about helium," Mr. Sarpalius said in an interview. "I talk to everyone I can in the Government about helium. And when I had the opportunity to explain to him that this was not really a billion-dollar loss, that this is a program that makes money for the Federal Government, that there's another side to this picture, he was fascinated by it. He was really interested in helium."
Critics of the debt-ridden program, which was bolstered in the 1960's amid fears that America might run out of helium as its space program was rushing to put men on the moon, have urged that it be abolished or privatized. "We may conceivably in the future need ermine pelts and Grand Marnier," said Pete Sepp, a spokesman for the National Taxpayers Union. "That doesn't mean the Federal Government needs to be in charge of stockpiling them."
But L. Dale Bippus, who as general manager of the Federal Helium Reserve of the Bureau of Mines oversees a stockpile of 32 billion cubic feet of the gas, enough to supply current Federal demands for the next 100 years, boasts of the Federal program with the huge surplus -- of helium. "We're the Fort Knox of helium," he said. "It was a wise investment, I think. We've got a tremendous asset here that we acquired at a reasonable price."
The economics of helium is complex. But, in essence, the problem is this: Although the Government is sitting atop a helium supply worth $1.6 billion at today's prices, there is no way it can simply sell off the gas and give the cash to the Treasury.
Doing so, virtually everyone agrees, would lead to a collapse in the world helium market, quickly dropping the price to pennies on the taxpayers' investment dollars. As expensive as it was to get into the helium program, it could prove even more costly to leave.
And so the federally owned helium sits in an underground mine, trapped beneath a layer of impermeable rock and released only when a Federal agency calls for it.
Odorless and colorless, helium has the valuable property of remaining gaseous to the extremely low temperature of minus 452 degrees. It is used mostly by NASA, which relies on supercooled helium to pressurize fuel tanks and to act as a copllant, and by the Defense Department for rockets and research.
 
Inflated Projections
 Financially speaking, projections in 1960 that the Government would make money in the helium business proved wildly inflated. Founded with a taxpayer loan of $352 million, the program is now $1.3 billion in debt, even though the Government charges its own agencies 20 percent more for helium than the going rate in private industry. Not that it has to worry about the competition: Federal law prohibits Federal agencies from buying helium anywhere except at the Federal reserve.
Defenders of the reserve say it is a moneymaker because it returned $28 million to the Treasury last year while costing only $15 million to operate. But critics say these figures are misleading because it is all Government money anyway.
In any event, the figures do not take into account the cost of servicing the debt. To pay that off by the statutory deadline of 1995, the General Accounting Office calculated in a report last year, the reserve would have to charge $3,000 per 1,000 cubic feet -- enough to inflate a 12-foot balloon -- on all sales in the next two years; its current price is $55, and private industry charges about $46.
"It's an affront to the free enterprise system," said Representative C. Christopher Cox, a Republican from Orange County, Calif., who has emerged as the chief Congressional critic of the reserve. "It's a hoary example of socialism, of state-run industry, at a time when the whole world has rejected socialism."
Mr. Cox has introduced an amendment to the National Helium Act of 1960 that would allow NASA, which bought 131 million cubic feet of helium in the last fiscal year, to buy helium privately. These suppliers already provide all the helium bought by non-Government customers, which account for about 90 percent of the helium used in the United States. While it is most commonly used to inflate children's balloons, helium is also used for things as varied as welding and magnetic resonance imaging.
The Cox amendment passed in the House but is languishing in the Senate. Whatever its fate, there is tremendous pressure from the private suppliers -- including Exxon, Enron, Mobil and other major corporations -- against the reverse concept: allowing the Government to sell gas to private customers.
And Mr. Bippus said: "I don't think the Government's job is to try to put private industry out of business."
 
'What Are We Going to Do?'
 But Mr. Bippus, on a tour of the complex here, said he was frustrated at the derision directed at his agency, where he has worked for the 37 years. And he was angry that the critics -- including Mr. Cox and P. J. O'Rourke, the humorist who in his 1991 book "Parliament of Whores" called the helium program "amazingly stupid, even by government standards" -- had never even bothered to come out to Amarillo.
"Well, we own it, so what are we going to do with it?" Mr. Bippus asked. "Are you just going to vent it out into the air? I could blow all this helium into the atmosphere. Is that going to make you feel better?"
For reasons unclear to geologists, the United States has the world's greatest concentrations of helium, mainly in Wyoming and in a field that stretches through the Texas Panhandle and into Oklahoma and Kansas.
The Federal helium program dates to 1925, when the Government refined the gas for use in blimps, then an emerging vehicle for use in war. The Germans desperately wanted it for their zeppelins, but the United States said no, so the Germans turned to flammable hydrogen, at least until the Hindenburg explosion in 1937.
 
'Helium Capital of the World'
 Today, less than 1 percent of the Government's helium is used for blimps, although there have been persistent reports that the Pentagon is working on a classified, helium-inflated spy craft referred to in military circles as the "stealth blimp."
There is no question that helium is important to Amarillo. Inscribed on the front of the local telephone directory is: "Amarillo is proud to be the helium capital of the world."
Mr. Cox said: 'No one ought to begrudge Bill Sarpalius his defense of this boondoggle. It's his job as a Congressman to defend it. But everybody in Congress votes on it, and not everybody in Congress is from Amarillo."
But Mr. Sarpalius insisted he was not protecting any local pork-barrel project, and instead believed he had persuaded the President of the program's merits. "If you're asking was there a tradeoff," he said, referring to his vote in favor of Mr. Clinton's budget, "there wasn't a tradeoff."
And out where the helium is kept, Mr. Bippus said that decades from now important new uses for helium would probably be discovered, and Americans would praise the Government's foresight in stockpiling it. "But it really comes down to this," he added. "If you could tell me what the future demand for helium was going to be, I could tell you whether this was a good investment."

He toured the Excell Helium Plant in Amarillo, Tex. (David Bowser for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuban Refugees Tangle Mexican Diplomacy

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20

 BODY:
A series of incidents involving Cuban refugees headed for the United States has brought Mexico's traditional friendliness with Cuba into new conflict with its effort to win approval for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The largest group, 72 Cubans, crept under a garden wall at Mexico's embassy in the Dominican Republic on Thursday, refusing to leave unless Mexico helped them get to Miami. 
 Like two similar cases, the incident in Santo Domingo has been complicated by American politics. In those cases, the refugees ultimately were allowed to travel on, but this time Mexico has refused, saying it will not act as a consular intermediary.
Cuban-American leaders, who support the flight of refugees, have pressed Mexico to change its mind, threatening to muster what influence they can against the trade agreement.
Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a South Florida Republican, said at least a few legislators from predominantly Cuban-American districts plan to vote against the trade pact already, in part because they are critical of Mexico's relations with Cuba.
Mexican officials say that they fear that anger over the refugee problem could further imperil the accord.
"We do not need any explosive issue to come up which is going to interfere with what is already a very difficult process," a senior Mexican official said, explaining the efforts to placate Cuban-American groups. "It is a relatively small price to pay."
Last month, the Mexican Navy picked up eight refugees off the Yucatan Peninsula. Seven others had died when their boat sank. Mexico deported the survivors, an act that led to protests by Cuban-Americans in Miami.
Within a week, the decision was reversed and the Cubans were returned to Mexico and given visas. The Mexican Consul in Miami, Bulmaro Pacheco, made the announcement in a news conference with the Cuban American National Foundation, a lobbying group Mexico has criticized in the past.
The Cuban Ambassador to Mexico, Jose Fernandez de Cossio, said Cuba did not oppose the departures of the shipwreck victims or of 11 Cubans who walked into the Mexican Embassy in Havana on Sept. 9 and refused to leave when political asylum was denied.
He insisted that those incidents had not hurt relations with Mexico. But the Cuban Government reacted sharply to the occupation of the Mexican Embassy in Santo Domingo.
"I think all of this is orchestrated," President Fidel Castro told La Jornada, a Mexico City newspaper. "It is the most provocative elements of the counterrevolution, the most recalcitrant enemies of Cuba, and those who want to create problems for Cuba and problems for the friends of Cuba."
Although Mexico said it is determined to stop the flow of refugees, the problem continues. Today officials reported that six more Cubans rescued from a sinking boat off the Cayman Islands had arrived in Veracruz, seeking safe passage to the United States. They were given temporary visas for Mexico.
 Amicable relations toward the Communist Government in Cuba have long been viewed in Mexico as a measure of foreign-policy independence from the United States. Over the last decade, Mexico has granted thousands of visas to Cubans but has never given them asylum, said a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Carlos Reta Martinez.
Prompted by fears of turmoil in Cuba, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration has quietly pressed Cuba to ease economic and political controls.
