HEADLINE: Britain May Act on Paris Trade Stance

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Britain, angered by what it sees as repeated French stalling on international trade talks, threatened on Monday to boycott European Community meetings if no world trade accord is reached by Dec. 15.
The British statement, made by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd at a European Community foreign and farm ministers meeting here, amounted to an extraordinary threat to paralyze the activities of the 12-nation community. The so-called empty chair policy was last employed by France in 1965 to immobilize the community over a budgetary dispute. 
 A British Government spokesman quoted Mr. Hurd as telling the meeting that it was inconceivable that "the European Community could proceed with normal business if it was seen as having caused the collapse of the Uruguay Round of trade talks."
Asked how normal business would be disrupted, the spokesman said Britain, and perhaps other states, could boycott meetings, provoking what he called "a community crisis."
Early this morning, the ministers reached an agreement on a statement that was vague enough to bridge the differences between the French and British positions.
But the British outburst reflected growing exasperation in London -- widely shared in Washington -- over the insistence, reiterated on Monday, of the center-right French Government of Edouard Balladur that an agreement on agricultural trade reached between the European Community and the United States last November must be renegotiated.
The agreement, named the Blair House accord after the Washington building in which it was negotiated, calls for a 21 percent cut over six years in the volume of subsidized grain and other food exports from the European Community and for a cut in the amount of land in the community used for oilseed production. It also contains a so-called peace clause, stipulating that the United States and the European Community must refrain from action against each other on farm-trade questions for six years.
At the time it was reached, the agreement was hailed by the United States and many European officials as a decisive breakthrough in the long-stalled world trade talks known as the Uruguay Round. These negotiations began in Uruguay in 1986 and world leaders have promised repeatedly, most recently at the economic summit meeting in Tokyo in July, to conclude them rapidly.
But arguments over liberalizing agricultural trade, which accounts for about 9.5 percent of international commerce and has traditionally been a highly protected sector, have repeatedly blocked the talks.
President Clinton, in a meeting last week with Prime Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi of Italy, stressed that there was no question of renegotiating the Blair House agreement.
Still, France, the second-largest agricultural exporter in the world after the United States, insisted on Monday that the Blair House accord was unacceptable. "We cannot hide the truth," Farm Minister Jean Puech declared. "A renegotiation is necessary."
French farmers, a vociferous lobby whose influence on French politics is considerable, have staged several protests against the Blair House accord over the last week.
France wants cuts in the community's subsidized food exports shifted to the end of the six-year period, guarantees that the community share in an anticipated expansion of the world food market in Asia and particularly China, a stipulation that the 21 percent cut be applied across the board and not product by product, and assurances that current large community stocks of food not be affected by the agreement.
Moreover, France wants the six-year peace clause expanded indefinitely so that the community has a cast-iron assurance that its agricultural policy will never again be contested by America.
The statement agreed upon by ministers today, after more than 12 hours of talks, contained no specific reference to the Blair House accord. But it said that the European Community Executive Commission, which negotiated the accord, should pursue negotiations with the United States with a view to "maintaining the community's vocation as a agricultural supporter" insuring that any General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreement does not force further changes of the community's agricultural policy.
Sir Leon Brittan, the community's chief trade negotiator, is scheduled to visit Washington on Sept. 26.
Community officials said the statement represented a compromise between the British insistence that there could be no renegotiation of the Blair House accord because this would effectively destroy the chances of a GATT agreement by Dec. 15, and the French insistence that changes must be made.
Alain Juppe, the French Foreign Minister, interpreted the statement to mean that the commission now had a mandate to wring concessions from the United States on extending the peace clause and on insuring that the proposed 21 percent cut in subsidized food exports is weakened.
But Mr. Hurd said the commission's talks in Washington would be purely exploratory. "Blair House will not be renegotiated," he declared.

HEADLINE: C. L. Sulzberger, Columnist, Dies at 80

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
C. L. Sulzberger, a prize-winning foreign correspondent and foreign affairs columnist for The New York Times for nearly 40 years and the author of two dozen books, most of them on foreign policy and world leaders in the cold-war era, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 80.
Mr. Sulzberger, who gave up his Op-Ed page column in The Times in 1978 but continued writing his memoirs and books on foreign affairs, died of natural causes after a long illness, his family said. 
 The son of Leo Sulzberger, he was a nephew of Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of The Times from 1935 to 1961. He was also a first cousin of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of the paper from 1963 to 1992 and still chairman of the Times Company.
In a career that began in the Great Depression and spanned World War II, the Korean and Vietnam Wars and the rise and fall of nations, Mr. Sulzberger roamed the world from his longtime base in Paris to interview historic leaders and to chronicle and analyze the major events of his time. His columns offered portraits of leaders and nations, opinions on foreign news and critiques of American foreign policy.
 
Career Spanned 5 Decades
 After graduation from Harvard and five years with other news organizations, Mr. Sulzberger joined The Times in 1939 and was its chief foreign correspondent from 1944 to 1954, when he became a columnist. His column, "Foreign Affairs," appeared three times a week, on the editorial page until 1970, then on the Op-Ed page until his retirement in 1978.
Mr. Sulzberger, who was banned from half a dozen countries for his reporting and won a special Pulitzer Prize citation in 1951, ranged over the field of foreign affairs, touching on military power, economics, diplomacy, industrial and agricultural production and especially the ideas and personalities of leaders.
As a reporter and commentator, he had the inestimable gift of a quick study: the ability to land in the morning in Moscow or Beijing, Prague or Johannesburg, and, with the benefit of speedy access to top leaders, to write by nightfall a cogent report giving the impression he had steeped himself in a subject all his life.
From presidents and Prime Ministers in their inner sanctums to royalty in palaces and rebels in mountain strongholds, he crisscrossed and circled the world to talk to and write with insight about Stalin, Nikita S. Khrushchev, Zhou Enlai, John F. Kennedy, Richard M. Nixon, Winston Churchill, Charles de Gaulle and many heads of government and state, ambassadors and foreign ministers, generals and secret agents.
 
Praise and Criticism
 His contacts with the famous and the mighty produced many notable exclusive articles, and he readily took credit for them. And while he was widely praised for his ability to uncover news and to comment upon it in a voice of wide experience and intelligence, some reviewers of his books an academic critics also said his views were pompous, debatable and laden with trivia.
Moreover, while he frequently challenged policy as formulated in Washington and other capitals, critics noted in retrospect that his reporting and commentary often tipped toward the official line of the leaders he covered -- that was, indeed, a general practice of diplomatic reporting in his era.
And he candidly acknowledged that his entree was enormously eased by his role as a Times correspondent and columnist, by his connections to the family that owned the newspaper and especially by the desire of leaders and revolutionaries to get maximum attention for their views through its widely read columns.
 
A Message for Kennedy
 At times, Mr. Sulzberger had behind-the-scenes roles in the affairs he wrote about. In "The Last of the Giants," a 1970 book about world leaders he had covered, he recalled that in a 1961 interview in Moscow, Khrushchev asked him to take a message to President Kennedy, and he did so. The contents were never revealed.
Mr. Sulzberger often injected himself into his accounts: "I limped goutily over to the Elysee -- for an appointment with President Pompidou," Henry Kissinger, "no slouch in the art of flattery, assured me that both he and the President thought my column was the best being written," or "I was sitting in the cold lobby of the Moskva Hotel this morning when John Foster Dulles came along, nudged me and suggested we go for a walk."
In 1977, Mr. Sulzberger was accused in an article in Rolling Stone magazine of having had a secret relationship for years with the Central Intelligence Agency. And a C.I.A. official charged that Mr. Sulzberger's Sept. 13, 1967, column on the Soviet K.G.B. had been lifted almost verbatim from an agency briefing paper.
There was no question that Mr. Sulzberger had extensive contacts with C.I.A. station chiefs and agents in many countries. And, it was pointed out, he would have been extremely useful to the agency with his access to foreign leaders and his influential voice in the pages of The Times.
The Times, after an extensive investigation, reported that the C.I.A. had counted a number of American journalists among its paid agents, but denied that Mr. Sulzberger had been among them. Mr. Sulzberger also denied that he ever worked for the C.I.A. or that he had used an agency briefing paper as a column.
 
A Good Listener
 A tall, bespectacled man with white hair and a thin smile that captured a blend of worldly wit and solemnity, Mr. Sulzberger was remembered by colleagues at The Times as convivial and generous, a raconteur who could be punditical at times but who also was a good listener and a good friend.
Close acquaintances, too, remembered him as a man who led a double life. There was a darker side to his personality, one that brooded in diaries about not having done more in life and that longed for the privacy of a fishing stream in the Colorado Rockies, where he went each summer, or his villa on the Greek island of Spetsai.
The darker side was illuminated in a 1980 book by Mr. Sulzberger, "How I Committed Suicide: A Reverie." In it, he spoke of profound loneliness after the death of his wife, the former Marina Tatiana Lada, in 1976. They had been married in 1942 and she had often accompanied him on his journeys and made their Paris home a salon for the illustrious and the powerful.
 
'The Keyes of My Prison'
 He also wrote of his departure from The Times, under a mandatory retirement program then in effect, and of the sense that he had outlived his era. And he declared: "How right Donne was, I thought, when he wrote, 'Mee thinks I have the keyes of my prison in mine owne hand, and no remedy presents it selfe so soone to my heart, as mine own sword' -- except it was mine own gun and not my sword."
Cyrus Leo Sulzberger was born in New York City on Oct. 27, 1912, and graduated magna cum laude from Harvard in 1934. While he wanted to go into journalism and had close family connections to The Times, he chose to start elsewhere to establish his name.
He started as a general assignment reporter for The Pittsburgh Press and a year later went to Washington for the United Press, covering labor, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve system. He later went to Europe and worked for The London Evening Standard and other newspapers and periodicals in the United States and Europe.
Joining The Times in 1939 as a young foreign correspondent at the outbreak of World War II, he traveled 100,000 miles through 30 countries in his first three years on the job, sending reports from the Balkans, North Africa, Italy, the Soviet Union, the Middle East and capitals and front lines across a war-torn Europe.
 
Arrest and Expulsion
 He wrote so many provocative articles about Balkan and Axis politics that he was successively banned from Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Italy. "A creeping tarantula, going from country to country, spreading poison," the Italian propagandist Virginio Gayda wrote of him. In 1941, he was arrested by the Gestapo in Slovakia and accused of being a British spy; he was later released without a trial.
As chief correspondent of The Times from 1944 to 1954, he directed the coverage of the end of the war in Europe with a distinguished group that included Drew Middleton, Raymond Daniell, Herbert L. Matthews, Clifton Daniel and James Reston.
After the war, Mr. Sulzberger chronicled the division of Europe into Western and Communist spheres, analyzed rival guerrilla movements in Yugoslavia and drew out for readers the complex character of Tito and won a special Pulitzer Prize citation in 1951 for an exclusive prison-cell interview in Yugoslavia with Archbishop Alojzije Stepinac, whose 1946 conviction on war-crimes charges signaled the start of the postwar struggle between church and state in Eastern Europe.
While he knew many world leaders on a first-name basis, he was perhaps most intimate with de Gaulle, the French statesman whose career and complex character filled scores of columns and many chapters of Mr. Sulzberger's books.
 
Books on Foreign Affairs
 Mr. Sulzberger's many books included "The Big Thaw," published in 1956, a personal exploration of the Soviet Union and its satellite countries in Eastern Europe under the Khrushchev regime; "What's Wrong With U.S. Foreign Policy," a 1959 critique; "A Long Row of Candles," a 1969 memoir; "The Fall of Eagles," a 1977 volume on the collapse of the Hapsburgs, the Hohenzollerns and the Romanovs, and "Seven Continents and Forty Years," a 1977 chronicle of Mr. Sulzberger's career.
Reviewers sometimes criticized Mr. Sulzberger's books for being repetitious, for injecting the author too much into accounts of conversations with interview subjects, and for too much trivia in the bulky volumes: what King Paul of Greece wore, and where Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower bought cheap clothing.
But more typically reviewers praised him for indefatigable reporting, for courage on dangerous assignments and for what Paul Grimes, reviewing "Seven Continents and Forty years," called his "sharp succinct portraits" of world leaders, and he listed a few: "She looks like a simple grandmother but she is obdurate and hard as nails," (Prime Minister Golda Meir of Israel), and "a small, pipe-smoking man with an unctuous manner . . . the face of a halibut with shark's eyes." (Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain).
 
Decline of U.S. Power
 Theodore H. White, in a review of "What's Wrong With U.S. Foreign Policy," said Mr. Sulzberger had documented "in overwhelming and appalling detail," how the United States had lost power in the postwar years and the 1950's. "Mr. Sulzberger's unique opportunities as global investigator for The Times are buttressed by his knowledge of history," Mr. White declared.
Among Mr. Sulzberger's honors were Overseas Press Club awards for the best consistent reporting from abroad in 1951, and for excellence in reporting and writing in 1957 and 1970.
He is survived by a son, David Alexis Sulzberger, of London; a daughter, Marina Sulzberger Berry, of London, and two grandchildren. The family said the funeral would be private.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Yen Ahead of Japanese Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday amid reports that the Bank of Japan was on the verge of cutting a key interest rate.
In Tokyo early today, the Japanese central bank formally announced that it was cutting its discount rate by 3/4 point. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices advanced. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for October delivery gained $2.70 an ounce, to $353.80.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 104.67 yen, from 104.50 yen on Friday, after drifting lower against the Japanese currency for most of the day. In early trading in Tokyo today, the dollar slipped slightly, falling back to 104.50 yen by late morning.
 
 
A SurpriseNews Agencies' Reports'People Are Convinced
 The dollar jumped after Japanese news agencies reported that the Bank of Japan would lower its discount rate to 1.75 percent from 2.5 percent, to keep the country's economy from slipping into recession. The reports surprised currency traders, who had been expecting only a half-point cut.
"People are convinced that the Japanese will cut rates," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. He said traders sold yen to protect themselves from a larger-than-expected rate cut.
Lower interest rates make yen-denominated deposits less attractive, diminishing demand for the currency. A rate cut could also help convince the Clinton Administration that Japan is serious about spurring demand for American exports. That could defuse the trade tensions that sent the yen soaring against the dollar this year.
Traders have been expecting Japan to cut interest rates for weeks. Speculation built last week after the Government announced a $57 billion economic package that appeared to fall short of American expectations.
The Clinton Administration has been pressing Japan to increase its demand for American goods in order to curb a swelling trade surplus.
Investors sold dollars for yen just after the economic package was announced, based on the belief that disappointment with it would lead American Government officials to push for a higher yen as a way to curb the surplus. A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive.
"Any indication that the U.S. will resume its calls for a stronger yen will drive the dollar back down to 101 yen very quickly," Keith Cheveralls, foreign exchange manager at Nippon Credit Bank, said. "The yen is the most politically sensitive currency in the universe right now."
President Clinton and his aides have occasionally endorsed the yen's strength this year, in which the dollar has tumbled as much as 20 percent against the Japanese currency.

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge on Bond Market Weakness

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The stock market took a deep dive yesterday amid weakness in the bond market and apprehension about the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its sharpest daily decline since early April.
"We had a very bad bond market in the afternoon," David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said. "On the stock market side, we have earnings worries. What I've been telling people is that a slow-growth economy is not an earnings-friendly economy."
 
 
Drop in the Afternoon
 After a morning spent basically flat, the Dow Jones industrials dropped steeply all afternoon to close at 3,575.80, down 37.45 points, or 1.04 percent. The Dow Jones transportations were down 4.70 points to close at 1,616.38, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 3.78 points, to 455.05. The American Stock Exchange composite index slipped 1.76 points, to 451.05, and the Nasdaq composite edged up slightly, by one-tenth of a point, to 740.21. 
 Volume was 231.1 million shares, which was not comparable to the 381.4 million shares traded during Friday's triple-witching frenzy, the highest volume on the Big Board since December 1992.
The bond market, which traders said was vulnerable now because of a lack of new significant economic data to give it guidance until Oct. 8, sold off in light trading. Traders spoke of reports of a large seller of 30-year Treasury bonds, profit taking and other factors that sent prices lower. The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.09 percent, its highest level since Aug. 21.
"My sense is that we're in a correction right now," Mr. Shulman of Salomon said of the stock market. "I've been looking for this for a while and I've been wrong. Now, after being bearish and wrong, maybe I'll be bearish and right."
Ned Collins, executive vice president in charge of trading at Daiwa Securities America, said after the close of trading that he was "a little shellshocked."
In addition to the bond market, he said, there was extensive program selling in the afternoon and also some repercussions from the "triple witching" selling of Friday, when three sets of options and futures contracts expired simultaneously. Many of the big firms that closed out contracts came back yesterday morning and took another look at their positions, he said, adding, "It's a very nervous market."
Mr. Collins also said market lore was playing a role in the selling, with a "three-year theory" making its way around Wall Street based on the observation that the market had rough Octobers in 1981, 1984, 1987 and 1990.
"A lot of people are expecting that the same thing will take place this October," he said. "People are saying, 'Let's get out before the bad stuff starts.' "
Mr. Collins anticipates more selling. "I just think that there are too many people that are anticipating this huge correction," he said. "Markets sometimes don't do what we want them to do when we want to do it."
 
 
Blue Chips Hit
 Blue-chip and cyclical stocks were among the biggest decliners. Alcoa was down 2 3/4, to 68 3/4; General Electric fell 3/4, to 97 1/4; Triple M slid 1 3/4, to 106; ITT was down 1 7/8, to 90 3/4, and International Paper dropped 1 1/2, to 61 3/8.
Among technology and related stocks, the story was mixed but negative on balance. Hewlett-Packard was down 2 7/8, to 65; I.B.M. slipped 1 1/8, to 42 1/4, and Compaq lost 1 7/8, to 55 3/4. Intel closed up 7/8, at 65 1/8; Oracle was up 2, to 54 5/8, on a "buy" recommendation from an analyst, and Novell was up 3/4, to 19 3/4. Microsoft declined 3/8, to 75 5/8.
The Paramount-Viacom merger and its attendant news continued to send ripples throug5h the market. The only gainer was Paramount, which closed up 1 1/4, at 69 3/4, after QVC Network said it would top Viacom's offer for Paramount. Others were down, with Viacom closing 5/8 lower, at 59 1/4, and QVC down 3 1/2, to 56.
Buenos Aires Embotelladora S.A., an Argentine soft-drink company, saw its American depository receipts rise 2 3/4 to close at 31 3/8, after it joined with Pepsi-Cola to form a bottling venture. Nike, the shoe maker, was down 1 3/4, to 46 1/4, on a prediction of weaker earnings.
Molten Metal closed up 2 1/2, at 25 1/4, after the company said it had received patent approval from Massachusetts for a recycling research and development facility.
Digital Communications Associates, a maker of data communications equipment, said it was considering an offer to sell the company. The stock closed up 3 1/2, at 17 1/8.

HEADLINE: CUBAN PILOT SAYS MILITARY HAS WOES

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 20

 BODY:
A Cuban Air Force pilot who on Friday defected to the United States said today that the country's economic crisis under Fidel Castro had now grown so severe that the nation's military elite and its equipment, morale and readiness were being hurt.
In an interview and a news conference here, Capt. Enio Ravelo Rodriguez said that one concern that led him to fly a MIG-21 jet trainer to Key West, Fla., from an air base just outside Havana was his fear of a popular revolt in which he would be called upon to fight against his people. Many colleagues, he said, share that same anxiety and are wrestling with their consciences. 
 "It is my belief that no pilot would be capable of taking any action against the Cuban people," Mr. Ravelo said. He described his 13-minute dash across the Florida Straits as "a journey from oppression to liberty."
Since the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991, which deprived the Cuban economy of up to $5 billion a year in subsidies, living conditions on the island have become increasingly austere and difficult. With food, fuel and medicine in short supply, many Cubans spend hours each day foraging for basic necessities and are grumbling with growing boldness about Mr. Castro's 34-year dictatorship.
 
'Barely Enough'
 To reduce those economic and political pressures, Mr. Castro recently announced that Cuban citizens would be allowed to have dollars and use them to buy goods at special stores. But Mr. Ravelo said members of the military had not been included in the decree and were being forced to live in circumstances worse than average citizens with access to dollars.
"We are now the oppressed," he said of Cuba's military, which long enjoyed special privileges as a reward for its role as "guardians of the Cuban Revolution." He said that in his own case the food supplied to his family was "barely enough to maintain them."
Mr. Ravelo, 32, described himself as a veteran of Cuba's war in Angola and said he had twice attended pilot training schools in the former Soviet Union, from 1981 through 1984, and then again in 1987. He left behind his 27-year-old wife, Elisa, and a 2-year-old daughter, Elisa Aura, but he said he hoped they would be allowed to join him in the United States.
He also said that worsening economic conditions had led to a sharp decline in military maintenance standards, since the government could no longer afford to spend the money to keep equipment in top fighting condition. He said that the MIG-21 he had taken on a routine training mission when he flew to the United States was one of many air force planes in that precarious state.
"The level of safety is horrible," he said. But he added that in the event of a military confrontation with the United States, the Cuban Air Force's best planes, the MIG-29, would be ready for combat.

HEADLINE: Japan Cuts Discount Rate 3/4 Point to 1 3/4%

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 21

 BODY:
In an unexpectedly aggressive move, the Bank of Japan this morning cut its official discount rate 3/4 point to the lowest level in history, 1 3/4 percent.
The central bank said it made the decision, which was formally announced before the financial markets opened here, because Japan's slumping economy "is still in a stagnant state." The bank had been expected to cut the rate this month, but only 1/2 point. 
 This is the seventh time the discount rate has been cut since July 1991, when Japan started slipping into recession. By contrast, the discount rate is 3 percent in the United States and 6 1/4 percent in Germany.
Japan's Government has been under severe pressure from the nation's business community to take action to stimulate the economy. The United States has also been pushing Japan to take pump-priming measures to help the world economy and to increase imports to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus.
The pressure intensified in the last two weeks as a survey by the Bank of Japan showed that business sentiment had fallen to its lowest level in nearly two decades and as the Government reported that Japan's gross national product had contracted by an annual rate of 2 percent in the quarter ended in June.
Still, cutting the discount rate, which is the interest level charged by the central bank when it lends money to commercial banks, is likely to have only a moderate effect in bringing about an economic recovery. Theoretically, with interest rates at unprecedented low levels, businesses will borrow more money to invest. Capital spending by businesses has been on a long decline.
But many Japanese companies, including automobile, steel and electric appliance makers, are being hurt by excess production capacity and might not need to borrow money anyway.
"It's not going to spur investment very much because there's too much excess capacity already," said Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Tokyo. He said, however, that the discount rate cut would help the economy somewhat by saving companies money on interest expenses, giving them more money to spend on wages.
The cut in the discount rate should spur commercial banks to lower their short-term prime rates by another 1/2 point from their current levels of 3 3/4 percent, Mr. Feldman said.
Paul A. Summerville, director of Asian research for Lehman Brothers, said that the central bank still had room to make another rate cut early next year. That is becuase inflation is low and downward pressure is being exerted on prices by the rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar, which makes oil and other imported products less expensive for the Japanese.
Last week, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa announced Japan's third emergency economic stimulus package in 13 months. The new effort consists of about $57 billion of increased public spending, business incentives and low-interest loans for housing.

JAPANESE STOCKS JUMP
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Japanese stocks were trading higher here today on news that the Bank of Japan had cut the discount rate. In midday trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 263.32 points, or 1.3 percent, at 20,529.35. On Monday, the Nikkei lost 125.01 points, or six-tenths of a percent, on top of a 111.11-point loss on Friday.
In trading in here earlier today, the dollar slipped slightly to 104.50 yen.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pesticide Plan Would Cut Use

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
After decades of scientific disputes and political strife over the safety of pesticides, the Clinton Administration will ask Congress to reduce sharply the amount of toxic chemicals used in American agriculture, forestry and other industries.
The Administration's plan, which was put together by three Federal agencies and will be proposed to Congress on Tuesday, calls for the Government to change the fundamental basis of it regulation of toxic chemicals used to kill weeds and insects and stop plant diseases. 
 Federal law requires that the potential risks of pesticides to health and the environment must be weighed against the economic benefits of their use. And until now, the Government tended to give more weight to economic arguments and data, generally putting the protection of crops and farmers' incomes ahead of public health.
 
Changing Standards of Proof
 The Clinton Administration's plan, parts of which were made available by Administration officials, calls for the Government to begin reversing that tendency and putting the safety of consumers first. Administration officials said that change would come about by lowering the standards of legal and scientific proof that must be used to demonstrate that a pesticide poses ahazard.
The plan also appears destined to put the Clinton Administration into a head-on confrontation with some influential political groups, including environmental advocates, the chemical industry, farmers and timber companies.
In part to build support among those groups, the Administration is also proposing to relax another pesticide rule, the Delaney Clause of the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act. The Delaney Clause outlaws any pesticides that have concentrated in processed foods and have also been shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals.
Last year, environmentalists won a court decision requiring the Government to interpret the law strictly and begin removing dozens of pesticides from the market.
 
A Major Departure
 The net effect of both moves, if approved, would be to control the use of pesticides more stringently as they are applied, with the goal that such rules would sufficiently limit the concentrations of pesticides that could eventually appear in food and water. Such an approach is a departure from the thinking that has shaped policy since chemical pesticides came to be widely used in agriculture and forestry in the late 1940's. To put that change into effect would require the Administration to win the votes in Congress to amend the two Federal laws regulating pesticides, as well as taking a number of administrative actions.
A senior Administration official called the plan "the best attempt in 20 years for a breakthrough on food safety reform." The official added, "We undoubtedly will take some flak from various interest groups but we plan to prevail because of the pressing need to overhaul an antiquated system."
Jay Vroom, the president of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association, a Washington-based group that represents the pesticide industry, which has $6 billion a year in sales, said he was nervous about the plans for more easily removing pesticides from the market. "But that may be the price we pay for getting what we want, which is a change in the Delaney Clause," he said.
Jay Feldman, the executive director of the National Coalition Against the Misuse of Pesticides, an environmental group, said conservationists would generally support the Administration's goal of reducing the amount of pesticides applied to the land. But environmentalists are also adamantly opposed to any change in the Delaney Clause and are likely to press for new provisions to encourage farm and forestry practices that do not use pesticides.
"You can congratulate the Administration for taking on an issue that is extremely controversial," Mr. Feldman said. "But you can fault them for failing to establish a system that questions the need for using pesticides altogether."
 
Added Risk to Children
 The Administration's plan comes three months after the National Academy of Sciences published a study saying that children may be at risk from exposure to trace levels of pesticides found not only in foods but also in products used in lawn care, restaurants and schools as well as in household bug killers.
The Environmental Protection Agency and the National Agricultural Chemicals Association say that between 800 million and 1 billion pounds of some 600 pesticide ingredients are used each year. Roughly 300 pesticides are applied to the land to protect much of the nation's grain, vegetable and fruit crops. The other 300 are used in industry, forestry, lawn care and the like.
The Clinton Administration's plan is largely a collection of proposals that the interest groups, Congress, the National Academy of Sciences and several previous administrations have discussed over the last decade.
The Department of Agriculture, the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency cooperated in putting the package together, which is largely directed toward amending the Federal Insecticide Fungicide and Rodenticide Act, the nation's pesticide control law.
 
Uncertainty and Money
 The centerpiece of the law is a provision that requires the Government to prove that a pesticide poses "an unreasonable adverse affect" on health or the environment before it can be removed from the market. The Government also must weigh that unreasonable affect against the economic benefits pesticides have for both farmers and consumers.
Because such a finding is fraught with both scientific uncertainties and important political and financial consequences, the Government has taken action to remove pesticides from the market only a handful of times in the last two decades.
The Clinton Administration proposes to reduce the levels of proof needed to show a pesticide is dangerous and to change the legal procedures for banning compounds. For instance, the law requires that if a chemical company protests, the Government put its case before an administrative law judge before it can remove a chemical, a procedure that has taken as long as four years.
The Clinton Administration's plan would eliminate that requirement and allow the Government to remove or restrict chemicals through administrative decisions.
 
Program to Cut Use
 The plan also calls for broader research and education programs to encourage farmers to cut in half the amount of pesticides used on roughly 300 million acres of cropland. The Administration said it hoped to meet that goal by the end of the decade.
Under the plan, the E.P.A. is given the principal responsibility for establishing new procedures for setting safety limits for pesticides in food. Such limits would be set up to protect children, taking into consideration the National Academy of Sciences finding that children are especially vulnerable to exposures to pesticides. The current safety standards are outmoded and largely designed to protect adults.
All three agencies are to cooperate in designing a new study of the nation's eating habits to determine which foods may pose the greatest risk.
And the Food and Drug Administration would be given more authority to seize foods found to have pesticides exceeding Federal safety standards.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally Appears to Near End

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market gave its strongest signal to date yesterday that the rally that pushed yields to their lowest level in 25 years could be over.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 24/32 of a point. And its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.09 percent, its highest level since Aug. 21, and up from 6.04 on Friday. 
 Since prices dropped sharply last Tuesday after a disappointing increase in August consumer prices, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped almost a quarter of a percentage point from a 25-year low of 5.86 percent. Yields on Treasury notes, from 10 years to 2 years, also rose as their prices declined.
The selloff in the bond market spread quickly to the stock market, driving down the Dow Jones industrial average 37.45 points, to 3,575.80, the steepest one-day drop since early April. [Page D8.]
 
 
No Resiliency
 There was no resiliency in the bond market yesterday as there was last week. Although prices moved down and yields rose after Tuesday's report of a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index, the market seemed able to bounce back each day after sharp price drops in the morning.
But while these and other signals are raising doubts about the future of the bond market rally, some analysts and traders are not ready to say it is over. They note that trading yesterday was very light, making big swings in the market likely. They pointed to the report of one large seller of 30-year bonds. They talked of profit taking and technical selling connected to the 30-year bond future contract and to the fact that the Treasury is auctioning $16 billion of two-year notes today and $11 billion of five-year notes tomorrow.
Ronald Connors, the Government trading manager at Bear, Stearns & Company, put his conflicting feelings on the market this way: First, he said: "I am not saying the bull market is coming to an end; it is still too early too tell that. It is still in a corrective phase."
Then, he added: "I am predisposed to being bearish on the market. There is so much good news in the market that it is subject to a reversal here."
Alan Levenson, a money market economist at UBS Securities, agreed with Mr. Connors that it would take new reports of economic weakness and low inflation to prompt new buying. "If the rally is not over, it will need fresh news to pick up steam again," he said. But the September employment report will not be released until Oct. 8, with the inflation data coming out the next week, leaving the market little direction until then.
At the same time, Mr. Levenson said that because longer-term interest rates were still significantly higher than short-term rates, there would be plenty of portfolio managers and individual investors who would want to buy longer-term securities to get higher yields, and this should give some support to prices.
David Ader, an analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the results of his survey of portfolio managers every two weeks made him feel a little more confident about the market outlook.
He said that managers indicated that they took the bond market's sell-off over the last week as as a positive correction after a strong rally without any real pause. And they indicated that with prices at their current levels, they were likely to use the cash on hand to buy Treasury notes and securities on further declines.
 
 
Portuguese Notes
 The rush of foreigners into the American market to raise money at low interest rates continued yesterday, with a $1 billion sale of 10-year notes by the Government of Portugal.
The sale is a global issue, which means it is sold simultaneously in the United States, Europe and Asia and can be traded in any of those markets.
The deal comes on the heals of a $3.5 billion sale last week of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds by Italy, as more European countries move to raise money in international markets. The sales were both firsts for Italy and Portugal.
Companies are also taking this route, as shown by the $27.7 billion in corporate bonds sold so far this year, according to Securities Data Company. The total so far this year is just below the $28.3 billion for all of last year and is greater than the sales in 1991 and 1990.
Manuel A. Pinho, the Director General of the Treasury of Portugal, said that the Government was doing a global issue to widen the investor base for Portugal and to "raise our profile in international markets."
Several investors at the road show presentations the Government did, he said, knew almost nothing about Portugal. He said that one money manager told him after after a presentation, "I thought Portugal was only a country of golf course and vinho verde," a light white wine with a slight sparkle.
The 10-year notes were priced to yield 5.83 percent, which is 45 basis points over the yield on the 10-year Treasury note at the time of the sale. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
While Portugal has a credit rating just slightly below that of Italy, the spread over the rate on the 10-year Treasury note was much narrower, a probable reflection of the severe political and economic difficulties in Italy. At the time of the sale last week, the Italian 10-year notes had a yield of 6.02 percent, 60 basis points over the yield on the 10-year Treasury note.
The spread was also lower than that on the other major global issues by European governments this year, including Sweden.

HEADLINE: Plan Offered By Giuliani On Hospitals

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Citing efforts to scale back government in cities and states across the country, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, proposed yesterday that the city shift control of as many as four municipal hospitals to nonprofit groups.
In a breakfast speech to a forum of business groups, he also said Kennedy International Airport should be turned over to private concerns. 
 His suggestions, part of a speech on fiscal policy, came on a day when Mr. Giuliani and Mayor David N. Dinkins sparred over the state of the city's economy and how to stem the loss of more than 350,000 private-sector jobs over the last five years. Later in the morning, Mr. Giuliani was endorsed by the 2,000-member union representing housing police officers, which supported Mr. Dinkins in 1989.
The Mayor, trying to highlight his own proposal to help create 110,000 jobs over a second term, went to West 47th Street in the diamond district yesterday to announce creation of a public corporation to help the jewelry industry with job training, improved security and expanded exporting.
 
Scaling Back Government
 Mr. Giuliani reiterated proposals to reduce the size of the city government through attrition and a 10 percent cut in the staff of the mayor and the comptroller, to encourage a state takeover of some city services and to reduce certain taxes.
He also suggested that the city experiment with privatization. Although Mr. Giuliani's running mate for comptroller, Herman Badillo, has called for all 11 of the acute-care hospitals under the jurisdiction of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation to be privatized, Mr. Giuliani offered a more cautious approach.
"You can't privatize all of them all at once," he said. "It wouldn't be realistic. There wouldn't be a buyer around. It probably wouldn't make sense." But he said two to four hospitals could be put under the control of nonprofit groups.
"It will give confidence that that can be done without people having their lives changed," he said.
He predicted that the experiment would save money and "deliver considerably better and more humane services." William J. Grinker, an adviser to Mr. Giuliani, said more details of the hospital proposal would be released in a health policy paper.
Privatization of city hospitals and airports has been explored, but not put into effect by various city and state officials before. But complications as well as policy questions arise, such as the fact that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a lease for the city's airports through the year 2015.
 
'Like Selling Yellowstone'
 Leland T. Jones, Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, said the revenues raised for the city by hospital sales would be minimal because the city would still have to pay its share of Medicaid costs. He added that privatization of health-care centers also raised questions of access. "It's like selling Yellowstone National Park," he said. "Right now it's open to anyone who can get there. If you sell Yellowstone -- a traditional Republican proposal -- it may be open to only those who can pay."
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dinkins also sparred over Mr. Giuliani's comment to the business forum that he had learned from President George Bush's mistakes and would not pledge never to raise taxes. "You're not going to hear me say, 'Read my lips,' because I don't know and you don't know what we face," he said.
In the diamond district, Mr. Dinkins said: "'He should take a George Bush approach. All the rest of his approaches are George Bush-like."
The Mayor, in remarks before about 40 industry officials at the Diamond Dealers Club, repeatedly called attention to the importance of the diamond and jewelry industries to New York's economy.
 
Lighting and Security
 But the actual commitment of city money to help the industries was modest. The Mayor said the city would contribute $35,000 to help set up the development corporation. The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, also set aside $780,000 in the city's capital budget last June to repair West 47th Street and provide improved lighting and security.
Mr. Dinkins was joined at the meeting with industry leaders by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who lauded Mr. Dinkins, calling him at one point "the finest Mayor that any city in America has ever had."
But while talking generally about the Clinton Administration's commitment to New York City, Mr. Brown offered no concrete Federal help for the jewelry industry.

HEADLINE: A Sluggish Forecast by Economists

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Finding little evidence that tumbling interest rates are about to perk up a lackluster economy, a panel of business economists predicted today that growth would edge up to 2.7 percent next year from an expected 2.3 percent in 1993, too little to dent the current unemployment rate of 6.7 percent.
"I think you can describe it as slow growth as far as the eye can see," said William C. Dunkelberg, vice president of the National Association of Business Economists, presenting the group's forecast at its annual meeting, which began here today. 
 The 41 economists on the association's panel also contended after examining housing, capital investment and other interest-rate-sensitive sectors that rates had been falling because the financial markets expected a continued weak economy -- not because "lower interest rates will make a weak economy strong."
Today's forecast was even lower than that predicted by the preceding survey in May, in which 1993 growth, fourth quarter to fourth quarter, was projected at 2.8 percent and 1994 growth at 3 percent.
One reason for the relative pessimism among the business economists was that they believed the recently enacted Federal budget plan would achieve savings through 1998 of $125 billion, just a quarter of the $500 billion expected by the Administration.
When Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's top economic adviser, was asked about this after delivering a luncheon address, she declared that it was impossible to determine what contribution the budget deal had made to lowering rates or even to prove that its more important effect would be to cut the Government's demand for money rather than to slow the economy.
But repeating earlier assertions, Ms. Tyson said, "The best counter-argument to that is the strength of the stock market," which has hit new highs in recent weeks before retreating somewhat of late.
 
Defends Trade Pact
 In her address, Ms. Tyson made a strenuous defense of the pending expansion of the North American Free Trade Agreement to Mexico, noting that two dozen studies of the accord had predicted that it would mean a net growth in jobs. She asserted that the liberalization of Mexican policy in the last seven years had already helped transform an American trade deficit into a surplus and had tripled United States exports to Mexico, with benefits to a wide range of industries.
She also said the job losses among American workers under the accord would be "very small," at most 200,000 over 10 years.
At a morning presentation, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Robert T. Parry, disputed commonly offered assessments of the nation's trade situation and assertions that the trade deficit, which he characterized as not necessarily bad, was a meaningful gauge of American competitiveness.
"I do not think the trade deficit is due to lower wages, superior technology and unfair trade practices abroad," Mr. Parry said. "On the contrary, I think we can find the sources of the trade deficit in certain macroeconomic fundamentals -- namely our own Government budget deficit and our investment and savings patterns."
On other subjects, Ms. Tyson said a plan disclosed by the Concord Coalition today to eliminate the budget deficit entirely was a "draconian" threat to economic growth. The group was founded last year by Peter G. Peterson, a former Commerce Secretary who is chairman of the Blackstone Group, and former Senators Paul E. Tsongas and Warren B. Rudman to prod politicians to address the Federal budget deficit head on.
And after her news conference, Ms. Tyson said she did not know of any decision that the Administration had made on the size of taxes on tobacco or alcohol that are expected to be part of its health care program that will be announced on Wednesday night.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Sees Free-Trade Boon

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
As the showdown nears in Washington over the fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement, it is no surprise that Caterpillar Inc. has been one of the strongest corporate voices in favor of the treaty.
From its base in this small city in central Illinois, Caterpillar has grown into the largest construction equipment maker in the world. It derives more than half its sales from exports. And it has a reputation as a company that has never seen a free trade proposal it didn't like. 
 The executives of Caterpillar sound like much of corporate America when they confidently echo the Government's claims about how beneficial Nafta could be for the American economy. But they are even more enthusiastic when talking about how Caterpillar stands to benefit.
In all, Caterpillar estimates that Nafta could help it sell an additional 350 pieces of equipment like bulldozers, tractors, and backhoes in Mexico each year. That would add $45 million a year to its Mexican revenues, on top of the $200 million that it already books. (Caterpillar reported $10.2 billion in total revenues last year)
That sales increase would be accomplished in two ways. First, Caterpillar is counting on Nafta to stimulate the Mexican economy, which in turn should lift the demand for all construction equipment, expanding one of Caterpillar's fastest-growing markets even more. "Mexico needs infrastructure and that plays to our strength," said Timothy L. Elder, the director of government affairs for Caterpillar.
In addition, rolling back the Mexican tariffs on American goods should allow Caterpillar to expand its market share in Mexico at the expense of Komatsu Ltd., and other Asian and European importers who will still be subject to Mexican tariffs.
Caterpillar said its exports to Mexico translates into jobs for 1,300 of its employees and 2,700 jobs for suppliers. But the company's executives conceded that actual employment levels reflected a wide range of operating concerns and could not be pinpointed with any specificity to the level or mix of sales to Mexico.
Over the long term, Caterpillar hopes Nafta will serve as a harbinger of lower trade barriers throughout Latin America. But the shorter term advantages alone are enough to convince the company that its interests are best served by the trade pact.
As things stand now, Caterpillar tractors and bulldozers built across the Illinois River from here in East Peoria face a 10 percent tariff going into Mexico. The company's marine engines, manufactured a few miles up the river in Mossville, Ill., must overcome a 15 percent tariff barrier, and its excavators, built outside Chicago in Aurora, Ill., face a 20 percent tariff. Nafta would eliminate all those barriers immediately and phase out similar duties on other Caterpillar products in five to 10 years.
 
More Flexibility
 Without those tariffs artificially inflating prices, Caterpillar said it would have the flexibility to either roll back prices to build market share or keep prices where they were and enjoy fatter profit margins. Caterpillar executives said the decisions about whether to use its Nafta-based cost advantage to expand the margins or to cut prices would be made on a product-by-product basis.
Either way, Donald Fites, the chairman and chief executive of Caterpillar, said he believed some Mexican customers were hoping the big equipment maker chose the former route. They have held back orders on the hope that Nafta would pass, allowing Caterpillar to give them a price break.
Even without Nafta, sales of Caterpillar products to Mexico have surged since the Salinas Government began reducing tariffs and easing spending restrictions that had been imposed in the early 1980's to reduce the debt burden in Mexico. Caterpillar sold just 11 machines to Mexico in 1983. Last year the total had jumped to 1,200.
 
Loss of Confidence
 But if Nafta is defeated, the prospects for Caterpillar in Mexico are much less certain. "If Nafta fails to pass, I would expect the growth to slow if not go the other way," said Mr. Elder, explaining that the setback might cause some to lose confidence in the Mexican economy.
Something Nafta will not do, Caterpillar executives said, is send American jobs to Mexico. To be sure, the treaty would also eliminate American tariffs ranging from 2.5 percent to 4 percent on construction equipment made in Mexico, making manufacturing south of the border for export to the United States slightly cheaper than it is now. But Caterpillar argues that the elimination of the far higher tariffs on exports to Mexico tilts the playing field further toward manufacturing its equipment in the United States.
"If we had an incentive to move there, it would have been exercised already," Mr. Elder said.
 
Strained Union Relations
 In fact, Caterpillar set up a manufacturing plant near Monterrey, Mexico, in the early 1980's when Mexican import restrictions cut off most exports from Illinois. Employment there has actually declined to 1,200 workers from 1,700 as Mexico relaxed the restrictions. But a good portion of the decline was related to the transfer last year of the company's forklift operations to a venture with Mitsubishi rather than the greater efficiency of American production, Mr. Elder said.
No amount of reassurance or lobbying is likely to generate support for the treaty among Caterpillar's unionized work force, which is represented by the United Automobile Workers. The U.A.W., like other unions, said it believed the treaty would accelerate the flow of jobs from the United States to Mexico and be used by management as another hammer in bargaining over wages and benefits in this country. Caterpillar's relations with the union have been particularly strained since the two sides failed to settle on a new contract last year and Caterpillar forced workers to call off a strike and return to work on its terms.
 
Half-Hearted Effort
 "This is as much of a threat to a Caterpillar worker as any other," said James B. O'Conner, a U.A.W. official at Caterpillar. "It's just not going to happen here over night."
Caterpillar has distributed some materials attempting to win support among the workers for Nafta, but the effort has been half-hearted. Company officials said the workers who supported its position were scared into silence by the union's outspoken opposition. Caterpillar has campaigned to drum up support among other employees, suppliers and customers, and the 252-member Nafta Illinois coalition.
A telling indication of the size of the gulf with the production workers came when Mr. Elders was asked whether the side provisions on environmental and other issues in the pact might contain language that could offset many of the financial benefits Caterpillar saw in Nafta.
"We haven't had a good chance to analyze the side agreements yet but the reassuring thing is that organized labor says they are horrible," Mr. Elder said.
 
'Symmetrical Exaggerations'
 In truth, there is no simple way to separate the potential gains and losses that might stem from Nafta from larger issues like the huge gap in wage rates that already exists between the United States and Mexico. That gap has already induced American companies to move hundreds of thousands of jobs south of the border and will continue to attract them whether or not Nafta passes.
"There are symmetrical exaggerations from both sides," said Thea Lee, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute, a research center in Washington that has been generally critical of Nafta. "The Administration talks only about the new jobs related to exports without taking into account those displace by imports. But Ross Perot talks only about the latter."

HEADLINE: Despite Support of Pact, An Uncertainty Lingers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Caterpillar is unusual among the corporate supporters of Nafta in its willingness to put a dollar estimate on the gains it expects.
Other corporate executives also support Nafta by an overwhelming margin, even though they are hard-pressed to project with any confidence what will happen. 
 Most endorse the general premise that Nafta will stimulate Mexico's economy enough to help the United States, that it will help the United States become more competitive in Latin America, and could spur acceptance in Europe and Japan of other free trade agreements that would boost American exports.
That consensus is one reason that a recent survey, conducted by Caterpillar's engine division, of top shipping and logistics executives at the 500 largest companies, found three of four assumed Nafta would lead to economic growth that would expand trucking and other distribution activities. A similar proportion, however, were unsure of how their own companies would be affected.
 
A Small Market
 Much of the haziness about the value of Nafta is because Mexico, a country with an economy about the size of the Chicago-Milwaukee region, is still a relatively small market for American manufacturers.
However uncertain the benefits, by the time the negotiators finished with the 2,000-page text last year, few industries faced risks large enough to create strong opposition among executives.
The textile industry, for instance, is in danger of losing some of its production to Mexico under Nafta. And yet many leading textile and apparel manufacturers now favor the treaty. They expect Asian textile companies, with which Mexico will compete for the lower end of the market, to be even bigger losers. Meanwhile the prospects for sending American textiles and raw materials into Mexico could improve sharply.
"We would not be supporting the agreement if we thought that it would jeopardize our investment here," said Ronald J. Sorini, the senior vice president for international development at Fruit of the Loom Inc. The apparel maker, based in Chicago, has more than 30,000 employees in the Southeastern United States and spent more than $250 million to upgrade domestic production last year.
 
Divided Views
 The appliance industry shows how the wording of specific provisions has divided views about the pact. Maytag, Amana, and Frigidaire are among the appliance makers that object to the phased removal of the 20 percent Mexican appliance tariff over a 10-year period, especially since the 2.8 percent to 5.1 percent American tariffs are eliminated immediately.
The companies say it unfairly rewards rivals like General Electric and Whirlpool for their big investments in joint ventures with Mexican appliance companies.
"We are being penalized by Nafta for having invested in the United States," said Douglass Horstmann, the director for government affairs for Maytag. G.E., for its part, said it supported the immediate removal of all tariffs but was only a minority partner in the Mexican venture and did not control its lobbying.
Whirlpool said it supported the phased reduction of the Mexican tariffs to prevent the Mexican industry from being wiped out by American competition.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
First-Quarter Nike Income Declined 7%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
For all their help hawking shoes and athletic gear for Nike Inc., Michael Jordan, Andre Agassi and other celebrities were powerless against unfavorable currency exchange rates, sluggish European economies and changes in United States tax laws.
Because of those factors, the athletic apparel company said yesterday, earnings for the first quarter fell 7 percent, to $114.1 million, or $1.49 a share, compared with the corresponding period last year. 
 Company officials said the decline was likely to continue, and that there would be layoffs to cut expenses.
The news hurt Nike stock, which fell $1.75 to close at a 52-week low of $46.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
In discussing the company's performance during an hourlong telephone conference and in a statement issued from his Beaverton, Ore., office, Nike's chairman, Philip H. Knight, painted a gloomy picture for the fiscal quarters ahead.
"Because of these variables and because continued caution by U.S. retailers and sluggish international economies have caused future orders for the next five months to total less than last year, we now believe earnings for fiscal 1994 will not match the record sales and income reported in fiscal 1993," he said in the statement.
While revenues for the quarter improved 1 percent, to $1.1 billion, a company record, sales were off internationally, the company's key growth area. Nike said that footwear sales outside the United States fell by 10 percent and apparel sales fell by 13 percent.
Further, worldwide orders for both categories scheduled for delivery between now and January were 4 percent lower than they were for the corresponding period last year.
The company said that if exchange rates for the dollar had remained constant over the year, the decrease would have been only 1 percent.
Company officials also told analysts that domestic orders for the next quarter were off by 10 percent, "a stunning figure," said Willard Brown of Dean Witter in Boston. "There was no way I could have forecast that," he said. "I thought they would have had flat sales. They got creamed."
The company said the earnings also reflected the 1 percent increase in corporate tax, retroactive to Jan. 1, passed by Congress last month as part of the deficit reduction package, and a one-time accounting charge.
In an attempt to stem some of the downward trends, Mr. Knight told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the company would lay off up to 4 percent of its 10,000 workers worldwide. In so doing, he said, the company could cut expenses by $50 million for the rest of the current fiscal year, which ends May 31, 1994.

HEADLINE: Digital to Cut German Jobs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation's German unit said today that it would cut 1,300 jobs in 1994 in an apparent effort to slash expenses against a background of tumbling earnings.
In a statement, the unit, Digital Equipment Deutschland G.m.b.H., said about 21 percent of its 6,200-member work force would be eliminated. 
 Digital said in August that it would shut a plant in Kaufbeuren, Germany, to cut excess capacity, putting 600 people out of work. In the last year, Digital has announced the closing of a number of plants in the United States as well as a production site in Ireland.
The Digital-Kienzle Computersysteme unit, based in Villingen with 2,600 employees, will bear the brunt of the reductions, the statement said. Digital's operations at the German headquarters, which has 3,600 workers, will also be subject to some reductions. Digital has 94,200 employees worldwide, with 33,000 in Europe.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Jumps as Cut in Output Is Expected at OPEC Talks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged yesterday amid expectations that OPEC will cut production and that the unseasonably cool weather in the Northeast will lead to greater demand for heating oil.
Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will gather on Saturday in Geneva to set fourth-quarter production levels and to discuss ways to push up the price of crude. Prices are near their lowest point in three years, and OPEC will be forced to limit production to keep them from falling further, traders said. 
 "Everyone's a little spooked" by OPEC and the coming meeting, said a trader with Pioneer Futures in New York. In the meantime, he said, prices "might go a little higher, but not much."
OPEC produces 37 percent of the world's oil. Overproduction by the group's members and slow economic growth have caused prices to fall recently.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for October delivery gained 63 cents to settle at $17.70 a barrel. October heating oil rose 1.81 cents, to 53.73 a gallon, and October unleaded gasoline rose 1.39 cents, to 50.27 cents a gallon. October natural gas gained 2.8 cents to settle $2.193 per million British thermal units.
Record low temperatures in New York City yesterday also helped push prices higher, as hopes rose that the winter would be cold and demand for heating oil would increase.
"It's a reminder, and people want to get started early," said Peter Leavitt, vice president of Weather Services Inc. in Bedford, Mass. To be sure, it's still too early to tell how cold winter will be, he said.
On other commodity markets, copper prices tumbled to their lowest level in six years after unusually strong demand for delivered copper in London eased suddenly on Friday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for December delivery fell 1.6 cent, to 77.05 cents a pound.
Traders said heavy demand for copper in London had lifted prices above realistic levels, and when that demand eased, prices fell to reflect bulging stockpiles and slow economic growth.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A campaign for Puerto Rico tries to redefine the island as more than a 'West Side Story' lyric.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
"WEST SIDE STORY" still has Puerto Rico's tourism officials asking a question posed in "The Sound of Music": "How do you solve a problem like Maria?"
The problem is that attitudes about Puerto Rico created by Maria, Bernardo, Anita and the rest of the characters from the stage musical and film versions of "West Side Story" continue to plague Puerto Rico, the tourism officials ruefully concede. 
 More than three decades after the Sharks rumbled and danced in iridescent outfits and stiletto heels, Stephen Sondheim's pointed lyrics still sting; for instance, "Puerto Rico, you ugly island, island of tropic diseases" and "Always the hurricanes blowing, always the population growing."
"There is that image Puerto Rico is 'West Side Story,' " said Manuel R. De Juan, deputy director of marketing and operations at the Puerto Rico Tourism Company, a Government-financed agency in San Juan responsible for marketing tourism. "We've found it in Germany, we've found it in Japan."
The objective, he added, is to replace negative perceptions with positive images of the island as "a place where you can have a world-class experience, whether on vacation, or to do business, or to live."
To that end, the tourism company is sharply increasing its annual advertising and public relations budget, to $20 million for 1993-94 from $13 million for 1992-93. And beginning this week, it is introducing a campaign created by its new agency that seeks to dispel old inaccurate impressions by creating a new inaccurate one.
The trick to the new campaign, by Marti, Flores, Prieto & Wachtel in San Juan, is that it relabels Puerto Rico a continent rather than an island. "Only a continent could offer so many great vacation experiences," the broadcast and print campaign asserts. "Only Puerto Rico puts it all within your reach."
"We want people to think of us as more than just another island" of beckoning beaches, said Steve Wachtel, president at Marti, Flores, who joined Mr. De Juan last week in New York to offer a preview of the campaign.
"Sun and sand are the table stakes for the Caribbean," he added. "You have that, or you're not in the game. But no one has ever communicated that idea of variety."
So the campaign ranges far beyond beaches into realms like nature ("the only tropical rain forest in the U.S. national forest system"), culture, heritage ("historic Old San Juan"), dining, shopping, scenery and sports.
"The Government is hellbent on making Puerto Rico one of the premier tourist destinations," Mr. De Juan said. "Part of our mandate is to make tourism a spearhead of economic growth."
"We want to double the contribution of tourism to our gross domestic product," he added, "from 6 percent to 12 percent. And doubling any business requires focusing single-mindedly."
Hence the campaign's conceit that Puerto Rico is not merely an island. If reclassifying an island as a continent sends geography teachers into paroxyms of indignation, so much the better; the clangorous outcry by grammarians against "Winston tastes good like a cigarette should" helped make that campaign one of the most talked about of the 1950's and 1960's.
"It's a way of shaking up people and saying 'Your perception is incorrect,' " Mr. Wachtel acknowledged. (Or as Mr. Sondheim wrote in a song for another musical, "Gypsy," "Ya gotta have a gimmick.")
The campaign by Marti, Flores, an affiliate of J. Walter Thompson, replaces long-running ads by Badillo/ Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in San Juan, the tourist company's previous agency, in which the actor Raul Julia called Puerto Rico "the shining star of the Caribbean."
"It was good at positioning us as a world-class destination," Mr. Wachtel said, "but didn't give us a specific personality." Mr. De Juan grumbled that in comparing Puerto Rico to Monaco, Scotland and other popular vacation spots, "we felt the ads said, 'The standard of quality is X, but you can also get it in Puerto Rico.' "
"Besides," he added, laughing, "they were mentioning my competition."
The Marti, Flores campaign will be introduced tomorrow at a promotional event in Times Square, as the commercials play on Sony Video One, the Jumbotron screen at One Times Square; they start running next Monday in 11 markets including Boston, Chicago, Dallas/Fort Worth, Los Angeles, Miami and New York. On Friday, the campaign's print portion begins with a 10-page advertising insert in USA Today.
Among those invited to the promotional event are Mayor David N. Dinkins; Pedro Rosello, the Governor of Puerto Rico, and Chita Rivera -- who is, of course, not only the star of the Broadway musical "Kiss of the Spider Woman" but also the original Anita in "West Side Story."

HEADLINE: Patterns;
A trade show challenges the runway A Ghost apart Tina Chow, the collector.

BYLINE: By Amy M. Spindler

 BODY:

A Challenger to the Runway
Runway shows may look like great theater to outsiders, but their validity is constantly being challenged. No one buys from the strobe-flashed catwalks anyway. The real business is done not from gilded chairs, but from folding ones, in trade shows and showrooms. 
 These days, the shows are more a photo opportunity and the mere raising of the curtain on another selling season.
Now, an upstart trade show is challenging even that idea. Some of Paris's avant-garde designers broke their collections in -- quel horreur -- New York this week.
Buyers got their first taste of the coming season on Sunday, when the New York Premier Collections show opened at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center two weeks before the spring ready-to-wear presentations are to begin in Milan.
The stew was thin, though. The most directional designers offered, generally, only bits and pieces of what they'll show for spring 1994. For some, it whetted the appetite. Others left with their stomachs rumbling.
The event, sponsored by Blenheim Fashion Shows Inc. and to end today, is an ambitious attempt to give buyers the jump on collections that have not yet been presented in the fashion capitals, and to give foreign designers a crack at American buyers who are not venturing overseas in the current economy.
For the forward-thinking, the show's timing presents several problems. Many boutiques still do not want to buy before seeing what style dictators in Europe propose. Designers risk being copied when exposing their ideas in advance of the runway season. And once buyers see a designer's wares at a trade show, the theater and surprise of a runway presentation are dulled considerably.
The American designer Kalinka, perched in her booth, said she had seen some new accounts. "Sales and shows are two different things, and sales come first," she said. "You show a touch of spring here, and then kill them on the runway."
Kenneth Richard was so unhappy about showing his hand this early that he pulled his collection from the trade show on Monday.
At least he turned up. Many of the most publicized participants were no-shows: Mark Eisen, Christian Francis Roth, Thierry Mugler, Robert Clergerie and Richard Tyler.
Retailers had mixed reactions. "I don't feel like we've gotten any guidance or direction here," said Bill Loya, who owns a boutique in Salt Lake City. "I expected more European designers with a great taste level, and I haven't found them."
But Maria Luisa Poumaillou, the owner of Maria Luisa, one of Europe's most directional stores, was upbeat about the show. She is considering opening a Maria Luisa shop in New York, and she saw some Americans in their studios: Todd Oldham, Byron Lars, Morgan Le Faye and Anna Sui. Ms. Poumaillou stashed seven Anna Sui flowered dresses in her luggage for her Rue Cambon boutique in Paris. "For me, Todd Oldham is great, because he was not at all concerned with this poor look everyone is doing," she said.
Ms. Poumaillou liked the early timing of New York Premier Collections. "After the French shows, there's not a single centime left," she said.
Marshall Lester, the chief executive of Blenheim's United States apparel division, said that he was satisfied with the show's first day and that he expected the event to evolve by next season. "Most Americans are still learning how to utilize a show like this," he said. "We're giving them something out of the ordinary."
 
Chance of a Ghost
 Ghost will be the lone London house on the New York runway schedule in October. But its designer, Tanya Sarne, is used to standing apart.
For 10 years, she's been making minimalistic dresses, when so many of her peers have been trussing women up in spandex.
"I've never liked stretchy clothes," said Ms. Sarne, reached in London. "I feel very encased. I don't like being put into clothes being made by middle-aged men. I know what I want to wear, but I don't think a man knows what I want to wear. I've always liked unstructured clothes that are comfortable, that I can work in and wash in the washing machine."
Ms. Sarne and Katharine Hamnett were each designing their own collections when they joked that they should team up and start a ghost-authored line. She ended up doing it alone, and the name soon illustrated the collection's philosophy. "It's developed into a fluid ghostly look, if you like, quite ethereal."
Sales for Ghost are stronger in the United States than Europe, so much so that Ms. Sarne is seeking a manufacturer here to avoid import duties.
 
Tina Chow, the Collector
 Tina Chow was perhaps not typical of the fashion collector that Christie's East expects to bid on her vintage couture pieces tonight.
"She wasn't obsessed with clothing, but she had a deep appreciation of fabric and construction and design," said her sister, the artist Adelle Lutz. "This probably all came from our mother, who studied couture in Japan. It's the Japanese sensibility of presentation. After you eat dinner, they give you one fine strawberry on a lacquered dish instead of a whole bowl of fruit, and that's how Tina looked at these pieces, with individual appreciation instead of as trends."
Ms. Chow's collection includes Fortuny, Balenciaga, Givenchy, Saint Laurent and Chanel. But Ms. Lutz said, "For me, some of the sweetest pieces are cheongsams, Chinese cut velvet dresses from the 30's or 40's. Cecil Beaton photographed her in these dresses for British Vogue, and that was the last sitting he did."
Before the auction, Mirabella magazine and Christie's will hold a benefit cocktail reception and preview, with proceeds going to AIDS charities. Ms. Chow died of AIDS in January 1992, at 41.
"She was an exception," Kathleen Guzman, the president of Christie's East, said of Ms. Chow, adding that she expected about 50 collectors to bid on the couture tonight, typically "a person who will buy it, save it and hope one day they'll open a museum."
She continued: "The kind of costumes Tina Chow collected transcend the pure collector. A lot of this fashion can be worn today."
