HEADLINE: Botanical Garden Joins Company in Drug Search

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
IN one of the largest such arrangements so far, Pfizer Inc. and the New York Botanical Garden are collaborating on a $2 million, three-year effort to collect and study plants from the United States as potential sources of new medicines.
It is the latest in a number of efforts by drug companies to step up prospecting for natural sources of pharmaceuticals. Scientists have found it more difficult than they had hoped to synthesize drugs from scratch, so researchers are turning once again to nature. New technologies for mass screening of plant and animal materials for medicinal properties have made this prospecting more practical in recent years. 
 Much of the action has focused on the tropics, but botanists believe the native plants of the United States also provide a potentially valuable source of drugs.
"Our collaboration with Pfizer seeks to begin the search for new plant-based therapies in our own backyard, so to speak," said Dr. Brian Boom, vice president for botanical sciences at the botanical garden.
The plant world "offers a rich array of naturally bioactive materials," but "only a small percentage of these have ever been subjected to modern techniques for assaying new drugs," said Dr. George M. Milne Jr., president of Pfizer Central Research in Groton, Conn. "We are excited by the prospect of working with the expert scientists" at the botanical garden, he said, "and with the wide range of plant extracts they will provide."
Under the agreement announced yesterday, Pfizer is putting up $2 million to finance the collection and identification of plant samples from across the country by the botanical garden. Pfizer scientists will test extracts from the plants in the hope of discovering either disease-fighting agents or chemical structures that would make it easier to synthesize medicines. If any of the extracts lead to a commercial compound, Pfizer will pay a royalty to the garden.
The agreement is similar in some respects to a landmark collaboration announced two years ago between Merck & Company and Costa Rica's national biological institute. Over two years, Merck paid $1 million for the prospecting and also pledged to pay royalties for any resulting marketable products. Costa Rica, in turn, pledged to use the $1 million to support conservation of the forests in which the plants grow.
Several other companies have undertaken collaborative efforts with botanical researchers in recent years, but the Merck agreement and the one announced yesterday are believed to be the two most expensive.
Plants have been used as medicines for thousands of years. But until recently, screening them to isolate their medicinal properties so that they can be produced in commercial form has been slow and difficult. Now the search has become more feasible as a result of greater knowledge about the chemical mechanisms through which plant compounds act on disease, coupled with the advent of automated screening techniques.
About a quarter of all prescription drugs used in the United States, it is estimated, originated with plants. But only one half of 1 percent of the world's higher plants have been thoroughly screened for their medical potential and chemical composition, said Dr. Michael J. Balick, the director of the New York Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany.
Dr. Balick, who will lead the garden in the Pfizer collaboration, said: "So much attention has been given to the tropics, which certainly are a rich source of plant chemicals, and so little attention to our own area. Both we and Pfizer felt it was time to mount an intensive search within the U.S."

HEADLINE: Zoos Find a New Role In Conserving Species

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ONE recent afternoon at the Bronx Zoo, Dr. Fred Koontz, the curator of mammals, watched a computer video display in which an oval representing the field of view of an orbiting earth satellite closed in on an area of Cameroon. There, three forest elephants have been fitted with radio transmitters developed in New York and tested on a zoo elephant named Maxine.
The orbiting satellite picks up signals from the elephants and sends reports on their positions to the United States. From these reports ecologists in the Bronx are discerning the animals' patterns of movement to determine their range, habitat and response to human settlements. Without this information a conservation plan for the threatened elephants cannot be devised. Virtually nothing has been known about forest elephant ecology until now because the thick jungle foliage makes the animals hard to follow on the ground. 
 Since the founding of the New York Zoological Society nearly a century ago, it has engaged in wildlife conservation around the globe. But that operation was mainly divorced from the zoo operation in New York, with its considerable knowledge about the biology of animals. Now the field conservation effort is expanding -- it currently includes 158 projects in 41 countries -- and the two operations have been merged. The idea is that the zoo will apply to these operations a range of expertise on animal nutrition, health, handling and reproduction, serving as a support base in ways never tried in the past.
And the leaders of the organization, now called NYZS/the Wildlife Conservation Society in recognition of the new strategy, are spearheading an effort to export their broadened mission to the zoo community at large. If the effort succeeds, it could transform zoos, giving them major roles in field conservation at a time when the shrinking global inventory of living species has become an environmental concern of the first magnitude. If zoos do not get out into the natural world and help conserve it, they risk becoming "quiescent museums," says Dr. William Conway, president of the society.
Zoos and aquariums constitute an extraordinary base of expertise for field conservation operations, said Dr. Conway. If their efforts could be refocused, he said, "it might be that we could really make a difference." Dr. Conway is the chairman of a committee of the American Association Zoological Parks and Aquariums that is investigating ways in which zoos might do that. Its first substantive meeting took place at the association's annual conference in Omaha last week.
"If any of the specialized big mammals, birds and reptiles are to be retained in the shrinking crevices between human populations," Dr. Conway said in a speech at the zoo and aquarium association's meeting in Toronto last year, it will have to be "on the basis of a much more supportive kind of conservation." Such areas -- small, fragmented islands in a sea of habitat disturbed by humans -- will inevitably become "mega-zoos" dependent on human management, he said.
 
Metamorphosis of Zoos
 The Toronto speech turned out to be something of a manifesto for the new campaign to project zoos into field conservation. Afterward, Sydney Butler, the zoo and aquarium association's executive director, enlisted Dr. Conway to head the effort. Though models have been provided by the New York organization and a handful of other zoos, extending the philosophy in practice will not be easy.
The main reason zoos have not been more involved in field conservation "is that there's lots of money tied up in their exhibits and their collections" and "a lot of pressure to keep money at home," said Mr. Butler. But conservation in the field "can also mean local conservation," he said; if a zoo wants to preserve the ecology of Chesapeake Bay, "that's fine with us."
Many zoos have gone through a metamorphosis since the days when they mainly exhibited animals in cages. They have created more natural settings for their animals, developed public education programs tying zoo exhibits to the ecology of the wild and become homes for endangered species, many of which are bred in captivity.
Theoretically, Dr. Conway says, zoos are now proficient enough to breed thousands of species; but in reality, economic factors restrict such programs to a fraction of their potential, and always will. And captive breeding cannot save animal populations in nature, the habitats they live in or "all those grand wildlife spectacles that so move our hearts and inspire our souls," he says. Once one has seen half a million wildebeests migrating in the Serengeti Plain in Tanzania, Dr. Conway said in his Toronto speech, "a remnant dispersed in a few collections is simply not an adequate fulfillment" of a zoo's responsibility.
Captive breeding and the reintroduction of captive-bred animals into the wild "are not panaceas for the endangered species problem" and should be considered only as "two of many weapons in the arsenal available to zoo biologists" to save species, says Dr. Michael Hutchins, the zoo and aquarium association's director of conservation and science.
 
Preservation Around the World
 For years, biologists have fanned out from the New York society's headquarters in the Bronx to study animals in the wild. Some have achieved something of a swashbuckling image. Among them are George Schaller with mountain gorillas in Africa and pandas in China, and David Western with elephants in Kenya. They often became conservationists out of necessity, to preserve the animals they studied.
More recently, the resources of the society, including the zoo, have been more deliberately and systematically focused on preservation. Under Dr. Schaller's leadership, for example, the society has worked with the Chinese Government to set aside a 100,000-square-mile nature preserve in the Qian Tang (pronounced Chahng Tahng) region of Tibet, one of the largest and most unspoiled ecosystems on earth. In Central America, the society is leading a cooperative effort by seven nations to create a protected wildlife corridor stretching from Belize and Guatemala to Panama, along which cougars can travel their natural prehistoric migration route between North and South America.
With habitats for large animals becoming increasingly degraded and fragmented, Bronx Zoo veterinarians have been closely monitoring animal health in the field. "It is a good indicator of environmental degradation," said Dr. William B. Karesh, a Bronx-based field veterinarian. The veterinarians also put out epidemiological brush fires in the wild. Animals are more vulnerable to disease and environmental toxins when habitats and populations contract, and zoo scientists have mounted rescue missions to save disease-ravaged populations.
Scientists at the zoo are investigating the effects of human handling on animals that must be moved around in the wild, a necessary evil in managing diminished populations. "What we're finding, for instance, is that actually knocking down some of these animals," as must be done to capture them, "has profound physiological consequences, and we're going to have to be much more careful than we've ever been in the past about what we do," said Dr. John Robinson, a vice president of the society.
Zoo scientists are working to develop genetic markers for elephant ivory in an effort to trace illegally traded ivory to its area of origin. They are studying the effects of temperature on anacondas, which are increasingly being hunted for their skins, to learn about their habitat requirements so that a conservation plan can be worked out. And on any given day, visitors to the Bronx Zoo may see exhibited animals wearing miniature radio transmitters that are being tested in a continuing program to improve the tracking of wild animals. The zoo, said Dr. Koontz, is becoming the "tool box" of field conservation.
Since conservation does not take place in a social and economic vaccum, Bronx-based conservationists are paying more systematic attention to working with national governments, local politicians and international aid agencies to preserve habitats and protect animals. The ultimate goal is to transfer expertise and technology to developing countries so that they can take the lead in their own conservation efforts.
While few zoos can boast the long history or breadth of the New York society's programs, some are beginning to get involved in field conservation. For instance, the Minnesota Zoological Garden at Apple Valley, Minn., and the Potter Park Zoological Gardens in Lansing, Mich., are jointly helping an effort to save the 400 Sumatran tigers thought to remain in the wild. The Toledo Zoological Park in Ohio is doing the same for the endangered Aruba Island rattlesnake. And in an example of what is called the adopt-a-park concept, the Minnesota Zoo has linked up with Ujung Kulon National Park on the island of Java in Indonesia to save what may be the most endangered mammal in the world, the Javan rhinoceros. Fewer than 50 remain, all in Ujung Kulon.
These sorts of activities, according to the new thinking, are not just desirable, they are critical to the future of zoos. To "retain their relevance in a changing world and ultimately insure their own survival," says Dr. Hutchins, "zoological institutions must change, and change rapidly."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Fred Koontz, left, and Dr. William Conway at the Bronx Zoo with a computer display showing sites where forest elephants, right, were tracked by satellite in Cameroon. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times; Andrea Turkalo)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WANG LABORATORIES EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY

 BODY:
As expected, Wang Laboratories Inc. emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The company's business plan was approved by Federal Bankruptcy Judge William C. Hillman in Boston. And the plan received approval from 94 percent of the creditors and 97 percent of the equity holders, Joseph M. Tucci, Wang's chief executive, said. The Lowell, Mass., company filed for Chapter 11 on Aug. 18, 1992. 
 Mr. Tucci said a bidding war had taken place between the Steinhardt Management Company of New York and another group of investors over a $60 million private sale of preferred stock and warrants in the new company, resulting in an improved deal for Wang. Steinhardt accepted a lower interest rate and 1.5 million shares rather than 2.4 million shares of stock. Wang, which had made its name in computer hardware, will now concentrate its efforts in the software business.

HEADLINE: Health Care Plan Would Take Double Tax Bite

 BODY:

To the Editor
"Health Aides See a Tax on Benefits Beyond Basic Plan" (front page, Sept. 5) reports an Administration proposal under which both workers and companies would have to pay Federal income tax on employer-provided health benefits if they exceed those in the standard package to be guaranteed to all Americans. 
 You focus on the politics of the proposal. But regardless of the politics, the idea is bad tax policy.
Under a personal income tax, all earnings should be taxed at the same rate, no matter in what form they are paid. Employers can now deduct payments to their workers, whether these payments are wages or health insurance benefits. The workers pay taxes on the wages, but not on the benefits. This violates the basic principle of the same rate of taxation.
However, the Administration proposal is a violation in the other direction -- "excess benefits" are doubled taxed, first at the employer level (because they are not deductible) and again at the worker's level. In effect, workers who want more insurance (even for good reasons) are discriminated against by the tax law.
How can the double tax be justified? One might argue that the Administration has come up with an insurance package that is perfect for everyone. Therefore, the double tax is designed to punish those with the presumption to want more than that much insurance. But there is nothing socially undesirable about spending your money on health insurance, if that is what you want to do. Alternatively, the Administration's goal may simply be to raise more taxes, whether or not the method is sensible or fair.
 
HARVEY S. ROSEN
Chairman, Dept. of Economics
Princeton University
Princeton, N.J., Sept. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN MOSCOW;
U.S. Supports Move By Russian Leader To Break Deadlock

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton, taken by surprise by the events in Moscow, moved swiftly today to throw the support of the United States behind President Boris N. Yeltsin in his showdown with the Russian Parliament.
"I support him fully," Mr. Clinton said in a statement released by the White House late this afternoon after Mr. Clinton was able to hold a 17-minute telephone conversation with the Russian leader. And Mr. Clinton and other White House officials were in touch with European allies tonight to encourage them to issue similar statements of support for Mr. Yeltsin on Wednesday. 
 Although there had been hints from Russian officials that such a confrontation might occur, the United States was informed by Mr. Yeltsin about his plans only an hour before his televised speech in which he ordered the disbanding of the Soviet-era Parliament and the calling of elections for a new legislature in December.
The White House scrambled throughout the afternoon to monitor and respond to the fast-moving developments, which included the vote later by the Russian Parliament to depose Mr. Yeltsin and install his bitter rival, Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, as acting president.
There is uncertainty in Washington tonight about whether Mr. Yeltsin will succeed. But having thrown its support repeatedly on Mr. Yeltsin's side in the past, the Clinton Administration was in no mood to change partners at this crucial moment in Moscow.
The Pentagon reported no troop movements around Moscow, and there was no advance indication here on how the political standoff would be resolved.
In embracing the Russian leader, the United States has decided that his suspension of a Parliament elected under Communist Party voting rules and largely hostile to Mr. Yeltsin's reforms is acceptable because Mr. Yeltsin promised new balloting in the name of democracy.
It was almost with a sigh of relief that after President Clinton telephoned Mr. Yeltsin, he said he came away convinced that the Russian leader would act in a way "that insures peace, stability and an open political process this autumn."
 
'Democratic and Free' Vote
 "He told me that it is of the utmost importance that the elections he has called be organized and held on a democratic and free basis," Mr. Clinton said.
The President justified Mr. Yeltsin's actions as a necessary jolt that broke the political gridlock in Moscow. Mr. Clinton said the Russian President's actions "underscore the complexity of the reform process that he is leading."
"There is no question that President Yeltsin acted in response to a constitutional crisis that had reached a critical impasse and had paralyzed the political process," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Rutskoi, who was interviewed by telephone by Chris Wallace on the ABC News program Nightline, objected to Mr. Clinton's support for Mr. Yeltsin.
"I am very deeply disappointed that the President of the United States is supporting these anti-constitutional actions," Mr. Rutskoi said. "If he sees these measures as being reform-like, he is deeply mistaken in that."
 
'Investment' in U.S. Security
 At the State Department, Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters that American support for Mr. Yeltsin's efforts for reform was "an investment in the national security of the United States."
Mr. Christopher declined to answer a question about whether Mr. Yeltsin had exceeded his authority under Russian law, saying, "I am not going to get into a discussion of Russian constitutional and legal issues."
The Clinton Administration's gamble in its support for Mr. Yeltsin on his unpredictable course was highlighted in a briefing for reporters by a senior Administration official this evening.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Yeltsin assured Mr. Clinton twice during their conversation of his intention to take steps that "will quicken the pace of reform." But the official also said: "There are uncertainties and risks associated with this course. I don't think anyone would deny it. I don't think President Yelstin would deny it."
The Administration's reaction is consistent with what it said last March, when Mr. Yeltsin threatened to suspend Parliament and abolish the Soviet-era Constitution, and the Administration stuck by him.
But Mr. Yeltsin's move today puts Washington in a bind. On the one hand, it sees Mr. Yeltsin as the country's best hope for democracy, a sort of Russian style Charles de Gaulle delivering his country from chaos by assuming authoritarian powers. To help drum up support for Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton telephoned Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany to relate his conversation with Mr. Yeltsin, the White House said.
On the other hand, the Administration knows that what is most important in Russia -- the continuation of democratic and economic reform -- transcends the political fortunes of one man.
 
No Unusual Troop Movements
 At the Pentagon, officials said tonight there were no unusual movements of strategic or conventional Russian forces since Mr. Yeltsin's declaration. Defense Secretary Les Aspin had not tried to contact the Russian Defense Minister, Pavel Grachev, a Pentagon spokesman said. "People are comfortable that their nuclear weapons are under positive control and everything is normal," said one Defense Department official.
In his briefing with reporters, Mr. Christopher said that the Russians gave the United States only about one hour's advance notice about the constitutional coup.
Russia's Foreign Ministry called in Thomas Pickering, the United States Ambassador to Moscow, and the ambassadors from Britain, France, Italy, Canada, Japan and Germany less than an hour before Mr. Yeltsin appeared on national television with his announcement.
Mr. Christopher received the first hint of today's actions last week, when Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, pulled him aside and suggested that there might be a political showdown in Moscow within a matter of days, a senior Administration official said. But Mr. Kozyrev, who was in Washington for last week's signing of the Israeli-Palestinian accord, did not tell Mr. Christopher directly that Mr. Yeltsin would dissolve the Parliament, the official said.
"It was a cryptic reference, not specific enough to know for certain something was going to happen," the senior official said. "Clearly, in retrospect, Kozyrev was trying to give the Secretary a signal."
 
Dissolution Not Expected
 One senior Administration official who closely follows Russia said it was assumed within the Administration that Mr. Yeltsin would give the Russian Parliament an ultimatum, but it was not expected that he would dissolve it.
Mr. Christopher, meanwhile, briefed key legislators this afternoon on the rapidly unfolding events in Moscow and urged them to redouble their efforts to pass an ambitious aid package for Russia.
Thus far, there is no inclination in Congress to penalize Mr. Yeltsin by withholding American aid, although some lawmakers urged the United States to make clear that the democratic process is more important than the fate of one political leader.

PUB-DATE: September 22, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1024 words

HEADLINE: Democratic Split Over Trade Agreement Widens

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The cracks in the Democratic Party over the North American Free Trade Agreement widened into a public crater today when Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader in the House of Representatives, announced his opposition to the accord.
At the White House, President Clinton, who has promised to work hard to win Congressional approval for the agreement, said of Mr. Gephardt's defection, "It doesn't help, but I don't think it's fatal." 
 Mr. Gephardt's position was not a surprise. He has been closely aligned with organized labor throughout his career, and the unions are ferociously opposed to the trade agreement. But Administration officials and some of Mr. Gephardt's friends in Congress were a bit taken aback by the splash with which he announced his stand.
They had been led to believe that the Missouri Congressman would play down his opposition to the trade measure and say he planned to concentrate on health care legislation, on which he sides with the President. Instead, Mr. Gephardt rented a room at the National Press Club and, before television cameras, read a 45-minute speech in which he called the accord a threat to American jobs, wages and living standards and potentially damaging to the environment.
 
Clinton's Perspective
 The trade agreement, which requires majority approval from the House and the Senate before it can go into effect, would remove trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada over the next 10 years, creating a huge North American free trade zone like the European Community. From Mr. Clinton's perspective, it is the most important issue facing votes in Congress the rest of this year, since health care will not be taken up until next year.
"President Clinton knows of my support for him and his Administration," Mr. Gephardt said. "I helped him achieve success on his economic plan, and I will be there by his side on health care, education, welfare reform, Russian aid and countless other issues. On this issue, as it stands, however, I must part company."
His colleagues in Congress expect that while he will speak and vote against the trade pact, Mr. Gephardt will not try to line up votes. "I don't think you're going to see Dick arm-twisting," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, one of about a dozen Democratic Representatives who went to the Press Club this afternoon to underscore their alliance with the majority leader.
Mr. Gephardt suggested as much in answer to questions. He emphasized that he would speak out on the merits and not the politics of the trade pact, insisted that his ability to control others' votes had been exaggerated and maintained, "I bring to this one vote."
Still, Mr. Gephardt is enormously influential, not only because of his position as party leader but also because other Democratic representatives respect his intelligence and the diligence with which he approaches issues. Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, is also opposing the pact. Their defection offers political cover to others who would like to vote against the trade pact but are worried about opposing the President.
It is unusual but not unheard of for leaders in Congress to oppose a President from their own party. Most recently, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 Republican in the House, led a large majority of Republicans in 1985 against Ronald Reagan's bill to overhaul the Federal income tax system.
Still, Presidents rarely rely on the opposition party to the extent Mr. Clinton is depending on Republican votes on the trade bill.
 
Looking for 30 Votes
 Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is coordinating the campaign in Congress in favor of the measure, said today that only 66 of the 258 Democrats in the House were committed to vote for the measure. He said he needed to persuade 30 or 35 more to reach enough votes to pass the bill. Mr. Matsui said he was counting on at least 120 of the 175 Republicans to vote for it.
If the House votes in favor of the legislation, the Senate is expected to do so also.
After the Gephardt speech, the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and other Democratic representatives who support the trade measure counterpunched with their own news conference. One of those lined up with Mr. Foley was Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat, who expressed his support publicly in Washington for the first time. He could be important in swaying Democrats on the fence because he is chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which raises and distributes money to candidates for Congress.
Across the Capitol, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, held a news conference with Senators Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Max Baucus of Montana to stress that some Democrats in the Senate were on the President's side.
 
Public Evenly Divided
 The latest New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,136 adults nationwide found that the public was fairly evenly divided on the trade matter but that the opponents of the agreement felt more strongly about the issue than those in favor. More than a quarter of those questioned had no position, meaning that public opinion could shift markedly in the weeks ahead.
The poll was taken by telephone on Thursday through Sunday and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Gephardt had withheld public judgment on the trade pact until he had assessed the side agreements negotiated this summer on labor and environmental issues. Today, he pronounced them inadequate.
Low wages, the acceptance of poor working conditions and lax environmental standards in Mexico, he said, would encourage American companies to invest there instead of at home.
"The agreement isn't sound, and our economy isn't ready for it," Mr. Gephardt declared. "In fact, the greatest failures in the agreement could exacerbate our worst economic problems: disappearing jobs and declining real incomes. Against the economic backdrop of the last 12 years, people are right to be concerned about the future."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The North American Free Trade Agreement is testing even the ability of the Democratic Party to hold divergent views. While Speaker Thomas S. Foley spoke in its favor, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader in the House, denounced it. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Going on Offensive, Whitman Plans Cuts In New Jersey Taxes

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLARK, N.J., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, announced an economic plan today with a promise over the next three years to make the most sweeping tax cuts in state history, to reduce the size of government and to create 450,000 jobs.
"This is radical, but when you look at what's happened to this state over the last three and one-half years, then it's obvious something radical has to happen," Mrs. Whitman said at a news conference. "If not, we are going to become a third-world country in this state." 
 As much as the plan is an economic blueprint for New Jersey under Mrs. Whitman as governor, it is a calculated political maneuver that she hopes will put her Republican candidacy on the offensive against Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, in the remaining six weeks of the gubernatorial race. Besides releasing her economic plan today, Mrs. Whitman also began broadcasting ads for the first time, including one touting the new tax cut.
Mrs. Whitman promised $1.4 billion in tax cuts, some to take place immediately and others to be phased in over the first three years of her administration. She said her plan would bring tax rates for some people back to the 1976 rates.
"My plan clearly and convincingly favors the hard-working middle-income citizens and taxpayers of this state," she said.
In a race in which polls show the two major candidates in a statistical tie and 9 to 12 percent of the electorate undecided, the fiscal issue is Mrs. Whitman's political trump card and she played it today, exactly six weeks before the Nov. 2 election, gambling that it will rekindle white-hot voter anger over Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990 and remove doubt about her own leadership abilities.
While Mrs. Whitman's plan was sweeping in its promises, it was short on details of how she planned to cut taxes and cover a projected $1 billion shortfall in the state budget for the next fiscal year. She did mention these specifics: an immediate move after taking office to reduce the number of state patronage employees being paid more than $50,000, the sale of the governor's helicopter, a 20 percent cut in the governor's staff and the privatization of government operations where feasible.
The centerpiece of Mrs. Whitman's proposal is a 30 percent income tax rate reduction -- 10 percent per year over three years starting with the 1995 tax year -- for every taxpayer with taxable income up to $80,000. It would cost the state $351 million a year in lost revenue over three years for a total of $1.053 billion in lost revenue.
For a married couple filing jointly and with a total taxable income of $50,000 a year, it would mean a savings of $345 annually.
Her proposal would eliminate state income tax entirely for individuals or married couples who make less than $7,500 a year in taxable income. It would save those wage earners $150 a year and increase the number of tax-exempt residents by 350,000, at a cost to the state of $35 million a year in revenue.
"In order to overcome the imbalances in the Florio administration's budget and to fund our tax cuts, we need to find approximately $900 million in savings in the first 18 months of my administration," Mrs. Whitman said.
 
Busy Maneuvering
 Mrs. Whitman said she would reach her goal "with tax reductions to create jobs and rejuvenate the economy" and promised budget savings and the leadership to control government growth, pledging to hold total spending increases to 3 percent a year, half the current growth rate.
On what could prove to be one of the most pivotal issues in the gubernatorial race, both sides worked furiously to outmaneuver the other.
Hours before Mrs. Whitman met with reporters here at a hotel near her campaign headquarters, Mr. Florio was in Newark trying to mute some of his opponent's political thunder by staging a reception in which a coalition of corporate leaders endorsed his re-election bid.
Mrs. Whitman timed the release of her economic plan -- announced at a 2:30 P.M. news conference -- to limit the response time that her rival had to start picking it apart on the first day.
The expected onslaught was not long in coming.
"Her plan is welfare for the rich," the Florio campaign said in a news release issued about an hour after Mrs. Whitman's news conference ended. "It gives someone making $300,000 a year a tax cut of $4,000, and gives a hard-working middle-class family less than $350.
"One of the big problems in evaluating this plan is that Mrs. Whitman won't even say how she's going to pay for this."
 
Panel of Experts
 The plan was drawn up by Mrs. Whitman's Council for Economic Recovery, a panel of fiscal, tax and business experts she created in July to devise an economic platform for her. The council was led by two co-chairmen -- Lawrence Kudlow, senior managing director and chief economist of New York City-based Bear Stearns & Company, and Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., president and chief executive officers of Forbes Inc. and editor-in-chief of Forbes magazine.
As Deputy Budget Director under during the Reagan Presidency, Mr. Kudlow was a chief proponent of supply-side economics, the theory that you can increase government revenue by cutting taxes and allowing business to flourish. That philosophy is at the center of Mrs. Whitman's plan, Mr. Kudlow said today.
On July 14, only days after winning the Republican nomination, Mrs. Whitman announced the creation of her economic council and said its members would help her develop an agenda on seven specific subject areas: taxes and budget, information services, sports and tourism, agriculture, financial services, organized labor and urban business. She said that as governor she would rely on some of the same advisers.
 
Political Trump Card
 At the time she announced the formation of the council, Mrs. Whitman did not say when she would make her economic plan public. As the summer passed and Mr. Florio increased his pressure on her to tell what she would do as governor, the economic blueprint grew into a crucial issue for the Whitman campaign.
Releasing her economic plan gives Mrs. Whitman her clearest chance yet to define the campaign agenda, but the move is not without risks.
Only a day after the June 8 primary, Mrs. Whitman criticized Mr. Florio for raising the issue of a tax cut, saying it was cynical to do so. She was forced to back off that stance because of strong support for tax cuts by members of the Republican legislative majority, with the powerful Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, as the principal champion of the idea.
Mrs. Whitman said today that she said it would have been cynical to propose a tax increase without first identifying how to pay for it.
"I've done that," she said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: White House Memo;
If It's Tuesday It Must Be . . . Health, Nafta, Yeltsin, Lunch

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The big house on Pennsylvania Avenue rang today with the clamor of its distant Jacksonian past.
Not in many years have as many people from as many different groups poured into the salons and onto the lawns of the White House in one day on as many different errands. Government activism is back in vogue, and this was a great chance to watch the show. 
 "Bill-signing on the South Lawn, talk-show hosts on the North Lawn, big-shots for lunch, and, yeah, Yeltsin on the phone," David R. Gergen, the Presidential counselor, said.
President Clinton, smiling, as he walked into a luncheon for about 20 newspaper and magazine columnists and bureau chiefs, said, "Place is buzzing like a beehive." At the luncheon, Mr. Clinton and his wife made their umpty-umpth concerted sales pitch for the Administration's health plan -- this one on the eve of the President's television speech disclosing its terms to the nation.
A few of the political pieces fell into place on schedule today; the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was one. But both Mr. Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton made it clear at lunch that in the course of the long debate ahead they knew they would have to make concessions to win further backing, phasing in universal coverage over a longer period than the planned three years. [Page A24.]
The message was compromise, flexibility, dialogue -- a far cry from the ideological war whoops that accompanied the budget battles last spring.
"As we move forward in the discussion," Mrs. Clinton said, "if we keep our focus on the principles that we think should guide this debate and the destination that we're all trying to get to, then we will have a very fruitful discussion in the Congress and we'll put together a bipartisan majority."
All day long, the ordinarily muffled corridors and waiting rooms of the White House were jammed with visitors, and long lines formed at many of the gates to the grounds.
"Bustle, energy," said George Stephanopoulos, one of Mr. Clinton's top advisers, in an essay in noun control. "No chaos, no disorganization."
Only the worker-bees were a bit grumpy. All the carryings-on, said a Presidential aide, had come close to overwhelming guards, groundskeepers, cooks and other members of the permanent staff. The Secret Service ran out of one type of identification tag for visitors and had to substitute another.
This morning, Mr. Clinton repaired to a huge tent, thrown up overnight on the South Lawn, to sign legislation creating a National Service Program.Hundreds came to watch him do it, including college presidents and professors, Sargent Shriver, the first head of the Peace Corps, a passel of excited college reporters, a grunge band in the obligatory torn jeans and long hair, and Tabitha Soren, the 20-something news commentator on MTV.
After lunch, the President lobbied 250 talk-show hosts from around the country, some of whom set up shop on the South Lawn. Rush Limbaugh was not there, having declined an invitation, but Blanquita Cullum of WLEE radio in Richmond came, even though Mr. Clinton is not at all her ideological cup of tea. She worked for the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the Reagan Administration, and she said her taste ran more to Patrick J. Buchanan.
When the President told them he had just had lunch with some columnists, the broadcasters laughed.
"I'm sorry, I'm sorry," he said, ever eager to play to the audience at hand. "Would it make you feel better if I said I didn't enjoy it?"
 
A Talk With Yeltsin
 Then he went back to his office to talk by telephone with President Boris N. Yeltsin about the Russian leader's decision to disband Parliament.
Something of the social engineer's optimism that often gripped the White House as Lyndon B. Johnson pushed through the Great Society gripped it today. Surprisingly often, the concerns at the center of government are petty and parochial, but no one doubts that the health care plan is different -- the last unfinished business of the New Deal, as many call it, a program in the Roosevelt-Truman-Johnson tradition, with the potential for sweeping social, economic and political change.
The President, who likes to hark back to his political idols, the Kennedys, looked back farther today, recalling that it was 50 years ago, in 1943, when the first measure proposing national health insurance was introduced.
It was sponsored by three gung-ho New Dealers -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, Senator James E. Murray of Montana and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, whose son sits in the House today. It was called "socialized medicine" by its foes and died a swift death, like two similar bills introduced by Harry S. Truman.
 
Clintons Love the Issue
 Both Mr. and Mrs. Clinton seemed fired by the sense that after all the distractions and dead ends of the last six months -- the haircut and travel-office imbroglios and the fights over homosexuals in the military -- they had finally reached the issue that may make or break this Presidency.
The details may confound many people and bore others, but "she loves this stuff, and so does he," Mr. Stephanopoulos said in a tone of wonderment.
Never mind that they had made many of the same arguments and answered many of the same questions a dozen times this week in conversations with television broadcasters, doctors, talk-show hosts, members of Congress, executives of small businesses, hospital administrators and anyone else who might have some effect, great or small, on the plan's fate; they did it again, radiating enthusiasm.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Poll on Changes in Health Care Finds Support Amid Skepticism

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
President Clinton tonight addresses a nation that is already convinced that the health care system is in crisis and, by a strong majority, says that it is willing to pay higher taxes to make health insurance secure and available to all, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
But the survey also shows a deep skepticism about the ability of the Government to achieve a successful overhaul of the system. Americans were sharply divided on whether the President "will be able to bring about significant health care reform," the survey found: 45 percent said he would, 41 percent said he would not. 
 Still, as Mr. Clinton prepares to present his plan before a joint session of Congress in a speech that will be broadcast nationally, starting at 9 P.M., there was much in the poll to support the notion that Americans have, at the very least, reached a consensus on the need for change and on a set of basic goals.
 
Support for Higher Taxes
 The survey shows overwhelming majorities support the idea of assuring health coverage to all Americans and guaranteeing that no one ever loses their insurance when they switch jobs or suffer a medical catastrophe. Sixty-one percent said they were willing to pay higher taxes to achieve those goals, and more than half said they were willing to have the Government require employers to pay most of the health insurance premiums to cover their workers -- a centerpiece of the Clinton plan.
When asked to name "the most important problem facing the country today," the public now rates health care second only to the economy. Forty-two percent said the nation needs to "completely rebuild" the health care system, with another 48 percent calling for "fundamental change." This sense of urgency runs across party lines -- 85 percent of the Republicans said they supported fundamental change or complete rebuilding -- and helps explain the bipartisan support on Capitol Hill for restructuring the system.
The survey was conducted last Thursday through Sunday by telephone with 1,136 adults nationwide. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. In addition to sampling error, the difficulties of conducting a survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into polls. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for example, can lead to somewhat different results.
 
High Stakes for Clinton
 For all the furor over the President's health care proposals in recent weeks as the details have filtered out and experts and constituent groups have weighed in, the poll indicates that most of the public has yet to fully focus on it. Eighty-four percent said it was too early for them to have a good understanding of what the Clinton plan will mean. Only 23 percent said they had heard or read "a lot" about the plan.
All of this raises the stakes for Mr. Clinton's speech tonight.
The verdict on the status quo was clear: 65 percent said they were dissatisfied with the cost of their health care, even if they did not pay for it directly; 55 percent said they were dissatisfied with their out-of-pocket costs for health care. And people were evenly divided when asked what worried them more: the cost of health care or not having enough coverage when they needed it.
Still, in keeping with earlier surveys, 71 percent said they were satisfied with the quality of their care. This explains why the White House has taken such pains to argue that the system can be restructured without sacrificing the quality.
In general, the survey found strong public support for some of the major goals the President has articulated for his plan: 83 percent, for example, said it was "very important" that "any health care reform plan" makes sure all Americans are covered. Sixty-seven percent said it was "very important" that such a plan cover long-term care for the disabled at home, another feature of the Clinton plan. And 73 percent said it was "very important" that preventive care be covered, which Clinton Administration officials say was a guiding principle in developing the basic benefit package.
 
Substantial Skepticism
 But between the idea of health care reform and the reality, the survey found substantial skepticism. Not surprisingly, most of the Democrats (62 percent) said they thought Mr. Clinton would be able to "bring about significant health care reform." But just 29 percent of the Republicans, and 29 percent of those who voted for Ross Perot, said they thought Mr. Clinton would be able to do so.
This skepticism was about the same among those who said they knew a lot about the Clinton plan and those who did not.
Similarly, people were sharply divided when asked if "the health care reform plan Bill Clinton is proposing is fair to people like you, or not?" Forty percent said it was fair, 36 percent said it was not. Younger people were more likely to think it would be fair to them; older people tended to be more skittish. Again, this judgment followed party lines, with Democrats likely to think it fair, Republicans likely to think it unfair and Perot voters evenly divided.
Perot voters, often characterized by their mistrust of government, were also skeptics when asked: "In the next few years, if the Clinton health care reform plan is adopted, do you think it will make health care in the United States better, make health care worse, or won't it have much impact one way or the other?" Fifty-seven percent of the Perot supporters said they thought it would make it worse or have little impact; 49 percent of the independents (an overlapping category) felt that way.
By comparison, 29 percent of the Democrats and 62 percent of the Republicans fell into that category of skeptics.
 
Modest Expectations
 The expectations of middle America for the Clinton health care plan seem, in some respects, quite modest. Despite the protestations from the White House, 80 percent in the survey said they expect their taxes will go up under the Clinton plan. Forty-five percent said they expect the amount they pay for health care will go up, and 53 percent said they expected the quality of their care to stay the same. Another 23 percent said they expect the quality to decline and 17 percent expect it to increase.
Seventy-six percent in the survey said they currently have a doctor they consider their own, and this relationship has a high value to them. Sixty-five percent of them said they would be willing to pay extra to keep seeing that doctor.
Still, there was an openness to the idea of health maintenance organizations and other types of alternatives to traditional fee for service medicine: 54 percent said they would be willing to choose a doctor from a limited list of qualified doctors if it meant that all Americans would be guaranteed health care. Fifty percent said they would wait longer for non-emergency appointments if it would further that goal.
But the idea of rationing stirs strong resistance. Only 36 percent said they would be willing, for the sake of universal coverage, to stop paying for expensive treatments that would extend a patient's life for only a short time.
The public supported several options to raise money to extend health insurance to all. Seventy-nine percent were willing to raise taxes on liquor; 73 percent said they were willing to increase the tax on cigarettes by $1 a pack. And 75 percent said they were willing to save money on Medicare by limiting how much doctors and hospitals can charge the Government for elderly patients -- suggesting a potentially popular way for the Administration to talk about cutting the rate of spending growth on Medicare.
The idea of requiring employers to provide insurance to their workers had the support of 54 percent. That rose to 63 percent when it was explicitly presented as a means of insuring health coverage to all Americans.
But there were substantial fears about the job impact of such a requirement. Those fears eased substantially when people were told that such a requirement could be coupled with subsidies to ease the burden on small businesses, which the Administration has promised to do.

International
Russian political instability intensified, with President Yeltsin dissolving the legislature and calling elections. The Supreme Soviet swore in Vice President Rutskoi as acting president. The developments caused nervousness in the financial markets. [Page A1.]
The Democratic Party's support of the Nafta weakened as the House majority leader announced his opposition. [A1.] 
 Poland's Government is trying to satisfy socialist concerns while remaining attractive to foreign investors. [A12.]
 
Markets
The stock market fell sharply, with the Dow industrials sinking 38.56 points. Analysts attributed the slide to turmoil in Russia and to the market's prolonged recent price run-up. [D1.]
Long-term interest rates rose but short-term rates fell as investors sought safety in U.S. securities amid Russia's turmoil. The 30-year Treasury bond yield rose to 6.12 percent. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Studies Show Futility of Rushing Some Heart Victims to Hospitals

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

 BODY:
It is futile, and economically wasteful, for emergency medical workers to rush heart attack victims to the hospital after efforts to resuscitate them in the field have failed, two major studies have found.
The studies, done in Memphis and Houston, add to a growing body of evidence that patients who do not respond to advanced cardiac life support before being rushed to a hospital have little chance of survival, researchers said yesterday. 
 Because of the high costs of hospital emergency care that does not improve the chance of living, and the risks associated with high-speed transport of patients, policies that require that all heart attack victims be rushed to a hospital should be abandoned, they concluded.
In studies being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers said that after examining thousands of heart attack cases, they found that only about a half of 1 percent of patients who were not revived with a pulse at the scene of their heart attack ultimately survived. And of the few who survived to leave the hospital, virtually all suffered permanent cerebral disability, the reports said.
Dr. Arthur L. Kellermann, the lead researcher of the 39-month University of Tennessee study of emergency cardiac care in Memphis, said the latest research clearly shows that rapid transport of unresponsive heart attack victims does not save lives.
"We need to make every effort we can to get the best care to the heart victim where he is," Dr. Kellermann said in a telephone interview. "But if the patient is so far gone that there isn't enough life left to be fanned back into a flame, we need to make the decision that we have done all that is possible and stop."
 
Cardiac Care Guidelines
 Dr. Kellermann, who has left Tennessee and is now director of Emory University's Center for Injury Prevention in Atlanta, said the recommendations of his study and a companion study done by researchers at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston are consistent with 1992 emergency cardiac care guidelines published by the American Heart Association.
The association said resuscitation may be discontinued in a pre-hospital setting when the patient remains unresponsive after adequate tries at emergency cardiac life support, provided no positive prognostic signs were evident.
Sudden cardiac arrest kills about 250,000 Americans a year. In areas that have model emergency medical systems -- Milwaukee and Seattle, for example -- up to 35 percent of cardiac arrest patients survive to leave the hospital, experts said. Survival rates vary widely from city to city, they said, but are generally 15 percent to 20 percent.
More than a half dozen previous studies in the last eight years have added to growing evidence that the most crucial time in caring for cardiac arrest patients is immediately after the event, the researchers said. The data show that if paramedics arrive quickly enough and restore heart rhythm and pulse, the patient has a good chance of surviving to reach the hospital and get further care. If the patient cannot be revived and stabilized, the studies show, the patient's chances of reaching the hospital alive are slim and of surviving to discharge even slimmer.
The new studies are the first to look prospectively, or as they happen, at large groups of cardiac cases that were handled by emergency medical systems involving many hospitals in a community.
The Memphis researchers, including Dr. Bela B. Hackman and Dr. Grant Somes, examined the cases of 1,068 adult cardiac arrest victims and found that 71 percent never regained a pulse after advanced life-support attempts by paramedics and that only 7 percent of those survived to be admitted to a hospital. Of the 29 percent who did respond to emergency care, 69 percent of those survived to be admitted and 26.5 percent lived to be discharged, compared with only 0.4 percent who lived to be discharged in the non-responsive group, the study said.
The Houston study, conducted by Dr. Marni J. Bonnin, Dr. Paul E. Pepe and others, looked at 1,322 similar cardiac arrest cases over 18 months and recorded similar outcomes. The study noted that all of those who survived to be discharged had regained circulation within 25 minutes after paramedics arrived and began giving treatment, which included opening airways and providing oxygen, administering electric shocks to restore heart rhythm and administering heart medication.
The results of these studies indicate resuscitation efforts can be ended in the field if patients do not respond, the Houston paper said, "but it must be recognized that these conclusions remain valid only as long as new or unusual treatment advances have not become available."
 
Weigh Survival Against Risks
 Dr. Kellermann said the ethics of stopping futile rescue attempts must weigh the slim chance of the patient's survival against the risk to the lives of emergency personnel and the public in high-speed transport accidents, which claim a score of lives each year. In addition, emergency room staff must be diverted from other patients in need, and hospitals must bare the cost of using dwindling resources to deal with hopeless cases, he said.
The Texas researchers estimated that the cost for each patient seen, tested and pronounced dead by a hospital emergency department at $2,000 to $3,000. Based on the incidence of cardiac arrest in the country, they estimated that continued but futile resuscitative efforts cost the nation up to $500 million annually.
In an editorial in the journal, Dr. William A. Gray of Southwest Cardiology Associates in Albuquerque, N.M., said an earlier study estimated that it also cost an additional $500 million to hospitalize those who initially fail to be revived in the field and fail to survive to be discharged.
"All of that time and money is spent for little or no benefit in overall survival," Dr. Gray wrote. "This is difficult to justify any longer when health care costs are coming under such intense scrutiny."

HEADLINE: Two Die as Nicaraguan Strikers Clash With Police

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 21

 BODY:
A nationwide transport strike turned deadly today as armed workers clashed with police, and Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega called for the ouster of the Government.
"The people are going to put a finish to this Government," said Mr. Ortega, whose leftist Sandinista government was defeated by President Violeta de Barrios Chamorro in elections in 1990. 
 A police officer and a bystander were killed and at least two other people wounded in a shootout between striking transportation workers and the police on a major highway outside Managua.
The violence on a highway near the international airport led American and Continental airlines to cancel scheduled flights to Nicaragua, officials of the United States-based airlines said. Each airline has one flight daily.
The strike had raised fears that Nicaragua's political crisis could deepen further. Hostage-taking by rearmed fighters on both sides of the civil war, and bitter political infighting, have continued to stall the nation's economic recovery.
United States-backed Contra rebels fought for most of the 1980's to overthrow the Sandinista Government.
Mr. Ortega, Mrs. Chamorro's predecessor as President, blamed her for the deaths.
He called for a "joining of ranks to unleash a popular battle in the streets."
"I don't see any other way out other than by the protests of the people," Mr. Ortega said.
The police fired tear gas, rubber bullets and then live rounds during the shootout with armed strikers manning flaming barricades on the Pan American Highway.
The indefinite strike by bus, taxi and truck drivers started Monday to protest a Government increase in fuel prices and imposition of vehicle taxes.

HEADLINE: Haiti in Turmoil as It Awaits Aristide

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Five weeks before the planned return of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haitians and foreign diplomats say the country's transition faces grave threats from logistical and political problems and from a wave of violence sweeping the country.
Hoping to shore up Father Aristide's transitional Government and send a message of its commitment to the restoration of democracy in Haiti, a high-level delegation of Clinton Administration officials arrived on Monday for a three-day visit. 
 The delegation, which is led by Alexander Watson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Hemispheric Affairs, includes two generals, who diplomats said had been included as a reminder to their Haitian counterparts about Washington's determination to insure Father Aristide's return on Oct. 30.
Seeking to dispel doubts, Mr. Watson said at a news conference today, "Not only do we think it is possible to return by Oct. 31, but we expect that he will be here to assume his responsibilities."
 
Killings by Auxiliary Police
 Since its installation earlier this month, the Government of Prime Minister Robert Malval, an interim leader chosen by Father Aristide, has been repeatedly and openly threatened by auxiliary police agents known as attaches, who have kept Cabinet ministers from using their offices and killed supporters of the deposed President.
United Nations and Organization of American States officials say they have documented many cases in recent weeks in which the attaches, working with apparent police and military complicity, have killed and kidnapped supporters of Father Aristide.
In the most flagrant example, on Sept. 11, one of the President's most prominent backers, Antoine Izmery, was dragged from a church service by a plainclothes attache and shot dead in the street. Officials who were present said that police officers nearby made no attempt to arrest the killer.
The new Government has been prevented by bands of thugs from taking control of the state media, and on several occasions attempts to occupy Government offices have been broken up by threats of violence.
Incidents like these have created deep divisions among Haitians and diplomats involved in the transition, with diplomats leading the political discussions insisting that things are firmly on track despite the violence. Others warn that the entire process is in disarray.
 
Differing Views of Violence
 These growing differences come through most clearly in discussions of the rising violence that has hit the country in recent weeks.
"It has been hyped way beyond the reality of what it is," said one senior American official, speaking on the eve of the Administration team's visit.
But many Haitian officials and foreign diplomats have begun to wonder if those managing the transition have lost sight of reality on the ground and warning that Father Aristide's return is increasingly threatened.
"I always thought this could work, but the international community has underestimated the gravity of the situation, and personally, I think things look very bad," said one senior diplomat involved in the transition, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Attaches are having regular meetings, guns are being distributed in the countryside, and in the capital the violence is just steadily rising."
United Nations officials say that in the last two months there have been more than 100 killings in the capital. Scanning still uninvestigated cases of killings, one official said that in the last four days alone there had been 36 reports of new slayings.
While only about 10 percent of those killed have been known as politically active, the official said that "the attaches are just going into the neighborhoods and opening fire to terrorize the population."
 
Preparations Behind Schedule
 Privately, many diplomats say that beyond the climate of violence, they have grown increasingly concerned that preparations for Father Aristide's return are running far behind schedule. Although the settlement of Haiti's crisis negotiated in July in New York called for the stationing of about 1,000 international police and military experts in the country, only a small fraction of that number have arrived.
Diplomats said today that at best, the first sizable contingent, 50 Canadians and 50 French police officers, would arrive within two weeks of a Security Council vote expected this week approving their use. That schedule would leave them only three weeks to begin training and monitoring their Haitian counterparts. Diplomats have said the international agents will not do law-enforcement duty themselves.

HEADLINE: Oregon Quake Jars Buildings And Emotions

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Most schools and businesses in this farming and timber town of 18,000 people closed today as city workers inspected each building for damage in an earthquake that shook southern Oregon on Monday night.
Centered 15 miles northwest of Klamath Falls, the earthquake, the second in this area in seven months, registered 5.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion and was followed by two aftershocks that witnesses said created a rolling sensation inside buildings. One person died in the initial quake when a boulder fell on a pickup truck. Several building facades fell, bridges cracked, causing roads to be closed, and cars were smashed by falling brick. 
 Gov. Barbara Roberts of Oregon declared a state of emergency in Klamath County. The Mayor of Klamath Falls, Todd Kellstrom, said city officials were still trying to determine the cost of the damage to buildings and businesses. Mr. Kellstrom spent this morning walking around the city and calming residents, some of whom walked the streets carrying cameras and camcorders.
"We've never had an earthquake to my knowledge," Mr. Kellstrom said. "Earthquake preparedness has never been a top issue. But we don't want that kind of talk now. We don't want to scare people any more than they are."
The 5.7 earthquake struck at 8:29 P.M., followed by two large aftershocks and several others throughout the night, ranging from from 4.6 to 5.4 on the Richter scale. In March, an earthquake estimated at 5.3 struck in Woodburn, 250 miles north of here.
Every increase one number on the Richter scale means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus, an earthquake measuring 6, which can cause severe damage, is 10 times greater than one measuring 5, which can cause considerable damage.
Residents of Klamath Falls said it was not the initial, more powerful, jolt that caused most of the damage, but rather the series of aftershocks.
The Klamath Falls Courthouse, City Hall, an apartment building and theater suffered some damaged. The city roped off the downtown area and set up two shelters on Monday night for those who were evacuated from their homes. Some people slept outside, frightened to sleep inside in case of aftershocks.
Kenneth L. Campbell of Phoenix was killed when a 14-foot boulder rolled onto a highway and smashed the truck he was driving. His wife, Phyllis, was riding in the passenger seat but walked away from the accident. An elderly woman died in her home after suffering a heart attack during one of the aftershocks.
In the past several years, geologist studying seismic activity in the Pacific Northwest have said that the area is due for a severe earthquake. In an article that appeared in the journal Science in April 1991, geologists wrote that a fault line in the Pacific Northwest was under increasing pressure. They explained that mountains along the Olympic Peninsula of Washington State were slowly being squeezed together while the coastline was rising. They warned that an earthquake measuring 9.5 -- more than 10 times greater than the devastating San Francisco earthquake of 1906 -- could strike the region, causing the coastal area to drop as much as six feet in minutes, generating huge waves.
But such a cataclysmic event seemed far from people's minds today as they cleaned up broken glass and hired contractors to check the seismic soundness of their homes and workplaces.
Don Hull, the state geologist, said the earthquake on Monday evening appeared to have occurred on a local fault line and not on the "megafault" stretching from Mendocino, Calif., to Vancouver, British Columbia. "The two faults are not connected, and seismic activity on one would not affect the other," said Mr. Hull, who is director of Oregon's geology and mineral industries department.
"Earthquakes of this type are to be expected in the future in the Klamath Falls area," he said. "We've had a very serious and important reminder of the power of earthquakes in Oregon. We're not nearly as well prepared as we should be given the types of earthquakes we expect."
Today, residents walking along the streets of Klamath Falls said they were concerned but did not see that they could do much to prepare for an earthquake.
Describing the quake, Pete Bernett, 17, whose family moved to Klamath Falls three years ago from Pasadena, Calif., said: "The whole house started flopping. I could hear the furnace bouncing underneath the house. We were surprised because everyone said there weren't supposed to be earthquakes here." 
At the Classico Italian Ristorante, the building's brick facade plunged to the ground, smashing a car below. Inside the building, Janet Bumala, a bartender told of holding on to a pipe during the earthquake. "Pots were flying off the stove," Ms. Bumala said. "The ceiling was falling down. Everything got quiet and then we heard a loud noise that sounded like a car wreck."
Nancy Shindler, 45, was at home when the earthquake struck. "The first one felt like a big gust of wind," she said. "The second one felt like living right next to a roller coaster."
Ms. Shindler said she had not made any preparations for an earthquake and did not know if her home would survive a big quake. "We don't really know what to do," she said. "We haven't talked about it because it hadn't been an option before."
As residents and store owners swept up the glass off the streets and checked for structural damage, many said they were uninsured for such a disaster.
Terry Bennett, owner of a shopping center, watched as engineers hammered pillars in her building to decide whether the structure should be condemned. Friends mistaken by the police as looters helped her clean up the store into the early morning hours.
"We usually just worry about strikes and unemployment here," said Ms. Bennett, a resident of Klamath Falls for 20 years. "I used to tell people moving here, you never have to worry about floods or earthquakes here."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Clinton Moves to Assemble Support for His Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton today put the finishing touches on the health care plan that he hopes will become the crowning achievement of his Presidency. At the same time, he raced to assemble a political coalition to support the plan and won an endorsement from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Mr. Clinton's proposal to control health costs and guarantee medical care for all Americans represents the biggest initiative in domestic social policy in a half-century. 
 On the eve of a speech by Mr. Clinton to Congress, Administration officials signaled a new willingness to compromise on parts of the President's plan if it did not generate savings as fast as he predicted. This flexibility is likely to please Senate Republicans, who want to delay new health benefits until savings in Medicare and Medicaid are confirmed.
The support of organized labor is indispensable to the success of Mr. Clinton's plan. But the White House never took it for granted and toiled tirelessly to please the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the 14 million members of its affiliated unions.
 
Fearing Cost to Workers
 While many unionized workers already have comprehensive health benefits, labor leaders say they fear that employers will shift more and more costs to workers if Congress does not approve Mr. Clinton's proposal.
With the general outline of Mr. Clinton's plan completed, the Administration focused its attention today on questions about its financing. Economists and members of Congress from both parties are already saying that Mr. Clinton's estimates of potential savings in the health care system are wildly optimistic. They say the plan will not cut health costs, but will increase the Federal budget deficit.
In the face of widespread skepticism, Mr. Clinton and his top aides made strenuous efforts today to defend the numbers in the health plan.
But Leon E. Panetta, the President's budget director, said the Administration was willing to consider "a longer phase-in" for the health plan if necessary to reduce the cost to levels acceptable in Congress.
As for stretching out the transition beyond early 1997, Mr. Panetta said: "You're reducing the benefits in the short term for some, but in the long run everyone's going to get the same benefit. Obviously there's going to be some adjustment on these pieces as we go through the political process."
 
No Compromise on Coverage
 A longer phase-in period would irritate many Democrats to the left of Mr. Clinton. Mindful of such concerns, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that the Administration would not compromise on the principle of health insurance for all Americans. "We have to have universal coverage as soon as possible," and that means within three years, she said.
Mrs. Clinton said she was willing to stretch out the transition period, if necessary. But Mr. Clinton said, "I'd rather not." The President and his wife made the comments at a luncheon with about 20 journalists.
At a White House briefing, Roger C. Altman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said, "If anyone can prove to us that there are flaws in our estimates of the costs of this -- I mean really prove it, which I doubt -- we would make adjustments on the cost side."
But he insisted that Mr. Clinton would not propose new taxes besides those known for months to be under consideration: taxes on cigarettes and perhaps on alcoholic beverages.
 
Deficit or Insurance
 Mr. Panetta said the White House might be willing to forgo some reductions in the Federal budget deficit envisioned in Mr. Clinton's health plan. To health policy experts and economists, one of the least believable parts of the Clinton proposal is his prediction that it will reduce deficits by a total of $91 billion over seven years.
Administration officials suggested today that these savings would be a bargaining chip in negotiations with Congress, which will be forced to choose between deficit reduction and a generous health insurance plan available to all by 1997.
"I think the deficit-reduction number is going to be vulnerable on Capitol Hill," Mr. Panetta said. "The large question for Capitol Hill to answer is, 'Do you want to achieve this much in terms of deficit reduction, or do you want to lessen the amount of deficit reduction and lessen the hit in terms of some of the other programs?' You're going to see some trade-off here."
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton had still not decided whether to propose an increase in taxes on liquor, beer and wine. This decision may not be made before the President's speech on Wednesday, they said. Mr. Clinton refused to tip his hand. "I've never said I would tax any kind of alcohol," he said at lunch today.
 
Total Cost Uncertain
 Asked about this, Mr. Altman said, "I heard someone say the President is upstairs having a drink and cigar and will make that decision shortly."
Mr. Altman, Mr. Panetta and other officials said they still did not know the total cost that would be imposed on businesses, families and households by the President's plan, which would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of health insurance costs for workers.
At a White House briefing today, Mr. Panetta and Mr. Altman, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and Robert E. Rubin, assistant to the President for economic policy, all defended Mr. Clinton's proposals for financing his health plan. But they have voiced profound doubts about many aspects of the plan in secret deliberations with the President and Mrs. Clinton, Administration officials said.
As labor announced its support, John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union, said, "The Clinton plan was enthusiastically and unanimously endorsed today" by the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the governing body of the federation.
While some unions have concerns about specific details, he said, "we believe the President has been bold and courageous in coming forward with this plan, the most comprehensive proposal for health care reform since Harry Truman's day."
Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said Mr. Clinton's plan would be good "for working people, good for their families and good for the country."
Mr. Kirkland said the federation would wage a major campaign to win Congressional approval of the Clinton plan. "Of course," he said, "we expect a tough fight. We do not expect those who profit from the inequities of the current health care system to give up their stranglehold without a fight. They may have money, but we've got the people on our side."
Mr. Clinton said his proposal would provide access to abortion for most women. Abortion will not be mentioned explicitly but may be covered under the heading of "pregnancy-related services," he said.
This is the way private insurance policies cover abortion, he said. They do not specify coverage of abortion, brain surgery, appendectomy or any other particular procedure, he said.
