HEADLINE: 2 Powerful Democrats Battle Over Transportation Projects

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The chairmen of two House committees are battling over $305 million in transportation projects that critics call pork and supporters call indispensable.
Representative Bob Carr, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Transportation, touched off the dispute by adding the projects to a $37.7 billion transportation spending bill. 
 In doing so, he enraged Representative Norman Y. Mineta, the California Democrat who heads the Public Works and Transportation Committee, which appropriates the money and is intended to set overall transportation policy.
The lines between the two panels are sometimes blurred.
"These conflicts are not just common, they're endemic, particularly between that committee and subcommittee," said Joseph White, a research associate at the Brookings Institution who is an expert on the appropriations process. "It's common for both chairmen to try to prove their mettle."
 
More for Michigan
 The dispute, expected to reach the House floor on Wednesday, involves 58 projects for highways, bridges, rail crossings and airport runways. Mr. Carr wants to give $109 million, more than one third of the new money, to projects in his home state; the states of other subcommittee members would also benefit.
Financing for the projects would come at the expense of money already earmarked for 41 states. New York, for example, would lose $15 million, New Jersey $8.5 million and Connecticut $6 million. California, Mr. Mineta's state, would lose $11 million.
To Mr. Mineta, Mr. Carr is engaged in a power grab and has violated a House rule against using a money bill to set policy. "There has been no review of all possible projects to determine that these are the best investments we could possibly make," the San Jose Congressman said in a letter to colleagues last month.
To Mr. Carr, Mr. Mineta is battling to preserve his turf at a time when his committee approves a policy bill only every five or six years, while money is appropriated annually. He said his committee conducted hearings on all the projects, and many more.
Both chairmen assumed their positions last January.
"What it boils down to is ego and pride of authorship," Mr. Carr said. "Any policy that impacts on money is of interest to us and is within our jurisdiction."
Mr. Carr said Mr. Mineta had not objected when the Appropriations Committee added money for California. He also noted that states, counties and municipalities sometimes ran out of needed money during the five or six years between authorization bills.
 
Trouble Ahead in Senate
 After criticism of his panel as a pork barrel haven, Mr. Carr in May adopted economic criteria for judging projects. The 58 projects passed a cost-benefit analysis, he said.
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Transportation, said today that he would block Mr. Carr's effort to add projects.
Even if the House approved the projects, Mr. Lautenberg said, "we're going to eliminate them" when the bill goes to a House-Senate conference.

HEADLINE: Ivy League Finds Itself Locked in Bidding War For Prospective Students

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
In the two years since an antitrust action led Ivy League institutions to stop setting common limits on awards to scholarship applicants, the colleges are increasingly being drawn into bidding wars for promising students, officials say.
A student can now receive financial aid offers that vary as much as $5,000 from college to college in the Ivy League. "We have certainly seen in the past two years more instances of significant divergences in financial aid awards," said James O. Freedman, the president of Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H. "What it does to us is a student calls us up and says, 'This institution gave me $2,000 or $4,000 or $5,000 more than you did.' That rarely happened before." 
 It was in part to avoid this that in the 1950's the colleges began sharing information about the most promising students and agreeing to fix the amount of scholarship aid. The practice, which also included the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was called "overlapping" and was accomplished through quarterly meetings of college financial officers. For many students, the amount of aid is a major factor in deciding to attend one of the eight Ivy League institutions, where tuition is the highest in the nation, averaging $25,000 this year.
But two years ago, faced with an antitrust action from the Justice Department, the colleges signed a consent decree in which they pledged to abandon the practice. Only M.I.T. refused to go along, contending that the Sherman Antitrust Act's prohibition of corporate price fixing should not apply to institutions of higher learning. Rather, it said, laws governing charitable institutions should apply. The goal of the scholarship meetings, it contended, was to spread resources more equitably and insure that there was enough scholarship money for poor and minority students.
 
Support From Appeals Court
 Until last week, it appeared that the university's argument, and more than $1 million in legal fees, had gone for naught. A Federal District Court had supported the Justice Department, but last week the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, gave M.I.T.'s contention new life, sending it back to the lower court for a new trial. The appeals court included an instruction that the university be permitted to make its case that it should be treated as a charitable institution.
The Ivy League universities were buoyed by the decision, even as they continued to adhere to the consent decree. Officials at most institutions said yesterday that they hoped the courts would ultimately back the overlapping practice. They added that they were still reviewing the court's opinion.
"We are happy that the court remanded the case back to the lower court," said Jon New, a spokesman for Harvard University who declined to make further comment on the decision. He said Harvard officials were studying the ruling to determine "what steps we will take."
But the Ivy League institutions lamented that as more students and parents began to understand the consent decree and became more sophisticated in shopping for the best financial aid package, an unprecedented wave of competition for financial assistance had resulted.
 
Seeking Market Forces
 The Justice Department, in arguing against the practice of overlapping, had contended that financial aid awards granted under it were essentially a form of price fixing. The scholarships were discounts from tuition, the department said, and it argued that the price of tuition should be set by market forces.
Some financial-aid experts have asserted that the benefits of such market competition should be available, particularly as the cost of a four-year college education continues to rise.
Student shopping for the best aid packages has been common for years among major public universities and the so-called public Ivies, like the University of Michigan, the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Texas at Austin.
In a study released yesterday by the College Board, tuition rates rose by nearly twice the rate of inflation last year. Four-year private institutions charged about 6 percent more, with the national average being $11,025. Four-year public institutions charged about 8 percent more, for a national average of $2,527.
 
Same Pool of Students
 The Ivy League institutions -- Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton, Yale and the University of Pennsylvania -- compete in the same pool of the nation's brightest students. They argue that the heightened competitiveness for bigger financial aid awards has been detrimental to both the colleges and their potential students.
In the last school year, Princeton University outspent its financial aid budget by $100,000 in part because of higher costs and the added dimension of students shopping for the best aid packages.
Princeton's total financial aid package, including scholarships, loans and work-study programs, for the average student receiving financial aid increased to $13,635 in the last school year, up from $13,136 the year before. The cost of tuition, room and board rose to $24,650 for the 1993-94 school year, up from $23,267 the year before. Other institutions reported similar increases, reflecting the increased comparison shopping by students and their families.
"Frequently when people come to this issue of students' and parents' shopping around, the question is, 'Well, isn't this just all to the good?' " said Robert Durkee, vice president for public affairs at Princeton. "The problem is that resources are finite.
"And so if one student gets more aid, then that money has to come from someplace else. And frequently it comes from awards that you can make to other students. That's why institutions have been concerned about these additional awards above need."

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Pal, Teacher and Now Power Broker: A Gathering Force of One at Pentagon

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
A combination of necessity and personal connections has suddenly transformed a little-known chemistry professor from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology into one of the most influential powerbrokers at the Pentagon.
Saddled with the deceptively bland title of Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition and technology, the official, John M. Deutch has parlayed his scientific sophistication and his longtime friendship with Defense Secretary Les Aspin into a role as the Pentagon's point man on issues from base closings and nuclear testing to military industry conversion. As the Pentagon's chief of acquisitions, Mr. Deutch (pronounced doych) is nominally responsible for overseeing the Pentagon's annual budget of about $100 billion for weapons and equipment -- out of a total military budget of $273 billion this year -- as well as nearly 800 scientists, engineers, logisticians and weapons experts. 
 But when the Administration delayed filling a raft of senior civilian posts at the Pentagon, Mr. Aspin repeatedly heaped new chores on his old college friend. "In bureaucratic terms, Deutch is the ink blot who's expanded in the power vacuum," said a senior House Democratic aide.
 
More Duties, in Tokyo
 Mr. Deutch, a 55-year-old former top Energy Department official, broadened his portfolio a bit more this week when he traveled to Tokyo to discuss sharing America's ballistic missile defense technology. Japan is deeply concerned over North Korea's recent test-launching of a long-range nuclear missile.
Later this month, a review board headed by Mr. Deutch is expected to decide the fate of the C-17, a new $40 billion cargo plane plagued by cost overruns and technical flaws. And in October, Mr. Deutch will oversee long-range budget plans from each of the military services to insure that they conform with the Administration's overall post-cold war military blueprint.
Mr. Deutch's style is hardly professorial. He is loud, brash and confrontational and has set out to shake up the Pentagon bureaucracy. "I found the C-17 to be an egregious example of poor management in the program," Mr. Deutch said in typically blunt fashion during a recent interview. "This program is in very deep trouble."
But then his academic roots have long reached deeply into the Federal Government: M.I.T. has for decades been so close to the military that some have called it a Pentagon farm team. While generally unknown outside policy circles, Mr. Deutch has been a familiar Washington insider for decades.
 
McNamara 'Whiz Kid'
 He has bounced between M.I.T. and Democratic administrations since he joined the Pentagon in 1961 as one of Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's original "whiz kids." Along the way he has gotten to know many who have gone on to top jobs in Washington, like the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey Jr., a longtime friend.
As the No. 3 official at the Department of Energy under President Jimmy Carter, Mr. Deutch ran all Federal energy research laboratories, and he commissioned a study on the physical condition and management of Government-operated nuclear installations after the disaster at the commercial power plant at Three Mile Island, Pa.
Some friends say Mr. Deutch, who was a finalist to be Secretary of Energy in the Bush Administration, was disappointed he was not offered a Cabinet post this time around. But associates say he is carving out a huge power base in his new job by combining his technical prowess, policymaking experience and close ties to Mr. Aspin and the Deputy Defense Secretary, William J. Perry.
In high-level meetings, the two friends call each other "Aspin" and "Deutch," just as they have since their graduate school days at M.I.T. 30 years ago. As students, Mr. Deutch said, they ate dinner together almost every night, furiously debating public policy into the wee hours.
Associates say Mr. Aspin and Mr. Perry are the intellectual drivers behind Pentagon policy while Mr. Deutch puts the policy into practice. "Les Aspin will have lots of good ideas and Bill Perry is a good strategic thinker, but Deutch is the guy who works out the details and bangs heads together," said Harold Brown, a former Defense Secretary who has known Mr. Deutch for three decades.
In their Pentagon incarnations, Mr. Deutch and Mr. Aspin differ little on goals, Mr. Aspin says. "We substantively want to get to the same place, and if there's any difference, maybe it's in the tactics," he said in an interview, without elaborating.
While Mr. Deutch is admired for his technical understanding of issues and their policy implications, some colleagues say he may be too inclined to reach decisions without fully weighing the potential political damage.
"Government has become more political," Mr. Deutch said, acknowledging the criticism indirectly. "There's a great deal more distrust of Government. Special interests are more intense, and it's a lot harder to get consensus on where the country should be moving."
 
'A Powerful Personality'
 Mr. Deutch can be impatient and abrupt, associates say; during the drafting of the Pentagon's comprehensive long-range plan, which he directed, he was known to race ahead of briefings that did not move along quickly enough.
"John has a very powerful personality, and people who aren't real sure of themselves may feel he is too domineering," Mr. Woolsey said.
Indeed, if Mr. Deutch were a fighter pilot, his call sign would be "Intensity." His tennis games with Mr. Aspin are legendary. ("He's never beaten me and never will," Mr. Deutch said, beaming.)
Even at casual gatherings, friends say standard Washington shoptalk often gives way to Mr. Deutch's latest scientific interest. "If you're ever invited to a barbecue at Deutch's house, the discussion afterward will inevitably turn from politics to more heavy subjects, like techniques for measuring the weight of air," said Rudy de Leon, a top aide to Mr. Aspin.
But his ability to converse as easily in arcane science as in arcane policy has only increased Mr. Deutch's currency with Mr. Aspin. The Defense Secretary chose Mr. Deutch to be the Pentagon's chief advocate for continuing underground nuclear tests for safety purposes.
 
Confident on His Feet
 After Mr. Aspin's presentation of the Pentagon's long-range review early this month, Mr. Deutch stepped up to give more details at a news conference. Nimbly fielding questions, Mr. Deutch all but shunted aside his partner at the lecturn, Adm. David E. Jeremiah, the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Such decisiveness has endeared him to Mr. Aspin, who agonizes over difficult choices. Mr. Deutch will need to marshal all his moxie to meet his most daunting challenge: overhauling the Pentagon's cumbersome and inefficient system of buying weapons and equipment.
The Pentagon has promised to simplify the acquisition process and encourage the use of commercial products and technologies instead of products custom-designed for military needs. "As the defense budget goes down, we don't have the luxury anymore to have separate industrial bases" for the military and the commercial sector, Mr. Deutch said.
Previous Administrations have tried, and largely failed, to streamline the weapons-buying system, running into resistance from the military industry and the Pentagon bureaucracy itself.
So how will this Administration succeed where others have stumbled? "There's a necessity to find the economies which will accomplish acquisition reform that wasn't required in the great expansion of defense budgets in the 1980's," Mr. Deutch said.
Industry executives express concern that Mr. Deutch and other top Pentagon brass lack strong industrial management experience. Mr. Deutch's appointed deputy, R. Noel Longuemare, is a vice president at Westinghouse Electric, but he has not been confirmed by the Senate.
The Administration's new long-range plan for the armed services encourages the military industry to consolidate. But the Pentagon will also keep buying certain advanced weapons, like tanks and nuclear submarines, even if they are not needed, in order to preserve critical technologies for the future.
"I'm worried that their defense conversion effort is too fragmented, too bureaucratic and out of whack with reality," said Bernard L. Schwartz, the chief executive of the Loral Corporation, a large military contractor.
 
Family Fled the Nazis
 Then again, difficult military challenges run in Mr. Deutch's family. Born in Brussels, Mr. Deutch and his family fled ahead of the invading Nazis, first to France and eventually to the United States. His father, an electrical engineer, became the deputy director of America's synthetic rubber program in World War II.
Mr. Deutch attended a private school in Washington before graduating from Amherst College and M.I.T. Between his stints in Government, Mr. Deutch returned to M.I.T. as a chemistry professor and eventually as provost. Friends say a major career disappointment came when Mr. Deutch was passed over to be M.I.T.'s president in 1990.
Divorced with three grown sons, Mr. Deutch now lives in suburban Maryland and has a cottage on Cape Cod. In his Senate confirmation hearings, he said he planned to return to M.I.T. when he leaves the Pentagon.
"I can't maintain many years in Washington without going back to get recharged," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John M. Deutch, a chemistry professor from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is the new Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition and technology. He was photographed recently in Washington. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Whitman Economist Has Reagan Credentials

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
In choosing Lawrence Kudlow to help create her economic plan, Christine Todd Whitman landed a swashbuckling Reagan-era economist who pitches Cadillacs on television and who is eager to try in New Jersey the supply-side economics he alternately embraced and rejected during his tenure in the White House.
Mr. Kudlow, now chief economist of Bear, Stearns & Company, is one of the two architects of an economic revival plan released today by Mrs. Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey. Along with Malcolm Forbes Jr., president of Forbes Inc. and editor in chief of Forbes magazine, Mr. Kudlow helped Mrs. Whitman put together a plan based on the supply-side theory that the best way to stimulate a stagnant economy is by cutting taxes. 
 "Shock therapy," Mr. Kudlow said.
 
The Same Philosophy
 Mr. Kudlow preached the same philosophy when he became deputy budget director under David Stockman during Ronald Reagan's first term as President. But shortly after landing the job, Mr. Kudlow and Mr. Stockman eased off of their supply-side proposals. They advised Mr. Reagan to scale back his tax cuts and to stretch them out over a longer period of time.
"Reagan and the supply-siders believed that cutting taxes first would force spending cuts," Mr. Kudlow said in 1984. "The theory was wrong."
But today Mr. Kudlow said that as governor of New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman would have some things President Reagan did not -- a line-item veto and the power to impound appropriations. In effect, the governor of New Jersey can simply refuse to provide funds for any program, salary or agency he or she chooses. Mrs. Whitman said she would use that power to trim $250 million from the state's 1993-94 budget within her first six months in office.
"If we had that kind of authority I believe we could have made a much bigger dent in Federal spending," Mr. Kudlow said. "Of course, Christie doesn't have to deal with the former Soviet Union in building up the defense budget."
 
'He's Into Power'
 Mr. Kudlow, a graduate of Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, is an impeccable dresser and chain-smoker who appears frequently on television business programs and has pitched Cadillacs for a local automobile dealer. Even his friends say he is more salesman than economic theorist.
"He's into power," said Jude Wanniski, a business consultant and one of the original supply-siders, who has known Mr. Kudlow for 20 years. "He wants to be a celebrity. He's a swashbuckler, a car salesman, a gunslinger. But it's hard to be angry at the guy."
For all his flamboyance, Mr. Kudlow is adept at forecasting, at least in the short term. He correctly foresaw the 1990-91 national recession when conventional wisdom predicted there would be no recession. And he foresaw the start of the end of the recession in the spring of 1991, when most other economists said the economy was still heading downward.
Mr. Kudlow said he met Mrs. Whitman last spring after her successful primary battle and agreed to be co-chairman of her Council for Economic Recovery.
"This was not going to be tinkering around the edges," he said. "I said, Christie, you're going to have to cut income taxes.' She said fine, that was her instinct too."

HEADLINE: SCHOLAR WHO SUED WINS $1.2 MILLION

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS

 BODY:
A Michigan judge ordered the University of Michigan yesterday to pay $1.2 million in damages to a scientist after a jury found that her supervisor had stolen credit for her research and that the university had failed to investigate properly.
The civil case is believed to be the first in which shortcomings in a university's inquiry into an accusation of scientific misconduct brought a large court award, and university officials say they are worried that it may encourage similar lawsuits. Judge Patrick J. Conlin of the Michigan Court of Claims in Washtenaw County issued the order yesterday and is expected to enter it officially today. 
 The suit was brought by Dr. Carolyn Phinney, a research psychologist who had worked on how to define wisdom and measure its accumulation as people age. She conducted interviews in which she asked subjects whom they considered wise and what qualified those on their lists. She found that wise people are commonly identified as those who avoid unwise and destructive actions.
 
Grant Application at Issue
 But Dr. Phinney contended that her supervisor, Dr. Marion Perlmutter, then a senior scientist in the university's Institute of Gerontology, took the work and submitted it for Federal grants for herself without naming Dr. Phinney as a principal investigator.
A university investigation did not determine whether Dr. Perlmutter was guilty of misconduct. Instead, Dr. Richard Adelman, director of the Institute of Gerontology, decided first to appoint colleagues of Dr. Perlmutter to investigate, then to end the investigation and order the two scientists to negotiate an agreement. Both sides refused. Dr. Adelman then suspended Dr. Phinney, whose contract was subsequently not renewed. She is currently unemployed.
Dr. Phinney sued Dr. Perlmutter, Dr. Adelman and the university.
A seven-person jury decided unanimously in May that Dr. Perlmutter had committed fraud in taking credit for the work and that Dr. Adelman had violated a Michigan law in retaliating against Dr. Phinney instead of properly investigating the case.
 
Jury Set Damage Amount
 The jury recommended damages of $130,000 for Dr. Perlmutter's actions and $989,000 for Dr. Adelman's actions. Judge Conlin ordered those amounts to be paid, adding about $100,000 in interest charges.
The university has not decided whether to appeal to the state supreme court. But a university spokesman, Walter Harrison, said the university considered its investigation of the matter sufficient. Mr. Harrison said he was speaking for the university employees who had been sued.
It is the university that is liable for damages.
Susan Knapp, director of publications at the American Psychological Association, who helped write the association's standards for giving credit to scientists, said the Michigan case was important because it was a sign that whistle-blowers and junior faculty members could win a significant case against a university.
She said she believed that the practice in science that has permitted senior authors to take much credit for scientific work merely because they hold the title of chairman or director was now being seriously questioned. Ethics standards issued by the association in recent months state that senior scientists are not entitled to be named as authors of scientific papers merely because of their jobs.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Outlines Plan for Future Economic Growth

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Trying to position himself as an incumbent candidate for change -- a challenging political proposition -- Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday sketched a broad blueprint for future economic growth in New York City, saying he would create 110,000 new private-sector jobs if elected to a second term.
For Mr. Dinkins, who has steadfastly insisted that his administration bore little responsibility for the recession that has cost the city more than 350,000 jobs since 1989, the plan was a sharp departure. He is now stressing job creation instead of job retention. 
 Yesterday, the Mayor proposed targeting a dozen industries with potential for growth -- including recycling, computer software and biotechnology -- and fueling their expansion through two new development funds, using public and private money, and by creating centers to nurture critical industries. The largest single program would be a $250 million economic development bank financed through the city's capital budget to help larger companies expand and to attract new businesses to New York.
The plan was praised by some business leaders. But it was denounced by the Mayor's political opponents and even by a prominent fellow Democrat, Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn, who dismissed the initiative as a political ploy and called it "too little, too late."
"We should have been doing this long before now, not waiting until an election time," Mr. Golden said immediately after the speech.
Mr. Golden, who also made clear that he was dissatisfied with the Mayor -- in part, by a Dinkins administration plan to move a police car pound from Whitestone, Queens, to the Brooklyn waterfront -- said he had not yet decided whom to endorse in the mayoral race.
Throughout the campaign, the Mayor has insisted that he should not be blamed for the job loss in the city because the recession was a national phenomenon. It might be difficult, a Democratic member of the City Council said yesterday, for the Mayor to argue now that he will be responsible for 110,000 new private-sector jobs over the next four years.
Mr. Dinkins suggested in his speech at the Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn that it was only now, when the national recession has ebbed and its effect in New York seems to be diminishing, that it made sense to commit substantial amounts of public money to stimulate the expansion of a dozen selected segments of the local economy.
Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said the city had been forced to take a defensive approach to jobs over the last four years, trying to keep companies in New York that contemplated moving elsewhere.
"It seems to us that now is the time to go on the offense," Mr. Sullivan said in an interview. "The fact that it's political season is in this sense coincidental. We've been working on this for about a year."
The plan, devised by a group of economic-development specialists working under Mr. Sullivan, calls for centers to help along e technological developments in critical industries, including computer software companies, biotechnology concerns and fashion design companies.
It was unclear who would pay for creation of the centers or how much they would cost. But the Mayor did propose establishing funds to help these and other industries to grow. For example, an advanced technology venture capital fund, under his plan, would have a total of $60 million. Of that, $10 million would come from the city, $10 million from private business and $40 million from Federal funds under the Small Business Investment Corporation program.
The proposed fund for job development in small and mid-sized businesses would also total $60 million and would use the same formula as the venture capital fund. Mr. Sullivan said the city's contributions would come from the operating budget; such money has not yet been appropriated and would require approval by the City Council.
The $250 million economic development bank would be financed by the city capital budget, Mr. Sullivan said. Because of the fiscal strains caused by the recession, the city has been cutting back the size of the capital budget in recent years. Mr. Dinkins would no doubt have to cancel or postpone some rebuilding projects to free up capital money for the proposed development bank.
"The plan you have in your hands is the real thing," the Mayor said in his speech. Then he took a jab at his Republican-Liberal opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani. "It doesn't promise what it can't deliver," he said. "And we won't change our minds 10 times after the 10 o'clock news."
Christyne Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, was similarly dismissive of the Mayor's proposal. "It's not a credible plan," she said. "Under Dinkins, New York City lost nearly 400,000 private-sector jobs and crushed small businesses with onerous fines and fees. He blames Reagan and Bush; he blames everyone but himself. He needs to stop playing the blame game and he needs to take responsibility."
"To target anything with 42 days left to the election is basically a joke," Ms. Lategano added.
Ronald K. Shelp, president of New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, called the Mayor's plan innovative. Mr. Shelp said that Mr. Dinkins had singled out the right industries for growth and that few if any cities had ever tried to create their own industrial development policies. But he said he did not know if the city could buck national and international economic trends on its own.
"We won't know until it's tried," Mr. Shelp said. "I think it's worth trying because we've got a trend: we've got a declining economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins introduced his plan for future economic growth in New York City yesterday, saying he would create 110,000 new private-sector jobs if elected to a second term. With him at the Metrotech Center in Brooklyn was Peter F. Vallone, right, City Council Speaker. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lending Plan Clears Senate Panel

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee today approved the Clinton Administration's program for spurring lending in poor communities, adding provisions to make borrowing by small businesses easier and to protect consumers from exploitation by home-equity lenders.
Some Republicans expressed doubts over the plan, pushed by the Clinton Administration to fulfill a campaign promise to provide seed money for unconventional lenders that make loans in poor communities where regular bankers are reluctant to lend. 
 But they went along with the plan in part because it also included provisions drafted by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, the panel's ranking Republican, to help create a secondary market in which loans to small businesses could be bundled and resold.
 
 
Reaction From Consumer Groups
 Consumer groups said the provisions to discourage home-equity lending abuses were a step in the right direction, although such provisions had been watered down somewhat.
The package was approved nearly unanimously, over the sole dissent of Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, who said its loan subsidies and usury limits represented a financial philosophy that had been "rejected all over the world except in North Korea and Cuba."
At the heart of the package is the Clinton Administration's proposal to spend $382 million over four years to promote the formation and expansion of community development financial institutions geared toward lending in low-income areas.
The most debated aspect of the program was whether to allow regular banks to qualify for Federal capital grants of up to $5 million that would be handed out to financial institutions specializing in community development, like community development loan funds and credit unions.
 
 
Clinton Proposal
 The Clinton Administration, in its proposal, had ruled out letting regular banks qualify for the subsidies through their specialized community development subsidiaries, which some banks use to make loans to poor borrowers. Such loans help banks comply with terms of the Community Reinvestment Act, a longstanding obligation.
The bill approved today would allow community development subsidiaries partly owned by regular banks or savings and loans to qualify for the subsidies, as long as no one company owns more than 25 percent of a single community development institution.
The question of letting ordinary banks participate directly in the program will arise again in the House, which has yet to draft its own version of the bill.
 
 
One House Plan
 Representative Floyd H. Flake, a Queens Democrat, and Representative Tom Ridge, a Pennsylvania Republican, are pushing a plan that would expand the program further by reducing the deposit insurance premiums paid by banks if they expand their community development lending. This approach is permitted under existing law, but money has never been made available to offset the premiums.
Other members of the House Banking Committee, however, have opposed that approach and have favored the Administration's original bill, which allows the subsidies only for banks whose primary purpose is lending in distressed communities.
The Senate bill's provisions to expand small business lending are viewed as a major change in existing law that may have far-reaching consequences. The idea is that banks will more willingly lend to small businesses if they can then sell the loans to other investors, who would buy interests in packages of loans in much the same way that home mortgages are currently bundled and resold.
 
 
Removing Regulations
 The approach conceived by Senator D'Amato accomplishes this by removing regulatory obstacles, not by setting up any new quasi-Government agency like those that sponsor secondary markets in mortgages and other financial instruments.
The provisions cracking down on abuses in home-equity lending are a response to hearings in which lawmakers were told of lenders making credit available at extremely high interest rates or with other onerous expenses, using a borrower's home as equity. When the borrower could not repay the loans, the lenders would foreclose on the property.
The bill would apply to loans charging interest rates of more than 10 percentage points above Treasury interest rates for securities of comparable maturity, or with initial points and fees of more than $400 or 8 percent of the loan's value, whichever is greater.
In such cases, lenders would have to provide special disclosures making clear the risks to the borrowers, disclosing the monthly costs and other loan features at least three days before the loan was completed.
But consumer groups said these provisions did not go far enough, especially since they did not apply to home equity lines of credit, in which the loan is not necessarily provided in a lump sum but can be borrowed in pieces up to a fixed limit.

HEADLINE: August Housing Starts Surged to 3 1/2-Year High

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Housing starts bounced back in August after an early summer slump to the highest level in three and a half years, the Government reported today.
Starts of new homes and apartments jumped 7.8 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million in August, the highest since a 1.44 million rate in February 1990, the Commerce Department reported today. 
 It was the biggest increase since housing starts advanced 11.1 percent a year earlier. Starts were up in every region except for the Northeast, where the drop was the first in five months.
Economists said the surge was stimulated by low mortgage rates. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.11 percent during August. The average rate was 6.96 percent last week, near a 25-year low and below 7 percent for a fourth straight week.
 
Low Rates 'the Dominant Factor'
 "Clearly the interest rates were the dominant factor," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "Job growth is still slow. Household formation is still slow."
Earlier in the summer, housing starts fell 1.7 percent in July after remaining flat in June. So far this year, the rate is 3.2 percent higher than it was for the first eight months of 1992.
The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said, "One month does not a trend make, but this is the first real sign that lower interest rates and lower prices seem to have a positive impact on the housing industry."
Economists expect interest rates to remain low in the months ahead. Federal Reserve policy makers were meeting privately today. Analysts believe that the Fed will decide to hold short-term rates steady because inflation remains in check and the economy continues to grow modestly.
Despite low mortgage rates, sales of new homes fell in July for the second time in three months. On the other hand, sales of previously owned homes, which are generally less expensive, rose for four months through July.
 
Permits Up
 A rise in applications for permits to build homes showed builders were optimistic about sales in August. Applications increased 7.5 percent for the month, to a 1.25 million rate, the highest level since 1.33 million in February 1990 and the second straight advance.
Mr. Seiders and other analysts predicted housing starts would stay near the August level the rest of the year. If so, they would total 1.24 million by the end of the year, up from 1.20 million in 1992 and 1.01 million in 1991.
Starts of single-family homes jumped 11 percent in August, to a 1.18 million rate, the highest since 1.23 million in September 1987.
Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, said the single-family sector was "really the only sector in which we can expect strength in the near future."
"The multifamily sector is still having to deal with the fact that we have a large inventory overhang of apartment buildings and therefore high vacancy rates among renters," he said.
Still, starts of multifamily housing rose 6.7 percent in August, to a rate of 143,000. Starts of apartments with five or more units rose 2.6 percent. Mr. Seiders attributed the gain to the restoration in August of a Federal tax credit for low-income housing.

HEADLINE: More Saving Is Urged

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Baby boomers must put away far more savings to insure a comfortable retirement, a Congressional panel was told today.
"The average baby boomer must triple his or her rate of savings to avoid a precipitous decline of living standards during retirement," Douglas Bernheim, a Princeton economics professor, told the House Ways and Means Committee's subcommittee on social security. 
 Professor Bernheim's findings contradict a recent study by the Congressional Budget Office that said baby boomers in educated, two-income families would be better off in retirement than their parents.
Many researchers have questioned whether there will be enough private and public resources to take care of the baby boomers -- roughly 76 million people born between 1946 and 1964 -- when they begin retiring early in the next century.
The budget office director, Robert D. Reischauer, told the subcommittee that the Congressional study dispelled some of the "scare rhetoric" about the baby boom generation.
But Professor Bernheim said the budget office report failed to consider differences in the economic climates experienced by baby boomers and their parents.
To maintain their standard of living after retirement, baby boomers must save more than their parents did at the same age, Professor Bernheim said. That is partly because they cannot expect their earnings to grow as rapidly as their parents' earnings did. Also, many boomers are having children later than their parents had, leaving less time after the child-rearing years to save money.

HEADLINE: BACKSTAGE WITH: Kurt Masur;
Politics, Podiums And a Maestro's Two Homes

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
HANGING on the wall above the stage-door guard's desk at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center are a good-luck horseshoe, a smallish American flag and a black-and-white photograph of Kurt Masur.
Mr. Masur, the bearlike German conductor whose off-the-podium trademark is a bolo tie, is no longer a visitor in New York. Upstairs in his office yesterday, he was eating takeout chili and talking about old movies he watches on his big-screen projection television. Tonight, he will begin his third season as the music director of the hometown orchestra, the New York Philharmonic. But he has not forgotten his first impressions of an intimidating city. 
 "Guest conducting, I felt lost here," he said. "You are surrounded by a lot of people, but you can feel very lonesome. I started thinking, 'How to meet those people, how to build concerts so people will know the Philharmonic plays for everybody, not just those with lots of money.' "
Looking across the room toward the garretlike floor-to-ceiling window, Mr. Masur said he had warmed to New York, now his home for five months of the year. He is juggling two orchestras: besides the Philharmonic, he remains the music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus in Germany. But on this afternoon, 36 hours before the first downbeat of the Philharmonic's season, he jumps from topic to topic, from how he once tried to get the composer Dmitri Shostakovich to change a single word in a chorus (Shostakovich said no) to how Mr. Masur's two cities have common problems: the homeless, the unemployed. "It seems nobody has a solution anywhere," he said.
He has squeezed his 6-foot-plus frame into a small chair, and his voice is quieter than it is when he is commanding the Philharmonic at rehearsal. Of course, his office, with its black leather sofa and medium-size Steinway, is smaller than the 2,800-seat Avery Fisher Hall; with the season about to begin, it still looks a bit unlived-in. His English is occasionally less than perfect, and he struggles to translate a German word or two, but there is no disguising his warmth for the musicians in the Philharmonic.
"I never wanted to change the orchestra," he said. "I thought I knew the orchestra before I came and thought I knew beneath the surface that this orchestra could only earn respect for what they do. What we could build is trust between the leading people: management, myself and the orchestra."
And so he has made the Philharmonic, once the orchestra of Gustav Mahler, Arturo Toscanini and Leonard Bernstein, his own, from top to bottom. On the stage are acoustical baffles he demanded, to improve the hall's murky sound. He has also scheduled "rush hour concerts" with a 6:45 P.M. starting time, for commuters too impatient to wait for the Philharmonic's 8 P.M. curtain.
In addition, he scheduled a series of forums at which anyone in the audience could ask him a question, no topic off-limits. One man asked what Mr. Masur could do to bring peace to Crown Heights, the Brooklyn neighborhood where violence erupted between blacks and Hasidic Jews a few weeks before Mr. Masur's first concert in 1991. (He says he cannot remember the answer he gave.)
He himself is a commuter. He lives in Rye, N.Y., with his wife, the violist and soprano Tomoko Sakurai, and their 16-year-old son, Ken David. Mr. Masur rides to rehearsals in a chauffeur-driven sedan and spends the time on the telephone to the Gewandhaus, "ruling Leipzig from a car," he says with a hint of a smile. He arrived on Monday to find new carpet in the aisles at Avery Fisher and fresh off-white paint in the lobby (no more dark brown walls).
Watching him rehearse is like watching a one-man aerobics class: he works up a sweat and changes shirts during rehearsal breaks every hour or so. Sometimes he talks over the orchestra, counting rhythms aloud like a piano teacher urging a student on before the big recital: "One AND two AND one AND two."
Sometimes he puts words of a kind to the music. On Monday afternoon he sang the opening chords to Beethoven's Overture to "Fidelio" like this: "SMET-a-na! SMET-a-na! SMET-a-na's my name!"
The point was the accents in a piece the orchestra had played dozens of times before. "If you do not do something fresh," he said, "it is like you are reading too fast and skipping over words, and that is just no good."
He was something of a surprise choice when the Philharmonic named him to succeed Zubin Mehta in April 1990. For 20 years he had been the music director of the Gewandhaus in Leipzig, a post that had once belonged to Mendelssohn. But beyond Leipzig, he was perhaps better known for his role in the democratization of the old East Germany as the Communist order collapsed. In that country's last few months he was mentioned as a candidate for president.
He is once again the subject of political speculation. His name appeared in press reports last month as a possible candidate for the presidency of Germany. Even Deborah Borda, the Philharmonic's managing director, could not resist teasing him about the rumors. At the season's first rehearsal, on Monday, she introduced him as "President Masur."
Now, as then, he maintains that it is not a job he wants.
"I answered this in 1990," he says. "Now I have one more reason: I am happy with two of the best orchestras of the world. And there is no reason to go into politics because I believe I can't change anything anymore."
He continued: "There's only one positive point in that, that people are trusting musicians. That's a good sign. This is coming from people who're tired, tired of power plays by politicians forgetting people. There's nobody like Clinton, who's younger, trying something new. In that direction, Germans are jealous of Americans' taking some risks."
But a day with Mr. Masur in New York is not about politics. And before long he was back on the podium, rehearsing again. The orchestra will play four concerts in the next six days, starting with tonight's televised concert. His programs are more varied than some Americans expected from a conductor who had spent so much of his career in Europe, in a city Bach called home. This year he will conduct everything from a world premiere of symphony by Alfred Schnittke to the Mahler's Ninth Symphony.
On nights the Philharmonic has off, Mr. Masur makes the rounds of everything from other classical concerts to jazz clubs like Michael's Pub, where Woody Allen sometimes sits in as a clarinetist. His son plays the piano and is learning the trumpet. "He's doing jazz also," Mr. Masur said, "so at home I listen to everything."
With his wife, they sometimes have family chamber concerts. (Mr. Masur has four older children from two previous marriages.) And on his giant television, they watch movies. One favorite, he said, is an old German movie about Johann Sebastian Bach's son Wilhelm Friedemann Bach, also a composer.
In juggling his two orchestras, Mr. Masur said, he had had to learn that being a music director in the United States is different from in Europe. In Europe, if the scheduled time for a break comes when the orchestra is five bars from the end of a piece, they stay on and work out the five bars. Here, under the musicians' contract with the orchestra, they stop.
In Lepizig, he has a say in every usher who is hired, every paycheck that goes out, duties that American orchestras leave to administrators. Mr. Masur says it is not completely different. "I'm interested in everything," he said. "Deborah Borda talks to me about her artistic impressions. I talk about how it's going in business. Of course, there in Leipzig, everyone expects me to say this or this or that, but I never do it alone. We have very democratic kinds of decisions.
"Very often if there are problems with conductors and an orchestra, it's not a mistake of both parties, it could be the mistake of management, trying to split them both, expecting the conductor would not care about the social problems of the musicians." He said he could succeed only if the musicians "feel I accept them as partners." If he had a cold relationship with the orchestra members, he said, "I couldn't live with it."

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
"AT $5 a box I'm not going to buy any of those," said the woman who was poring over the shelves of cold cereals at a supermarket. "I'm going to stick with oatmeal."
She was reflecting a growing sentiment among shoppers that cold cereals, as well as many other brand-name products, cost too much. And they are registering their disapproval in numerous ways: switching to other brands or waiting for coupons and two-for-one offers that reduce the cost by as much as $1. 
 More often than in the past, shoppers are turning to supermarket brands, rather than those of some national company. The reason is simple: the difference in price between the private-label brand and the national-brand of cereal is significant: often more than a $1 a pound.
What everyone wants to know is whether the lower price affects the nutritional quality or the taste.
The answer is no.
As the shopper of the 80's who rarely looked at a price tag has given way to the shopper of the 90's who wants to know what everything costs, cereals that sell for more than boneless chicken breasts, or even some cuts of beef, are being scrutinized. Cereal prices rose 71 percent between 1983 and 1991, almost double the 37 percent increase in food prices in general, according to the Food Marketing Policy Center of the University of Connecticut at Storrs.
Sales of private-label cereals increased 6 percent between 1991 and 1992, from 171 million boxes of cereal to 181 million boxes, according to the Private Label Manufacturers Association in New York. Sales of national brands went up less -- by 4 percent -- but the disparity in market share is still enormous. In 1992, 2.4 billion boxes of brand-name cereals were sold.
Although private-label brands still represent a tiny part of overall cereal sales, the industry is worried, and there is talk about the plight of national brands. In a column in the July 26 issue of Supermarket News, David Merrefield wrote, "There's ample reason to acknowledge that brands are under increasing pressure and that low-overhead private labels are in ascendancy."
Researchers say that the retail price of a box of a national-brand cereal is more than double the actual cost of producing it and that 15 to 20 percent of the retail price is profit to the manufacturer. For years supermarket chains have carried private-label brands for everything from coffee to toilet paper, but their general reputation was that they were lower-quality imitations of national brands.
In recent years there have been efforts to upgrade the quality of the private-label offerings, in some instances even making them premium quality, and today it is almost impossible to tell the difference between a private-label cold cereal and its national-brand counterpart.
Many supermarket chains have several private-label brands of the most popular cereals like corn flakes and Rice Krispies. In the last few years the Kroger supermarket chain has expanded its line of store-brand cereals from 6 or 8 to 22. Paul Bernish, a company spokesman, said sales so far this year are 28 percent ahead of 1992, with gains for all but one of the private-label cereals.
Jeffrey Nedelman, the vice president for public affairs at the Grocery Manufacturers of America, a trade group in Washington, said: "The recession has had a profound impact on purchasing habits. People want value -- a combination of quality and price. When the economy is bad, private-label sales spurt up a bit."
According to a survey by the Gallup Organization for the Private Label Manufacturers Association, even though private-label cereals still have only a fraction of the market, acceptance of them is at an all-time high: "Nearly 9 out of every 10 respondents in the Gallup study, or 86 percent, said they have purchased store brands, a level of acceptance that is unparalleled in U.S. consumer history."
More than 70 percent of the 1,215 shoppers surveyed by telephone said a very important consideration was the "quality of store brands." The survey, which was conducted in September and October 1991, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 2.8 percentage points.
There are several private-label cereal manufacturers. One of the biggest is Ralston Purina, which also has a small share of the national-brand market.
The private-label cereals not only come close in taste, appearance and nutrition to the national brands they are copying, but in many instances the packaging is quite similar.
"They get as close as they can without stealing," Mr. Nedelman said.
And they give their products names that usually make it possible to figure out what they are imitating in a matter of seconds. Cheerios becomes Tasteeos, Cocoa Puffs becomes Cocoa Crunchies, and Fruit Loops are Fruit Rings. When the name doesn't provide an immediate clue, the picture on the front of the box does.
Some cereals, like corn flakes, raisin bran and shredded wheat, can use the same names because the names are not trademarked.
When comparing the cereals, there was only one significant difference:private-label raisin bran had more raisins than the national brand. Raisins are a significant source of iron, and in the house brand they provided 100 percent of the Recommended Daily Allowance for iron; Kellogg's Raisin Bran had only 45 percent of the R.D.A. for iron.
The other, less important difference was in the appearance of the bite-size shredded wheat: the pieces in the private-label brand were not neat and tidy little biscuits, like those from Nabisco.
But after they are covered with milk, who would know?

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
There are still people around who get a kick out of meeting former New York Mayor EDWARD I. KOCH, and GEORGETTE SHIPP, a court stenographer from Bergenfield, N.J., is one of them.
Not only did she get to exchange a few words with Mr. Koch yesterday afternoon, but he also gave her $10,000, something she had never anticipated when she happened to walk by a promotion being conducted by the Milton Bradley Company for its newest game, "Oodles." 
 Ms. Shipp, 28, who was laid off from her job in December, was walking to the unemployment office when she noticed a crowd in Bryant Park.
"I remembered that the day before someone had handed me a flier about the game 'Oodles' being played there," she said. "I thought, 'Let me give it a shot.' I noticed Ed Koch there and he is one of the first famous people I've seen in my life, so it was exciting."
She answered three questions from the game so her name went into a bowl for the $10,000 drawing. Mr. Koch picked hers out.
Now Ms. Shipp, who graduated from the Stenotype Academy in New York last month, will be able to buy a computerized court-reporting machine and pay off her student loans.
"You just never know what's going to happen," she said. All that good luck, and Mayor Koch, too.

HEADLINE: Justice for Jurors

 BODY:
There should be cheers for Judith Kaye from jury boxes near and far. As New York State's Chief Judge, she has created a special panel to improve the quality of jury life. It's not just a local problem.
Judge Kaye will rate a gold star if her panelists can dispel the frustration of being yanked away from home or job to sit on uncomfortable chairs in an airless room for days on end, waiting to get on a jury. She already qualifies for a silver star for her considerate initiative. 
 The project has three aims: to increase participation by people who are not now summoned, particularly minorities, and by people who duck their duty by claiming exemption; to make the system more efficient, and to make jury duty "a positive experience."
It is already positive for most people who actually make it onto a jury, where they experience a trial and then reach a verdict. But for the many who wait in vain for some involvement the experience is negative. One remedy would be to shorten the number of days on duty; let people go home if they don't get on a jury in the first day or two. Or put them on standby, reachable by telephone.
The panel is headed by Colleen McMahon, a partner at a large New York City firm. The 30 panelists include court officials, lawyers and the like. But several were picked simply because they are real people who have served as jurors.
Some things that need fixing cannot be changed without new law -- raising fees for jury duty, or drawing names from new lists like the unemployment and welfare rolls. But some of Judge Kaye's ideas could be carried out without much ado, if only someone would order them done -- like more telephones in the waiting room, things to read, space to get some work done, cleaner rest rooms, child care services, and more.
Ms. McMahon observed the other day that many jurors feel "everything is done for the lawyer's convenience or the judge's convenience, and nothing for the jurors' convenience." Amen. Judge Kaye's concern may make life better for jurors everywhere, if other states follow her lead. But it's enough if she only makes life better for willing-but-thwarted New Yorkers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In America;
Fudging Health Care Costs

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
In the mid-1960's Lyndon Johnson tried to hide the true costs of the Vietnam War from Congress and the American people. He was pushing his Great Society programs and felt that if Congress knew how expensive the war was becoming it would say, in effect, "Mr. President, you can't have both."
And the President knew that instead of financing the Great Society, Congress would choose to finance the war. 
 So Lyndon Johnson concealed the real numbers, declined to seek a tax increase to pay for the war, and set the nation on a moral and fiscal course from which we have yet to recover.
When Richard Nixon ran for President in 1968 he proved to be no more careful with the truth than Lyndon Johnson. Mr. Nixon claimed to have a secret plan to end the war. He didn't. The plan was a fantasy, a figment of a cynical candidate's imagination that was dressed up as fact and sent out to seduce the electorate.
The war went on until 1975.
In 1980 Ronald Reagan told us the biggest whopper of them all. The wonder is that anybody believed him. In his warm and agreeable way, he told us that he would increase military spending, reduce taxes and at the same time, miraculously, he would demolish the deficit and balance the budget.
Mr. Reagan was wildly popular. It was as if Santa Claus had been elected President.
Now Bill Clinton, a fast talker who has already made his share of promises he's been unable to keep, is making his pitch to Congress and the public on health care reform.
The smart money suggests that truth is about to take another shellacking.
With Ronald Reagan's communications director at his elbow, President Clinton claims his plan will bring health care costs under control; will cover every legal resident of the U.S. (including 37 million people who currently have no insurance); will not require a major tax increase, and, incredibly, will generate an extra $91 billion to reduce the budget deficit.
The President insists this will all be accomplished without reducing the quality of medical care.
Enter Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who will try to guide aspects of Mr. Clinton's plan through the Senate Finance Committee. On the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Senator Moynihan said the Administration's claim that it would reap $91 billion in deficit reduction from health care reform was a "fantasy."
And he said the Administration would not get the $238 billion in savings from Medicare and Medicaid that it is planning on. "That's not going to happen," said the Senator.
He suggested that candor would be the Administration's best approach, asserting, "We must not pretend that this is going to be free."
Presidents apparently assume that Americans are incapable of digesting bitter truths. The truth about health care is that major reform cannot be achieved easily or cheaply. There will be pain and sacrifice or there won't be health care reform.
The President has an obligation to be clear about that. There are many benefits to be realized from Mr. Clinton's plan. But it is a proposal that could affect up to one-seventh of the nation's economy. Anything that large has to have some down sides.
Under the plan a significant number of jobs will likely be lost. Many people with good health insurance will pay more and get less coverage. Some health care is likely to be rationed. And it is possible that health care reform could end up adding to the budget deficit.
The President and Hillary Rodham Clinton are now focused on the huge task of selling the health care proposal. The President will give his television address tonight. Tomorrow the Cabinet and other top officials will carry the sales campaign to all 50 states.
Usually in such a campaign the product's benefits are emphasized and its drawbacks or defects are given short shrift. It's the way you sell soap, and cars, and iced tea. It's also the way Lyndon Johnson tried to sell his war and Ronald Reagan sold his economic plan.
It's not the way you want to sell health care reform. The nation deserves a serious and candid discussion of this enormous proposal. And it deserves to hear the truth from its President.

HEADLINE: SUNY Maintains Quality and Access Despite Budget Woes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with interest, and sadness, your recent news article about the devastating cuts to public higher education in California and the impact these cuts seem to be having on the access and opportunity that were once hallmarks of California's great public university systems. 
 Because New York State and the State University of New York have also experienced major budget problems -- but at a much more measured pace, with more political support and without the losses of students to other states or to the streets -- I urge potential students of SUNY (and CUNY) not to lose faith or hope.
The State University of New York has indeed suffered through the most difficult budget years in our history, with reductions of some $200 million over a four-year period. Yet even during the darkest fiscal days of 1991-92, both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the legislative leaders were supportive and constructive in their attitude toward the State University. Budget reductions were reluctantly imposed and efforts were made, as far as possible, to protect SUNY and CUNY.
In recent years both the Governor and the legislative leaders gave SUNY the tools to allow us to manage our way through these fiscal difficulties, first with the 1985 flexibility legislation, then with the 1992 retirement incentives, and this year with additional flexibility measures.
This year, even though the fiscal situation was still tight, the Governor and Legislature approved a budget that gave SUNY the first increase in three years, which seems to have put us on the road to recovery.
Despite our very real problems, SUNY has remained accessible. Enrollments have held constant. New first-time, full-time and transfer enrollments this year will be about the same as last year, and there does not seem to be any exodus of New York students going out of state. This has occurred at a time of significant budget difficulties, and when high school graduating classes in New York State shrank by a stunning 13 percent in only two years.
We are grateful for the support of Governor Cuomo, Senator Ralph J. Marino, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, the chairmen of the Higher Education Committees, Senator Kenneth LaValle and Assemblyman Edward Sullivan, and legislative colleagues. Their support and the austerity spirit of our faculty and campus presidents will help us to continue weathering a slow economic recovery, but keeping SUNY quality and accessibility high.
 
D. BRUCE JOHNSTONE
Chancellor, State University of N.Y.
Albany, Sept. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: Tell Teen-Agers It's Not O.K. to Get Pregnant;
Lack of Disincentives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lynn Martin decries the "past where a child was branded illegitimate or a desperate marriage ruined two or more lives," and she decries it as "equally damaging to ignore the economic and social realities faced today by single teen-age mothers" (Op-Ed, Sept. 8). 
 Unfortunately, these economic and social realities look a lot worse to us than they do to her. Obviously, if they looked as bad to her, she would act differently, as indeed she did in the past. Society fails strongly to disapprove of unwed motherhood and to make such a state abhorrent to the single teen-age mother and to her parent(s). The result is what you see today. That is why society imposed such strictures in the first place!
It is not the incentive of welfare but rather the lack of disincentives -- both societal and economic -- that has led to the current situation. The knowledge that she and her baby won't starve, indeed that they will not even have to inconvenience the existing household -- or even the father by requiring support and extra room -- removes any impediment to the girl, to her parents and to the baby's father. In short, why not?
In the old days the girl's father went after his daughter's lover with a shotgun. Why? Partly because of the shame, and partly because he didn't want the financial responsibility of raising some teen-age boy's children. Today, we all have to raise teen-age boys' children. And the shame is on us, not on them.
The solution is simple. Make birth control available, finance free or inexpensive abortions, at least the first time, and remove all financial assistance. Nature will quickly take its course. The result will be the greatest kindness to the greatest number: a few bad marriages and illegitimate children, but far, far more children born into mature, two-parent families.
 
ELLEN SCHNEIDER
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Sept. 13, 1993

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Vision of Foreign Policy Reversed

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton's national security adviser today presented the first outline of the Administration's foreign policy vision. The adviser, Anthony Lake, said the vision aimed to replace the cold-war policy to contain the Soviet threat with a policy to enlarge the family of democratic market economies.
"The successor to a doctrine of containment must be a strategy of enlargement, enlargement of the world's free community of market democracies," Mr. Lake said in a speech at the School of Advanced International Studies of the Johns Hopkins University. 
 At the time it is announcing its health-care initiative, the Administration has also started a blitz of speeches to define the guiding principles of its foreign policy, after having been criticized by many foreign-policy experts for lacking a coherent framework for making decisions on issues like Bosnia and China.
The public, though, seems to be warming to Mr. Clinton's foreign policy. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted from Sept. 16 to Sept. 18 showed that 52 percent of Americans approved of Mr. Clinton's handling of foreign affairs and 25 percent disapproved, with 23 percent expressing no opinion. A month earlier 42 percent approved, 42 disapproved and 16 expressed no opinion.
 
Response to Critics
 The shift may stem in part from the remarkable handshake at the White House last week between Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. Mr. Clinton presided over the ceremony.
On Monday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher outlined Administration plans to finance the Middle East peace efforts. On Thursday the representative at the United Nations, Madeleine Albright, is to give an address on the use of force and foreign policy, replying to critics who say the Administration has excessively emphasized multilateralism.
Next Monday, President Clinton is to address the United Nations on America's role in international peacekeeping.
The essence of Mr. Lake's speech today in Baltimore was the issue of choice, that in a world in which the United States no longer has to worry daily about a Soviet nuclear threat where and how it intervenes abroad is increasingly a matter of choice. What he tried to do in his hourlong speech was to lay out the broad principles on which the Administration would make its choices.
"To be successful a strategy of enlargement must provide distinctions and set priorities," said Mr. Lake, who cited four areas that should guide foreign policy, but refrained from discussing specifics for places like Bosnia or Somalia.
The highest priority in a strategy of enlargement, he told the students and professors, "must be to strengthen the core of major market democracies, the bonds among them and their sense of common interest." Economic stagnation and its political consequences, Mr. Lake said, "undermine the ability of the major democratic powers to act decisively on our many common challenges, from GATT to Bosnia."
 
'Make the Greatest Difference'
 The second imperative for enlargement is to help democracy and markets expand and survive in places like Russia, Eastern Europe and other former Communist lands "where we have the strongest security concerns and where we can make the greatest difference," said Mr. Lake, who spoke before news of the latest upheaval in Russia.
The goal has to be to transform formerly threatening countries into economic and diplomatic partners. Practically speaking, that means continuing to drum up international economic support for the still fragile Russian efforts and taking tough public positions to staunch the reversal of democracy in places like Haiti, Guatemala and Nigeria, he said.
The third element, he said, are the choices that have to be made to minimize "the ability of states outside the circle of democracy and markets to threaten it." Policy toward rogue states like Iraq or North Korea, Mr. Lake said, has "seek to isolate them diplomatically, militarily, economically and technologically."
The fourth part, he added, has to be deciding where to intervene in human rights tragedies in an era in which restraints on intervention abroad are far fewer than in the days of the superpower confrontation.
"Public pressure for our humanitarian engagement increasingly may be driven by televised images, which can depend in turn on such considerations as where CNN sends its camera crews," Mr. Lake said. "But we must bring other considerations to bear as well, cost, feasibility, the permanence of the improvement our assistance will bring, the willingness of regional and international bodies to do their part and the likelihood that our actions will generate broader security benefits for the people and the region in question."
Mr. Lake said efforts in Somalia and Bosnia were "important expressions of our overall engagement, but they do not by themselves define our broader strategy in the world."
He said although there were "clear reasons to engage and persist" in Bosnia, "they do not obliterate other American interests involving Europe and Russia, and they do not justify the extreme costs of taking unilateral responsibility for imposing a solution."
