HEADLINE: Restaurant Empires Built of Diverse Pieces

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
SEEKING financial stability in rough economic times, chefs and restaurateurs are both diversifying and opening less-expensive places. Rather than staking their futures on a single crown jewel, they are trying to feed people in as many ways and places as they can dream up. They are opening bistros, spaghetti houses, pizza parlors, carryout shops and bakeries. They're providing off-premises catering. And they're selling jams, salsas and T-shirts -- even copies of the restaurant's furniture.
The restaurant mania of the 1980's encouraged the most fashionable chefs to open more than one expensive place, sometimes in different cities. Most of them soon learned that those restaurants could not be sustained without their presence. When the economy worsened and the great shakeout began, their enterprises suffered. Some were left with only their original restaurant; others were left with nothing. Stephan Pyles, who began with the highly acclaimed Routh Street Cafe and Baby Routh in Dallas and went on to open two more restaurants in Minneapolis, has no restaurant now, though he is working on a new place that is expected to open this year in Dallas. 
 The 1990's present a new challenge. Today, said Wolfgang Puck, the Los Angeles chef who is one of the most successful empire builders, security, rather than ego or novelty, is the driving force.
"A single restaurant depends on a particular chef," Mr. Puck said. "It is an added security to have smaller restaurants, cafes, frozen packaged food. Very few people can afford $50 to $60 for dinner."
Many chefs are able to expand into related food businesses because they tend to be better educated and more financially astute than they were two decades ago and because they are in great demand as partners. Like the seamstress in a little atelier whose ability with a needle turned her talent into a clothing empire, these chefs have parlayed their signature restaurants into culinary empires.
"The opportunities are so much greater today for chefs," Mr. Puck said. "People come to them to open new places." Mr. Puck began earlier than most to parlay the success of Spago, which opened in 1982 in Los Angeles, into Chinois on Main in Santa Monica, Calif.; Spago in Tokyo; Postrio in San Francisco; Granita in Malibu, Calif., and most recently Wolfgang Puck's California Cafe in Universal City, a semi-fast-food restaurant that specializes in pizza and grilled chicken.
But even Mr. Puck has made some costly mistakes. His brewery-restaurant, Eureka, folded in 1992 and lost $5 million. "I made a mistake making the brewery and the restaurant one company," he said. "The restaurant was very successful, but the brewery drained all the money. We were undercapitalized. It was a good lesson not to be involved in something over which I have no control."
An effort to market frozen desserts in 1986 also flopped. "We probably overestimated what we could do. The desserts were too expensive -- $2 to $2.25 a portion," he said. "It was very badly planned." Mr. Puck has been very successful with his frozen-pizza business, which started in the late 80's and has been in the black for three years.
Mark Miller of Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M., and Red Sage in Washington has also been experimenting with diversification. Both restaurants have retail stores selling food, T-shirts, cookbooks and trinkets. The Santa Fe store, Coyote Casino, is quite successful, earning $750,000 a year in its 800 square feet, Mr. Miller said. "The only way to have a top-quality restaurant is to have a diversified income," Mr. Miller said. "We lower our costs in the restaurant when we buy in large amounts."
The combination store-restaurant concept also provides a certain synergy. "When you buy a Ralph Lauren T-shirt, you are buying into a certain life style," he said. "When you are eating in a certain restaurant, you are buying into a certain style represented by the restaurant. A store makes the style of the restaurant more accessible."
Even the design elements of Red Sage are for sale, if somebody asks. Someone bought a dozen solid cherry, leather upholstered chairs at $600 each. But T-shirts with the Red Sage logo remain the best sellers. "We sell a T-shirt that costs $7 for $15," Mr. Miller said. "We make the same $8 as we make off $100 worth of food, and it's advertising and it doesn't go bad."
The Red Sage General Store has not proven to be as successful as the Coyote Casino. Donald Senich, the general manager of all the Red Sage enterprises, said the reason may be because the clientele in the Washington restaurant is made up largely of business people, while in Santa Fe the customers tend to be tourists who have time to browse in the store next door.
Mr. Miller is looking for other ways to make and save money. Red Sage is starting to buy produce and fish directly from the wholesale market, cutting out the middlemen, a move that is expected to save 30 percent. It has also contracted with farmers in nearby Virginia to grow fruits and vegetables for the restaurant next year.
Meanwhile, another Coyote Cafe is scheduled to open in Las Vegas, Nev., in mid-December, and Mr. Miller is planning a series of Asian restaurants that could be replicated easily.
Unlike other chefs who always want to be connected to a stove, Mr. Miller, who is an anthropologist by training, seems bitten by the entrepreneurial bug. "It's very hard, once you start running companies, to cook someone's chicken on the grill," he said.
Michel Richard of Citrus in Los Angeles, who started his professional life as a pastry chef, has a different perspective. No matter how far-flung his empire, he never wants to be away from his pots and pans. "Being a chef is a religion," he said. But having an empire is good for the ego and for security.
"I like to see my name all over the place. I have a big ego. I also have six kids, and it's tough to make money in one place."
Citrus has bred a smorgasbord of business ventures: three less-expensive versions of itself -- Citronelle, in Santa Barbara, Calif., Washington and Baltimore; a sorbet shop in Washington; the Broadway Deli in Santa Monica; a business that sells jams, olive oil and souvenirs at Los Angeles International Airport, which are also sold at the Broadway Deli; a videocassette on cooking, and a cookbook to be published in November. Mr. Richard is also talking with Villeroy & Boch about putting out a line of china.
Some restaurateurs are building similar empires. The Santo family, owners of the Sign of the Dove, have four other, lower-priced restaurants in Manhattan -- Arizona 206, its cafe, Contrapunto and Yellowfingers, each with a different theme -- as well as Ecce Panis, a bakery with two locations. Ecce Panis supplies bread to all the restaurants and to the public.
The original bakery and the restaurants are within a five-block area on the Upper East Side. "That makes it manageable," said Henny Santo, one of the owners. "If we have a problem, it allows us to be at all five restaurants within the hour.
"Opening two Sign of the Doves is not economically feasible today," she said. "Different types of restaurants are more interesting to create and allow for diversity. Depending on economic times, one restaurant may not be doing well, and with other kinds of restaurants you have a cushion." Mrs. Santo said that after the stock-market crash in 1987, which signaled the beginning of a recession in New York, the restaurants with less-expensive meals "were supporting the Dove," where the prices are higher.
Even Kin Khao, a two-year-old Thai restaurant in SoHo, has diversified, opening an Asian grocery and noodle shop. Brad Kelley, who owns the restaurant and store with Lee Ping, said they hoped to open noodle shops elsewhere in the city, something they would not do with Kin Khao because "it would lose its uniqueness."
Mark Peel and Nancy Silverton always knew that one restaurant would not provide an economic cushion. "The restaurant is not your retirement," Mr. Peel said. "There is never that sense of permanence because the life cycle of a restaurant is limited."
By opening both a restaurant, Campanile, and La Brea Bakery in Los Angeles, they played to their strengths. Ms. Silverton, who was a well-known baker, turned out breads and pastries for the restaurant, the public and other restaurants. Within two years, La Brea reached its production limit. Last year, it moved to much larger quarters.
"The restaurant business has been tough in the last few years," Mr. Peel said, "but the bakery business has been terrific. Bread is not subject to trends as much as restaurants are."
Unlike other chef-entrepreneurs, Roberto Donna, of Galileo in Washington, isn't looking to the future, at least not yet, but he is busily building his own empire.
He insisted he was not expanding for monetary rewards, even though he is an owner of I Matti, a trattoria; Pesce, a fish market and restaurant; Il Radicchio, a pizzeria and spaghetti house; Il Pane, a bakery, and El Patio, a South American restaurant, and has opened a catering division of Galileo.
"If I want to make big money I need to open a big place," he said. "You always hope to make some money, and probably psychologically I'm preparing for when business is going down, but now Galileo gets more and more business. In each restaurant we serve different food, and it's fun to cook different food all day. I'm never bored."
Besides, Mr. Donna said, he's too young to worry about the future: "I'm not looking for security; I'm only 32."

 CORRECTION:
An article in the The Living Section yesterday about the diversification of restaurants into other businesses misidentified a general store affiliated with the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M. It is Coyote Cocina, not Coyote Casino.

HEADLINE: Aristide Seeks the Removal Of Army and Police Chiefs

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide called today for the immediate removal of the head of the Haitian military, the Port-au-Prince police chief and hundreds of plainclothes police officers who the deposed President said have been involved in politically motivated killings in recent weeks.
"Cedras is a killer, Michel Francois is a killer and, of course, we ask for their removal," Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, said at a news conference. Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras is the head of Haitian armed forces, who deposed him in a coup two years ago, and Colonel Francois is in charge of the police in the country's capital. 
 But despite a recent surge in violence, which included the assassination of a close adviser, Father Aristide stopped short of calling for the immediate reimposition of economic sanctions against Haiti.
The sanctions were suspended by the United Nations Security Council on Aug. 27 as part of an agreement between Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, and Mr. Cedras that is supposed to lead to President Aristide's return to power on Oct. 30.
"If in the light of those agreements, the international community thinks the imposition of sanctions is the best way to reach the goal, which is the removal, the immediate removal, of the coup leaders, I say yes," Father Aristide said.
 
Governors Island Accords
 Later, Father Aristide said he personally supported reimposing sanctions on the ground that Haiti's military leaders, by engaging in politically motivated killings, had violated the agreement, which was signed on Governors Island in New York.
"I respect the Governors Island accords, and therefore I am in favor of resuming sanctions," he said.
But the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said today that he would not recommend that the Security Council reimpose sanctions now. He told Reuters, the news agency, that he preferred to await the arrival of United Nations police monitors, mainly from France and Canada, in the next two weeks.
"Before asking for new sanctions, let us begin the process, and then we will see," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said.
Clinton Administration officials say they are not inclined to support reimposing sanctions now. Rather, they prefer to continue plans to purge Haiti's military and police of leaders who have been involved in human rights abuses and to give training to lower-ranking soldiers and police officers.
 
U.N. Aides Blame Police Chief
 Father Aristide held his news conference at TransAfrica, a black-run public policy group that specializes in issues dealing with Africa and the Caribbean.
United Nations officials, including Dante Caputo, the special United Nations envoy for Haiti, blame the police chief, Colonel Francois, and plain-clothes officers known as "attaches" for much of the violence in Haiti.
Father Aristide said the police force must be purged of these officers, whom he compared to the notorious Tontons Macoutes, the secret police force that operated under the former dictator Francois Duvalier.
"The heads have to be removed and with them the attaches who are the Macoutes," President Aristide said.
 
Safety Concerns Raised
 Some civil rights leaders expressed concern to President Aristide about his personal safety. Some, like Wade Henderson, director of the Washington office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, drew the analogy with Benigno Aquino, the former Philippines Senator who was assassinated the day he returned home from a self-imposed exile in 1983.
Mr. Henderson suggested in the meeting that Father Aristide delay his return until his safety could be asssured. But Father Aristide refused, saying his restoration would be "a day of international celebration."

With him at a news conference in Washington yesterday were, from left, Representative Kweisi Mfume, chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus; Earl G. Graves, head of Black Enterprises, and Randall Robinson, director of TransAfrica. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Aristide Seeks the Removal Of Army and Police Chiefs

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide called today for the immediate removal of the head of the Haitian military, the Port-au-Prince police chief and hundreds of plainclothes police officers who the deposed President said have been involved in politically motivated killings in recent weeks.
"Cedras is a killer, Michel Francois is a killer and, of course, we ask for their removal," Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, said at a news conference. Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras is the head of Haitian armed forces, who deposed him in a coup two years ago, and Colonel Francois is in charge of the police in the country's capital. 
 But despite a recent surge in violence, which included the assassination of a close adviser, Father Aristide stopped short of calling for the immediate reimposition of economic sanctions against Haiti.
The sanctions were suspended by the United Nations Security Council on Aug. 27 as part of an agreement between Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, and Mr. Cedras that is supposed to lead to President Aristide's return to power on Oct. 30.
"If in the light of those agreements, the international community thinks the imposition of sanctions is the best way to reach the goal, which is the removal, the immediate removal, of the coup leaders, I say yes," Father Aristide said.
 
Governors Island Accords
 Later, Father Aristide said he personally supported reimposing sanctions on the ground that Haiti's military leaders, by engaging in politically motivated killings, had violated the agreement, which was signed on Governors Island in New York.
"I respect the Governors Island accords, and therefore I am in favor of resuming sanctions," he said.
But the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said today that he would not recommend that the Security Council reimpose sanctions now. He told Reuters, the news agency, that he preferred to await the arrival of United Nations police monitors, mainly from France and Canada, in the next two weeks.
"Before asking for new sanctions, let us begin the process, and then we will see," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said.
Clinton Administration officials say they are not inclined to support reimposing sanctions now. Rather, they prefer to continue plans to purge Haiti's military and police of leaders who have been involved in human rights abuses and to give training to lower-ranking soldiers and police officers.
 
U.N. Aides Blame Police Chief
 Father Aristide held his news conference at TransAfrica, a black-run public policy group that specializes in issues dealing with Africa and the Caribbean.
United Nations officials, including Dante Caputo, the special United Nations envoy for Haiti, blame the police chief, Colonel Francois, and plain-clothes officers known as "attaches" for much of the violence in Haiti.
Father Aristide said the police force must be purged of these officers, whom he compared to the notorious Tontons Macoutes, the secret police force that operated under the former dictator Francois Duvalier.
"The heads have to be removed and with them the attaches who are the Macoutes," President Aristide said.
 
Safety Concerns Raised
 Some civil rights leaders expressed concern to President Aristide about his personal safety. Some, like Wade Henderson, director of the Washington office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, drew the analogy with Benigno Aquino, the former Philippines Senator who was assassinated the day he returned home from a self-imposed exile in 1983.
Mr. Henderson suggested in the meeting that Father Aristide delay his return until his safety could be asssured. But Father Aristide refused, saying his restoration would be "a day of international celebration."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Overview;
CLINTON ASKS BACKING FOR SWEEPING CHANGE IN THE HEALTH SYSTEM

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton sought to establish a place in history tonight as the guarantor of health care for all Americans, asking Congress and a national television audience to work with him to enact the most sweeping national program since Social Security in 1935.
He argued that this was the time to confront and vanquish a problem that had thwarted past Presidents back to Franklin D. Roosevelt. 
 "Tonight we come together to write a new chapter in the American story," he told the joint session of Congress. "This health care system is badly broken and it is time to fix it." [Transcript, page A24.]
 
'Most Urgent Priority'
 He said, "At long last, after decades of false starts, we must make this our most urgent priority: giving every American health security, health care that can never be taken away, health care that is always there."
The President paid tribute to his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the plan's architect, who watched the speech in a packed House chamber, saying: "When I launched our nation on the journey to reform the health care system, I knew we needed a talented navigator." He continued: "Luckily for me and our nation, I didn't have to search very far." At that, the lawmakers sprang to their feet for one of two standing ovations they gave the First Lady. Mrs. Clinton beamed back from the gallery, where she sat between C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General in the Reagan Administration, and T. Berry Brazelton, the noted pediatrician.
 
Angry Descriptions
 The speech signified the culmination of eight months of planning and political bargaining. And long before Mr. Clinton walked into the House chamber tonight, the speech had been firmly established in Washington as defining for his Presidency. Alternating long descriptions of policy with forceful, even angry descriptions of conditions today, he clearly held that same political sense of the moment himself.
As he described a plan that would be gradually phased in by the year 2000, his choice of words often recalled the themes that had worked in his campaign for the White House. He spoke often of "change" and the "courage to change." And his litany of responsibilities that Americans should accept -- reducing teen-age violence and pregnancy, quitting excessive smoking and drinking -- recalled the neo-liberal values that helped him appeal to former Reagan and Bush voters.
The need to act was warmly acknowledged by the lawmakers of both parties, who repeatedly applauded Mr. Clinton's exhortations and appeals for change. But the blizzard of comments, pro and con, that swept in from interest groups that felt he was going too far, or not far enough, foreshadowed the hazards to come.
 
Two Early Problems
 While the President promised security, in order to attain it his plan would not only alter the shape of one seventh of the economy but would change one of the most sensitive relationships in American society: the ties between doctors and patients.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the issue's programmatic and political complexity. But he said the nation was in "a time of great change when miracles do happen." A handshake has shattered the deadlock in the Middle East and the Berlin Wall has fallen, he noted, adding: "Now it is our turn to strike a blow for freedom -- the freedom for Americans to live without fear of their own nation's health care system."
At the immediate legislative level, two sets of headaches were instantly clear today. House committee chairmen argued about who would get to have Mrs. Clinton testify first, and Republicans emerged from a White House meeting this morning with instantly conflicting views.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said after the morning meeting, "We can have bipartisanship." But Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the No. 3 House Republican leader, scorned the President's plan as "unacceptable" because of its large Government role and attacked today's efforts as "the biggest marketing operation since New Coke."
The Democrats who commented were generally hopeful. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, who broke with Mr. Clinton over free trade on Tuesday, said this morning: "I said in the meeting that everybody in the room has worked on this issue for their whole time in Congress, and we don't have much to show for it. I'm more optimistic now about getting health care done than I've ever been since I've been here."
 
Promise to All
 The plan, which Mr. Clinton sketched tonight only in broad outline but will formally submit as legislation in a few weeks, seeks universal health insurance coverage for all Americans, including the 37 million now not insured. They would be guaranteed a generous basic package of coverage, negotiated separately in each state by alliances of consumers with insurance companies and medical groups. Most employers would be required to pay 80 percent of average premiums.
Every American and legal alien resident would have a personal health care card, which Mr. Clinton brandished tonight. It would serve as a promise that insurance would never be canceled, even for people who fall ill or lose their jobs. Mr. Clinton says only about $100 billion in additional taxes would be needed, including a hefty increase in cigarette taxes.
The program promises a new prescription-drug benefit for the elderly, and, by limiting annual increases in insurance premiums, seeks to hold down costs in the private sector. That would make it possible to cut $234 billion over the expected increases in Medicare and Medicaid costs over the next seven years without simply pushing those costs onto other customers. Those savings estimates are probably the most doubted part of his plan; few lawmakers consider it politically possible to achieve those savings.
Mrs. Clinton carried the burdens both of organizing the development of the plan and explaining it to Congress, where lawmakers have been impressed with her thoroughness and ability to listen even when they disagreed with her solutions.
As he described his plan, the President emphasized six "fixed stars," or critical principles that health care legislation must follow, while stressing that he is ready to work with Congress and change specific provisions of his proposal.
He listed "the principles that must guide our reform of America's health care system: security, simplicity and savings; choice, quality and responsibility."
Security is plainly the Administration's first selling point, and the President began by saying: "Security means that those who do not have health care coverage will have it and, for those who have it, it will never be taken away. We must achieve that security as soon as possible."
He described the health security card that will guarantee benefits "that can never be taken away." And he said "So let us agree on this: whatever else we disagree on, before this Congress finishes its work next year, you will pass, and I will sign, legislation to guarantee this security to every citizen of this country."
Mr. Clinton, addressing one fear that could cripple the plan politically, promised to "maintain the Medicare system."
Simplicity would be achieved, he said, by reducing paperwork. "We have more than 1,500 insurers with hundreds and hundreds of different forms," he said. Those forms, he continued, are "exasperating for anyone who's ever tried to sit down around a table and wade through them and figure them out," and because of it, "the medical care industry is drowning in paperwork."
 
Route to Savings
 Savings were essential, he said, because "rampant medical inflation is eating away at our wages, our savings, our investment capital, our ability to create new jobs in the private sector and this public treasury."
He said savings would be achieved when limits on insurance premiums and curbs on the growth of Medicare and Medicaid force changes in the system.
Universal coverage was essential to savings, because "when people don't have any health insurance, they still get health care, but they get it when it's too late, when it's too expensive -- often from the most expensive place of all, the emergency room."
He said choice would be greater, not less, under his plan. "Americans believe they ought to be able to choose their own health care plan and keep their own doctors. And I think all of us agree. Under any plan we pass, they ought to have that right."
Greater responsibility, he said, was needed to make the system work better. At one level, he said, that would mean insurance companies could no longer cancel customers when they got sick, and profiteering and fraud must be punished.
But more broadly, he said: "Responsibility in our health care system isn't about them. It's about you. It's about me. It's about each of us."
He said every American should pay something toward their health care, even if it was "as small as a $10 co-payment."
He said, "Every employer should provide coverage, just as three-quarters do now. Those who pay are picking up the tab for those who don't today. I don't think that's right."
While there would be some changes in costs, with increases for firms that now provide no coverage or for young single people in their 20's he said, "the vast majority of the Americans watching this tonight will pay the same or less for health care coverage that will be the same or better than the coverage they have tonight."
After going through those points, Mr. Clinton warned that the nation would soon be "bombarded with information from all kinds of sources." He said, "I ask you only to think of this: when you hear all of these arguments ask yourself whether the cost of staying on this same course isn't greater than the cost of change, and ask yourself when you hear the arguments whether the arguments are in your interest or someone else's."
The President was interrupted by applause 35 times in a 53-minute speech.
In the Republican Party's formal televised response, the tones were deliberately muted, and the party's highest-visibility speakers, like Mr. Dole and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, were kept to the sidelines.
In a conscious effort to portray his party as open to cooperation and compromise after the bitter partisanship of fights over the budget and economic stimulus measures, Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina began and closed by emphasizing hopes for agreement.
"We all agree that we need to increase access to health care," he began a speech prepared for delivery after Mr. Clinton's. And he concluded by saying, "Republicans will work with the Administration to forge a health care system that will work for you. We give you that commitment,"
But in between he scoffed at the Administration's draft proposals as "a giant social experiment devised by theorists who have never met a payroll." He said Mr. Clinton's " 'one size fits all' Federal health care system will be bitter medicine for Americans to swallow."
Mr. Campbell was joined by Senator Connie Mack of Florida, who said the national debate to come would be over how -- not whether -- to accomplish health reform. "And we want it done right," Senator Mack said, "with less government and more freedom."
Representative Nancy Johnson of Connecticut said Republicans "oppose what amounts to national price-fixing."
"We need not sacrifice jobs or compromise economic opportunity to assure all citizens access to good health care," she said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: News Analysis;
Pledging Peace of Mind

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton rode to power on the economic anxiety of the middle class and the promise that the Government could do something about it. Tonight, standing before the nation with a health security card in his hand, he tried to deliver, pledging a vast new benefit for all Americans.
"With this card, if you lose your job or you switch jobs, you're covered," Mr. Clinton declared, holding aloft the freshly-minted red, white and blue card. "If you leave your job to start a small business, you're covered. If you're an early retiree, you're covered." 
 In his speech and in the political struggle to come, Mr. Clinton hopes to move beyond the contentious details of the health plan and keep the public focused on the fundamentals: the fear of a medical catastrophe, the security of "health care that's always there," and the promise of a card as tangible and comforting as the Social Security card was to the Depression generation.
The idea of health care reform has gained force on the campaign trail over the last five years, breaking through in the 1991 Pennsylvania Senate race and driving much of the 1992 Presidential campaign before bringing Mr. Clinton to this speech. "It is a magic moment and we must seize it," the President said, in a speech infused with an almost wartime sense of urgency.
But now comes the hard part.
What his advisers hope the public carries away from tonight's speech is the image of lawmakers, Republican and Democratic alike, applauding the broad goals set forth by the President, beginning a period of bipartisan work on health care. They hope the lawmakers respond to Mr. Clinton's gestures of conciliation, to his plea to make health care a crusade that transcends partisan politics, to his willingness to bend on details in pursuit of the first truly national health insurance program.
"This is our chance," Mr. Clinton declared. "This is our journey. And, when our work is done, we will know that we have answered the call of history and met the challenge of our times."
What the White House fears is a debate that bogs down in mechanics, that turns partisan and parochial, that pushes all the interest groups that have a stake in what amounts to a seventh of the American economy into blocking one part or another of a sweeping bill, ending in a stalemate.
Senator Jay Rockefeller, the West Virginia Democrat who has worked on the health issue for years and is a Clinton ally, said today: "The problem with legislation is that people always focus on this part or that part that they don't like. And they forget that we're not trying to invent some new program; we're trying to save ourselves from catastrophe."
This, in fact, will be a central theme from both the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who led the task force on health care and will continue to lobby for the bill. Mr. Clinton illustrated his speech, again and again, with horror stories of people trapped and brutalized in the current system. The choice, he and Mrs. Clinton will argue, is changing the system or remaining with a disastrous status quo. And the debate, they will argue, should not lose sight of the broadest goals that are shared by millions of Americans.
With some frustration, Mrs. Clinton said this week: "When Franklin Roosevelt proposed Social Security, he didn't go out selling it with actuarial tables and books of regulations. He basically said, 'Look, here's the deal: You pay in; you're taken care of; you have Social Security in your old age.' If he'd had to have been pressed to the wall saying, 'Well, what about the spouse who didn't work, and what about somebody who only worked 20 quarters instead of 24 quarters' -- I mean we would never have had Social Security."
 
No Easy Task
 Nobody, in fact, ever suggested that modern politics made sweeping social programs easy. Mr. Clinton is trying to do what Presidents Harry S. Truman, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon could not, and he is trying to do it when the public is in a quirky and dangerous mood. The public, in fact, does see problems on the domestic front, led by the economy and health care. But the skepticism toward government, epitomized by the following Ross Perot has attracted, is great.
This tension between a yearning for action and a doubt that government can truly deliver has become a hallmark of the Clinton Presidency, and it will be at the center of the struggle over health care. Mr. Clinton all but glows with his confidence in government to pull off this extraordinary feat; his aides, notably Ira C. Magaziner, have been briefing eagerly and happily on the workings of their plan. The emotional subtext for all these briefings by all these Clintonians is powerful: a generation of Democrats shut out of power by the 1980's is scaling the Mount Everest of social policy.
They see a nation of consumers, newly informed and empowered, making rational health care choices based on a wealth of data from their health care alliance. It is, in their view, and in the view articulated by the President himself tonight, the Clintonian third way -- neither left nor right, neither government-run nor left to the vagaries of an ill-functioning market.
 
Now, the Debate
 But on Capitol Hill, and all over the country, a rough debate is about to begin. The first phase is already clear: can the Administration achieve the savings it projects in Medicare and Medicaid spending to finance much of its package? Other flash points are apparent: for all the talk of bipartisan cooperation, can Republicans and Democrats agree on requiring all employers to pay part of their employee's premium costs?
Is the Clinton blend of market forces and regulatory controls a uniquely American system, as its architects argue, or a hodgepodge, as its critics assert?
And, perhaps the biggest question, can the Government actually fix this problem? This was the question that Mr. Clinton returned to again and again in his speech tonight. "It's hard to believe that once there was a time, in this century, when retirement was nearly synonomous with poverty, and older Americans died in the streets," he said. "That is unthinkable today because over half a century ago Americans had the courage to change, to create a Social Security system that insures no Americans will be forgotten in their later years."
And yet, it requires a leap of faith.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was in Congress when President Johnson finally succeeded in passing the Medicare program. In an interview today, he praised the leadership now being shown on health care but declined to predict an outcome. "This is big," said a man who has seen huge legislation come and go and who has rarely seemed cowed.

HEADLINE: President's Nominee As Head of Military Backs Bosnia Force

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, President Clinton's choice to be the top officer of the armed forces, gave strong support today for sending 25,000 American troops to Bosnia to help enforce any peace settlement reached there, but said the overall operation would cost $4 billion in the first year alone.
General Shalikashvili, a Polish-born artillery officer named to succeed Gen. Colin L. Powell as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee that a force of 50,000 heavily armed NATO troops would have a good chance of success in such a mission, if the proper command structure was established and the warring factions committed themselves to observe an agreement.
 
A 'Tragic Association'
 The general also said he had been shocked to learn that his father fought in World War II in a Nazi-organized unit commanded by the Waffen SS. The general said he learned about his father's ties with the SS unit only last month from news reports. 
 "I'm deeply saddened that my father had this tragic association," General Shalikashvili said in his opening statement. "To me, he was a kind and gentle man, and I loved him very much."
His statement, read earnestly, lasted only about five minutes and the references to his father came at the very end, just before he began taking questions from the Senators.
In his confirmation hearing before the Senate panel today, General Shalikashvili (pronounced shah-lee-kahsh-VEE-lee) countered the skepticism that many Senators voiced about American involvement in the Balkans with a strongly argued rationale.
"The alternative of not doing so is also very expensive," said General Shalikashvili, who is the current NATO military commander. "There is a likelihood that fighting will break out again, that it will reach sort of a final crescendo."
[In Brussels, the Balkan negotiators told NATO officials that any force sent to Bosnia should be well-armed and deployed quickly. Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations envoy, said that the NATO force would probably face opposition from local "warlords" who answer to no one. Lord Owen, the European Community negotiator, said there was a need to "go in fast and firmly with a seriously credible force" and that it must be more powerful than the lightly armed peacekeepers now deployed by the United Nations.]
General Shalikashvili, 57, who directed the relief operation to help the Kurds in northern Iraq after the Persian Gulf war, warned that winter in Sarajevo is less than 60 days away and residents face harsher prospects than they did last winter. "Women and children and old people will pay an awful price if there is not a peace settlement," he said.
General Shalikashvili's comments stand in contrast to the cautious views of General Powell. Both officers have expressed reservations about the usefulness of air strikes to achieve military results in Bosnia and of putting American ground troops in Bosnia before the warring Serbs, Croats and Muslims reach a peace agreement.
But General Shalikashvili, who was General Powell's top aide before taking the NATO post and is his choice to succeed him as Chairman, has also said the West tended to overestimate the military power of the Serbs and has seemed more willing to send American troops to enforce a peace accord.
 
Warm Reception From Panel
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the panel, said General Shalikashvili's confirmation was virtually assured, but that a vote by the full Senate might be delayed until the Administration names the general's successor at NATO.
Senior Pentagon officials said today that Mr. Clinton would nominate Gen. George A. Joulwan of the Army, who heads the United States Southern Command in Panama. General Joulwan is responsible for American military activities in Latin America, except for Mexico and the Caribbean. He has also held several commands in Europe.
General Shalikashvili today received a warm reception from the panel. Senators refrained from questioning him about what he knew about his father's military career, and seemed to go out of their way not to blame the son for the father's mistakes.
General Shalikashvili's toughest questioning came from Senators who expressed fears that the United States faced increasing danger of sending troops to ill-defined, open-ended regional conflicts around the world.
General Shalikashvili said that Washington should send troops only to conflicts in which the United States had a clearly defined interest, proper control over American forces, and the ability to withdraw at its discretion.
When Senators asked how Somalia fit that description, the general defended the United Nations mission there. "If we were to leave now, we might put in danger all that was done and the country might very well return to where it was," he said.
But he also criticized the operation. "I am bothered that the United Nations that runs this operation does not have a clear articulation of the political and economic goals," he said. "That's a failure to communicate."

HEADLINE: Secrets of Long Life From 2 Who Ought to Know;
In Their Book, Westchester Sisters Share Lessons From More Than a Century of Living

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 17

 BODY:
Two days shy of her 104th birthday, Sarah De lany and her younger sister, Annie Elizabeth, who is 102, sat in their front parlor doling out secrets to long life like candy on Halloween night. (Yoga, cod liver oil and a daily dose of garlic, chopped fine and swallowed whole, are all recommended.)
Sadie and Bessie Delany, daughters of a slave who became the country's first black bishop of the Episcopal Church, have also lived to tell how they outsmarted the "rebby boys" of the Jim Crow South and outlasted just about everyone who ever tried to hold them back. 
 Bessie Delany became the second black female dentist in New York State, while Sadie Delany became the first black home economics teacher in a New York City high school. (In recent years, she received a letter from the Board of Education threatening to cut off her pension unless she proved she was still alive.) They moved to Harlem in its heyday, surviving the Depression and socializing with the likes of Cab Calloway and W. E. B. DuBois.
And now they are relishing the chance to pass on some of what they learned along the way, in a book written with Amy Hill Hearth, "Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters' First Hundred Years" (Kodansha). Released here on Sept. 10 and in Japan on Sept. 15, in time for Revere Your Elders Day, it is already in its third printing.
"A long time ago nothing that black people did was put in books," noted Sadie Delany, a handsome woman in a rose-colored suit, sitting ramrod straight by a window in a room lined with old volumes and family photographs.
The sisters had no plans to tell their story to the world until a news paper article about them attracted the interest of a publisher; they still have trouble believing that so many people are interested in them. These days, there is a waiting list of reporters and television crews eager for an invitation to the red brick home they bought in 1957, when they were among the first blacks to integrate Mount Vernon.
The two sisters, who have lived together all their lives, still do their own cooking and look after the place with the help of a housekeeper who comes every other week.
"She's 87," Bessie Delany said approvingly. "She's our speed."
And they still take good care of each other, as they have always done.
"I've never been afraid or alone in my life," Bessie Delany said.
They were so sheltered growing up on the college campus of Saint Augustine's College in Raleigh, N.C., where their parents taught and raised 10 children, that they were shocked by the franker passages of the Bible.
"We never went downtown in our lives without an escort until we were grown women," said Sadie Delany, instinctively reaching behind her sister's chair to pull her jacket around her when it slipped off one shoulder. But their parents' protectiveness was all to the good, they said. In those days, the sisters said, white men often kept a "colored family" on the side, and their father warned them of the dangers of even speaking to a white man, or any married man.
After the Jim Crow laws went into effect in Raleigh in 1896, when the sisters were children, they remembered the rude surprise of being asked to step to the back of the trolley car and refused service at a drugstore where they had always gone for nickel limeades.
Even then, they said, they managed to find ways around some of the restrictions. Sadie Delany's system was playing dumb, refusing to understand directions to sit in the back of a store, asking "Back where?" until she wore the shopkeepers down. Her sister's method was more daring.
 
Talk of the 'Surrender'
 "Miss Fresh was always looking for ways to do what I pleased," said Bessie Delany, whose wry smile and bright eyes give away an exuberantly subversive nature. Remembering sneaking a drink from the dipper on the forbidden side of a water fountain in a public park, "I'd just take a drink of the white water," she said. "It didn't taste any different."
She has always been more confrontational than her sister, she said, and more bitter about the plight of her people.
"When the Surrender happened," she said, referring to the end of the Civil War, "the poor whites gradually took over the barber shops, even the dance calling -- all the work that had been done by Negroes." Only women could get jobs then, as maids.
It is a source of considerable pride to the Delany sisters that neither of them ever worked for white people. (In their book, Bessie Delany addresses a message to David Duke: "This is just to set the record straight. I am a Negro woman. I was brought up in a good family. My Papa was a devoted father. I went to college; I paid my own way. I am not stupid. I'm not on welfare. And I'm not scrubbing floors. Especially not yours.")
After going as far as they could at St. Augustine's, they worked for years as teachers to earn the money for college because their father counseled against accepting scholarships that would leave them obligated to benefactors. With tuition in hand, they finally moved to New York and attended Columbia University, where Bessie Delany graduated with a D.D.S. in 1923 and Sadie Delany earned a master's degree in education in 1925.
Bessie Delany became so well known in Harlem that postcards addressed to "Dr. Bessie, New York City" somehow found their way to her. She charged $2 for a cleaning and $10 for a gold filling, never turning away those who could not pay and running something of a social-services office along with her dental practice.
Sadie Delany got the teaching post she wanted after working with a speech coach to change the southern accent that was often cited as the rationale for keeping black teachers from teaching white students. Even then, she said, she had to "sneak" into the school where she was assigned, based on her top marks on a teaching exam: She decided not to show up for the job interview, sure she would be turned away because of her race. Instead, she sent a letter to school administrators explaining that there had been some mix-up, and simply showed up on the first day of school.
 
Finishing Thoughts
 Both sisters chose a career over a family, never thinking that it was possible to do both and apparently never regretting the decision.
"I was very attracted to some of my beaux, but they knew I wasn't going to change and get married because I had decided to go into dentistry," Bessie Delany said. "I wasn't a play person."
"Bessie was a nice girl," her sister put in.
"And you can't eat everything you see," Bessie Delany concluded, as the sisters shared a long laugh.
They have probably lived this long, they say, because they have not had husbands to worry them to death.
Until Sadie Delany broke her hip in June, they had been in the habit of rising at 6:30 A.M. for yoga. They sleep in until 7 now, when they get up for a breakfast of oatmeal, half a banana, bran and eggs prepared with water and pepper -- no salt -- and a little grated cheese.
"You must stir it, stir it, stir it creamy like a custard," said Bessie Delany, suddenly jumping up to get the jar of chopped garlic that they dip into every morning.
"And that will last you all day," said Sadie Delany, finishing her sister's thought.
After morning prayers, when the sisters call the names of all those they either hold dear or think could use some help, they have a quiet time for reading before their noon meal, which might include a half-dozen vegetables.
 
Listening to Talk Radio
 The mail arrives at 1 P.M. -- an important daily event, since they refuse to get a phone -- and in the afternoon, they pay bills, answer correspondence and take a short walk. Supper is usually just a milkshake, though sometimes they have jello made with wine, or some other treat, before going upstairs to watch the MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour. And long after her sister turns in, Bessie Delany stays up late listening to talk radio.
The issues that concern them most range from the national deficit to bad parenting. ("It makes me mad these people who have one child and they don't even comb their hair," Bessie Delany said. "My mama washed all 10 of us every day in a tub and changed the water for every one.")
They are not keen on doctors, and did not even have a primary physician until Sadie Delany's fall.
Most of them "don't know what to do with us," she said, as if speaking about a group of pitiably slow students. "When something's wrong they say, 'You're still living, what do you expect?' " Still, she adds playfully, "the gentleman who came to teach me to use the walker had the softest hands."
Bessie Delany is a great admirer of Hillary Clinton and her work on health care reform, calling her "the power behind the throne" and "the first lady in the White House I've paid attention to since Eleanor Roosevelt."
When the sisters talk about how the book has changed their lives, they don't talk about money (and neither does their agent).
What Bessie Delany does talk about is how her perspective on race relations has been changed somewhat since the experience of publishing the book has brought her in contact with white people who, in a world of enduring social segregation, she would not otherwise have had the chance to know.
"Just since we started this book, we met them," she said.
